column9: Alabama
column10: damaged his right eye. He lost the sight of that eye and subsequently suffered partial hearing loss in his teens. These disabilities led Wilson
column11: a passionate naturalist from an early age
column12: to focus on small organisms
column13: particularly ants
column14: that he could study at close range. Observing their tiny worlds led him to a global vision of the importance of biological diversity in the survival of species including our own. Wilson
column15: who has died aged 92
column16: has been called a modern Charles Darwin for his influence as both a close observer and a unifying theorist. He was also a campaigner whose humane and elegant writings were among the first in recent times to argue that we have a moral duty to value other species
column17: not only for their own sake but also for the sake of future human generations. Fascinated by the apparent selflessness of social insects such as ants and bees
column18: which would sacrifice themselves to protect their colony
column19: in 1975 he published Sociobiology: The New Synthesis. The book sought to provide an evolutionary explanation (based on the work of the Oxford University zoologist William Hamilton) for the existence of apparently altruistic behaviour in a wide range of species. A single chapter addressed altruism in human societies
column20: suggesting that humans evolved to support the reproductive success of their close relatives as a way of ensuring that the altruistic individual’s genes were represented in succeeding generations. Although Wilson argued that human altruism and social structures were also products of culture
column21: his book provoked a resurgence of the “nature v nurture” debate. Soon after its publication
column22: a number of high-profile biologists
column23: psychologists and sociologists from his own university
column24: Harvard
column25: wrote a furious letter to the New York Review of Books
column26: denouncing him for biological determinism and implying that he was providing support for racist and sexist beliefs. Long before the days of the Twitterstorm
column27: opponents whipped up such rage against Wilson that in 1978 protesters dumped a jug of iced water over him as he sat on the platform at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Not in any way deterred
column28: Wilson followed up with On Human Nature (1979)
column29: for which he won his first Pulitzer prize. Today most scientists accept
column30: as Wilson argued
column31: that genetically determined “human nature” includes the capacity to develop extremely flexible patterns of social behaviour under the influence of culture. By the time Sociobiology was published Wilson had already developed ideas that would prove even more influential in ecology and conservation. As a young researcher
column32: he had travelled widely in his quest to document some of the millions of species of ants and other invertebrates. Observing and collecting in New Guinea
column33: the South Pacific and the Florida Keys
column34: he began to think about how different species disperse
column35: compete
column36: survive or become extinct in a confined area such as an island. With the ecologist Robert MacArthur he wrote The Theory of Island Biogeography (1967)
column37: showing how a balance developed between immigration of new species and the extinction of previous residents based on birth and death rates and the number of individuals the environment could support. They distinguished between animals that produce many young and invest little in their care (r-strategists) and those that produce fewer young but care for them in early life (K-strategists)
column38: depending on the stability of the environment. Today ecologists recognise that there is a continuum between the two life history strategies
column39: but the concept has been highly influential. Wilson’s numerous contributions to his field also include the discovery that insects used complex systems of chemical signals to organise their societies. Just as Darwin developed much of his theory of natural selection from studying finches in the Galapagos archipelago
column40: Wilson’s work had implications far beyond island habitats. As burgeoning human populations encroach on wild spaces
column41: they confine the habitat that remains to smaller and smaller parcels. Wilson’s work showed how this has led to a collapse in biological diversity
column42: with consequences beyond the loss of individual species. In the latter part of his life he became a prominent advocate for the conservation of biodiversity. His book Biophilia (1986) argued that an affinity for other species is fundamental to humanity. In 2016
column43: aged 87
column44: he published Half Earth: Our Planet’s Fight for Life
column45: building on an earlier idea that we should set aside half of the planet’s surface for wildlife. His language was forthright and decidedly un-academic. “We’re extinguishing Earth’s biodiversity as though the species of the natural world are no better than weeds and kitchen vermin
column46: ” he wrote. “Have we no shame?” Born in Birmingham
column47: Alabama
column48: he was the only child of Edward Wilson
column49: a former army accountant
column50: and Inez (nee Freeman). His parents divorced when he was seven
column51: briefly placing him as a boarder in the Gulf Coast Military Academy in Gulfport
column52: Mississippi. As he wrote in his autobiography
column53: Naturalist (1994)
column54: the strict discipline of the school
column55: and the southern code of behaviour inculcated by his father
column56: left him with a belief that he should “never back down if honour is at stake”; he attributed his later willingness to face up to his academic opponents to this upbringing. He dealt with the unhappiness in his home life by focusing intently on the natural world
column57: deciding at the age of 11 to document every species of ant in his home state. At 13 he made the first report that fire ants
column58: an invasive species
column59: were living near his home in Alabama. While still an undergraduate at the University of Alabama
column60: he published a survey of the fire ant’s progress across the state. He began a PhD at the University of Tennessee before transferring to Harvard
column61: which housed the largest museum collection of ants in the world. He spent the rest of his career there
column62: winning a second Pulitzer prize in 1991 for his monumental volume The Ants (co-authored with a fellow entomologist
column63: Bert Hölldobler). He retired from teaching in 1996 but continued to write and campaign as professor emeritus and honorary curator in entomology. He received numerous honours
column64: including the US national medal of science and the Crafoord prize (often regarded as a Nobel prize for ecologists). The E O Wilson Biodiversity Foundation was set up in his name in 2005 to continue his educational work in conservation. In October 2021 Wilson participated via video link in a discussion with David Attenborough on the Half Earth concept
column65: where he was asked to comment on whether the Covid-19 pandemic would change attitudes to the interconnectedness of species. He replied that in future the pandemic would be regarded as “just a flick on a movie screen”
column67: he added “We will never come out from under the loss of species that we have been carelessly allowing to happen just by our ordinary everyday activities. Extinction is for ever.” Wilson married Irene Kelley in 1955 and they settled in Lexington
column68: Massachusetts. She died in August 2021. Wilson is survived by their daughter

column8: 'Eating disorders'];"An increasing number of women are losing their monthly periods because they are following a social media trend for restrictive diets and excessive exercise
column9: experts say. Charity heads and nutritionists have raised the alarm about the increase in hypothalamic amenorrhea
column10: a condition where the body enters survival mode because it is under-fuelled
column11: causing menstruation to stop. It is a reversible disorder caused by stress related to weight loss
column12: excessive exercise and trauma. Martha Williams
column13: a clinical advice coordinator at the leading eating disorder charity Beat
column14: said the condition was becoming more widespread
column15: and was often seen in people who were not underweight and did not have a low body-mass index. “There are not exact statistics on this issue but the majority of people we see have lost their periods and some of these women are not seriously underweight. Some are a healthy weight but have restrictive eating
column16: ” Williams said. Women often consulted their family doctor when their period stopped
column17: but Williams said many GPs did not have the right training to spot the underlying cause
column18: and prescribed the contraceptive pill to restart menstruation. Williams said the pressure of lockdown was difficult for a lot of people
column19: and the message from the government promoting an hour of exercise a day was not helpful for everyone. “The emphasis on this message was likely quite damaging for someone struggling to regulate their exercise levels.” She added that social media could be a “problem”
column20: because women shared edited photos of their bodies
column21: creating unrealistic expectations of how people should look. Williams said fitness influencers would also tell their followers what they ate in a day
column22: including how many calories
column23: which did not help those with eating disorders. Women have been raising awareness on Instagram about the implications of overexercise and so-called clean eating – a restrictive diet concept where a person avoids refined and processed foods. Chloe Hodgkinson helps girls with disordered eating
column24: amenorrhea and periods
column25: based on her own experiences. When she stopped taking the contraceptive pill her period did not return
column26: and doctors said it was normal for menstruation to be delayed. Although Hodgkinson felt it was related to the fact she was undereating
column27: because her body mass index was not low doctors did not take her seriously. She went to a dietician who told her she had low oestrogen
column28: after which she changed the way she approached exercise and eating
column29: and her periods resumed.

column1: “I have clients who have worked with a dietician or nutritionist or doctor and I help them get back into training after losing their cycle and help keep them accountable to their period journey
column2: ” she said. Hodgkinson gets more than 20 messages a day
column3: “with girls simply wanting answers because they can’t get them anywhere else. “They can relate to me
column4: they see old me in them now and see that I’ve come out the other side … They need to support to see that life is better this side
column5: ” she said. Renee McGregor
column6: an eating disorder dietitian
column7: said in the past 12 months she had had 1
column8: 000 hours of contact time with clients and 95% of them had had hypothalamic amenorrhea. “It’s a big problem
column9: bigger than people appreciate
column10: particularly because for so long it has been – not that it should be – accepted that when women do lots of exercise they lose their period.” She said the problem was often misdiagnosed
column11: with women being turned away from GP surgeries and told their period had not resumed because their body was getting used to coming off the pill. “I had someone last week who was told by a gynaecologist that because they do not want children right now it’s not a problem. But not menstruating has a wider impact on physical and mental health
column12: ” she said.";https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/jan/06/women-losing-their-periods-because-of-restrictive-diets-and-excessive-exercise;7

column4: 'Air transport'];"A computer glitch at the Gatwick control tower left flights unable to land or take off at Britain’s second biggest airport during the morning peak. After a delay of more than two hours
column5: the planes refuelled and continued on to the Sussex airport. An easyJet flight from Belfast was diverted to Luton airport
column6: on the other side of London. The three flights were diverted during the “switch down” of the IT system

column1: A Gatwick spokesperson said: “Earlier IT issues in the air traffic control tower this morning have been resolved and flights are arriving and departing the airport as normal. Some flights may still experience delays however and passengers are advised to check their flight status with the airline.” A spokesperson for easyJet

column3: said it was “experiencing some disruption to our flying programme as a result” of the IT failure. “While this is out of our control we apologise for the inconvenience caused by the diversion and delays and would like to thank passengers for their patience and cooperation

column6: 'Art and design'];Tracey Emin has said she is launching her own “revolutionary” art school in Margate as part of her broader plan to transform the seaside town into an “artist’s haven”. The school

column9: and there’ll be really strict rules
column10: ” she said in an interview with the Times. “No subletting
column11: no smoking
column12: no loud music. And if people don’t want to do the rules then they won’t have a studio there. “The other thing
column13: because the rents are going to be so low
column14: I’m not having people having part-time jobs and then never coming in. So
column15: I’m setting it up so they … will have time to work and paint.” Students will be required to regularly put their work on public view
column16: Emin added
column17: “so there’s like this constant intellectual rigour. People can’t just be passive”. The mortuary will be turned into a “mini museum” filled with her own work. Emin will also launch an accompanying artist’s residency programme at a separate location to encourage artists to permanently move to Margate
column18: where she grew up and returned after the death of her mother. “So it’s organically making the place right for the right people

column24: with Margate now
column25: especially after the cancer and everything
column26: it’s all making sense what I’m doing. I am sort of helping. I am making an artist’s haven.” Emin
column27: who shot to fame in the 1990s with her work
column28: Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-1995
column29: said last year people had not understood the “seriousness” of her art and wrote her off as a “narcissistic
column30: deranged
column31: screaming banshee”. Her recent exhibitions include a 2018 neon sign in St Pancras station in London that reads “I want my time with you” and last year her paintings

column8: 'Economic policy'];"It was between Christmas and new year that Boris Johnson began to worry about the next crisis. In the preceding weeks
column9: Covid had been the big dividing line with his backbenchers as the prime minister wobbled over further restrictions but was chastened by an angry cabinet and a mass rebellion of his MPs over the light-touch plan B measures. But a cost of living crisis has the potential to be the much more serious matter in 2022
column10: and the prime minister told aides he wanted work to begin on what other mitigations for rising energy prices might be necessary. Despite this
column11: Johnson may have thought he had a few weeks’ grace with his backbenchers and friendly newspapers for having decided against new Covid restrictions. That hope was undone in the first press conference of the year when the prime minister stumbled over a question from the Sun over energy bills and the potential to cut VAT – a key Labour demand. When he entered the chamber for prime minister’s questions the following day
column12: Johnson appeared to have come prepared for a victory parade in front of his MPs for allowing a normal Christmas and new year despite surging Covid cases.

column1: But Angela Rayner
column2: the Labour deputy leader
column3: took him immediately to task on inflation
column4: tax rises and heating bills
column5: and the prime minister made a string of errors in response
column6: denying his own words on inflation and twice radically overstating the warm homes discount
column7: saying it was a rather implausible £140 a week. Time and again his backbenchers howled about the pressures their constituents were facing on fuel
column8: food bills and tax rises. One of his key cabinet loyalists
column9: Jacob Rees-Mogg
column10: had gone rogue in a cabinet meeting on Wednesday
column11: asking for the prime minister to reconsider his plans for a national insurance rise in April
column12: which will come just as a revised price cap is likely to drastically push up energy bills. The chancellor
column13: Rishi Sunak
column14: is not minded to pursue major interventions. And Johnson’s problem is that many of the options open to him will fall short. Of what has been suggested so far
column15: such as an extension of the warm homes discount or even a VAT cut on bills
column16: nothing is likely to make much of a dent in the eye-watering rises consumers are likely to see.

column1: The cost of living crisis has the potential to be immensely damaging politically in a number of ways. Many voters who are not especially vulnerable will now care more about a sky-high energy bill than catching Covid. Labour can draw stark parallels with the start of Johnson’s time in No 10. When voters ask themselves whether they feel better or worse off
column2: for many the answer will be the latter. MPs privately say the opposition has a chance to inflict real damage on this issue
column3: rather than on sleaze scandals or rows over Covid restrictions
column4: both of which can sway disgruntled voters midterm but may not ultimately be what matters in the polling booth. Crucially
column5: the squeeze on voters’ pockets gives MPs opportunity to attack the government over their pet grievances
column6: whether that is net zero
column7: deregulation
column8: tax rises or failure to be sufficiently enthusiastic about Brexit. Each one can be seen as a remedy and attract a caucus of troublemakers. A popular and deft prime minister could find ways to contain and mitigate the pressures
column9: with the support of his backbenchers. But with more difficult decisions on the pandemic and embarrassments over sleaze and rule-breaking likely to come
column10: Johnson’s reputation is sufficiently damaged within his own party to make the task even harder.";https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/jan/06/combination-cost-of-living-crisis-covid-spell-trouble-boris-johnson;1

column5: 'Sport'];"The Football Association is to proceed with a plan to use VAR at only nine of 32 FA Cup third-round fixtures

column1: The FA Cup has used VAR since 2018

column3: however

column6: with clubs not licensed having to install the necessary minimum of four cameras and costs having to be covered to operate them and hire the necessary officials. “Video assistant referees provide match officials with additional support and should be utilised wherever possible
column7: ” the FA said. “However

column1: The Premier League introduced VAR permanently at the start of the 2019-20 season. The EFL opted against doing the same owing to cost

column1: 9;9;5249;5249;Met investigating Tory peer Michelle Mone over ‘racist message’;2022-01-06T13:28:16Z;['David Conn'];['UK news'
column2: 'Michelle Mone'];"The Conservative peer Michelle Mone is being investigated by the Metropolitan police for an allegedly racist message she is accused of sending to a man of Indian heritage. The recipient of the message
column3: Richard Lynton-Jones
column4: complained to the police last summer that during a disagreement following a fatal yacht collision in 2019
column5: Lady Mone told him in a WhatsApp message he was “a waste of a man’s white skin”. Lynton-Jones gave a statement to the police in October
column6: providing screenshots of the messages. He is understood to have told the police in his statement that he believed Mone racially attacked him by using those words in the message
column7: that he found it grossly offensive and felt harassed
column8: alarmed and distressed by it. The alleged contents of WhatsApp messages
column9: in which Mone also allegedly described Lynton-Jones’s partner as a “mental loony” and “nut case bird”
column10: were revealed by the Guardian last month. Mone has repeatedly denied she is racist and her lawyers have questioned the authenticity of the messages. In screenshots of the messages seen by the Guardian
column11: Mone appears to accuse Lynton-Jones and his partner of showing insufficient respect following the yacht crash off Monaco
column12: in which a crew member was killed – an accusation they reject. The WhatsApp screenshots show the Tory peer responding after Lynton-Jones told her to back off
column13: writing: “Your [sic] a low life
column14: a waste of a mans [sic] white skin so don’t give us your lies. Your [sic] a total disgrace.” The Metropolitan police confirmed they were investigating. “In June 2021 police received an allegation of a racially aggravated malicious communication in relation to information posted on a messaging app
column15: ” they said in a statement. “Police spoke to the complainant and advised that for the investigation to progress a statement would need to be taken; for this to be admissible in any future court proceedings
column16: this would need to be done in person. ”In October
column17: the complainant gave a statement to police and the investigation continues. A 50-year-old woman has been invited to attend for an interview under caution at a future date.” Mone is understood to have been scheduled to be interviewed under caution on 23 December
column18: but that appointment was reportedly delayed. The police declined to say when the interview was now scheduled to happen.

column1: When the Guardian first reported on the allegedly racist message
column2: a representative of Mone initially said: “Baroness Mone is 100% not a racist. Baroness Mone and her husband have built over 15 schools in Africa in the past three years.” Her lawyers later provided another statement in which they said Mone had “no access” to the messages and no “detailed memory of them”. “She is not prepared to comment on the messages unless and until their authenticity has been confirmed but Baroness Mone
column3: in any event
column4: very strongly denies that she is a racist
column5: a sexist or that she has a lack of respect for those persons genuinely suffering with mental health difficulties.”

column1: In separate correspondence
column2: her lawyers also said their client believed at the time that the man had “no trace whatsoever of non-white colouring or any features” that would suggest he was not “100% white and British”. In a subsequent post on Instagram
column3: Mone denied the WhatsApp message was racist
column4: saying: “Since when did calling out a man on his actions after a manslaughter and his entitled white privilege constitute racism?” A lawyer for Mone indicated to the Guardian that Mone’s Instagram post did not suggest she now accepted that she sent the message. It has since been reported that Lynton-Jones has started libel proceedings against Mone
column5: accusing her of defamation. Mone is reported to have said to friends she will vigorously defend any action. It is understood that there has been no finding of manslaughter following the yacht crash
column6: and that part of the investigation has been closed.";https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/jan/06/met-investigating-tory-peer-michelle-mone-over-racist-message;1

column1: 10;10;5250;5250;‘Poor meat and ill-treated animals’: Spain in uproar over minister’s remarks;2022-01-06T13:24:28Z;['Stephen Burgen'];['Spain'

column9: 'Meat'];"Claims by a Spanish government minister that factory farming is damaging the environment and leading to the export of poor-quality meat have provoked a furious backlash after his comments were published in the Guardian. In an interview published on Boxing Day
column10: Alberto Garzón
column11: the minister for consumer affairs
column12: defended traditional grazing “as an environmentally sustainable means of cattle farming”. “That is sustainable; what isn’t at all sustainable is these so-called mega-farms
column13: ” he said. “They find a village in a depopulated bit of Spain and put in 4
column15: or 5
column17: 000 head of cattle. They pollute the soil

column20: Pedro Sánchez’s
column21: centre-left Socialist Workers party (PSOE).

column1: His remarks have provoked outrage from the meat industry
column2: opposition politicians and from senior members of the PSOE

column4: the government spokesperson

column11: the average Spaniard consumes more than 1kg. Pedro Barato
column12: the president of the Asaja agricultural association
column13: accused Garzón of irresponsible behaviour and called for his resignation. “The Spanish livestock industry depends on exports to survive

column15: the president of the Basque veterinary association in Vizcaya
column16: also demanded Garzón’s resignation
column17: saying that the comments by what he called the “pseudo-minister” were another demonstration of “the poor quality of our political representatives and their lack of respect for the livestock sector”. The centre-right Citizens party said in a statement that “in a single paragraph” Garzón had caused “irremediable” damage to Spain’s livestock industry
column18: while Pablo Casado
column19: the leader of the conservative People’s party

A report published in October said that intensive pork farming probably played a major role in one of Spain’s biggest environmental disasters that led to the death of thousands of fish in the Mar Menor
column21: a saltwater lagoon in south-east Spain. Scientists blame decades of nitrate-laden runoffs from the farms for triggering vast blooms of algae that deplete the water of oxygen

column26: ” he said. “Eating too much meat is bad for our health and for the planet.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/06/spanish-minister-under-fire-after-mega-farm-claims-in-guardian;3

column14: was released. Hex stars Rosalie Craig and has music by Jim Fortune and a book by Tanya Ronder whose plays include Dara and who is married to Norris. It has been an unprecedented time in theatre

column2: 'UK news'];The former Scottish National party MP Margaret Ferrier will stand trial in August accused of travelling from Glasgow to London in September 2020 knowing she had symptoms of coronavirus and wilfully exposing others to the risk of infection. column8: 'Commodities'];"The boss of one of the UK’s fastest-growing energy suppliers has said Britain must find £20bn to rein in soaring household bills that have compounded fears about a cost-of-living crisis in 2022. Greg Jackson
column9: the chief executive of Octopus Energy
column10: said his company did not know yet how much bills would rise in the run-up to 7 February
column11: the deadline for when the regulator Ofgem sets a new cap on what suppliers can charge customers. The record wholesale gas prices across Europe has led to forecasts that average annual bills in the UK could leap from £1
column12: 277 to more than £2
column13: 000 when the cap comes into effect in April. Jackson said talks between energy suppliers and the government would have to find a way to avoid global gas prices being passed directly on to consumers. “We’ve got to recognise that as a result of the pandemic
column14: every sector is asking the Treasury for help and there’s not an infinite supply of money
column15: ” he said. “The reality is that the UK buys most of its energy on a global market and we’ve had to pay about £20bn more than usual this year. So
column16: in some way or another
column17: the UK is going to have to pay that money.” Octopus
column18: a renewable energy provider
column19: is one of the fastest-growing companies in the sector
column20: with 3.1m customers. It has been at the heart of industry talks with business secretary
column21: Kwasi Kwarteng
column22: who is said to be determined to avoid bailing out large energy companies. Jackson has been a leading proponent of an alternative £20bn loan scheme
column23: under which a commercial lender makes a fund available that suppliers can dip into in order to refrain from hitting customers with sudden hikes in their energy bills. The suppliers could then pay the lender back over time with the money they make from staggered price increases
column24: cushioning the blow to household finances.

column1: Jackson said the sector should explore the plan
column2: which may need government oversight but not necessarily any state funding
column3: “before we go looking for help from the public purse or elsewhere”. “The energy sector has always had large access to private finance
column4: ” he added.

column1: Asked whether a windfall tax should be imposed on North Sea oil companies that have made money from higher gas prices to help fund lower bills
column2: Jackson refused to dismiss the idea. He added that it should be separate from broader efforts to reduce household bills. The expectation of rising gas bills adds to wider fears that 2022 will be characterised by a massive squeeze on the cost of living that could push more people into poverty and upend British politics. UK households face a hit of £1
column3: 200 this year
column4: according to the Resolution Foundation thinktank
column5: with more expensive energy bills piled on top of rising taxes and the effect of stalling wage increases.";https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/jan/06/octopus-ceo-uk-20bn-household-bills-loan-scheme;2

column8: shipping and hiring staff for warehouses

I have been in business for 30 years and I don’t think I have ever been through another period of economy-wide inflation on this scale. That’s an environment we are going to have to get used to trading in … How well we fare in that environment is difficult to see.” The fashion and homewares chain is the first retailer to report its Christmas trading results
column12: potentially giving an indication of how the high street fared in the biggest sales period of the year. The group said it now expected to make £822m in annual profits

column1: In the eight weeks to Christmas Day
column2: Next said its sales rose 20% on 2019 – before the Covid pandemic – despite suffering “materially lower” levels of stocks than it had hoped for while its delivery service had struggled because of labour shortages in its warehouses and distribution networks. “The fact that our sales remained so robust in these circumstances is
column3: we believe
column4: testament to the strength of underlying consumer demand in the period
column5: ” the company said. Lord Wolfson said the surge in sales of suits
column6: in particular
column7: was “a measure of how little has been bought of those products over the last two years”. The group’s strong performance was underpinned by an 85% surge in full-price online sales compared with 2019 at its Label business
column8: which sells brands such as Ted Baker
column9: Nike and Mint Velvet. Online sales of Next goods in the UK and overseas were also up by more than 30% in the three months to 25 December
column10: while sales in its UK and Irish stores fell 5.4% on 2019. Wolfson said sales in stores had been much better than the 10%-plus fall anticipatedprobably because the high street was beset by very heavy discounting two years ago. “A lot of those [businesses doing the discounting in the past] are not even trading today
column11: ” he said. “That’s likely to have helped in [Next] stores.” He added that shoppers had not been significantly deterred from coming into Next shops by the Omicron surge. Next said it was assuming there would not be further disruption fro the pandemic but it was unclear how much it had benefited from shoppers spending their savings built up during lockdowns and whether a return to spending on holidays and other social activities would hit sales of non-essential goods such as clothing. Sales are expected to rise by 7% in the year ahead

Next expects its prices to increase by almost 4% this spring and summer while the price of its autumn ranges would be 6% ahead of last year because of higher freight and manufacturing costs. The company said that average wages were also set to rise by 5.4% across the group driven by the April increase in the legal minimum wage as well as shortages of warehouse and technology workers.

column8: 'Television industry'];The BBC has hired ITN’s chief executive to lead its news coverage
column9: at a time when the broadcaster is struggling with substantial budget cuts and facing scrutiny over the impartiality of its coverage. Deborah Turness will inherit a newsroom that is halfway through an unpopular two-year restructuring process and has lost hundreds of experienced staff through redundancies and relocations. Its audience remains enormous across the UK and abroad but it is struggling with the transition away from traditional broadcasting formats and is regularly used as punchbag by politicians. Turness said that in an era of digital growth and innovation the BBC’s global reach gave it an edge. She said: “In the UK and around the world there has never been a greater need for the BBC’s powerful brand of impartial
column10: trusted journalism.” She will be paid £400
column11: 000 a year – £60
column12: 000 a year more than her predecessor
column13: Fran Unsworth. Her job title has also been upgraded from director of news to CEO of BBC News. Her background as an on-the-ground television producer could be helpful when working alongside the BBC director general
column14: Tim Davie
column15: who has no experience making programmes. Turness made her name during a decade-long stint as editor of ITV News
column16: before moving to New York in 2013 to run the sprawling NBC News operation. The first woman to run a major US news network
column17: she faced internal opposition as she dealt with the scandal over NBC host Brian Williams exaggerating claims about his experiences in Iraq. After four years in that job she returned to London to oversee two NBC-backed television channels that struggled to gain traction – a relaunch of Euronews and an abandoned plan to set up an international-focused version of Sky News. Last year Turness returned to ITN – who make news programmes for ITV
column18: Channel 4
column19: and Channel 5 – as chief executive
column20: in what was perceived by many staff as a homecoming. Nevertheless
column21: Davie persuaded her to jump ship and shape the future of the public broadcaster’s news operation – seeing off competition from internal BBC candidates such as Jonathan Munro and Jamie Angus. Her start date has yet to be confirmed but Turness’s first significant domestic decisions are likely to include finding a replacement for Laura Kuenssberg as political editor and managing the ongoing rotation of prominent on-air presenters. She will also have to work out whether any parts of the BBC’s news output will have to be shut down in order to meet looming budget cuts caused by years of below-inflation licence fee settlements. Any cuts are likely to cause anger among audiences and politicians
column22: at the same time as the corporation tries to work out how to attract younger audiences who increasingly get their news from elsewhere. There are also ongoing issues around the BBC’s attempts to define impartiality in the modern media environment
column23: with internal and external disputes over everything from coverage of transgender issues to Westminster politics and devolution matters.;https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/jan/06/bbc-news-hires-itn-deborah-turness-chief-executive;6

The Commission Nationale de l’Informatique et des Libertés (CNIL) said on Thursday it had fined Google a record €150m for making it difficult for internet users to refuse cookies – small text files that build up a profile of a person’s web activity for commercial purposes. It fined Facebook €60m for the same reason.

column1: Internet users’ prior consent for the use of cookies is a key pillar of the EU’s data privacy regulation
column2: and a top priority for the CNIL. “When you accept cookies
column3: it’s done in just one click
column4: ” said Karin Kiefer
column5: CNIL’s head of data protection and sanctions. “Rejecting cookies should be as easy as accepting them.” The watchdog said the facebook.com
column6: google.fr and youtube.com websites did not allow the easy refusal of cookies. Citing the example of Facebook
column7: it said: “Several clicks are required to refuse all cookies
column8: as opposed to a single one to accept them.” It said the companies had three months to comply with its orders
column9: including making it easier for French users to decline cookies
column10: or face extra penalty payments of €100
column11: 000 for every day of delay. A Google spokesperson said: “People trust us to respect their right to privacy and keep them safe. We understand our responsibility to protect that trust and are committing to further changes and active work with the CNIL in light of this decision.” A spokesperson for Facebook’s parent company
column12: Meta
column13: said: “We are reviewing the authority’s decision and remain committed to working with relevant authorities. Our cookie consent controls provide people with greater control over their data
column14: including a new settings menu on Facebook and Instagram where people can revisit and manage their decisions at any time
column15: and we continue to develop and improve these controls.” In 2020
column16: the CNIL strengthened consent rights over ad trackers
column17: saying websites operating in France should keep a register of internet users’ refusal to accept cookies for at least six months. It also said internet users should be able to easily reconsider any initial agreement concerning cookies via a weblink or an icon that should be visible on all pages of a website.";https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/jan/06/france-fines-google-and-facebook-210m-over-user-tracking-cookies;6

column6: 'UK news'];"I moved to Hull in 1971 because it was the most unlikely place in the world to start an experimental theatre company – plus rents were cheap and social security were unlikely to find us any proper jobs. I was 23 and I believed that theatre could change the world. I still do. I wanted to make uncompromising
column7: provocative

column11: for people who didn’t go to the theatre. I wanted Hull Truck to be a nuisance. Number 71 Coltman Street was cold and dark. On the ground floor was a room full of broken furniture and feral cats. We lived and rehearsed upstairs. The play Children of the Lost Planet was devised over 12 weeks. It was about a bunch of young people of our age living in Hull and trying to negotiate their way through the minefield of sex and drugs and rock’n’roll – always write what you know about. The winter of 1972 was freezing. We only had a small fan heater and rehearsed under a tent of blankets. The heater blew up so we burnt the broken chairs from downstairs. We bought a clapped-out Morris van for £35 and a lad from the youth theatre stole us a tax disc.

column4: 'US Capitol attack'];"Americans are not exactly known for nuance. Maybe it shouldn’t surprise us then that the rightwing protests that turned into a riot at the US Capitol building on 6 January 2021 were immediately described as a coup attempt. For most Democrats

column7: the protesters were the worst slur they could think of: they were “foreign”. George W Bush compared them to people in a “banana republic” and the Republican congressman Mike Gallagher agreed that “we are witnessing absolute banana republic crap in the United States Capitol right now.” The Florida senator Marco Rubio described the events in a tweet as “3rd world style anti-American anarchy”. But despite all the fears
column8: the pro-Trump rioters on 6 January didn’t exactly look like hardened fascists. Most wandered disorganized to the Capitol
column9: looked on from a distance
column10: took selfies and then trotted back to their hotel rooms after they got bored. These weren’t the street fighters we’ve come to associate with the rise of the far right internationally. Perhaps the strongest sign that the United States wasn’t actually in danger of falling to fascism that day was the response to 6 January from American elites. It is well established that big business interests have historically aligned both with fascism
column11: as was the case in the 1930s
column12: and rightwing authoritarianism
column13: and authoritarianism more generally
column14: during moments of crisis. As the Columbia law professor Tim Wu wrote in his recent book on monopolies: “The monopolist and the dictator tend to have overlapping interests.” Trump
column15: of course
column16: has something in common with fascists. He uses mass communications to stoke already widespread disaffection
column17: directing anger not at economic power brokers but at minorities and perceived cultural elites. He has encouraged violence and threats of violence against his enemies
column18: culminating in the mobilization one year ago today.

column7: which represents the country’s largest corporations
column8: issued a condemnation of the actions almost as strong. Finance capital

They are pouring in millions to support the campaigns of politicians who would roll back voting rights. And they are rallying their resources to oppose legislation that would give working-class people greater power in the economy. But

column21: US politics is indeed in crisis – but the crisis is a slow-moving one. It’s not as dramatic as a fascist storming of a Capitol building or a military takeover. But it’s almost as harmful to democracy in the long run. ••• This brings us to the question of institutional reform. In the United States

column1: A two-party system with this kind of structure all but guarantees that divided government is the norm rather than the exception – and that’s not to mention the role of a powerful judiciary. It was a political arrangement built by America’s founders to muzzle popular passions and ensure elite rule and that changes to the constitution through amendments are almost impossible to bring about. Contrary to myths about American stability
column2: it hasn’t actually worked out that well. In the 19th century
column3: the structure of US government
column4: particularly its devolution of power to states
column5: protected slavery and the power of plantation owners
column6: which led directly to a bloody civil war. In the 20th century
column7: things were more stable
column8: but this required an unusual amount of elite consensus and cross-party cooperation. But that consensus became harder to maintain after the exodus of northern liberals from the Republican party and southern Dixiecrats from the Democratic party created a more ideologically coherent system. We had a center to center-left party incorporating some business interests
column9: as well as the labor movement and a disproportionately racial-minority base of workers
column10: on the one hand
column11: and on the other a rightwing party of business with a solid popular base among conservative southern whites. The resulting level of polarization was not unusual by world standards

column17: elections almost always result in divided government and the opposition can use the system’s many chokepoints to hamper the ruling party’s attempts to govern. Republican distrust of state institutions – reflected both in their skepticism of election results as well as vaccine safety – has grown more intense. Tens of millions of Trump voters justified the 6 January riot at the Capitol

column20: the problem isn’t that American democracy is about to be overthrown; it’s that America isn’t much of a democracy to begin with. We need to create one people can believe in. Bhaskar Sunkara is the founding editor of Jacobin magazine and a Guardian US columnist. column9: an insect-trapping tobacco plant and an “exploding firework” flower are among the new species named by scientists in the last year. The species range from a voodoo lily from Cameroon to a rare tooth fungus unearthed near London

column12: Kew
column13: and their collaborators around the world. All are vital parts of the planet’s biodiversity and some may provide food and medicine. However
column14: several are already extinct in the wild and many threatened by the destruction of forests
column15: expanding palm oil plantations and mining. There are 400
column16: 000 named plant species and two in five are threatened with extinction. The scientists said it was a race against time to identify new plants before they disappeared for ever. In total
column17: scientists across the world have named about 2
column18: 000 new plant species each year for at least a decade. “It’s almost bewildering that we’re still discovering so many
column19: ” said Dr Martin Cheek
column20: at RBG Kew. “But now is our last chance to find unknown species
column21: name them and hopefully protect them before they become globally extinct.” The new ghost orchid is one of 16 new orchids from dense and remote forests in Madagascar. It was named Didymoplexis stella-silvae by Kew’s Johan Hermans
column22: meaning “star of the forest” as it grows in complete darkness and has star-like flowers. It has no leaves or chlorophyll for photosynthesis and gets all its nutrients in symbiosis with underground fungi. The flower only pokes through the forest-floor humus for a day to attract pollinators

column4: floods
column5: and fires caused by climate change
column6: ” said Hermans. “It really is a race against time.” The unusual tobacco plant was among seven new species found near a truck stop in Western Australia and is covered in sticky glands that trap and kill insects
column7: most likely as a defensive measure. “The arid parts of Australia
column8: which include most of the continent
column9: have been thought of as almost barren
column10: but in recent years these poorly studied areas have yielded many new and unusual species
column11: ” said Prof Mark Chase
column12: at RBG Kew. The tropics are known hotspots for biodiversity and a spectacular new species of primrose found in Borneo was named Ardisia pyrotechnica because its shower of white flowers resembles exploding fireworks. However
column13: it is already assessed as critically endangered

column1: The new pink voodoo lily has a 30cm-tall flower spike and was found in a small corner of the vast Ebo Forest of Cameroon. The tree named after Di Caprio was also found in the Ebo Forest. But despite the cancelling of logging permits in August 2020 by the president of Cameroon
column2: Uvariopsis dicaprio remains critically endangered because its habitat remains unprotected from potential future logging.

column9: which has a coral colour and a velvety texture

column2: 'Colorado'
column3: 'US news'];"It was just after sunrise on New Year’s Eve when climate scientist Daniel Swain paused outside his home in Boulder county
column4: Colorado. Snow was beginning to fall and a strong acrid smell – “like burned plastic”
column5: Swain said – hung on the newly chilled breeze. A fast-moving wildfire had torn through the area the day before
column6: leaving devastation in its wake. Driven by winds of more than 100mph
column7: what started as a small brush fire swiftly consumed nearly 1
column8: 000 homes within 24 hours.

column1: While relatively small in size – just 6
column2: 000 acres – the wildfire was the most destructive in Colorado’s history
column3: a feat that speaks to the growing danger of what Swain calls the “urban fire storm”. Areas where suburban sprawl meets landscapes primed by drought and other climate conditions to burn – known as the wildland urban interface (WUI) – are growing
column4: posing new threats in places once considered safe from wildfire. The Colorado fire engulfed neighborhoods and commercial districts alike
column5: forcing 35
column6: 000 people to flee their homes. It torched a Target
column7: a Tesla dealership
column8: and a Costco
column9: not long after unsuspecting Sunday shoppers were evacuated. Two people are still missing. “The wildland urban interface extends over a far broader area than many folks realize – and it is also dynamic
column10: ” Swain said. “Most of the time it is true that these areas are safe from wildfire but given conditionally extreme wind conditions and extreme drought
column11: they became part of that interface.” That the fire also happened in December
column12: a time once considered well outside of fire season
column13: has also raised alarm. “It was strange to have the snow start falling
column14: ” Swain said
column15: “and to have that smell of the remnants of almost 1
column16: 000 homes wafting through the air.” The area had had one of its warmest winters. This year
column17: the 30in of snowfall Boulder typically gets by December failed to appear. The region saw just 1.6in of precipitation since the beginning of August. “That’s natural variability
column18: ” atmospheric scientist Matthew Cappucci noted on Twitter
column19: “but in warmer world
column20: it’s easy to evaporate more of what little water falls.” When the fire ignited
column21: drought levels in the area were classified as “extreme” by the US Drought Monitor. It’s long been clear that what’s considered “fire season” is stretching longer
column22: covering more months of the year. And
column23: while that increases the number of days when a fire could start it also brings conditions in line with winter weather patterns – like dry wind – that vastly increase the danger. Strong gusts aren’t unusual in Colorado
column24: especially in the Boulder area
column25: but without snow and rain to dampen the risks
column26: disaster was able to strike. “A lot of these events – from fires to mudslides – are just a consequence of extreme events many months in the making
column27: ” said Andrew Hoell
column28: a meteorologist for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s physical sciences laboratory
column29: noting the compounding effect drought and heat has had on fires. Record-low precipitation was intensified by record-high temperatures. It’s a recipe for disaster
column30: and one that Hoell is familiar with. “I am used to talking about extreme events
column31: ” he said. But
column32: based in Boulder
column33: this one hit close to home. His house was spared
column34: but many in his community
column35: both colleagues and friends
column36: lost their homes. “It always gets you down. But when it’s your friends
column37: your neighborhood
column38: your community – it is a whole different ball game.” Thousands without homes are searching through the rubble and trying to put back the pieces. Recovery is expected to take years. The cause of this blaze is still under investigation. The Boulder county sheriff
column39: Joe Pelle
column40: told reporters that downed power lines
column41: which were initially suspected as the ignition source
column42: have been ruled out.

column1: Most fires are still started by people
column2: intentionally or not
column3: and with more people living in high-risk areas
column4: the dangers only continue to mount. “What the science said is that growth is occurring faster in the wildland urban interface than anywhere else” said Carrie Berger
column5: fire program manager of the forestry & natural resources extension fire program at Oregon State University. “That’s where people are moving most rapidly.” A third of US homes currently stand in the WUI and that number is only going to grow as the construction march into the wildland continues
column6: and as higher temperatures increase the boundaries of burnable land. That’s why scientists and disaster experts are pushing for a shift in focus from suppression to preparation. “We live in a fire landscape
column7: ” Berger said. “I don’t think there’s any place that is safe from wildfire.” She emphasized the need for a community approach to fire safety
column8: complete with home hardening techniques like reducing vegetation that brushes up to buildings
column9: crafting and coordinating plans
column10: and using fire-resistant building materials. Climate scientist Daniel Swain echoed her calls. While this disaster hit close to home
column11: he emphasized that the next one could occur anywhere. “This is not a unique problem to Boulder county. This is not a unique problem to Colorado. This is not even a unique problem to the American west – and I think this comes at a surprise to most people
column12: ” he said. As temperatures rise and aridification spreads into other landscapes
column13: big blazes could erupt out of the forested areas in the upper midwest. They could spread through Florida
column14: burn in Georgia
column15: or blacken suburban New Jersey the way they do now in California and Colorado. “All of a sudden you have conditions that really aren’t all that different from what they would be like in the west
column16: ” Swain says. “That might make things possible that were simply impossible before.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/06/urban-fire-storm-suburban-sprawl-wildfires-colorado;1

column6: 'Law'];"There were cheers from the public gallery of Bristol crown court when the verdicts of not guilty were returned. Eighteen months after Bristol’s now infamous statue of the slave trader Edward Colston was sent crashing to the pavement
column7: the four young people who had been charged with criminal damage were acquitted. The strategy that the prosecution appears to have adopted – in a case that some now argue should never have been brought to trial – seemed to centre on asking that the jury be blind to history. Who the statue venerated
column8: they argued

column7: they had
column8: so argued the defence
column9: permitted the statue to become an “indecent display”. Having established these arguments Liam Walker QC
column10: representing Sage Willoughby
column11: the youngest of the defendants
column12: argued that the Colston Four “were on the right side of history”. Jurors were invited to join them there. In the aftermath of this verdict those who now have questions to answer are Colston’s defenders. In particular the Society of Merchant Venturers
column13: a grouping that for decades dismissed and discounted appeals for the statue to be removed or contextualised. Its strategy of muddying waters and maintaining the status quo fostered indecision and inaction. Decades of inertia were brought to an end in just under three hours – the time it took for the jury to arrive at its verdict. The merchant elite of late Victorian Bristol who erected the statue of Colston
column14: many of them members of the Merchant Venturers
column15: did so in the full knowledge that the man they sought to elevate to civic sainthood had been a trader in human flesh. The details of his grim career had been obscured but not obliterated. Despite what they knew they expanded the bizarre cult of rituals
column16: religious services and exclusive dinners that had been built around him
column17: but their most public triumph was the erection of the statue. To validate the imposition of the cult of Colston on to the wider city they falsely implied that the statue had been paid for through popular
column18: public subscription. They did all of this confident in the belief that no one would ever question their decisions
column19: as no one would ever come to care about Colston’s crimes or his victims. Their confidence sprang from their collective inability to envisage a future moment in which the Africans who had perished in the bellies of the Royal African Company’s ships
column20: or on the plantations of Barbados or Jamaica
column21: would matter to anyone in Bristol or beyond. The moment they were unable to conceive of is now. The generation for whom the lives of Colston’s victims matter deeply is the generation from whom the four defendants in this case were drawn. In the months since the murder of George Floyd millions of people across the world have examined their nations’ official histories
column22: and the history lessons they were taught at school. They have discovered missing chapters
column23: half-truths and lost connections between the crimes of then and the inequalities of now. As Rhian Graham
column24: one of the Colston Four
column25: noted in the impromptu speech she made from the pavement outside court
column26: the dethronement of Colston was not a stand-alone event
column27: but part of a global movement. I am writing this from Covid isolation in a hotel on the southern coast of Barbados. From my window I can see the approaches to the island
column28: the sea lanes along which the ships of the Atlantic slave trade once passed
column29: before docking to unload their human cargoes. To the north of me is a place called Speightstown
column30: its nickname in the 18th century was “Little Bristol”
column31: so firmly was it connected to the slave traders and sugar merchants of that English city 4
column32: 000 miles away. The global shift of consciousness that inspired the toppling of Colston was also a factor in the decision made by the people of this island to break decisively away from that history and become a republic. This shift in consciousness
column33: translated into action across the world by the young
column34: will be strengthened by this verdict; and by the very fact that when made aware of long obscured historical and moral truths
column35: an English jury chose to placeitself – and the city of Bristol – on the right side of history. David Olusoga is a historian and broadcaster";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/06/britains-shameful-slavery-history-matters-thats-why-a-jury-acquitted-the-colston-4;2

column6: 'Society'];"French MPs have passed the government’s controversial vaccine pass bill after three days of an angry stop-start debate. The legislation
column7: which requires people to be fully vaccinated to enjoy social
column8: sporting and cultural activities
column9: was approved by a large majority in the assemblée nationale in the early hours of Thursday morning. The bill was passed by 214 votes against 93 and 27 abstentions. It will now be presented to the upper house
column10: the sénat
column11: to be debated on Monday. Ministers had hoped to introduce the controversial measure on 15 January
column12: but the often heated parliamentary debate was suspended twice this week. The law was first held up when MPs voted to go home just before midnight on Monday
column13: then again on Wednesday after a row erupted over language used by the president
column14: Emmanuel Macron’s when he promised to make life difficult for unvaccinated people. While more than 90% of French adults have been fully jabbed
column15: one of the highest rates in the world
column16: the remaining 10% – estimated at around 5 million people
column17: including Brigitte Bardot
column18: the actor turned animal activist
column19: have refused to have the Covid vaccine. Until now they have been able to use a passe sanitaire (health pass) that required either vaccination
column20: recovery from Covid or a negative Covid test for everyone over the age of 12 to access restaurants
column21: bars
column22: museums
column23: theatres and other public places. In October
column24: the government put an end to free Covid tests for unvaccinated people
column25: but the new legislation goes a step further in requiring people to be fully vaccinated to access such places.

column1: Macron said the measure was intended to coerce vaccine-hesitant people to get inoculated by further restricting their everyday activities. The law also introduces hefty fines and prison sentences for anyone caught using or supplying fake vaccine passes and for establishments that fail properly to check visitors’ vaccine status. The pass will not be required for shops or medical facilities such as hospitals and clinics. Vaccination is currently compulsory only for health workers
column2: but the new law would extend this to those who work in venues where they are in contact with the public. Macron
column3: who is expected to be re-elected in April
column4: has ruled out making the vaccine obligatory for everyone. About 66
column5: 000 people had their first vaccine on Wednesday after the president’s controversial comments
column6: the highest number in 24 hours since the beginning of October.

column1: The prime minister
column2: Jean Castex
column3: told the French news and weather channel BFMTV he hoped the vaccine pass could come into force on 15 January as originally planned and described the Covid situation in France as “extremely worrying”. Castex defended Macron’s controversial use of the verb “emmerder” (widely translated as “piss off”) in his vow to put pressure on those French people who refused to be vaccinated
column4: saying the former president
column5: Georges Pompidou
column6: had used the same word. Macron also angered critics by calling unvaccinated people irresponsible
column7: adding: “Someone irresponsible is not a citizen.” “Let’s not play with words
column8: of course the non vaccinated are still [French] citizens
column9: ” Castex said. “What the president wanted to say is that when you are a citizen of our beautiful republic
column10: you have rights
column11: but also duties. It’s called civic-mindedness
column12: it’s called a sense of responsibility.” On Thursday
column13: it was revealed Bardot was among those facing Macron’s ire: the 87-year-old actor said she had not been vaccinated as she was “allergic to all chemical substances”.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/06/french-mps-pass-controversial-covid-vaccine-bill-with-large-majority;1

column6: 'Money'];Motorists paid £5m more a day for fuel than they should have last month after petrol station owners refused to pass on a drop in wholesale prices to consumers
column7: the RAC has claimed. The motoring organisation called December a “rotten month” despite the price of unleaded petrol falling by 2p per litre
column8: after estimating that petrol retailers should have reduced the cost by 12p. The RAC said that instead of pocketing the traditional long-term margin of 6p a litre
column9: retailers took an average of 16p a litre on petrol and 12.5p on diesel. Across December
column10: the RAC estimates that drivers collectively lost out on £156m
column11: or £5m a day
column12: from the wholesale price cuts not being passed on by retailers. “December was a rotten month for drivers as they were taken advantage of by retailers
column13: ” said Simon Williams
column14: fuel spokesperson at the RAC. “In the past when wholesale prices have dropped retailers have always done the right thing – eventually – and reduced their pump prices. “This time they’ve stood strong
column15: taking advantage of all the media talk about ‘higher energy prices’ and banked on the oil price rising again and catching up with their artificially inflated prices
column16: which it now has done.” The Petrol Retailers Association (PRA)

column19: and there have been far fewer of these transactions because of the reduction in business activity between Christmas and New Year
column20: ” said Gordon Balmer
column21: executive director of the PRA. “The costs of running petrol stations rose all year
column22: with electricity up 19%
column23: vastly reduced margins from fuel cards as well as increased national insurance and wage inflation.” In September
column24: the PRA chair
column25: Brian Madderson
column26: said he did not “condone profiteering” as petrol prices rocketed and filling stations ran dry due to panic buying. The RAC said in December it cost drivers £6 more to fill up a typical family car than if petrol retailers had stuck to taking the traditional 6p margin and passed savings on to motorists. Diesel vehicle owners paid £4 more than they potentially could have. The RAC said at the end of last year Asda had the cheapest petrol

column7: 'Sport'];"There was a moment early in the second day at the Sydney Cricket Ground when Steve Smith looked nailed on for a hundred. Sure
column8: it was a dot ball
column9: and sure
column10: he was on seven at the time. But there was something about the way he stepped into a straight drive back at Stuart Broad
column11: the feet moving perfectly
column12: the timing crisp with no attempt at power
column13: the line so straight that the bowler bent to scoop up the ball. At the ground where Smith made three international centuries in the previous Australian summer
column14: he looked like Smith looks when he is most switched on. Yet a few hours later
column15: it was Usman Khawaja raising his bat to the cheers of a home crowd. Broad had got the better of Smith for 67
column16: to an uncharacteristic push at a ball that didn’t require one. Khawaja had left the bowling impeccably
column17: defended it resolutely
column18: and taken it on when given the opportunity
column19: in an innings that showed all of the best parts of his game built over the course of his lengthening career.

column1: It was the shortcomings in his game that led to Khawaja spending most of the past two and a half years outside the national team
column2: having been dropped after the third Ashes Test at Headingley in 2019. Khawaja had not had a terrible series batting at first drop
column3: making 40 in an important partnership at Edgbaston and 36 in another at Lord’s. But he hadn’t made a compelling score
column4: and then ran into some bad luck or bad timing. Australia pulled the trigger on the opener Cameron Bancroft early
column5: replacing him with Marcus Harris after two Tests. Marnus Labuschagne impressed in the third Test as Smith’s concussion replacement
column6: and had to be retained when Smith returned. Had Australia given Bancroft one more match
column7: he could either have succeeded and kept his spot
column8: or been replaced by Khawaja moving up the order. But with Harris having played only once
column9: selectors had to keep him for a stint that was ultimately worse than Bancroft’s
column10: while Khawaja returned home to a poor Sheffield Shield season and floated out of the reckoning entirely. Since then the reasonable conclusion has been that Khawaja’s time is done. He turned 35 just before Christmas
column11: while Labuschagne has cemented himself in Khawaja’s old spot at No 3
column12: and Will Pucovski emerged as the young tyro most likely to accompany David Warner’s final years at the top. Warner and Smith are also moving deeper into their 30s and overall the Test team has needed to be refreshed.

column1: But just as things change quickly in one direction
column2: they can go quickly in the other. Khawaja had a good half-season
column3: Pucovski was ruled out with another concussion injury
column4: Travis Head returned a positive Covid test
column5: and suddenly there was a spot that needed to be filled
column6: and a job that needed to be done. Khawaja is no stranger to solving problems for Australia. During the one-day World Cup in 2019 he was thrown in at No 5 despite never having batted there in List A cricket. In the current match he was asked to bat there despite never having done so in Tests. By this point of his career the details such as where he bats don’t seem to faze Khawaja. He walked in on the first evening with Australia 117 for three
column7: with trouble looming for the team if he failed
column8: and instead made sure that he didn’t. He first batted through to stumps
column9: then through the first session of the next day with Smith
column10: before assuming the senior role once Smith was gone. Through those hours
column11: and his 260 deliveries
column12: his patience and concentration shone through. At times in his career Khawaja’s innings have been ended by lapses in either. After a long first session with an extra half-hour
column13: as he moved beyond his half-century
column14: he opened up his repertoire of strokes: that lavish cover drive
column15: a back cut
column16: the pull. But they were careful selections for the right occasion
column17: not extravagances for their own sake. Through he went past tea
column18: towards sunset
column19: taking Australia to a point where his eventual dismissal for 137 prompted a charge towards a declaration rather than a rearguard.

column1: Of course
column2: there is the question of what is next. But Khawaja before this match said that he was filling in for the match in Head’s spot. He is probably right
column3: with the longer-term holder having been anointed and having made his own match-defining century in Brisbane. Head will return for the fifth Test in Hobart. Khawaja’s assignment was short-term and it has been fulfilled immaculately. It doesn’t need to lead to anything else for it to be a triumph in its own right
column4: a player showing that he still has what it takes years after he stopped getting that chance. Beyond Hobart
column5: Australia will play nine Tests in Asia in the coming year. On his last visit in 2018 Khawaja made his masterpiece 140 to save a Test in Dubai. There is every likelihood that more chances will arise
column6: and Khawaja has shown himself ready.";https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2022/jan/06/khawaja-stand-in-century-a-triumph-for-australias-old-problem-solver-ashes-cricket;4

column9: 'Neuroscience'];Dogs may appear to have selective hearing when it comes to commands but research suggests they are paying attention to human chit-chat. Researchers – who arranged for headphone-wearing dogs to listen to excerpts from the novella The Little Prince – revealed the brains of our canine companions can tell the difference between speech and non-speech when listening to human voices
column10: and show different responses to speech in an unfamiliar language. The team said the findings supported other studies that suggest animals may share some human skills. “Our capacities to process speech and languages are not necessarily unique in all the ways we like to think they are
column11: ” said Dr Attila Andics
column12: senior author of the study at Eötvös Loránd University in Hungary. The research involved 18 dogs of various ages and breeds that were trained to lie in an MRI scanner without restraint or sedation
column13: but with headphones on. They were then played recordings either of humans reading excerpts from The Little Prince by Antoine De Saint-Exupéry or those same recordings cut up into small pieces and put back together in a different order so it sounded unnatural. The results
column14: published in the journal NeuroImage
column15: reveal the dogs’ brains showed a different activity pattern in the primary auditory cortex for speech compared with non-speech
column16: with the findings similar regardless of whether the language used – Hungarian or Spanish – was familiar. Curiously
column17: the longer the dog’s head was
column18: the better their brain could distinguish speech from non-speech. The team also found the activity pattern was stronger for non-speech. “In humans
column19: you typically see stronger response to speech
column20: ” Andics told the Guardian
column21: adding it appears a different mechanism is at play in dogs and they are not “tuned in” to speech. “Probably what they detect is that the normal
column22: natural speech sounds natural. And the other one sounds surprising
column23: strange
column24: not the typical pattern we hear
column25: ” he said. The research also revealed familiar and unfamiliar languages gave rise to different responses in the secondary auditory cortex and precruciate gyrus – but only for speech. That was important
column26: said Andics
column27: as it suggested the ability to distinguish between languages was not simply down to the speakers being different. Instead
column28: the team said
column29: the differences seen between languages for speech are probably down to exposure to the familiar language and a sensitivity to language-specific regularities. “This is also supported by the observation that older dogs show the stronger differentiation between the two languages
column30: ” said Andics. He said it made sense to explore response to human speech in dogs
column31: since they shared our environment. But questions remained. “Whether this is something that only dog brains can do or not
column32: or whether dogs indeed became better at detecting speech as a result of certain brain changes during these tens of thousands of years of domestication
column33: we are not sure
column34: ” he said. Sophie Scott
column35: professor of cognitive neuroscience at University College London
column36: said she welcomed the research. “[It is a] very nice demonstration of just how much dogs are listening to our voices and how much information they’re pulling out
column37: even if that is not necessarily speech that is directed to them or containing words they might recognise
column38: ” she said. “Almost everything that you can find about human speech and human language and you say
column39: ‘ah this is unique to humans’
column40: you find an animal somewhere that can do it.”;https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/06/dogs-may-be-able-to-tell-difference-between-speech-patterns-study-finds;6

column4: 'Beauty'];"At the temple of regret
column5: you can have your mistakes burned away by a smiling practitioner
column6: if you are willing to pay a hefty fee. I’m at an unremarkable office block near Monument tube station in central London
column7: watching the remorseful have their body art erased at Pulse Light Clinic
column8: which offers state-of-the-art tattoo removal using laser technology. As penitents of all ages
column9: walks of life and ethnicities walk through the door
column10: one thing becomes clear: there are a lot of terrible tattoos out there. In a spotless treatment room beside a £6
column11: 500 tattoo-removing PicoSure laser machine
column12: senior practitioner Cherry Brierly is recounting her clients’ stories. “I had one lovely guy
column13: ” she says brightly. “He had a tattoo on his head. He was in his 60s
column14: newly divorced. He came in and said: ‘It’s not me any more. I need to find a new wife.’” The tattoo said: “Made in London”. It disappeared in a single session. Probably the worst tattoos Brierly has removed were the terrible jokes: “‘Tupac’ written across the stomach
column15: ” she says. “Or ‘Brexit’ on the bum. Or camel drawn on a toe.” As a tattoo remover
column16: Brierly has a direct line into the shifting vagaries of the human psyche. “One guy did practically his whole body
column17: ” she says. “Everything was tattooed. He’d gotten divorced and was a Muslim.” As some Muslims believe tattoos are forbidden
column18: she thinks they were his way of declaring he didn’t want to be a Muslim any more. There was just one problem: he rediscovered his faith. “All that was within six months.” The most common tattoos Brierly removes
column19: however
column20: are tribal designs out of favour since their 90s heyday. “Tramp stamps” – a tattoo on a woman’s lower back – are also routinely sandblasted away
column21: as are dolphins
column22: another relic of the 90s. (Samantha Cameron has one on her foot.) More recently
column23: Brierly has had clients coming in to have full sleeves removed
column24: as the 2010s trend beloved of footballers and social media influencers burns itself out. And then
column25: of course
column26: there are names – heartbreak is always good business for the tattoo-removal trade. “We’re impulsive
column27: ” says Brierly when asked what she has learned from her career. “Very impulsive.” In an adjacent treatment room
column28: Candice Smith is having a youthful indiscretion scrubbed clean. “I remember I was walking down the street
column29: ” says the 30-year-old social work student
column30: from east London
column31: “and someone said: ‘She’s got a strawberry on her leg!’ I think that did it for me.”

column1: I contemplate the offending soft fruit
column2: on Smith’s left calf. It is the size of a baby’s head
column3: badly rendered in wobbly fluorescent pink. In all honesty
column4: she’s making the right call. “It was only a small tattoo I wanted
column5: ” Smith sighs. “But it ended up being massive.” Smith can’t even remember why she got the strawberry tattoo – she is not particularly keen on the fruit but was 18 at the time
column6: a wannabe Camden scene kid with tattoos
column7: a face full of piercings
column8: and an extreme haircut. “The regret kicked in as I got older
column9: ” Smith says. She’s having it lasered off so that she no longer has to worry about covering it when the weather gets warm. “Over the years
column10: ” she says
column11: “it has just ruined every summer. I’m forever trying to cover it with the perfect length dress
column12: and midi dresses aren’t my thing. Or culottes
column13: which I don’t really like
column14: but I wear because they cover the tattoo.” She is halfway through a course of six treatments
column15: at a cost of £600
column16: and her tattoo is much faded
column17: although still visible. (Most tattoos take a number of sessions to be removed.) “I was shocked at how much it cost
column18: ” Smith says. “But I felt like getting this removed was very worth it for me.” Astonishingly
column19: despite all this
column20: she doesn’t regret the tattoo
column21: and says it serves as a learning curve for her children. Beside her

column23: she explains
column24: pose a challenge
column25: because pink is especially tricky to remove. “The way tattoo removal works
column26: ” Cazzetta says
column27: “is that the laser breaks down the ink into very small particles
column28: and the blood that flows under the skin takes away the ink.” The laser works on all skin types with black ink
column29: but it can cause pigmentation – a permanent change to the colour of the skin – with coloured tattoos on black skin. Pink
column30: yellow
column31: and white are the most stubborn colours to remove; a practitioner may be able to fade them considerably
column32: but a trace will remain. “They will go down in potency
column33: ” says Cazzatta
column34: “and look like a bruise.” Some clients choose to cover up these faded remnants with a new tattoo; others are simply happy for their old ink to be barely visible. Visitors to the clinic are increasingly seeking to have their old tattoos removed and replaced by handiwork from artists more talented than the one who did the original tattoo. With darker inks
column35: the laser can have phenomenal results: the tattoo simply vanishes
column36: as if it was never there. Cazzetta
column37: who is heavily tattooed

column39: then had it lasered off after the breakup. “I wanted to join all my clients with their experiences

column42: ” Cazzetta smiles.

column1: She relishes the challenge of a tattoo like Smith’s strawberry. “Every tattoo can be extremely different from another

column4: sometimes

column8: “because the ink was pushed so deep into the skin”. Smith has prepared for her session by rubbing anaesthetic numbing cream on to the tattoo – a must for anyone contemplating laser tattoo removal. Without it

column10: “the pain is horrific. I’m not going to lie. It’s a feeling you can’t describe. Like burning hot oil.” The cream “takes the pain off
column11: ” Brierly says. “You can sit through it. It’s fine. You can still feel it
