column13: it’s horrible.” The treatment itself takes less than two minutes: Cazzetta zaps the tattoo with a PicoWay laser

column15: the PicoSure and PicoWay
column16: depending on the type of tattoo being removed.) “The only way I can explain it
column17: ” says Smith
column18: “is that it feels like someone is stretching an elastic band and flicking you with it
column19: without stopping.” At the end of the session
column20: her strawberry is further faded: a berry stain

column1: What becomes clear
column2: after only a few hours in the clinic
column3: is that there are a lot of tattoos out there that are not what the client had in mind. “I knew what I wanted

column15: I love it.’” The tattoo in question is an orange maple leaf on her upper arm. Clay then added a rose to it
column16: thinking she would like it more
column17: but now she regrets that too
column18: and wants both removed. This
column19: says Brierly
column20: is a common error. “My advice for anyone is that if you don’t like a tattoo
column21: don’t cover it. Just get rid of it. Because it escalates. Some people get two cover-ups and then blackout over the top
column22: and then take it off.” It’s best to treat a bad tattoo like a recipe that’s beyond saving: toss out the entire meal and start afresh
column23: rather than trying to salvage it with additions.

column1: Clay is in for a patch test

column7: “and I’m getting it removed.” Britain’s unquenchable enthusiasm for tattoos means Pulse Light Clinic is
column8: for now
column9: doing a roaring trade. Unless the tattoo is particularly large

column5: tattoo removal is an option for our most visible errors of judgment. Just don’t forget the numbing cream.";https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2022/jan/06/i-hated-it-the-minute-it-was-finished-bad-body-art-and-regrets-in-a-tattoo-removal-clinic;5

column9: the Malawian rights activist Paul Msoma wrote that he was in Kamuzu central hospital

I was left wondering where the funds that had been released for the country’s Covid-19 response were going. “My situation is getting bad and l desperately need oxygen
column11: ” Msoma wrote on Facebook. “Anyone who can urgently help out there please help by donating this very gadget.” Kamuzu central hospital is one of the biggest referral hospitals in Malawi and it did not seem right for such a big hospital not to have oxygen flowmeters

column31: 378 deaths

They say every global citizen shall be required to have a mark in order to engage in any business. There is another myth that has been taking turns

column38: as 82.57% of Malawi’s population lives in rural areas

column9: and Chakwera commits to full transparency for all Covid spending. Madalitso Wills Kateta is a freelance journalist based in Lilongwe

column7: 'Australian immigration and asylum'];"Novak Djokovic’s Australian Open journey started in comfort
column8: and excitement. A photo showed the tennis star with a huge grin on his face
column9: bags packed
column10: as he boarded his Emirates flight from Dubai. “Let’s go 2022!” he posted to Instagram. But it ended with him trapped in an immigration hotel infamous for detaining refugees

column1: The news that the world No 1
column2: who refuses to reveal his vaccine status
column3: was en route to Australia enraged many. Melbourne was one of the most locked down cities in the world
column4: and the Covid vaccine is mandated in the majority of its workplaces. Many residents questioned why Tennis Australia and the Victorian government were allowing an unvaccinated sports star to play.

column1: But after touching down in Melbourne about 11.30pm local time
column2: Djokovic never made it through arrivals. Australian Border Force officials stopped him after it emerged that his team had applied for a visa that does not allow medical exemptions. In a statement
column3: the ABF confirmed Djokovic did not meet the entry requirements and his visa was cancelled. “Non-citizens who do not hold a valid visa on entry or who have had their visa cancelled will be detained and removed from Australia
column4: ” the statement said. As Djokovic waited alone in an airport room

column6: waving a Serbian flag.

column1: Slobodan Bendjo and Krstomir Dusanovic had been waiting at Melbourne airport since midnight
column2: ready to welcome the tennis star. Armed with an accordion and a Serbian flag
column3: the pair were walking around the airport playing music.

column1: “We are here to await the champion
column2: ” Dusanovic said. They were not deterred by the fact the tennis star was being told to leave Australia
column3: they said. “We’ve still here to welcome him

column5: when he comes here

column1: A young fan
column2: Andrew Mitrovic wandered in with his mum. He held a makeshift sign that said “free Nole”. They had brought tickets to see Djokovic play and were devastated he hadn’t been allowed in. About 10am
column3: he was moved to the Park hotel in Carlton
column4: an infamous immigration detention hotel. It houses 36 refugees – some of whom have been detained for nine years. The windows in the hotel can’t be opened – they have been sealed shut and there was recently a Covid outbreak among the detainees. An unusual crew of Djokovic supporters
column5: refugee advocates and anti-vaxxers gathered outside the hotel.

column1: Husband and wife Ziggy and Billy Misovic came down to show their support for the tennis star. Waving a flag from Djokovic’s home town

column6: but never any media

column9: and public.” The refugees are not allowed on the roof for fresh air and have recently reported finding maggots and mould in their food. column3: 'Culture'];"Each page of Sara Freeman’s debut novel holds a slim paragraph
column4: two at most. And if there are two paragraphs on one page
column5: then these are divided by the symbol of a crescent moon
column6: so that at no point is any section of text close to touching another. At all moments
column7: the writing in Tides has to contend with an expanse of vacant space. The experience of reading such a novel is like travelling through a series of expertly designed studio flats. You marvel at every interior you come to: a whole unto itself
column8: not a foot wrong in the design. But then you turn the page and enter yet another four walls
column9: the last beginning to fade from your mind. Only at the end are you able to conceive of all these paragraphs at once
column10: imagine a whole tower block of crafted text. Prior to the novel’s start
column11: Mara
column12: the main character
column13: underwent the tragedy of a stillbirth. After that
column14: she could no longer endure any of the relationships that bordered that terrible experience – not with her husband
column15: nor her brother
column16: his wife and their new baby
column17: who lived on the floor below her apartment
column18: “their joy so firmly lodged beneath her grief”. And so she boards a bus that will take her far away
column19: to an American seaside town: 2
column20: 353 inhabitants
column21: a few shops
column22: hostels
column23: then the bay and the water beyond that. For much of the novel
column24: she drifts from place to place
column25: staying at various hostels
column26: spending nights passed out blind drunk on the beach or with strange men – before she finds more permanent residence in the disused attic of a wine shop
column27: where she has got herself a temporary job. Freeman’s chosen form
column28: then
column29: acts as a visual manifestation of her protagonist’s state: her refusal of proximity
column30: her abnegation of all those people and places that had previously been contiguous to her life. Now
column31: nothing can touch her
column32: nothing must last. All the places she ends up in feel as interstitial as the paragraphs themselves
column33: the attic “a square of dispossessed land” from which
column34: after each night
column35: “she sets to work on erasing the signs of her own presence”. This mirroring of structure and plot is smart. It can be very effective. But it also feels too artificial
column36: too neat
column37: to the extent that it draws attention away from the plot and towards its own ingenuity. It is an example of American literary critic and poet Yvor Winters’s “fallacy of imitative form”
column38: his attack on modernist poetry wherein the “form succumbs to the raw material of the poem”
column39: weakening both the poem’s ability to convey its meaning and the form itself. Freeman has suggested that Tides started as an exploration of intense sibling relationships and the way these come to seem abnormal if they continue into adulthood. As children
column40: Mara and her younger brother Paul were inseparable (character names
column41: as well as events occurring before the time of the novel
column42: are drip-fed to the reader
column43: Mara’s life a landscape under fog gradually burning away until the past is at last a clear day). Paul’s first word was “Mara”. Hers was “mine”. She carried him everywhere she went. As such
column44: Mara has found it hard to accept Paul’s marriage
column45: the way “every bit of life has been collectivised
column46: their knowing too. Two skulls pressed together: two wills collapsed.” The subtle violence of the imagery perfectly expresses her abject horror at seeing her brother wrenched from her and becoming conjoined with another. Throughout Tides
column47: there is play between singular and plural pronouns – Mara’s fear of becoming a “we” once more
column48: and her equivalent terror at remaining an “I”. The slow revelation of the depth to which Paul and Mara were previously enmeshed is the strongest
column49: most disturbing aspect of the book
column50: and what makes it live in spite of its fragmented form. Freeman hammers her paragraphs down into perfected
column51: indivisible units
column52: without any bulk or extraneous matter. When it works
column53: her images are light as gas. Naturally
column54: there is an abundance of water-related imagery. After several months in the town
column55: Mara realises no one has come to save her. “The fact solidifies beneath her
column56: a layer of black ice under every thought.” And then
column57: as she begins to come back to herself
column58: in part because of a relationship with someone new
column59: “there is summer right beneath
column60: a current of it under a thin layer of ice”. This lover describes to her the inner workings of the tides
column61: their “rush and release of water”
column62: but she knows what she will remember from the conversation is not the tides’ mechanism
column63: but “the tendon in his neck straining as he talks
column64: the clavicle lifting like a lock”. Each image is eloquently expressed
column65: but when it becomes the only thought on a page
column66: without other images to jostle against
column67: it loses its vitality. In a 2010 interview
column68: Don DeLillo described how he limits himself to one paragraph per page when drafting his novels. It allows him to see more clearly the shape of the words. But in their final form
column69: those paragraphs are brought back into colloquy with one another. As with stanza breaks
column70: readers intuitively make something of these divisions; they do not require the separation of a whole page to understand the rupture that might have occurred in time
column73: the splitting of paragraphs between pages does not become more than a formal pretension
column74: one that slows down and makes less coherent an otherwise very strange and poignant novel. • Lamorna Ash’s Dark

column5: 'Culture'];"François Truffaut’s sublime autobiographical debut is now rereleased
column6: a portrait of the artist as an unhappy child. He deserved every prize going simply for those heartstopping images of the children’s faces as they watch a Punch and Judy show. This is its first release in the UK since 2009
column7: but maybe 62 years is now enough perspective to see fully how the grim scenes of home life and school life
column8: which would have been accepted as contemporary realism in 1959 and for years afterwards
column9: now look like historical documents. The title itself
column10: from faire les quatre cent coups
column11: means to hand out punishment
column12: raise hell
column13: sow wild oats – but this is an ironic upending. Truffaut’s alter ego
column14: Antoine Doinel
column15: is receiving the blows. They rain down on him. Cruelty and humiliation and desperation – and defiance – are this kid’s destiny.

column1: Jean-Pierre Léaud played the 12-year-old lead in this and the five successive Doinel films
column2: a role which was to define his entire life. Like Truffaut
column3: Doinel is a truant
column4: a delinquent
column5: a kid from an unhappy home and a thief: he steals money
column6: a bottle of milk
column7: a typewriter and
column8: most importantly of all
column9: a piece of writing. For a class assignment
column10: he plagiarises
column11: or at any rate paraphrases
column12: a passage from Balzac’s Quest of the Absolute from 1834
column13: about the death of the alchemist Balthazar Claes
column14: repurposing it for the supposed death of his own grandfather. Doinel even has a candlelit shrine to Balzac in the cramped family apartment
column15: which almost burns the place down. But Doinel has a tyrannical and narrow-minded schoolteacher (veteran player Guy Decomble
column16: resembling Maigret with his coat and pipe) who is nicknamed petite feuille – little leaf – and is a petty little pedant. Instead of applauding Doinel’s good taste and even conceding that this semi-larceny shows audacity and imagination
column17: this man is simply satisfied with his own cleverness at spotting the borrowing and punishes the boy. It is the ultimate mortification.

column1: Doinel knows that his mother
column2: the brassy Gilberte (Claire Maurier)
column3: is unfaithful to his jokey
column4: affectionate stepfather Julien (Albert Rémy); he has seen her kissing a man in the street and knows that gifts of money may be involved. So when he pretends that his mother is dead as a bizarre excuse to explain one truancy – a grotesque lie for which Julien comes to school with his still living mother and slaps Doinel’s face in front of his class – it is clearly an act of matricidal wish-fulfilment of some sort. Doinel bunks off school
column5: roaming all around town and of course going to the movies. But despite what is perpetually written about The 400 Blows
column6: movies are not overwhelmingly important to Doinel. They do not “save” him the way they really did save the young cinephile Truffaut
column7: whose friendship and mentorship with critic and intellectual André Bazin meant that he was spared dire punishment for desertion during national service. Doinel spends more of his time ranging far afield outside the cinema: in real life
column8: in the streets of Paris. But there is one in-joke: his parents take him to the movies to see Jacques Rivette’s Paris Belongs to Us (which was not actually released until 1961
column9: two years after The 400 Blows). Maybe Doinel is Truffaut’s alternative-reality version of himself: a self without the redemption of cinema
column10: his abortive Balzac homage standing for the loss of art. With Gilberte’s shrugging permission
column11: Doinel is sent to juvenile detention
column12: put in police custody with grownup criminals and ladies of the night and then the psychological “observation unit” out in the country near the coast. That brings us to the final
column13: almost apocalyptic scene on the beach
column14: where Doinel has ended up after running away from reform school. We know that he has never seen the sea. So how does he feel on seeing it now the first time? Does it look like freedom to him? Or another blank wall? When Truffaut freeze-frames on Doinel’s face at the very end
column15: it shows him looking careworn and haggard for the first time: the freeze-frame has captured the moment at which the boy has become a man. This is the 401st blow – aimed at us. • The 400 Blows is released on 7 January in cinemas.";https://www.theguardian.com/film/2022/jan/06/the-400-blows-review-francois-truffaut;5

column8: 'Australia news'];"Novak Djokovic is awaiting his Australian Open fate in a Melbourne immigration hotel as the world No 1 mounts a legal challenge against Australia’s a decision to cancel his visa Djokovic’s lawyers succeeded in a bid to stop him from being deported on Thursday with a full hearing in the federal circuit court now scheduled for Monday. The tennis champion spent eight hours detained at Melbourne airport overnight before Australian Border Force officials announced he had been denied entry into the country on Thursday morning. They cited a failure to meet Australia’s Covid vaccination exemption requirements.

column1: It is understood the reigning Australian Open champion was relying on a previous Covid infection as the basis for his exemption to compete – but that is not recognised by the federal government.
After unsuccessfully pleading his case at the airport
column2: Djokovic was transported to an immigration hotel in the inner Melbourne suburb of Carlton. As the political and diplomatic ramifications unfurled
column3: Djokovic’s lawyers were working to obtain an interim injunction to stop his deportation. In a snap hearing before judge Anthony Kelly on Thursday evening
column4: it was agreed a full hearing between the player and the home affairs minister would be heard on Monday. Djokovic cannot be deported before that hearing. The parties are due to submit evidence and submissions over the weekend. The court heard Tennis Australia had said it would need to know whether Djokovic could compete by Tuesday for scheduling purposes. The judge asked whether Djokovic could be moved to a hotel with a tennis court so he could practice. Kelly said he would try to accommodate the parties to come to a resolution but stressed the court would not be rushed. “The tail won’t be wagging the dog here
column5: ” Kelly said. “If Tennis Australia decides to do what it wants to do in running its enterprise
column6: it will. All I can do is provide every facility available to this court to assist these parties to resolve it in the best way possible.”

column1: The legal challenge could go all the way to the high court but there are just 11 days before Djokovic is due to start his campaign for a record 21st grand slam title at Melbourne Park. “People must be fully vaccinated as defined by Atagi [the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation] to gain quarantine-free entry into Australia
column2: ” the Australian prime minister
column3: Scott Morrison
column4: said on Thursday. “That means people who do not meet the definition will not be approved for quarantine-free entry. “I am advised that such an exemption was not in place and as a result he [Djokovic] is subject to the same rule as anyone else. This is nothing about any one individual
column5: it is simply a matter of following the rules
column6: and so those processes will take their course over the next few hours and that event will play out as it should.”

column1: The ABC reported on Thursday night that border force officials were also investigating another tennis player and an official granted medical exemptions by Tennis Australia. Djokovic’s predicament has become the epicentre of a political tit-for-tat between Morrison’s federal administration and Daniel Andrews’s state government in Victoria. The Serbian travelled to Australia after receiving an exemption from Tennis Australia and the Victorian government to compete. It was granted following a process that included assessment by two panels of health experts. Djokovic had expected that exemption would – along with his federal government-issued visa – allow him to play at the Australian Open. On arrival
column2: however
column3: border force officials at the airport said Djokovic was unable to justify the grounds for his exemption. Morrison said on Thursday that Tennis Australia had been advised several months ago that a recent infection did not meet the criteria for an exemption to enter Australia unvaccinated.

column1: Tennis Australia and Victorian government officials said Djokovic

column4: 'Business'

column6: 'UK news']";"It’s been 10 years since Steven Bartlett unsuccessfully applied to be a contestant on Dragons’ Den. Since then a lot has changed. The school dropout
column7: who once stole food from corner shops and foraged for loose change to keep his hunger at bay
column8: went on to start his own company from his bedroom and was a millionaire by age 23. Bartlett will be the youngest ever investor – or “Dragon” – on the BBC’s hit series when it returns on Thursday. But pay attention and you’ll see him everywhere – whether it’s debates on daytime television
column9: motivational quotes on Instagram or on his podcast
column10: the Diary of a CEO
column11: which has consistently topped business charts for the past year. Joining the show is a privilege and a responsibility for Bartlett
column12: who hopes young people from less privileged backgrounds like his
column13: especially minorities who don’t always see themselves reflected in certain programmes or industries
column14: will feel enabled. “Dragons’ Den was the only window I had into business from 12 years old
column15: ” he said. “It’s like the first time you go to New York City after seeing it in films for your entire life. But I understand what I bring. A new perspective from a new era of business. “I feel a responsibility because there’s never been a black
column16: young Dragon on the show. The most powerful role models
column17: of course
column18: are those that are most relatable.” Bartlett was born in Botswana to a Nigerian mum and a British dad. His mum left school aged seven and can’t read or write
column19: his dad was a structural engineer and “very
column20: very smart”. The family (he is the youngest of four siblings) moved to Plymouth
column21: Devon
column22: where they “struggled financially in a nice
column23: white
column24: middle-class area”
column25: something he expands upon in his bestselling book
column26: Happy Sexy Millionaire. That feeling of otherness
column27: of not having “the nice things other people had”
column28: drove him. “I learned that if I was to have anything
column29: it wasn’t going to be left for me under the Christmas tree
column30: it was going to be a direct consequence of my own actions.” He was an insecure boy who struggled in school
column31: barely scraping through GCSEs and A-levels. His attention
column32: he says
column33: was focused elsewhere – from organising school trips to brokering deals with vending machine companies and taking a cut. It was clear from a young age that his interest and talents lay in the world of entrepreneurship. So it wasn’t entirely surprising that he dropped out of his course in business management at Manchester Metropolitan University after just one lecture. He says he looked around the room
column34: full of hungover students and a lecturer handing out felt-tip pens
column35: and “realised this wasn’t going to take me to where I needed to go”. He has vociferous opinions of the education system
column36: which he calls a “propped up scam” held together by a number of stakeholders
column37: none of which are incentivised to help young people nurture their talents and work towards what they’re good at.

column1: “You’ve got the employment world that requires a 2:2 for jobs. You’ve got the university who are getting paid to drag you in and keep costs low
column2: and then you’ve got the schools
column3: which are ranked by grades. It’s an archaic system that hasn’t moved with the modern world fast enough. Information is almost redundant by the time universities publish their textbooks. There’s probably not that many that have been written about blockchain
column4: but we know it’s a pivotal part of our future.” Bartlett’s first proper registered business at 18 years old – a marketing agency called Social Chain – now valued at $600m. He talks much of the importance of following your internal voice and knowing your purpose
column5: a thread that runs through the work of contemporary self-help gurus
column6: including his most recent podcast guest
column7: Jordan Peterson. “I’m really bad at doing things I don’t want to do. If you’re fortunate and take the right steps
column8: that culminates in a life where you’re doing a lot of things you do want to do.” This explains why he left Social Chain in 2020 to pursue new projects
column9: including Thirdweb
column10: a company that creates blockchain-based applications
column11: and Flight Story
column12: a marketing platform. In the latter part of last year
column13: he was also listed as number six in the UK’s black power list alongside Marcus Rashford and Michaela Coel. “Quitting has been demonised in our society. It’s associated with being weak. But it’s the incredibly important thing you have to do before you start the next thing.” His key advice for creating a successful business is being unromantic about your hypothesis. After all
column14: Jeff Bezos originally looked to create an online bookstore. This
column15: and other lessons about business life
column16: were imparted through interviewing other entrepreneurs and business leaders. Though he imagined they’d be incredibly unique
column17: he says he discovered that most of his guests are actually very similar. “They’re all affected by the same anxieties. One thing that happened to them on the playground might steer the course of their life. Sometimes your curses become your blessings and vice versa. Most of the time
column18: having a really shitty childhood is the reason why my guests end up being really remarkable people in their later life.”";https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/jan/06/how-steven-bartlett-went-from-dropout-to-youngest-ever-dragons-den-investor;2

column1: 61;61;5301;5301;The Expectation Effect by David Robson review – mind-changing science;2022-01-06T07:30:02Z;['Oliver Burkeman'];"['Science and nature books'
column2: 'Society books'
column3: 'Culture'
column4: 'Books'
column5: 'Health'
column6: 'Society'
column7: ""Alzheimer's""]";"When dozens of apparently healthy young men who had emigrated from Laos started dying in their sleep in the late 1970s
column8: US medical authorities couldn’t fathom what was going on. They termed the phenomenon “sudden unexpected nocturnal death syndrome”
column9: but that was just a label for their bafflement. Today
column10: we think we know the cause: the men experienced sleep paralysis
column11: which is common and harmless in itself; but they understood it as a visitation from the dab tsog
column12: a malevolent spirit who sits on victims’ chests at night. Living far from the shamans and family members who might have helped them ward off the evil
column13: the men panicked
column14: probably exacerbating a form of heart arrhythmia more prevalent in people from south-east Asia
column15: and triggering cardiac arrest. The science writer David Robson’s mission in The Expectation Effect is to convince us we shouldn’t look on those men with condescending pity: our own expectations and beliefs
column16: however irrational
column17: influence our health
column18: happiness and our survival no less decisively. Take
column19: for example
column20: ageing: if you think it’s a matter of inevitable cognitive decline and becoming useless to society
column21: you’re more likely to experience hearing loss
column22: frailty
column23: even Alzheimer’s. Such attitudes predict higher levels of stress and inflammation
column24: which in turn contribute to a range of disorders. (By contrast
column25: in places such as Sardinia
column26: where centenarians are numerous and thriving
column27: their role in intergenerational households is thought to be a factor: it encourages them to expect to stay active.) If you convince yourself that you’re prone to insomnia
column28: you’ll suffer the symptoms of insomnia – even if the truth is that you sleep fairly well. And it’s common for participants in medical trials to experience not only the placebo effect but the “nocebo effect” – drug side-effects such as nausea
column29: dizziness or rashes
column30: even though they’re only taking sugar pills. To an extent
column31: the “expectation effect” is the stuff of self-help cliche: “Whether you think you can or think you can’t
column32: you’re right
column33: ” Henry Ford is supposed to have said
column34: rather irritatingly. But one of Robson’s many strengths as a chronicler of science is to take what might seem familiar and show – to his own evident excitement
column35: as well – just how much deeper the rabbit hole goes. You knew about the placebo effect. But did you know it often works
column36: a little mind-bendingly
column37: even when the patient knows they’re taking a placebo? (This is promising
column38: in terms of medical ethics
column39: because it suggests that people need not be deceived in order to benefit.) And if you knew that
column40: did you know there’s evidence that the placebo effect is growing more powerful over time
column41: as more people learn of the placebo effect
column42: and thus expect to experience it? That’s right: the placebo effect has a placebo effect. Expect your expectations to change your life
column43: and they will. While the book abounds in compelling anecdotes – the cyclist who thought he was injecting performance-enhancing drugs
column44: and performed better accordingly; the Portuguese TV show that caused an outbreak of breathing difficulties in its viewers – Robson’s central point is that the expectation effect isn’t an amusing psychological quirk
column45: but a fundamental aspect of our interactions with reality.

column1: Our brains are “prediction machines”
column2: steering us through life by generating expectations
column3: and only revising them when unavoidable. Those expectations then play a vital role in shaping what we experience. This explains why far more people
column4: especially children
column5: see a rabbit in the famous “duck-rabbit” optical illusion around Easter than at other times of year. But it also helps explain why pupils from low-income backgrounds tend to live down to their teachers’ academic expectations – and why some of those teachers tend to react with discomfort
column6: not pride
column7: should they defy their assumptions instead. “Like a dramatist carefully crafting a narrative arc
column8: ” Robson writes
column9: “we don’t like the objects of our expectations to go off script.” Robson is aware of the objection that this might all sound like a paean to positive thinking. He rejects that claim: the expectation effect concerns specific outcomes
column10: not a general effort to feel good. Moreover
column11: the cult of positivity reinforces the idea that merely experiencing negative emotions constitutes a crisis
column12: or a personal failing
column13: leading only to more negative emotions: “By demonising unpleasant but inevitable feelings
column14: we have been creating a potent nocebo out of modern life.” In any case
column15: wisely harnessing the power of expectation isn’t a matter of eliminating bad things so much as reframing them – for example
column16: by understanding the feelings of exertion during exercise as evidence that you’re making yourself fitter. (Likewise
column17: I think “writer’s block” is often best thought of simply as what it feels like to push yourself creatively.) That way
column18: apart from anything else
column19: you’re far less likely to quit when the going gets tough. Startling research even shows that when people are encouraged to think of the physical movements in which they already engage for their jobs as exercise
column20: they reap greater health benefits. The result of marinating for a while in this outlook is surprisingly transformative. We’re accustomed to thinking of the external world as an implacable thing that either lives up to
column21: or more commonly frustrates
column22: our expectations. That’s why I’ve always been fond of “defensive pessimism”: keep your expectations low
column23: and you can only ever be pleasantly surprised. But this approach defines our expectations as wholly impotent: vain hopes that reality might or might not deign to fulfil. The Expectation Effect shows that
column24: on the contrary
column25: our expectations participate actively in that reality. Clearly
column26: believing that you could be a champion salsa dancer in your 80s – to pick one of Robson’s examples – doesn’t guarantee that you will be. But it might prove easily as important as the genes you were born with. We defensive pessimists could do with remembering that sometimes things do actually turn out really well – especially if you expect them to. • The Expectation Effect: How Your Mindset Can Transform Your Life by David Robson is published by Canongate (£18.99). To support the Guardian and the Observer buy a copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply.";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/06/the-expectation-effect-by-david-robson-review-mind-changing-science;6

column1: 62;62;5302;5302;‘I was there’: Democrat recalls horror and fury on day of Capitol attack;2022-01-06T07:00:06Z;['David Smith'];['US Capitol attack'
column2: 'US news'
column3: 'US politics'];"It was a visceral cry at the moment of maximum peril for American democracy. A furious mob had overrun police and was nearly at the door of the House of Representatives. Inside the chamber
column4: Republican Paul Gosar was launching a spurious challenge to Joe Biden’s election victory in Arizona. Then
column5: at the back of the gallery on the second floor
column6: Democrat Dean Phillips rose to his feet and screamed at the top of his lungs at Gosar: “This is because of you!” The outburst was out of character for a “Minnesota nice” congressman with a reputation for moderation and working across the aisle. But a year later
column7: Phillips remains convinced it was an urgent and necessary response to the deadly insurrection inspired by then president Donald Trump. “It’s not my style to break decorum and to scream
column8: ” he told the Guardian
column9: “but I have to say at that moment I felt the way that tens of millions of Americans did
column10: which is there were people responsible for what was about to transpire and there are moments where you do what you got to do
column11: and I had to do it. I don’t regret it one bit because it’s true.” Phillips
column13: comes from a business background. He led a family-owned distillery – producing vodka
column14: gin
column15: rum and other liquors – and ice cream company. He was elected to Congress in 2018
column16: representing Minnesota’s third congressional district
column17: and is vice chair of the bipartisan Problem Solvers Caucus. “I never imagined I’d be doing this
column18: ” he admits. “I woke up the morning after the 2016 election
column19: saw the reaction of my daughters
column20: who were 18 and 16 at that time – their fear
column21: their tears – and I promised them right then and there I would do something
column22: and here I am.”

column1: On 6 January 2021
column2: he had been advised that there could be trouble so told his staff to stay home. He watched his office TV “horrified” as Trump gave a speech urging supporters to “fight like hell” to overturn his defeat. He then walked to the House to begin certifying Biden’s election victory. But soon he received text messages from anxious family members showing video of protests forming outside. “I asked my colleague
column3: Tom Malinowski from New Jersey
column4: to walk from the House chamber with me to look out the windows and a Capitol police officer literally screamed at us to get away from the windows and get back into the House chamber. We asked if everything was OK
column5: and – I’ll never forget it – she said
column6: ‘You’re in the United States Capitol. It’s the most secure building in the country’.” They returned to the House chamber just as Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Majority Leader Steny Hoyer were being evacuated. Gosar was at the microphone
column7: leading efforts to subvert his state’s electoral college vote
column8: when the sergeant-at-arms urged members to take cover behind seats and prepare their smoke hoods – prompting Phillips to feel “fury” and let rip at the Trump loyalist. While members on the House floor were able to escape
column9: there was no way out for 20 sitting up in the gallery due to coronavirus safety measures. “I screamed at my colleagues at that moment to follow me to the Republican side of the chamber because I thought it would be safer
column10: ” Phillips says. “I thought the insurrectionists were coming for us. “First
column11: it was almost impossible to get through these railings; you either had to go under or over. But more than that
column12: I recognized at that very moment that a lot of my colleagues couldn’t blend in. I’m talking about those of color. It really left an indelible mark on me. “That whole day changed me
column13: of course
column14: as it would anybody
column15: to recognise that privilege and the fragility of democracy and also a significant increase in my empathy for those who have endured trauma in their lives
column16: which is life-changing.”

column1: Rioters reached the doors of the House chamber but found their way blocked by an improvised barricade and Capitol police with guns drawn. After an ordeal lasting about 25 minutes
column2: Phillips recalls
column3: members in the gallery were led out by a Capitol police officer and through a maze of tunnels. “We ran into the Rayburn lunch room and it was a bizarre moment because there were people just having lunch at the tables. The sun was shining in from the big plate glass windows and here we are
column4: an officer with a rifle running with us into the lunch room and people just stunned
column5: looking at us like
column6: what the heck’s going on? Of course
column7: the TVs moments later would sure change that.” The group was then moved on to a committee room where they were finally safe. But their shared ordeal would stay with them. They now call themselves “the gallery group” and still meet regularly
column8: sometimes with facilitators or therapists. “It’s been the most wonderful support group imaginable because we endured it together
column9: ” Phillips says. On the night of 6 January
column10: with the Capitol finally secured
column11: they and other members returned to the House and Senate to finish the job and ratify Biden as president. For a fleeting moment
column12: it seemed that Democrats and Republicans were united in completing the work of democracy and jettisoning the authoritarianism of Trump. But it was not to last. In the year since the insurrection
column13: some Republicans have embraced Trump’s “big lie” and his portrayal of the mob as patriots driven by a noble cause; others have simply remained tight-lipped and failed to denounce it. Phillips
column14: who sees them up close during sessions of Congress
column15: believes they are motivated by self-preservation of both position and personal safety.

column1: “That’s perhaps the saddest part of all this. Many of my colleagues – especially those who voted to impeach
column2: those who voted to impanel the January 6 commission
column3: those who voted to certify the election – have received horrifying threats to their safety and the safety of their loved ones. It’s an unenviable position but it’s also our responsibility and duty. I understand self-preservation but I do wish principle would take precedence
column4: ” he says. It has been difficult for Phillips to witness 6 January denialism as Republicans and rightwing media attempt to rewrite the history of what happened that day
column5: variously characterising it as a “normal tourist visit” or an FBI “false flag” operation designed to entrap Trump supporters. The former president himself insisted that his followers were “hugging and kissing” police. The Democrat says: “This is one of those rare occasions where I was there. I was inside. I heard the gunshot. I saw the remnants of the insurrection in the rotunda and went with [Congressman] Andy Kim at midnight that night to help clean it up when I saw him on his hands and knees alone.” “I saw the body armour. I saw the clubs. I saw faeces. I saw the speaker’s office ransacked. I saw with my own eyes people on the ground under arrest. I saw the mob breaking in. I met with the officers who were subject to it since. I was there to bear witness to it and to hear people say it didn’t happen or it wasn’t a big deal or it’s time to move on
column6: shame on them.” Republicans’ denial of reality
column7: and continued addiction to Trump
column8: has raised fears that 6 January was the beginning
column9: not the end
column10: of American democracy’s near death experience. The party is imposing sweeping voter restrictions across the country and seeking to put “big lie” believers in charge of future elections. Trump could mount another bid for the White House in 2024 with many checks and balances no longer in place. Phillips comments: “We are at the precipice of a very slippery slope and it’s a long way up the mountain when you’re building a democracy but it’s a fast ride down when it slips away. We collectively have to make a choice and a decision here
column11: starting with the simple fact that this is not something that one side or the other can win.”

column1: “If one side upends democracy and destroys its institutions and disrespects the rule of law
column2: chaos will result
column3: violence will result and everything that those propagating this claim is important to them – a strong
column4: stable
column5: secure
column6: prosperous country – will have been lost. That’s why I try to be a voice of reason and a bridge builder
column7: not a destroyer.” A self-described eternal optimist
column8: Phillips believes there is still a cohort in the Republican party that can find a way back to the mainstream. He describes Liz Cheney and Adam Kinzinger
column9: Trump critics serving on the House select committee investigating 6 January
column10: as “heroic”. “I know there are more that share that sentiment that simply are not as public. I have confidence that we will see some type of restoration of principle
column11: assuming American voters find that important.” The congressman’s efforts to lower the political temperature include a series of “common ground” get-togethers in his home district that encourage mutual understanding between constituents across the ideological spectrum. He says: “They’ve inspired me and made me more optimistic because I’ve discovered when
column12: with some intention
column13: you bring people together with disparate political perspectives and break bread
column14: get to know each other and share life stories
column15: common ground is readily available and easily discoverable.” But in this age of polarisation and negative partisanship
column16: there must be some awkward conversations? “We had an experience just a few weeks ago in which someone pulled up in what would be considered a vehicle that a Donald Trump supporter might be driving and someone who was on the far left of that person – in a very uncomfortable moment but it turned out to be a very productive one – acknowledged what she felt when she saw that vehicle pull into the parking lot and what she expected of the person who drove it. “It took courage to share that. It took courage for the driver of the vehicle to listen to it. At the end of the evening
column17: for both of them to recognise their shared humanity and shared interest in a safe and secure country
column18: was a moment of great reassurance but one that can only occur if people stop stereotyping and actually start breaking bread together.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/06/capitol-attack-democrat-dean-phillips-recalls-horror-fury;1

column2: 'Money'
column3: 'Death and dying'
column4: 'Society'];One of my brothers has a serious addiction and mental health issues. My elderly parents are concerned about what might happen to their estate after their deaths. My brother is not likely to be safe with any amount of money
column5: but he will need ongoing care
column6: which they currently fund. They do not want to leave behind a divisive decision
column7: or any more of their life’s work to be handed over to drug dealers. What do you advise they do? LW
column8: London Start by consulting a specialist solicitor or financial adviser. I asked the government-sponsored Money and Pensions Service (MaPS) for options. Andrew Johnson
column9: a senior money expert
column10: suggests a will trust. This is created within the will which enables nominated trustees to hold property for the benefit of one or more individuals. Trustees would have legal responsibility to make decisions in your brother’s interests. The MaPS website provides guides on setting up a trust and how to choose a financial adviser. Email your.problems@observer.co.uk. Include an address and phone number. column1: 64;64;5304;5304;Walk like a Minoan: hiking and foraging in eastern Crete;2022-01-06T07:00:05Z;['N/A'];['Crete holidays'
column2: 'Greece holidays'
column3: 'Europe holidays'
column4: 'Walking holidays'
column5: 'Walking'
column6: 'Life and style'
column7: 'Adventure travel'
column8: 'Travel'];"Like swirling paper scraps from a bonfire
column9: the charcoal-winged vultures circled high overhead. When I imitated a lamb’s bleat they circled closer
column10: stretching their massive wings and craning long wrinkled necks. The bone-white rocks of the Gorge of the Dead was a fitting backdrop for these pterodactyl-like birds – I could have been in a scene from Jurassic Park. Named not for the hikers that have perished here (happily none has) but because it’s littered with caves where the Minoans once buried their dead
column11: this seven-mile canyon – also called the Zakros gorge – is the end of the Cretan section of the ultra-long-distance E4 hiking route. The whole trail runs for more than 10
column12: 000km from Tarifa in Spain to Cyprus
column13: but this island’s stretch starts 320km away in the north-western town of Kastelli-Kissamos and ends at the remote resort of Kato Zakros.

column1: My plan was to hike a bite-size 35km stretch of the E4 in reverse
column2: from Kato Zakros
column3: near the start of the gorge
column4: to Vóri
column5: a hamlet further south where I would catch a bus back to the port town of Sitia. Far from the doom and gloom of TV and social media and the stress of living in a Covid-stricken world
column6: I would heal my soul – for a weekend
column7: at least – by hiking through untamed landscapes and foragiing for food in one of the wildest corners of Crete. Packing my old rucksack with fruit
column8: drinking water and a bag of crumbly feta cheese
column9: I set out in early December. Just over 300 nautical miles from Libya and on roughly the same latitude as Cyprus
column10: eastern Crete is almost as warm as Andalucía in winter. In summer and autumn
column11: soaring temperatures can make hiking sticky and unpleasant
column12: but winter means temperatures around 20C
column13: and the sun shining gently in a sky the colour of stone-washed denim.

column1: Leaving the vultures behind
column2: I was soon deep inside the gorge
column3: hiking on a slippery
column4: shale-strewn path between skyscraper-high cliffs. Apart from the drone of bees in the late-flowering thyme and the fierce whistle of a golden eagle somewhere on high
column5: the silence was absolute. The caves where the Minoans once worshipped the souls of their ancestors – and where in later years defiant locals hid from the successive wrath of Venetians
column6: Turks and Nazis – stared down at me like the blankly watchful faces of ancient Greek masks.

column1: After two hours of hard hiking I collapsed on a rock near the top of the gorge and took in the view. Far below
column2: the once-magnificent Minoan Palace of Zakros
column3: with its remains of marble-pillared halls
column4: shrines and ceremonial pools
column5: shimmered like a mirage above the horseshoe-shaped bay of Zakros. It was from the bay that the Minoans once sailed – boats weighed down with jars of wine
column6: olives and figs – to trade for gold and ivory with Egypt and Syria. It was easy to picture the square-sailed ships setting out from this lonely spot; with little or no tourism and only a handful of inhabitants
column7: Kato Zakros still has a sense of antiquity. Scrambling up one final
column8: staircase-steep section of gorge I emerged near pano (upper) Zakros: a handful of tavernas and a cluster of square white houses in the Unesco-classified Sitia Geopark. At Hotel Zakros I lunched on fried snails (xochloi bourbouristi) in vinegar
column9: rice-stuffed courgette flowers (kolokithanthi gemisti) and other delicious meze.

column1: Leaving Zakros I followed a winding road – past an old mill and the springs that once fed it – and into a sheltered valley where I found an abandoned citrus grove and filled my pockets with tiny sweet tangerines and waxy-skinned lemons. A buffeting wind that tugged at my pack pushed me up along a track lined with purple heather and out on to the plateau of Mavros Kambos – the Black Plain – named for a bloody skirmish with Ottoman troops in the 16th century. Black was a misnomer
column2: however: the fertile plain was viridescent with horta
column3: the wild greens that have been a staple of the Cretan diet since Minoan times. I gathered some of my favourites – galatsida (common brighteyes)
column4: radiki (dandelion) and agriozohos (golden fleece) – for dinner. By 6pm when I reached Skalia (abandoned in the 18th century after its inhabitants were massacred by the Turks) the sun was low on the horizon
column5: casting an eerie scarlet light on the old stone houses with their caved-in walls and roofs. Finding a sheltered spot I boiled the horta on my camping stove
column6: drained off the water
column7: added lemon juice and olive oil and ate it with a chunk of feta
column8: enjoying the contrast of salty pungent sheep’s cheese with the tender greens. It was dark by now – so dark that
column9: apart from the distant glow of a village far below
column10: there was no light at all and stars filled the entire sky. It was breathtaking – like being inside a geodesic dome pasted with millions of glittering snowflakes.

column1: Filled with renewed energy after my vitamin-packed foraged dinner I set off along a flinty path fringed with purple heather to Ziros
column2: where I spent the night at Arismari apartments
column3: a sparkling modern complex in the centre of the village. With its small square houses – and backdrop of jagged blue mountain
column4: this tiny village 30km from the nearest town seemed incredibly isolated when I woke to bright sunshine the following day. Nikos
column5: who owns the cafe where I breakfasted on toast and local thyme honey
column6: told me that recent DNA tests by a Florida university proved that most of the inhabitants in this Lasithi region are descended directly from the Minoans.

column1: A dirt track – via vineyards that produce the crisp and spicy Assyrtiko wines – led through the tiny mountain village of Armeni and then down along a winding road to Vóri. A fug of wine and woodsmoke told me I was approaching a casani
column2: the copper still where – in winter – Cretans distil grape skins left from winemaking to produce raki. Manolis
column3: the shepherd who owned the still
column4: handed me a plastic beaker of what looked like spring water. I took a sip and nearly choked on the burning 70% proof alcohol. Manolis told me he’d lived in Lasithi all his life. I mentioned what I’d heard about the DNA tests. “Eh!” he shrugged and took a deep slug from his beaker. “The Minoans loved dancing
column5: women and raki – of course they were our ancestors!”

column6: 'Mental health'];"The evidence for whether new year resolutions are effective is mixed. Make them Smart – specific
column7: measurable
column8: achievable
column9: realistic and timely – and they can be a spur to effective action. But vaguer resolutions such as “get fit”
column10: “lose weight” or “stop wasting so much time” often conceal a deeper self-criticism that undermines our intentions. The underlying approach is that we must simply try harder – sometimes at everything at once – and that sets us up to fail. We binge on diets
column11: then binge on food and
column12: finally
column13: binge on guilt. I’ve found that apps that help turn my unfocused intentions into a Smart plan really work. A Couch to 5K programme got me running
column14: and I liked having a clear objective. It feels good to be fitter. You might see a bald bloke running with a waddling gait
column15: but I see goals met and targets smashed – and a 10K in my sights. But there’s a downside to resolutions
column16: even when they’re effective and we achieve them. The focus on results has got me checking my Google Fit stats a little too often
column17: introducing an element of data-driven compulsiveness to the simple activity of exercising my body. It reminds me of the impulse I sometimes feel to check my Facebook likes and Twitter followers. I sense it fits with a wider cultural current: the strain coming from the constant effort to keep up
column18: be productive and get ahead is a source of stress
column19: not its cure. Recognising this
column20: part of me wants to simply ditch my phone and forget the targets. I’m a Buddhist
column21: I’ve taught mindfulness for 15 years
column22: and that part of me wants to be unproductive and turn
column23: as we say on our courses
column24: from doing mode to being mode. My favourite exponent of such non-utilitarian living is John Keats
column25: who advocated “delicious diligent indolence” in a letter written to a friend in 1818: “Let us not
column26: ” he writes
column27: “go hurrying about and collecting honey
column28: bee-like buzzing here and there for a knowledge that is to be arrived at
column29: but let us open our leaves like a flower
column30: and be passive and receptive.” Keats’s word “diligent” signals that
column31: by indolence
column32: he doesn’t mean inertia. Maintaining an alert receptivity requires what Buddhism calls practice – a conscious effort to develop it over time
column33: which should be undertaken with “balanced effort” – a middle way between wilful or compulsive striving and self-indulgence. The Buddha’s image of this was of a musical instrument whose strings must be tuned neither too loosely nor too tightly.

column1: Drawing on my experience as a mindfulness teacher
column2: I have some suggestions for middle-way practices that foster the alert receptivity Keats recommends. The first is learning to settle the mind. Meditation is by no means the only way to do this
column3: but it’s popular because it offers simple methods for shifting attention from the flow of thoughts to something calming
column4: like the breath. If you’ve tried it for yourself you’ll know that the thoughts don’t just stop
column5: and you sometimes feel uncomfortable. But settling the mind and stepping into a different kind of awareness is actually a fairly straightforward process. That’s a start
column6: but the value of doing this is the “mental space” that opens up by freeing yourself from mental strain and clutter. So it’s important that we don’t just fill the space up again with more input. Buddhism has always spoken of the need to “guard the gates of the senses” – to manage what we expose our minds to
column7: if we want them to develop. And that takes on fresh importance when
column8: with a few clicks
column9: we can access an effectively unlimited supply of movies
column10: music tracks
column11: websites and just about any other diversion we can imagine. There’s not much point in achieving a goal like getting fit or losing weight if it becomes a new source of stress. What I’m really seeking as I run is a sense of flourishing and vitality
column12: and that can only happen by being fully present and aware in each moment
column13: not just when I reach 10K. A more mindful way of living values simplicity over consumption and allows space between activities. It focuses on doing one thing at a time and doing it fully. We need time to reflect and to be curious. These things can be practices
column14: and perhaps you can frame them as Smart resolutions. But in the end we don’t just need to be smart. We need to be wise. Vishvapani Blomfield is the Buddhist contributor to BBC Radio 4’s Thought for the Day and leads meditation on the RoundGlass app";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/06/new-year-resolutions-cause-stress-mindful;7

column8: local officials who often knew the families

The enumerator added – even more mysteriously – “Never worked. Enjoys Father’s Egyptian Pension”. The British love of animals – or perhaps the national fondness for mild subversion – is evident in the many families who listed family pets among their household members
column10: including “Bobby the Dog” and “Tarzan the Cat”. “The census enumerators rarely had a sense of humour about these entries and struck them out
column11: ” said David Olusoga

column13: Lancashire

column16: head of content publishing operations at Findmypast
column17: said they had expected humour and gentle sabotage of a document that was
column18: after all

column20: ” she said. “People were angry that they had been promised a postwar ‘land fit for heroes’ by the government but were
column21: instead
column22: experiencing mass unemployment and poor housing.” Many people used the form to protest: “David Lloyd George
column23: build houses”
column24: instructed Henry Burrough in Durham in a large note added to the form. “Lloyd George is hereby requested to bring forth that ‘Land fit for heroes’
column25: ” he added. “Nation’s duty to provide houses.” James Eldon Haynes in Yorkshire agreed. “Out of Work in the Land Fit for Heroes
column26: ” he wrote. Robert Stevens in Liverpool

column28: wrote: “Please help me. Times are hard.” “It’s fascinating to see how many people subverted the Census and used it as a means of protesting to those in power
column29: ” said Olusoga. “This use of the Census reminds me of the way people now use Twitter.” The way the Census had to be filled out unpeeled other intimate details: it had to be completed on 19 June before midnight. On that night
column30: the creator of Sherlock Holmes

column33: ” said McKee. “A seance seems the logical explanation of that gathering.” Other hidden treasures were discovered during the three years of intensive conservation and digitisation devoted to the Census. A dead menagerie of insects were found within its pages: 532 historic insects from a century ago. “I don’t know what’s been done with them
column34: ” said Olusoga. “I like to think a specialist conservationist has whisked them away to start a dead zoo.”";https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/jan/06/1921-census-of-england-and-wales-reveals-nation-reeling-from-war;3

column1: 78;78;5319;5319;Republicans are laying a path back to power – and paving it with lies | Rebecca Solnit;2022-01-06T06:00:01Z;['Rebecca Solnit'];['US Capitol attack'

column6: 'Donald Trump'];"When the insurrectionists of 6 January rampaged through the Capitol
column7: congressman Andrew Clyde of Georgia helped barricade a door
column8: and he fled when the rest of Congress did. A photograph shows him looking panicky
column9: mouth wide open and arm gesticulating wildly
column10: behind what appears to be a security team member with a gun drawn
column11: defending him. But a few months later he declared: “Watching the TV footage of those who entered the Capitol and walked through Statuary Hall showed people in an orderly fashion staying between the stanchions and ropes
column12: taking videos
column13: pictures. You know
column14: if you didn’t know the TV footage was a video from 6 January
column15: you would actually think it was a normal tourist visit.” Clyde’s account of 6 January might be a little more preposterous than those of his fellow Republican legislators. But they all joined him in pretending nothing much had happened and objecting to the investigation of the day’s events. After all
column16: they were partly responsible
column17: most of them. It was elected Republicans who supported and spread the earlier lies that Donald Trump had won the election
column18: the lies that fed the insurrection; and then they lied some more about their own words and actions before
column19: during and after. In the immediate aftermath
column20: the then Senate majority leader
column21: Mitch McConnell
column22: was angry and shaken
column23: declaring: “The mob was fed lies. They were provoked by the president.” Then he too began the project of walking it all back. What has ensued is a cover-up in plain sight. When Trump took office in 2016
column24: Republicans faced a crisis: their party had won
column25: but only by ushering to a minority victory one of history’s most extravagantly dishonest men. They had to stand with him or against him
column26: and most chose to stand with him. Others chose to fade away by resigning or going home when their terms were up. Almost none of them stood up against him. The famously vindictive Trump punished any signs of disloyalty
column27: so they were loyal. And to be loyal meant joining him in corruption and lies. “If we nominate Trump
column28: we will get destroyed ... and we will deserve it
column29: ” Lindsey Graham tweeted in the spring of 2016
column30: before becoming one of Trump’s most grovelling sycophants. In a way
column31: the sycophants got stronger: if truth restrains us and links us together
column32: they unchained themselves. We make contracts with each other with words; we share information
column33: make agreements and commitments
column34: hold each other accountable and show who we are. Lies are broken contracts
column35: in which words misrepresent what the speaker knows; they aim to delude
column36: exploit and divide. The liar may get stronger
column37: but the social fabric gets weaker. That strength is precarious
column38: so lies have be piled atop lies to keep accountability at a distance. Of course
column39: politicians of all stripes are notoriously shifty
column40: and the Republican party had no great reputation for honesty previously. Many of their campaigns long before Trump could politely be called misleading. But after 2016
column41: they clustered around the gaslighter-in-chief like bugs around a streetlight. I often think of what Trump did as disinhibition: the pallid
column42: bashful untruths of yore were replaced by baldfaced outrages. They lost any compunction about openly contradicting themselves
column43: and did so often
column44: never more than with the insurrection of 6 January. As the mob was smashing its way into the building
column45: congressman Jim Jordan had been on the house floor accusing election officials in six states of corruption. A week later he declared: “I’ve never said that this election was stolen.” But
column46: as CNN noted: “Jordan claimed in October that Democrats were working to steal the election and spoke at a Stop the Steal rally in Pennsylvania two days after the election. In December
column47: he said he didn’t know how he could be convinced that ‘Trump didn’t actually win’ the election.” During the hours when the mob rampaged through the US Capitol building
column48: House minority leader Kevin McCarthy called up Trump
column49: reportedly furious. “The president bears responsibility for the attack
column50: ” he said shortly thereafter. Then he devoted himself to winning back Trump’s favour and playing down what had happened. “Pressed on whether he regretted working to overturn President Biden’s 2020 victory
column51: Mr McCarthy took the position that he did no such thing
column52: ” the New York Times reported in April. Then he worked hard to sabotage the investigation into what had happened
column53: by trying to put two congressmen most loyal to the big lie
column54: Jim Banks and the ever-disruptive champion shouter Jim Jordan
column55: on the committee. The house majority leader
column56: Nancy Pelosi
column57: blocked their appointment. Banks was later caught sending out letters
column58: seeking information from government agencies
column59: claiming he was the ranking Republican on the 6 January committee
column60: of which he was never in fact a member. By September
column61: McCarthy was full team cover-up: the Guardian’s Hugo Lowell noted that McCarthy “threatened to retaliate against any telecommunications company that complied with the records requests” of the congressional committee investigating the 6 January insurrection. That’s not technically lying
column62: but it’s certainly an attempt to prevent the truth from being known. There’s a lot to cover up
column63: especially if you don’t want the committee to find out the extent to which Congress itself was involved in the attack on Congress. The politicians who fled in fear thereafter threw themselves into denying the threat and protecting its chief instigator. No one did so more slavishly than the then vice-president
column65: who was pressured before and during 6 January to violate the law and exercise a power he did not possess to change the election outcome. “If Vice President @Mike_Pence comes through for us
column67: ” Trump had tweeted early that day; and then
column68: “Mike Pence didn’t have the courage to do what should have been done to protect our Country and our Constitution”. At Trump’s instigation
column69: the mob was chanting: “Hang Mike Pence!” Pence trivialised the event when he told the Christian Broadcasting Network: “I’m not going to allow the Democrats to use one tragic day in January to distract attention from their failed agenda and the failed policies of the Biden administration.” Capitol police officer Aquilino Gonnell
column70: who was seriously injured defending the politicians
column71: told NPR: “That one day in January almost cost my life. And we did everything possible to prevent him [Pence] from being hanged and killed in front of his daughter and his wife. And now he’s telling us that that one day in January doesn’t mean anything. It’s pathetic. It’s a disgrace.” One of the first lies to explode out of the insurrection was that somehow the attack on the Capitol was the work of Antifa. The very idea of Antifa
column74: a transformation of scattered individuals and impromptu groups of antifascists into a cohesive sinister gang that could be blamed for pretty much anything
column75: anywhere. The New York Times described how on 6 January the right was claiming that the insurrection had been led by Antifa
column76: not Trump supporters. By the end of the day
column78: the claim was all over Twitter
column79: and: “Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida had stood on the ransacked House floor and claimed that many rioters ‘were members of the violent terrorist group antifa’.” The claim
column81: “has hardened into gospel among hard-line Trump supporters
column82: by voters and sanctified by elected officials in the party” That is
column83: they took the position that the riot
column84: which at the time Republican legislators begged the president to stop
column85: was instead a riot by an essentially imaginary leftwing organisation with no conceivable motive to prevent the confirmation of Biden’s victory. Now the investigation is closing in on the role that many in Congress played in the attack on Congress. Having fled their own mobs
column86: they are now trying to flee the truth
column87: and relying on the fact that a significant portion of the country prefers the lies. The Republicans who helped the failed coup along and then dismissed its import are preparing to do it better next time. The Democratic senator Brian Schatz tweeted on Tuesday: “They are organizing the next one
column89: but as a central organizing principle for the next election.” The Senate majority leader
column93: the Republican party with his big lie and with his desire to stop democracy. We have no choice but to move forward
column94: ” by which he meant overturn the filibuster to pass voting rights legislation. 6 January was one confrontation; there’s another one coming. The lies may implode at some point
column95: but the liars have to be defeated. Rebecca Solnit is a Guardian US columnist. Her most recent books are Recollections of My Nonexistence and Orwell’s Roses";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/06/republicans-power-and-lies-mob-6-january-congress-truth;1
