column11: 'Fish Tank'];"Andrea Arnold’s films are known for their spare dialogue
column12: and in her first documentary it is more pared-backed than ever: Cow consists of 94 minutes of moos
column13: with the odd off-camera interjection from farmhands. It is hardly a thriller (though the ending is pure Tarantino). But it is one of the most beautifully crafted and tender portraits of a life you are likely to see. Arnold
column14: who started her professional life as a rollerskating TV presenter on the children’s Saturday show No 73
column15: began thinking about documenting an animal’s life nine years ago. Eventually she settled on a cow. “I thought a cow would be interesting because they work so hard
column16: getting pregnant and giving milk their entire lives. It’s a huge job they do.” She chose Luma because she was told she had a big personality and was feisty. Arnold and her team spent four years
column17: on and off
column18: filming her. Why did she make Cow? “I wanted to show a non-human consciousness. I was intrigued as to whether we would be able to see her consciousness if we followed her long enough.” Her friends have told her Cow is the most personal film she has made. “One friend said there was nowhere for me to hide in a documentary; it was more raw and I was more exposed
column19: she said.” But what is she exposing? “Well
column20: things to do with my childhood
column21: I suppose. But I don’t talk about all that because it’s too complicated. It’s extremely messy
column22: so I can’t really.” We meet at a cafe in south London
column23: where she has has lived for 27 years. Arnold is a youthful 60
column24: dressed in jeans
column25: beret
column26: and a fake fur coat “made of real teddy bear”. She is warm and engaging but fiendishly private. She admits to having a 27-year-old daughter
column27: and being one of four children brought up by a single mother
column28: but declines to answer most questions about family. However
column29: she does it with such charm that the sparring becomes enjoyable. Bits and pieces gradually emerge
column30: from which we can piece together a partial jigsaw.

column1: Her films are like this
column2: too: composed of fragments
column3: open to different interpretations. In the autobiographical Wasp
column4: which won the Oscar for best live action short in 2004
column5: a single mother of four is asked out for the first time in years. She pretends she is looking after the kids for a friend and leaves them outside the pub to play without telling her date
column6: which results in all kinds of chaos. Arnold’s narratives are rarely linear and usually elliptical
column7: leaving us to fill in the missing details. In her first full-length work
column8: Red Road
column9: we only begin to understand towards the end of the film why protagonist Jackie has been stalking a newly released prisoner. After it finishes
column10: we find ourselves rewinding the film in our head
column11: reinterpreting all that has gone before – or simply watching it again.

column1: Astonishingly
column2: three of her four movies – Red Road
column3: Fish Tank and American Honey – have won the Jury prize at the Cannes film festival. In Fish Tank
column4: which tells the story of a 15-year-old girl finding her way in the world
column5: there is no mention of her absent father because he’s an irrelevance. In American Honey
column6: a road movie about a group of disadvantaged youngsters crossing America and trying to get by flogging magazines
column7: she pretty much does away with backstory. As for her Heathcliff in Wuthering Heights
column8: he barely utters a word – it’s all about the unspoken emotion. Arnold is a wonderful film-maker. Her movies are beautifully written (or under-written)
column9: nuanced and gorgeous to look at
column10: even when the world they depict is brutal. They are often unbearably tense
column11: her characters invariably living on the brink of violence or betrayal. Although Cow is a documentary
column12: it still feels very much like an Arnold film. It starts with Luma giving birth. In a lovely extended scene she licks her baby clean of amniotic fluid and the calf starts suckling. Luma really is luminous in the pitch-black cowshed – stills from the film look like bovine Rembrandts. While Cow never anthropomorphises Luma
column13: it does allow us to see the world from her perspective. It’s impossible to watch without imagining what is going on in her head.

column1: There are recurrent themes in Arnold’s films – single mums and struggling children
column2: chaotic lives
column3: sexual and commercial exploitation. Cow fits perfectly into this pattern. Luma is the ultimate single mother
column4: constantly pregnant
column5: separated from her children
column6: milked for all she is worth. Arnold’s work could easily be a misery-fest
column7: but it isn’t because she is also alert to all that’s good in life – the intensity of youth
column8: the first flushes of love and lust
column9: dancing yourself to oblivion
column10: the power of resilience. Her characters may not thrive but they are survivors. Again
column11: Cow is consistent with that vision. We experience the purity of the mother-child bond in the first few hours after birth
column12: the joy of the cows at spring turnout when they are let loose in the fields
column13: the literal and metaphorical fireworks as cattle mate on Bonfire Night. As in all her work
column14: music plays a large part. Some songs are piped into the cowsheds from Radio 1 to keep cattle and farmhands happy; others are handpicked by Arnold. Although animals are not the subject of her other films
column15: they feature prominently. In Red Road
column16: Jackie
column17: who works as a CCTV security camera operator
column18: frequently zooms in on a man with a dog – without saying a word
column19: Arnold conveys Jackie’s sense of longing. In Fish Tank
column20: 15-year-old Mia suffers so much trauma in silence
column21: and it’s only when she hears her friend’s horse has been put down that she cries. And Arnold’s short Dog features one of cinema’s most disturbing animal scenes. A teenage girl and boy are having sex. As usual
column22: we witness the scene from the girl’s perspective. While the boy thrusts away
column23: the girl sees a dog steal his stash of dope and eat it. She laughs – at what she has just witnessed
column24: not the boy. But the boy feels humiliated and takes a terrible revenge on the dog.

column1: Animals have played a huge part in Arnold’s life. When she was young
column2: the family home on a low-rise estate in Dartford
column3: Kent
column4: was full of waifs and strays – numerous cats and dogs
column5: guinea pigs and gerbils
column6: and a sheep who lived in the garden but would wander in for the occasional chat. “I remember Mum going absolutely mad when we got back with the lamb.” Her mother
column7: who was only 16 when Arnold was born
column8: died a couple of years ago. Were they close? “I’m not going to talk about it
column9: ” she says in a sing-song voice. Fish Tank is about the troubled and competitive relationship between Mia (an aspiring dancer
column10: as Arnold was) and her mother. They even compete over her mother’s boyfriend Conor
column11: played with a chilling brilliance by Michael Fassbender. At times Mia is ferocious (she headbutts a fellow schoolgirl without compunction
column12: and abducts Conor’s daughter in a terrifying scene) yet we are always aware of her vulnerability. I ask Arnold if she could headbutt her way out of trouble as a teenager. She laughs. No
column13: she says – she has never had a scrap in her life. “But I’ve stopped fights. I can probably count 20 fights I’ve stopped in the last few years. I’m very good at reading that kind of situation and I’m not frightened of it. It’s probably why I’m a film-maker. I’m vigilant and able to read people. I’ve got some skills from my childhood that have served me well as a film-maker.” Did she stop fights as a kid? “I tried to sometimes. But that’s difficult to talk about because; that’s a lot to do with my …” She trails off. “I can’t talk about this stuff. It involves too many people.” So instead she tells me how she stopped a fight in a pub in Essex. “One of the blokes had the guy on the ground and was kicking his head against the gutter. And everyone was just watching. The guy who was kicking him suddenly got tired
column14: stopped and was panting and I saw there was a moment to get in there. Also because I’m a female I feel they’re not going to turn on me.” She pauses. “Though I have stopped fights and they have turned on me. I stopped a boy hitting his girlfriend. He was punching her in the street and nobody was doing anything and I got in between them. The girl ran away
column15: and he just went mad at me. He got hold of my hair
column16: pushed me on the ground and spat at me. Then my friend had to try to get him off me.”

column1: What makes her intervene? “I can’t bear seeing people being cruel or violent to other people.” Has she always been fearless? “I’ve always been fearless
column2: but I’m not tough.” She thinks about what she’s just said. “Actually fearlessness is a kind of toughness.” The young Arnold was a bright girl
column3: who rarely got the opportunity to excel. She left her comprehensive school at 16 to take up hairdressing
column4: hated it
column5: and returned to the sixth form. At 18
column6: she auditioned to be a presenter for No 73
column7: and got the job. She looked so cool – rollerskating
column8: glamorous
column9: carefree – but she says she was always uncomfortable in front of the camera. “I think I look terrified. It was live so it was terrifying. Everyone I was with had done some training and I hadn’t done any whatsoever.” After seven years
column10: when No 73 finished
column11: she decided to reinvent herself as a director. She realised she could turn the stories she had been writing into films. Arnold disappeared from view and has rarely been seen on TV again. She was so determined to make a new start that she swapped continents to retrain at the American Film Institute of Los Angeles. In 1998
column12: she made her first short film
column13: Milk
column14: about a traumatised woman who has given birth to a stillborn baby and addresses her grief by having sex with a man young enough to be her son
column15: who ensures her breast milk doesn’t go to waste. Whatever Arnold’s protagonists have been through
column16: they are never simple victims; they still have “lots of lights on” as she says. The same can be said of Luma. She has endured the toughest of lives
column17: but there is never any sense of her giving up. Towards the end of the film
column18: her udder ligaments have ruptures
column19: she can barely be milked
column20: and she drags her teats painfully along the floor. But
column21: Arnold says
column22: the more she struggled
column23: the more stoic she became. “I sensed this huge sense of service for us. She was still doing this thing she’s been taught to do.”

column1: The longer she spent with Luma the more she was able to read her moo music. As the animal got older
column2: and was separated from more calves
column3: she also seemed to become angrier
column4: Arnold says. She is convinced Luma felt compassion for the other pregnant cows
column5: aware of what they were about to lose. “They say the difference between humans and animals is that we can see the past and think about the future
column6: but I could see Luma knew what’s coming when she’s pregnant. She got particularly mad when she saw the farmer taking away a calf from another cow.” Every time she does a Q&A with an audience about Cow
column7: Arnold is amazed by the response. “We had a screening at the London film festival. People were crying
column8: one person fainted
column9: somebody was sick
column10: somebody had a panic attack. Somebody said to me it made them think women’s bodies are not their own; somebody said ‘It makes me think of infertility and how hard I’ve tried for a baby’; somebody said ‘It’s made me feel about my mother and the relationship we’ve never had’; somebody talked about the relationship with a mother she did have
column11: and somebody said it made them think about how our lives are managed.”

column1: As for Arnold
column2: more than anything Cow has made her think of the importance of being seen. “I kept saying involuntarily during the edit: ‘I’m seeing you
column3: Luma. Don’t worry Luma
column4: we see you.’ I’m not sure any farm animal really feels seen. And I wondered what that meant in terms of her existence.” Has making the film changed her? “Every film changes me. I take a long time making every film
column5: and each one is like a massive growth for me.” She returns to the idea of being seen. “I wonder how much we see not just other animals but each other. Do we really take on board each other and listen and react to people – our families
column6: our friends
column7: our partners
column8: the person on the street?” She knows she’s just made a film about a cow
column9: but to her it feels more elemental. “It’s made me feel a lot about how we’re all connected. I think all living things feel the kindness or cruelty of other living things
column10: so all the decisions we make about how we behave with animals
column11: with plants
column12: with somebody getting on the bus
column13: are so important.” • Cow is in cinemas in the UK and Ireland from 14 January and exclusively on MUBI from 11 February";https://www.theguardian.com/film/2022/jan/06/i-kept-saying-dont-worry-luma-we-see-you-andrea-arnold-on-her-four-years-filming-a-cow;5

Reprieve said it believed the raid was the first “track and kill” drone operation targeting a known individual to be acknowledged by the UK since the killing of 21-year-old Briton Reyaad Khan in Syria in August 2015 by an RAF drone strike – although the circumstances were different. At the time MPs had not voted for air raids against IS targets in Syria
column12: only Iraq. A fortnight later
column13: David Cameron
column14: then the prime minister

column16: Cameron added

column14: 'Environment'];The acquittal of four people charged with criminal damage for toppling the statue of the slave trader Edward Colston during a Black Lives Matter protest in Bristol is the latest in a series of cases in which juries have cleared protesters despite there being no question of their having carried out the actions for which they were tried. Most recent examples related to the environment
column15: with those on trial arguing that their deeds were a proportionate response to the climate crisis. Here are some examples. Roger Hallam
column16: co-founder of Extinction Rebellion
column17: was cleared by a jury in 2019 despite not denying causing criminal damage worth £7
column18: 000 when he sprayed the walls of Kings College London
column19: with the words “divest from oil and gas” in protest against the institution’s fossil fuel investments. Hallam
column20: who was acquitted along with another activist
column21: said it showed “ordinary people
column22: unlike the judiciary
column23: are able to see the broader picture”. In April 2021 six Extinction Rebellion protesters were cleared of causing criminal damage to Shell’s London headquarters despite the judge directing jurors that those on trial had no defence in law. Protesters poured fake oil
column24: glued themselves to windows and doors
column25: broke glass
column26: climbed on to a roof and sprayed graffiti as part of wider demonstrations across the capital. Before reaching their verdicts
column27: the jury had asked to see a copy of the oath they took when they were sworn in. Thanking the jurors
column28: the judge said it had been “an unusual case”. Six climate crisis activists whose protest halted the Docklands Light Railway
column29: which serves London’s financial district
column30: were acquitted by a jury in December 2021. Five of the Extinction Rebellion protesters climbed on top of the train with banners that read “Business As Usual=Death” and “Don’t Jail the Canaries” while a sixth glued herself to a train window. They were charged with obstructing trains or carriages on the railway and acknowledged their roles in the protest but successfully argued that their action was a lawful protest against government inaction on the climate crisis. While there has been a flurry of cases involving Extinction Rebellion recently
column31: there have been previous examples of acquittals by juries concluding that ostensibly criminal actions were motivated by good intentions. In 2008 six Greenpeace climate change activists were cleared of causing £30
column32: 000 of criminal damage at Kingsnorth power station
column33: Kent. The activists admitted trying to shut down the coal-fired station by occupying the smokestack but argued they were legally justified because they were trying to prevent climate change causing greater damage to property around the world. It was the first case in which preventing property damage caused by climate change had been used as part of a “lawful excuse” defence in court. In 2001 Lord Melchett
column34: then executive director of Greenpeace
column35: and 27 other supporters were cleared by a court of causing criminal damage despite admitting destroying a crop of genetically modified maize. The defendants said that they acted to prevent pollen from the maize from polluting neighbouring organic crops and gardens. There have also been a string of acquittals in cases of sabotage of military equipment. In 2007

column37: Toby Olditch and Philip Pritchard
column38: who broke into RAF Fairford Gloucestershire
column39: to sabotage US bombers at the outbreak of the Iraq war
column40: were cleared of conspiring to cause criminal damage after they argued the B52s would have been used to commit war crimes in Iraq. In 2000
column41: two anti-nuclear protesters who entered a dockyard planning to disarm one of Britain’s Trident submarines with an axe were cleared of conspiracy to cause criminal damage. Sylvia Boyes and River (formerly known as Keith Wright) admitted that they plotted to damage HMS Vengeance while it was docked at Barrow-in-Furness
column42: Cumbria

column4: 'Coronavirus'];"Chinese hospital officials have been fired after a pregnant woman lost her baby after she was denied entry at a Xi’an hospital due to coronavirus lockdown restrictions. On the night of 1 January a woman in labour was denied entry to the Xi’an Gaoxin hospital because her negative test result was four hours too old. She began bleeding heavily while waiting outside
column5: and was eventually admitted but the baby died.

column1: The woman’s story and an accompanying video went viral on social media
column2: and was reported by local Chinese media. A related hashtag on Weibo was viewed 600m times. On Wednesday
column3: the Shaanxi Province and Xi’an Municipal Health Commission said it had launched an investigation and determined the baby’s death was an “accident caused by negligence”. Two hospital officials were fired and a manager suspended. The head of the Xi’an health commission also received a formal warning from the Chinese Communist party for mishandling emergency care in the city. Xi’an
column4: a city of 13 million in Shaanxi province
column5: is two weeks into a strict lockdown that has kept residents inside their homes and shut down entertainment venues
column6: shops and public transport. Authorities say the lockdown has allowed them to get on top of the outbreak of Covid cases
column7: which they said were now trending downwards. However
column8: there have also been concerning reports of food shortages and delayed or blocked access to medical care. Strict vaccine and testing requirements for anyone seeking medical care appeared to cause confusion and prevent some people from accessing emergency treatment.

column1: In a statement reported by state media
column2: the hospital in the woman’s case said it had done “everything that should be done”. “Now the Health Commission and the Women’s Federation are investigating. They paid much attention to it
column3: and they were more than fair.” The hospital has been ordered to apologise to the public
column4: improve its processes
column5: and ensure all patients can access emergency care. Epidemic prevention and control were not grounds for preventing a patient’s treatment
column6: authorities said
column7: and new “green” channels would be opened for patients with acute and critical illnesses to access treatment. On Wednesday officials also said cases were trending down in Xi’an
column8: with most new cases detected in quarantine or closed areas. More than 42
column9: 000 people have been put into quarantine centres
column10: according to state media. Xi’an has recorded about 1
column11: 800 cases since 9 December. China’s continued commitment to zero Covid has apparent general public support in a country that has recorded far fewer cases than many other nations despite the virusfirst being detected there. However
column12: there are growing concerns about the impact of continued restrictions
column13: which are getting stricter as local officials strive to prevent and respond to outbreaks or face potential punishment. Additional reporting by Xiaoqian Zhu";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/06/china-fires-hospital-officials-after-pregnant-woman-loses-baby-due-to-covid-lockdown-rules;4

column1: 84;84;5325;5325;Country diary: The willow stems that once held the countryside together;2022-01-06T05:30:53Z;['Sara Hudston'];['Trees and forests'
column2: 'Environment'

column4: 'UK news'
column5: 'Farming'];"What would farmers do without baler twine? Blue
column6: pink
column7: yellow or orange
column8: this thin
column9: strong
column10: polypropylene string seems to hold the countryside together. It ties up gates
column11: zigzags crazily across holes in fences and lashes down tarpaulins. Originally made of natural sisal fibre
column12: baler twine was invented towards the end of the 19th century. Its primary purpose was to machine-bind hay and straw bales. But what did people use before industrialisation
column13: when they had to rely on the materials immediately to hand? Withy
column14: or willow
column15: is one answer. Its slender
column16: whippy stems have been used for millennia for weaving and fastening: the root meaning of “withy” is to twist or plait. Basketmaker Malcolm Seal cultivates willow on his smallholding near Powerstock Common
column17: north-west of Dorchester
column18: where he also keeps curly fleeced Gotland sheep. I visit on a day when he is harvesting coarse withies suitable for garden structures. Willow grows fast in damp earth – in one year Malcolm’s plants reach nearly three metres high. I watch as he cuts the stems close to the ground and gathers them into bundles
column19: known as wads. He secures each wad with a withy bond
column20: a traditional tie made from a single
column21: long stem.

column1: There are several stages in making a bond. First
column2: Malcolm takes a withy stem and whirls it clockwise – this is called cranking. There’s a small
column3: dry pop as the fibres break
column4: then he twists it and lets the tightened stem turn back on itself. He threads the straight end through the loop and then encircles the wad
column5: before further cranking and coiling so the tie is held in place by its own tension. That twisting
column6: self-hold principle is an ancient method
column7: used for all manner of materials: thatchers employed it to secure straw to roofs and hayricks. It even works for hair. In 1948
column8: two men cutting peat in a willow-grown bog near Osterby in Germany uncovered a human head. The man’s long hair was held back in a distinctive self-tying fashion
column9: similar to a withy bond. The Roman historian Tacitus describes this iron-age hairstyle – known as a Suebian knot – in his account of Germanic tribes
column10: written in about AD98. • Country Diary is on Twitter at @gdncountrydiary";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/06/country-diary-the-willow-stems-that-once-held-the-countryside-together;3

column1: 85;85;5326;5326;‘So-called border vigilance’: PM’s tough guy act on Djokovic won’t distract from failed Covid response | Malcolm Farr;2022-01-06T05:05:53Z;['Malcolm Farr'];['Australian Open'

column7: 'Vaccines and immunisation'];"Novak Djokovic’s visa cancellation and possible deportation has become a scarifying issue for Australian sport and the federal government
column8: a political break point thanks to the inattention and ignorance of the prime minister
column9: Scott Morrison. Morrison was so busy struggling to extricate himself from the mess he had created over the provision of reasonably priced rapid Covid tests
column10: he had no awareness of
column11: or capacity to fully deal with
column12: the controversy so obviously set to arrive with the Serbian tennis champion. Djokovic has previously expressed reluctance about Covid vaccination and has consistently refused to disclose his vaccination status. And it was obvious a hemisphere away he was ready to drive his worldwide celebrity and remarkable sporting record through the resolve of Australian authorities
column13: having secured a medical exemption. No-vax Novak was confident he would be let through.

column1: In this objective he was helped
column2: unwittingly
column3: by the prime minister of Australia
column4: who finally got around to doing his job. “Rules are rules
column5: ” Scott Morrison eventually advised Djokovic
column6: in an echo of a stern suburban dad scolding a child for staying out late. But it’s difficult to be severe with the tennis champ because the prime minister didn’t know the rules
column7: either. On Wednesday
column8: he duck-shoved responsibility for the world No 1 being allowed into Australia unvaccinated. “Well
column9: that is a matter for the Victorian government. They have provided him with an exemption to come to Australia
column10: and so we then act in accordance with that decision
column11: ” he told reporters
column12: clearly not knowing what he was talking about. By Thursday
column13: he had been educated on the matter and announced in muscular fashion it was a federal government matter
column14: and the Serb was out – one of the highest-profile figures ever to be punted from Australia
column15: pending Monday’s court hearing. “Rules are rules
column16: especially when it comes to our borders
column17: ” Morrison said in that scolding statement. “No one is above the rules.” And he ended the reprimand with a protective assurance: “… we are continuing to be vigilant.” The home affairs minister
column18: Karen Andrews
column19: might have been Morrison’s educator on the matter
column20: as she issued a statement – headed “Australia’s border rules apply to everyone” – contradicting the prime minister’s Wednesday press conference ramble. “While the Victorian Government and Tennis Australia may permit a non-vaccinated player to compete in the Australian Open
column21: it is the Commonwealth Government that will enforce our requirements at the Australian border
column22: ” Andrews said in part of a statement. Neither Morrison nor Andrews can now breathe easily. And nor can the foreign affairs minister
column23: Marise Payne. There remain stark questions about the so-called border vigilance Morrison was so hairy-chested about. Djokovic had a visa to get to Australia. What happened when he got here is one thing
column24: but clearly he boarded an aircraft with Australian-issue credentials saying he had a right to land here. Payne will be pressed to explain where and how that visa was issued when there are so many restrictions on the travel of vaccinated Australians. Is there a tennis service
column25: a net accord?

column1: Answers on these matters won’t arrive in a rush
column2: as Morrison will wring as much political gain as he imagines he can from this. His keenness to be seen as the tough guy with Djokovic – once it was explained to him it unavoidably was his responsibility and not that of the Victorian premier
column3: Dan Andrews – was the first sign that border protection would be ramped up. His problem is that even insulting and exploiting the world’s best tennis player will not be sufficient distraction from the growing confusion over the response to Omicron as it overwhelms towns and cities. Morrison’s admission that he gets rapid tests for free
column4: while thunderously objecting to other Australians getting the same deal
column5: quite simply stinks. If it’s not the hypocrisy or the deliberate misleading
column6: it’s the broad policy failure of the federal government’s Covid response. There is only one tennis player being deported. There are thousands of Australians every day discovering they have been infected by the virus
column7: and many others unable to get tested but who know they are stricken. None of them will feel safer because Novak Djokovic has been thrown out of town. Malcolm Farr is a political journalist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/06/so-called-border-vigilance-pms-tough-guy-act-on-djokovic-wont-distract-from-failed-covid-response;1

column3: 'Asia Pacific'];Tan Lili

column14: China has promoted policies for schools to help students exercise more. “We have 11 full-time PE teachers

column4: 'Europe'
column5: 'World news'];"Berlin police dogs trained to attack perpetrators have been put on an enforced break
column6: along with their handlers
column7: over contradictions between the methods used to control them and a new law to prevent cruelty to dogs. The use of pulling collars to channel a police dog’s aggression towards an agitator or potential criminal contravenes the law
column8: introduced by the former agriculture minister
column9: which came into force on 1 January. Police said that about 49 dogs
column10: out of about 130 used for operations from arresting perpetrators to drug and explosives detection or locating missing persons
column11: were suspended from duty until a solution was found that would not involve officers breaking the law. A police spokesperson
column12: Thilo Cablitz
column13: said: “We are currently unable to deploy a section of our service dogs due to changes in the animal protection act governing dogs.” Those suspended include dogs working alongside special forces
column14: the SEK
column15: and those used to protect people as well as to arrest offenders.

column1: The training of “Schutzhunde”
column2: or protection dogs
column3: involves being able to control when a dog ends an attack
column4: by tugging briefly on a “pulling collar” to restricts the animal’s airway. The logic is that if a dog’s aggression
column5: considered necessary for the apprehension
column6: is not controlled
column7: it could cause serious injury or death to the perpetrator. Under the new ordinance
column8: brought into law by the former agriculture minister Julia Klöckner
column9: the use of such punitive stimuli is no longer allowed when training dogs. While primarily introduced to improve standards of dog ownership in Germany
column10: the rules are intended to apply to all German dogs
column11: including guard dogs. The agriculture ministry has said its decision was based on scientific studies showing that punitive stimuli “contradicts the concept of animal welfare”. Included in the act are rules governing the all-round care and upkeep of dogs
column12: from the size
column13: temperature and ventilation of their kennels
column14: to breeding practices. Dog owners are obliged to take their pets for regular walks
column15: to spend time with them and to ensure they have contact with other dogs. Chaining dogs
column16: except under certain circumstances and conditions
column17: pinch collars and other equipment or practices considered to induce pain
column18: are forbidden. Klöcker has said the need for an update to existing legislation was long overdue but had become urgent during the pandemic
column19: as increasing numbers of people with no experience of owning pets had bought dogs
column20: and cases of abuse were rife. Pet shop owners and breeders should also carry more responsibility for dogs’ welfare
column21: she said. The law change has been known about for months but its effect on the daily workings of police attack dogs seems to have taken police and politicians by surprise. Stephan Kelm
column22: the vice-chair of the Berlin branch of the police union
column23: GdP
column24: said a solution needed to be found
column25: as the dogs’ suspension would have “severe consequences for domestic security”
column26: and the union had asked for the federal interior minister

column1: Despite a rocky past

column6: 'Antoine de Saint-Exupéry'];"The road to Broadway now includes a stop at Rooty Hill. The Sydney Coliseum Theatre opened in the western Sydney suburb in December 2019
column7: funded in part by the Rooty Hill RSL’s gaming revenue and designed to function as both a lyric theatre and concert venue that could attract major productions – and major names – to the region. Now
column8: by hosting a three-week season of The Little Prince – based on the beloved bestselling 1943 novella by Antoine De Saint-Exupéry and produced by the Broadway Entertainment Group – the venue has become part of an international pipeline. The production premiered in Paris in 2019 and made its Australian debut last year at the Sydney Opera House; in March
column9: it lands at the Broadway Theatre in New York. The stage show is directed and choreographed by Anne Tournié
column10: with co-direction by Chris Mouron. It is faithful to the book’s plot
column11: language and structure
column12: as well as its fabulist elements and its heartfelt insistence that the most valuable parts of life lie beyond work
column13: routines
column14: and habits. An aviator crashes in the desert and comes across the titular Prince (Lionel Zacharias
column15: in bare feet and boasting a shock of blonde hair). He has left his tiny asteroid – where he rakes out the little volcanoes that come up to his knee and tends to a rose that has stolen his heart – to explore the world.

column1: This production is designed to travel. Built from a strong foundation of visual art and movement
column2: it blends circus arts and dance on video projections that cover the floor and backdrop and relies on these non-verbal elements for the majority of its storytelling. For the rest
column3: there is a Narrator
column4: played by Mouron
column5: who also adapted the novella’s text for the stage. She speaks mostly in English and occasionally in French (the entire work is sur-titled in English); sometimes
column6: her voice lifts in song. She guides us through the scenes as the Prince travels through space to meet an arrogant king
column7: a bustling businessman
column8: and a drunk
column9: among others
column10: before landing on Earth and making a lasting impact on the aviator.

column1: It is still that aviator’s story
column2: framed by his encounter with the Prince
column3: which we see here
column4: but Mouron speaks for every character as the story’s singular voice
column5: and keeps the production tied to De Saint-Exupéry’s work by taking very few liberties with the language – it’s less of a new adaptation than a cross-artform translation. It’s as though the story is now a pop-up book being shown to us. Marie Jumelin’s video design is gently surrealistic
column6: creating new skies and visual vocabulary for each planet on the Prince’s journey. When performers swing on aerial ropes to simulate flying
column7: they seem suspended in the middle of the universe. There is often a riot of stars
column8: which makes perfect sense: this is a story that looks constantly to the stars and remarks on their value.

column1: Against such detailed video
column2: Tournié’s choreography is often necessarily simple
column3: consisting mostly of bold and broad steps that immediately suggest meaning. The Vain Man (played by Antony Cesar and who
column4: in the production’s most trite update
column5: is obsessed simply with taking selfies) tumbles and break dances
column6: performing tricks on tricks
column7: while the Rose (the heart of the show and a clear audience favourite
column8: played by Laurisse Sulty) is given romantic
column9: balletic shapes. Acrobatic balancing balls cleverly represent planets – the Prince walks onstage on one in his first entrance
column10: evoking the novella’s famous illustrations of the character atop his little asteroid. The ultimate effect is more beguiling than it is persuasive. The production is almost too true to the novella; at nearly two hours long
column11: it begins to overstay its welcome (the opening night audience – children and adults alike – became audibly restless). While its reliance on video technology is its most dazzling element
column12: it is also its riskiest; on opening night

column6: 'Washington DC'];"It was a day that shook America. Joe Biden will lead sombre commemorations on Thursday to mark one year since the US Capitol insurrection that left five people dead and the nation’s democracy wounded

column11: according to an excerpt released by the White House. “Are we going to be a nation that accepts political violence as a norm? Are we going to be a nation where we allow partisan election officials to overturn the legally expressed will of the people? “Are we going to be a nation that lives not by the light of the truth but in the shadow of lies? We cannot allow ourselves to be that kind of nation. The way forward is to recognise the truth and to live by it.” Biden has been “clear-eyed” about the “threat the former president represents to our democracy”

column13: Jen Psaki

column1: Defeated in the 2020 presidential election

Scores of police were beaten and bloodied and congressional offices were ransacked in the worst ever domestic attack on the seat of US government. Trump this week cancelled his own anniversary event – a press conference at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida that had been scheduled for the evening of 6 January – reportedly at the urging of advisers. A year on from the attack

column6: not the lies that some have spread since
column7: and the peril it has posed to the rule of law and our system of democratic governance
column8: ” Psaki told reporters on Tuesday. Biden will put an extra spotlight on the role of Capitol police and others on the scene
column9: Psaki said. “Because of their efforts
column10: our democracy withstood an attack from a mob
column11: and the will of more than 150 million people who voted in the presidential election was ultimately registered by Congress.” Psaki was asked at the press briefing what the president’s message will be to the many Republicans who believe Biden stole the election from Trump
column12: despite overwhelming contrary evidence. “What he’s going to continue to do is speak to everyone in the country. Those who didn’t vote for him
column13: those who may not believe he is the legitimate president

column16: a moment of silence on the House floor
column17: a conversation with the presidential historians Doris Kearns Goodwin and Jon Meacham
column18: testimonials from members of Congress and a prayer vigil. Four people died on the day of the riot and one Capitol police officer died the day after. Four officers have since taken their own lives. The crowd called for the then vice-president

column1: But Trump

column1: Naively

column14: despite everything

column5: 'BBC'];There is an intern inside Diane Morgan’s beehive. The person
column6: after being shrunk to fit
column7: operates a tiny control panel to create Morgan’s facial expressions. The only problem is that they are not very good at it. Perhaps the hairspray Morgan wears for her role in Mandy (BBC Two) has clouded the intern’s brain. They keep pulling on the lever that twitches her pursed lips into a lop-sided smirk
column8: or using the rotator ball to make her Marty Feldman-like eyes swivel in a parody of human sarcasm. Or at least
column9: this is my explanation for why Morgan’s performance as the titular mardy
column10: functionally unemployable Lancastrian tends towards the two-dimensional. It not only accounts for why Mandy is obsessively focused on keeping her hairdo in place. It also explains why there is not the remotest hint that Mandy’s character will develop. She looks like a homage to Coronation Street’s Bet Lynch
column11: with her heels and hatchet glares
column12: but has none of Bet’s rounded humanity or narrative arc. She more closely resembles other Lancastrian comic ciphers such as Twinkle in Dinnerladies (played by Morgan’s friend and fellow Boltonian Maxine Peake)
column13: who was forever subverting her boss’s patriarchal mind games with lines including: “All right
column14: keep your scrotum on.” Or Caroline Aherne’s checkout girl in The Fast Show
column15: deriding shoppers’ purchases: “Parmesan cheese? Smells like a tramp’s crotch.” The twist here is that Mandy is neither an ancillary character nor delivering a gag in a weekly sketch
column16: but rather intended to carry the series. You might think that Morgan’s character should seem to involve more than being manipulated from within her hair by a tiny
column17: undertrained intern. But that is to miss the magnificence of Mandy. In a sense
column18: this is a revolutionary sitcom
column19: dedicated to the philosophy that people don’t really change and that richly developed narratives aren’t all that. There is an episode of Seinfeld in which Kramer test-drives a car to see how far he can go without putting in more gas. Mandy is like that: how far can she go with zero character development and only the most threadbare storylines? Not as far as season three
column20: I would guess
column21: but I have been wrong before. In this episode
column22: the season two premiere
column23: Mandy is sent by jobcentre lackeys to work at a stately home. Her previous jobs all ended in disaster: there were fatalities after she ineptly processed fruit at a banana plant
column24: and she saw an alien in the aisles while working in Co-op
column25: where she racked up a £79 bill for edam after wilfully misinterpreting the staff discount. At Brampton Hall
column26: Mandy dresses as a scullery maid and takes visitors on tours exploring the house’s past. “This is the room where John the Baptist died
column27: ” she explains to sceptical couples in jumpers. It is as if Lucy Worsley turned up for a TV documentary gig in period costume but knew nothing about history and decided brazenly to invent nonsensical claims on the fly
column28: staring dead-eyed at anyone who doubted her. Offered folding money by some dimwit tourist
column29: she reveals more of the house’s history: “Ronnie and Reggie used to live here
column30: but were killed because they stole Michael Heseltine’s ashtray.” Mandy
column31: then
column32: is the soul sister of Philomena Cunk
column33: the gormless know-nothing pundit created by Charlie Brooker and performed by Morgan. She is also closely related to Liz – whom Morgan plays in Motherland – a woman heroically scathing about the middle-class pieties of child rearing. Later
column34: Mandy is tasked with serving nibbles at a book reading in the hall
column35: but she takes the vol-au-vent tray to the wrong room and finds herself among satanists conducting a black mass. That furious clattering noise you can hear is National Trust and English Heritage press officers typing statements distancing themselves from Brampton Hall’s employment practices and room-hire policies. Long story short
column36: Mandy is strapped to an altar by masked yet unacceptably naked satanists and rescued only when Lola
column37: her designated-driver mate
column38: shows up. “What the devil is going on here?” Lola exclaims. “My badminton got cancelled
column39: ” says one devil worshipper. Then Lola smacks the men’s bare buttocks (the biggest laugh of the episode
column40: in my book) and chases them off. Why satanic ritual requires nudity is beyond me. The episode ends with two revelations. The first I won’t disclose
column41: but if you can’t guess the identity of at least one satanist
column42: you are too dim to be watching Mandy. The second is more astounding. According to the credits
column43: the show was written and directed by Morgan – not by a homunculus inside a hairdo. I would never have guessed.;https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/jan/05/mandy-review-slap-my-bum-and-call-me-a-satanist-diane-morgan-is-back;5

column3: 'Law (US)'];"Lawyers for Ghislaine Maxwell have called for a retrial after a juror said in recent post-trial media interviews that he was a victim of sexual abuse.

column1: Maxwell was found guilty on 29 December of five counts for facilitating the late financier Jeffrey Epstein’s sexual abuse of girls
column2: some as young as 14. Prosecutors have also asked judge Alison Nathan to investigate the juror’s remarks. “While the court instructed jurors that they were free to discuss their jury service with anyone of their choosing
column3: some of the statements
column4: as related in the media
column5: merit attention by the court. In particular
column6: the juror has described being a victim of sexual abuse
column7: ” prosecutors wrote. “Assuming the accuracy of the reporting

column9: but stated that ‘he would have answered honestly’. “Based on the foregoing

column11: ” they wrote to Nathan. The juror’s claim that he did not recall being asked about sexual abuse has spurred questions

column13: sexual abuse
column14: or sexual assault?” Another asked: “Witnesses in this case may testify claiming sexual abuse or sexual assault. Would you have any difficulty assessing the credibility of a witness claiming sexual assault or abuse just like you would any other witness?” In their letter
column15: prosecutors proposed Judge Nathan schedule a hearing in about a month

column17: ” they wrote. “If the court decides to schedule such a hearing
column18: the government respectfully requests that the court’s staff promptly contact the juror to notify him of the hearing and inquire whether he would like counsel to be appointed in connection with it.” One of Maxwell’s lawyers

column21: describing it as “an issue of pressing importance”. While this filing had some redactions

Everdell asked Nathan to set a schedule for both sides to submit filings on the issue. “Should the defense prevail on this motion – and we believe the law and facts are clearly on our side – it would render all other post-trial motions moot. Ms Maxwell should not have to expend precious time and resources briefing other motions when this motion can and should be dispositive
column23: ” Everdell said. “Accordingly
column24: the defense respectfully requests that the court set a briefing schedule for this motion alone and defer setting a briefing schedule for any other post-trial motions.” Jeffrey Pagliuca
column25: another one of Maxwell’s lawyers
column26: said in a filing shortly thereafter that “the government’s request for a hearing is premature because based on undisputed
column27: publicly available information
column28: the Court can and should order a new trial without any evidentiary hearing. “It is clear to Ms Maxwell that based on this record alone a new trial is required
column29: ” Pagliuca also wrote. David S Weinstein
column30: a former federal prosecutor who is now a partner at Jones Walker LLP
column31: said: “Based on the letter motion that was filed today by the government
column32: it’s clear that they want to ensure that it’s the court who conducts any questioning of this juror.” He said: “They want to put the court on notice that this information is out there and they want to prevent any other third party from speaking to this juror before the court does” – including Maxwell’s defense team. At issue will be what the juror said on his questionnaire. If he answered no
column33: the motivation behind that answer could influence the outcome of any inquiry. For example
column34: if he answered no because he was not paying attention
column35: that might present less of a problem than if he knowingly answered in the negative to avoid being disqualified. “If it turned out he checked the box yes
column36: and both the defense and prosecution never bothered to follow up on it

column38: ” Weinstein said. Weinstein said that the process would involve Nathan questioning the juror. Then
column39: Nathan will provide the information from this questioning to both sides. “If the answers are ‘I misled you because I wanted to serve’

column46: ” New York criminal defense attorney Julie Rendelman told the Guardian. “Keep in mind that this juror suggests that his own experience as a victim of sexual abuse not only impacted his decision making but others in the jury who he relayed his story to.” Late Wednesday afternoon

column8: Homer Plessy engaged in a trailblazing act of civil disobedience that led to the landmark Plessy v Ferguson supreme court decision
column9: Louisiana’s governor stood 130 years later and issued a posthumous pardon to the late civil rights pioneer. Beneath a grey sky and in a ceremony laced with symbolism and repentance
column10: Governor John Bel Edwards signed the pardon for Plessy
column11: a Creole man of color who purchased a ticket for a whites-only train cabin and was subsequently arrested for violating Louisiana’s Separate Car Act. Plessy’s case resulted in the infamous 1896 court decision
column12: which legalized the “separate but equal” doctrine and ushered in the Jim Crow era of racist segregation. “The stroke of my pen on this pardon
column13: while momentous
column14: it doesn’t erase generations of pain and discrimination. It doesn’t eradicate all the wrongs wrought by the Plessy court
column15: or fix all of our present challenges
column16: ” Edwards said. “But this pardon is a step in the right direction.” The ceremony
column17: on the grounds of the old station that is now a campus for the New Orleans Center for Creative Arts
column18: was attended by descendants of both Plessy and John Ferguson
column19: the Louisiana judge who initially ruled against Plessy before the case made it to the supreme court.

column8: 'Conservatives'];"It’s an ill wind and all that. With Keir Starmer testing positive for Covid for the second time in a matter of months
column9: it was the deputy leader
column10: Angela Rayner
column11: who got to take on Boris Johnson at the first prime minister’s questions of the new year. Which was just the news that Johnson didn’t want to hear
column12: because Rayner is his worst nightmare. First off
column13: she’s a woman and Boris has a major problem relating to women without mansplaining. More importantly
column14: though
column15: she’s a working-class woman who is very comfortable speaking her mind. Where Starmer may back off and err on the side of caution and politesse
column16: Rayner is never happier than when going toe to toe. Especially when she’s up against someone who is struggling in the polls and whom she doesn’t much respect. Rayner began with a flick at the ongoing investigation into parties at No 10 – it never hurts to remind your opponent of nasties coming down the road – before homing in on the here and now. In October he had said that fears of inflation were unfounded. Given that inflation was now running at 6%
column17: how had he managed to get it all so wrong? “Um
column18: er
column19: ” said Johnson. For a moment – the trademark hesitations and incoherence aside – it looked as though Johnson might actually try to answer the question directly. He even began a half-formed sentence to that end. Then half way through he gave up and decided to do what he always does. When under pressure or not. He started lying. How could he have forgotten to do something so natural to him? Maybe it was the Rayner effect. “I said no such thing
column20: ” he continued. It was a pure invention that just happened to have been captured in an interview he had given to Sky. From that point on
column21: Johnson was pretty much lost
column22: careering from one car crash to the next. In between wittering on about cold weather payments and the warm home discount – he claimed it was worth £140 a week: it isn’t
column23: it’s £140 a year
column24: though this was probably less a lie and more total ignorance – he just bounced from one lie to the next causing ever greater self-harm. First he tried to claim that the country would be in lockdown if Labour had got its way. Where he got this idea from is anyone’s guess. Most likely it was his own wish fulfilment; what he would have liked to do had he not been too weak to face down the rightwing libertarians in the Tory party. All Labour had ever done was back plan B and said it would be guided by the scientific data. Then he smashed into the next lie. Labour was committed to nationalising the gas industry. It isn’t: Starmer has specifically ruled that out. Then
column25: when Rayner wondered why the government was so keen to rule out cutting VAT on fuel bills – something Johnson had promised as a Brexit dividend – Boris exploded into faux outrage. How dare people who had voted to stay in the EU demand that he keep his promises? He was fully entitled to break as many as he liked to remainers. And
column26: in any case
column27: Labour wanted to rejoin the EU. Pure fantasy. Even the Lib Dems have given up on that one. When Starmer is faced with so many lies in a matter of minutes
column28: he tends to have a mini-meltdown himself. As if the idea of a prime minister being unable to tell the truth does not compute with his version of reality. And you can sort of see his point. It’s a sign of how low we’ve sunk into the shit that we’ve grown used to the idea of Johnson as a serial liar. We don’t expect anything else from him. But where Keir
column29: frets
column30: Rayner runs with it. Sensing Boris was badly losing the plot – if you can lose something you never really had – she paused to ask if he was feeling OK? And he really wasn’t. He was having one of his worst days. He knew that all of his lies would unravel long before the end of PMQs but was unable to prevent himself from telling them. He was so busted. So exposed. He knew it and his own benches knew it. Some Tories tried to offer some encouragement – their jobs are hanging by the same thread as Boris’s and
column31: like it or not
column32: they are symbiotically entwined with him – but it was all a bit half-hearted. Not least because all the red wall MPs care about their constituents’ cost of living. The session ended with Edward Leigh moaning about foreigners. Boris couldn’t bring himself to tell him Vote Leave had promised Indians they could come to the UK post Brexit. Things didn’t much improve for Johnson when he came to give the Covid statement right after PMQs. There again
column33: it’s never the easiest lie to spin that you’ve made all the right calls for the right reasons
column34: when everyone knows that you only did what your party would allow. Or more specifically what the Coronavirus Recovery Group would allow. Donkeys led by yet more donkeys. Rayner pointed out some of the more obvious dangers of hospitals being overwhelmed
column35: operations cancelled and people with heart attacks expected to take a bus to A&E but it was the SNP’s Ian Blackford who got to the heart of the matter. Riding out the pandemic had consequences. More people would die. Which probably wouldn’t affect Boris or many Tory MPs that much
column36: but would certainly be one hell of a bummer for those who died. And for their friends and families. So maybe now was the time for a bit more caution. A bit of humility. Only Johnson doesn’t do caution or humility. He just ducks and dives
column37: doing what he needs to do to get through to the end of the day more or less intact. The consequences left to pile up for tomorrow. Steve Baker and Mark Harper
column38: two hardline members of the CRG
column39: invited Boris to end all restrictions now. In their world
column40: it is their bravery in standing up to Omicron that had forced it into being weaker than Delta. Had the government imposed another lockdown
column41: Omicron would have been inspired to be a much stronger variant. Or something. Whatever drugs they are on
column42: count me out. Boris hummed and hahed

column4: 'Australia news'];"Researchers studying the purple-crowned fairy wren in far northern Western Australia have discovered the birds romancing outside the normal breeding season for the second year running. The development is highly unusual in the 16-year program at the Australian Wildlife Conservancy’s (AWC) Mornington Wildlife Sanctuary
column5: which closely monitors the birds and was identified in a three-week survey carried out during the dry season in October and November. Ordinarily breeding takes place during the wet season between December to April when insects are plentiful. It is indicated by “brood patches” – bare patches on the belly – of female birds and bent tail feathers caused when they nest their eggs in cramped nests.

column1: But Dr Niki Teunissen
column2: a postdoctoral research fellow at Monash University who conducted the recent dry-season survey
column3: said that when she caught female birds they showed all the telltale signs of a “busy season”. “Some of those females already had fledglings
column4: so they’d already successfully bred
column5: ” Teunissen said. “Then I caught them and found that they had brood patches
column6: which means they already had a nest again. So it’s a busy season. “We don’t really understand why it’s happening but we would love to find out.” As it is had occurred for the second year running the discovery upended much of what researchers thought they knew about the bird’s lifecycle. Teunissen said there may be several contributing factors for the birds changing up their schedule
column7: though so far any theories were “speculative” without further research. She said the region had experienced good rainfall after a period of drought which may make it more attractive for the birds
column8: especially as life can be difficult during the wet season.

column1: Not only is their habitat – wetlands along rivers – under threat from fire and cattle grazing
column2: but it is also prone to flash flooding during the wet season that can see local waterways rise metres in a matter of minutes. Last wet season 40% – two in every five nests – were washed away. Another contributing factor may be pressure from cuckoos that lay their eggs in the wrens’ nests for the wrens to raise. As the cuckoos are not around in the dry season it is possible the wrens have adapted. “What I take away from it is that if anything these birds are clearly more flexible in terms of the time of breeding than we thought
column3: ” Teunissen said. Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: The purple-crowned fairy wren has two sub-species – the eastern sub-species and the western sub-species. The population being studied by the AWC belongs to the western sub-species. The birds get their name for the purple crown the males wear during the breeding season. This colouring fades when not in season
column2: but last season they were purple all year round. With only an estimated 7
column3: 000 birds in the wild they are considered an endangered population that is in decline. The birds only live for four years on average
column4: however the oldest bird tracked by the program has lived to 15 years.

column1: Unlike the superb fairy wren
column2: which has a reputation for promiscuity with the female birds regularly cheating on their partners
column3: Teunissen says purple-crowned fairy wren’s are “quite faithful”. The birds do not always mate for life but they can form stable relationships with couples raising their young together and defending their territory together outside breeding season.

column1: While the longest breeding pairs last eight years
column2: Teunissen says divorce is not unheard of. “And what we find is that usually when divorce happens the female leaves to join a male elsewhere who’s got better habitat
column3: so it’s all about real estate really
column4: ” she said. “It really is a soap opera and we follow them in so much detail that we know exactly what each individual bird is up to sometimes.”";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/06/australian-researchers-baffled-as-endangered-purple-crowned-fairy-wrens-breed-outside-season-again;3

column5: 'Law'];"The story of how Elizabeth Holmes came to defraud some of the richest and most powerful investors in the US

column12: 'Politics'];It’s choose your poison time for a government that must know allowing low-income households to suffer the full blast of the scheduled rise in energy bills in April is a political non starter. After six months of high gas prices in the wholesale market
column13: the regulator Ofgem’s price-setting formula is likely to spit out a figure close to £2
column14: 000 on average for an annual dual-fuel bill
column15: or a year-on-year increase of roughly £700. That is simply unaffordable for many. And the implied £20bn-ish hit to discretionary consumer spending will do little to encourage a whoosh of post-Omicron activity the Treasury is relying on in other areas of the economy. Some form of subsidy or smoothing mechanism for bills must be found. From where the chancellor sits
column16: though
column17: you can see why he may not fancy cutting VAT. It’s charged at 5% on energy bills
column18: so even a temporary removal would only reduce a £2
column19: 000 bill by £100. Nor would it be targeted: all bill payers would benefit. On that score
column20: Boris Johnson is correct to describe it as “a blunt instrument”. Rishi Sunak’s real worry
column21: though

column23: remember
column24: is trusting that VAT receipts from electricity will rise over time as fuel duties from petrol and diesel decline when we plug in our electric cars. It needs VAT to be seen as fixed. A windfall tax on North Sea gas producers? That will be tempting
column25: but the design would be key. Some of the producers who are enjoying current conditions are also hooked into government-backed carbon capture projects
column26: so a windfall tax risks complaints about jeopardising long-term incentives and investment. Should nuclear generators
column27: or energy trading firms
column28: also be included since they are also beneficiaries of high wholesale prices? Determining who should pay
column29: and defining a “windfall” profit while wholesale prices are still volatile
column30: can quickly become a messy business. Back in 1997
column31: the beauty of the then chancellor Gordon Brown’s windfall tax on privatised utilities was its simplicity: it was levied on the grounds that the companies had been sold off too cheaply
column32: which was almost unarguable. Definitions were clear and boardroom grumbling could be ignored. Boosting the size and availability of the warm homes discount available to vulnerable households is a far simpler idea. There is at least an established mechanism for payments and the benefits
column33: unlike with a VAT removal
column34: would be targeted. How much would it cost to make a meaningful difference? A case can be made for any number as high as £10bn
column35: which would upset the Treasury’s spending arithmetic for the next financial year. And
column36: again
column37: Sunak may fret about an exit given that analysts expect next autumn’s price cap to be set even higher than April’s. Thus you can see the political temptation to grant a £20bn multi-year loan to energy supply companies to make them manage the headache. The government would avoid the appearance of setting energy bills and consumers would pay over time. It’s hardly a pain-free or risk-free option
column38: however. It means telling consumers their bills won’t fall even when wholesale prices do. And underwriting loans to a sector where two dozen companies have gone bust in the last three months would be a brave move. The government has already nationalised Bulb and probably does not want to add to its collection of failed suppliers. It is hard to predict where ministers will land among this range of unattractive choices
column39: but a massively expanded warm homes scheme gets the vote here. It would be targeted
column40: which is an essential requirement
column41: and would confront the problem head-on instead of putting the bill on the never-never. The hardest part would be expanding the definition of “vulnerable” consumers: the whole point about a £700 hike to the default tariff is that newly vulnerable households will be created

column43: as on Wednesday
column44: don’t change the basic fact that a political choice has to be made about how much money to throw at easing the price shock. Doing nothing is not plausible. Ofgem sets the price cap in early February and any support scheme for low-income households needs to be announced simultaneously. column4: 'Animals'];"New Hampshire police officers were engaged in a low-speed dog-chase on a highway along the state’s border with Vermont when they discovered that a real-life Lassie was leading them to rescue two men thrown from a truck and suffering from hypothermia. The driver
column5: Cam Laundry
column7: and his passenger
column8: Justin Connors
column10: were found injured but alive on Monday thanks to Tinsley
column11: Laundry’s canine companion. Another dog
column12: Connors’ bulldog
column13: was hit by a car and found dead on the side of the road after the accident. Captain Tim Cohen of the Lebanon police department said Laundry’s truck appeared to have fallen from the embankment into the woods “in such a way that it would not normally have been seen by a passing motorist”. “It’s pretty incredible that we were able to help these men
column14: not even knowing that they were there to begin with. It was a good stroke of luck
column15: ” Cohen said. “The dog definitely played a large part in this because it drew our attention to that area.” The two friends were heading back home from dinner before the car accident. Laundry was not wearing a seatbelt and was charged with driving under the influence. He called the incident “a wake-up call”. “I couldn’t believe the amount of intelligence she had to know that we were in distress and kind of do a Lassie-thing and go get help
column16: ” Laundry told the Guardian. “I’m still trying to recollect everything that happened. She’s a little guardian angel.”

column1: It was onlookers from the road that first alerted police to the loose German shepherd on a bridge. “Of course we care about the dog. We don’t want to see it get injured
column2: but it can also pose traffic hazards to motorists or pedestrians
column3: ” Cohen said. “We wanted to make sure the dog didn’t cause an accident
column4: especially on the interstate.”

column1: “[Tinsley] wouldn’t really get near anybody
column2: ” Cohen said. After chasing the dog for five to 10 minutes back and forth between New Hampshire and Vermont on the Veterans Memorial bridge
column3: police followed Tinsley to a gap in the road’s guardrail near the intersection of interstate of 89 and 91
column4: later revealed to be the scene of Laundry’s crash. Emergency services were immediately called. The Lebanon police chief
column5: Phillip Roberts
column6: said he had seen this behavior from police-trained dogs before
column7: but never from a household pet. Laundry is back home now and Connors is recovering from leg and neck surgeries in hospital. “I want my friend Justin to get better as soon as possible. Things could’ve been a lot worse than they were
column8: ” Laundry said. “We’re very fortunate to be here today because of my dog
column9: Tinsley.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/05/real-life-lassie-dog-rescue-new-hampshire;5

column4: 'Infectious diseases'];Two entrepreneurs with no apparent background in healthcare have made £20m – and could make tens of millions more – after landing roles as middlemen between the UK government and a US firm that won £3.7bn of contracts to supply lateral flow tests. Charles Palmer
column5: whose background is in property
column6: and Kim Thonger
column7: a former shoe retailer

column9: a business that had just £85 in the bank and debts of £3

column12: trading as Tried&Tested

column14: Dr Rachel Limbrey

column23: ” he said. “We had multiple calls within a 24-hour period. And they kept asking: can you really do this?” A leak of confidential documents in September 2020 revealed the existence of Operation Moonshot

column32: based in Harrow
column33: north-west London
column34: reportedly receives “a few pennies” for each test supplied by Innova
column35: an arrangement thought to be the reason for the £20m increase in its net assets

column5: 'US news'];"More than 40% of Americans still do not believe that Joe Biden legitimately won the 2020 presidential election despite no evidence of widespread voter fraud

column12: conducted from 1 to 5 January of this year

column16: nearly two-thirds or 63% said that the 6 January attack has at least temporarily changed the way they think about their democratic government. A third said that those changes are temporary. Nearly as many
column18: said that those changes are permanent. About 37% of those surveyed said they had lost faith in American democracy (48% of Republicans and 28% of Democrats)
column19: while 10% said they had never had faith in the system. Forty-nine percent said they did have faith. Fifty-eight per cent of Americans said they supported the investigative work of the House select committee investigating the riot. Eighty-eight percent of Democrats support the inquiry
column20: compared with 58% of independents and 32% of Republicans. Just slightly more than half of American adults
column22: said individuals associated with the insurrection should face criminal penalties if they refuse to comply with subpoenas. Republicans have also been revealed to be three or four more times as likely as Democrats to say voter fraud is a problem in their state

column25: and faith in American democracy.";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/05/america-biden-election-2020-poll-victory;1

column3: 'Africa'];"My aunt Anne Mobbs
column4: who has died aged 84
column5: was a community organiser and activist who was fully committed to promoting social justice. Born into a Jewish family in Tottenham
column6: north London
column7: Anne was one of the five children of Miriam (nee Weinberg)
column8: a seamstress
column9: and Nathan Wrightman
column10: a carpenter. She and her two sisters were evacuated to Cornwall during the second world war

column13: she quickly became an active CND member until
column14: with her husband
column15: David Mobbs

column1: Anne and her family also lived in Ghana and Zambia

column3: I was heavily influenced by Anne’s commitment to help those who were suffering in the harsh political climate. She also supported successful campaigns to get Oxford city council to disinvest its pension fund from apartheid South Africa. In her work as an assistant community relations officer in Oxford
column4: from 1975 onwards
column5: she helped to win racial discrimination cases and to organise support for initiatives celebrating black culture. From the late 1980s onwards
column6: Anne was Oxford city council’s Fun in the Parks festival organiser
column7: booking music
column8: bands
column9: circus acts
column10: comedians and stalls. She also helped to set up the annual Oxford international women’s festival
column11: raised the profile of the Oxford bail support group
column12: set up by Asylum Welcome to secure release of those held at Campsfield House detention centre
column13: and was a driving force behind the closure of the centre – garnering support from the band Radiohead. Even in retirement Anne could not resist getting involved
column14: supporting a local group in the Jericho area of Oxford
column15: where she lived. Anne and David separated in 1973 and divorced two years later. She is survived by her children
column16: Keir
column17: Ruth and Amanda

column10: 'Society'];"John Harris may be correct to frame the avoidance of vaccination by a significant portion of the UK population as the consequence of mistrust in authority or government (Understanding
column11: not judgment
column12: should shape our response to those who remain unjabbed
column13: 2 January). However
column14: I and many millions of others do not trust this government at all
column15: but we still accepted vaccination. Social factors may explain the existence of vaccine avoidance
column16: but they do not justify it. Under UK laws
column17: no degree of inequality allows a car driver to transfer to the right side of the road in protest against a mistrusted government. True freedom is the liberty from being harmed by others
column18: regardless of whether those actions are deliberately harmful. The freedom to “innocently” spread disease is not a fundamental right. The enormous human cost of supporting unvaccinated and seriously ill patients in hospital is having a direct impact on all our lives. It is time to take the moral high ground: celebrate the vaccinators and publicly avow that vaccination is good
column19: that being vaccinated is a public duty and that failure to comply by any citizen without adequate medical reasons is a dereliction of that public duty. Dr Patrick Byrne Bermondsey
column20: London • John Harris refers to the supposed “coercing [of] people into getting vaccinated using stringent Covid passports”. Having a Covid passport allows people to access certain defined services; if they don’t want to be vaccinated they won’t have access
column21: but no one is forcing them to such access. In any case
column22: there are many actual constraints on people that are a vital part of society
column23: such as wearing seatbelts. No one is being coerced into being vaccinated; this is simply the price for taking part in normal society. Dr Richard Carter Putney
column24: London • Maybe the unvaccinated do deserve our empathy
column25: not judgment
column26: but understanding and feeling their pain doesn’t solve the problem. The fact remains that they endanger themselves but
column27: much more importantly
column28: everybody else through their potential viral transmissibility. Insisting that access to certain venues and activities are limited to the fully jabbed might indeed imply a negative judgment
column29: but surely avoiding this possible offence is much less important than protecting the national community as a whole? Dr Bill Jones Beverley
column30: Yorkshire • John Harris risks oversimplifying people’s understanding of why some of us – around five million adults according to his article – remain unvaccinated in the UK. While there is plenty of evidence that people from particular communities mistrust the public institutions that wish to see them vaccinated
column31: this certainly isn’t the case for all five million of us. As a white
column32: middle-class public servant
column33: I can’t really be considered “historically mistrustful” of institutions
column34: nor am I reckless
column35: but I do have my own sincerely held reasons for not wanting to be vaccinated
column36: none of which are derived from “online cults”. Actually
column37: I don’t want judgment or empathy
column38: I just want there to be safe spaces for debate to take place
column39: where people need not fear being labelled cranks. This includes within national newspapers like the Guardian. As it is
column40: Mr Harris merely continues to promote the prevailing discourse – that in an ideal world everybody would be vaccinated. Paul Martin Berkhamsted
column41: Hertfordshire • Have an opinion on anything you’ve read in the Guardian today? Please email us your letter and it will be considered for publication.";https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/jan/05/vaccination-as-the-price-for-taking-part-in-society;7
