column5: 'Nursultan Nazarbayev'];"For years
column6: Nursultan Nazarbayev has been used to performative adoration from the citizens of Kazakhstan. The country’s leader for nearly three decades
column7: he was showered with praise and adulation at showpiece events
column8: and his image smiled down from billboards across the country.

column1: When he stepped down in 2019
column2: he was able to choose his successor
column3: Kassym-Jomart Tokayev
column4: and kept significant power as head of the security council and general behind-the-scenes powerbroker. He retained his official title of Elbasy
column5: or leader of the nation. Astana
column6: the capital city he ordered built in the heart of the Kazakh steppe
column7: was even renamed in his honour. To Nazarbayev
column8: it must have seemed like he had found an answer to the problem vexing ageing autocrats across the region: how to step aside in old age without risking retribution. Vladimir Putin and others were doubtless watching with interest. The events of the past few days might suggest that different lessons should be drawn. Statues of Nazarbayev
column9: meant to be monuments to his legacy
column10: have been torn down by protesters. Instead of chanting “Elbasy”
column11: many angry Kazakh protesters are now chanting “Shal ket” – or “Old man
column12: out!” Discontent at poverty
column13: inequality and corruption led to increasing unrest in the country in recent years
column14: and much of the anger is directed at Nazarbayev himself
column15: who for so long appeared untouchable. Among Central Asia’s vicious and repressive autocrats
column16: Nazarbayev always seemed the most nimble. Born in 1940
column17: he rose through the ranks of the Communist party and became Kazakhstan’s first leader on independence. He managed to hold the country together during the 1990s
column18: and later to avoid the extreme repressive violence of his peers in Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan
column19: while also avoiding the revolutionary sentiment of Kyrgyzstan. When 16 people were killed in 2011 protests
column20: he solicited advice from Tony Blair about how best to spin the violence. He charted a delicate geopolitical course in the years after Kazakh independence
column21: remaining friendly towards Russia
column22: while also courting western leaders and energy companies
column23: who turned a blind eye to the lack of democracy and instead focused on securing lucrative contracts in the country. Western lawyers
column24: accountants and advisers helped the new Kazakh elite invest their fortunes in London mansions and Swiss villas. His daughter and grandson are believed to own £80m of London property. Nazarbayev also engaged a steady stream of western architects and urban planners to build his new capital city. In 2010
column25: Nazarbayev
column26: perhaps with one eye on the clock
column27: ordered scientists to investigate the creation of an “elixir” that could prolong human life. Eventually
column28: it seems
column29: he accepted the inevitability of the human ageing process and announced in 2019 he was stepping aside. Last year
column30: the director Oliver Stone made a hagiographic film portrait about Nazarbayev’s time in office
column31: named Qazaq: History of the Golden Man
column32: and numerous statues to the retired leader were erected across the country. Now
column33: his image has become a lightning rod for discontent. On Wednesday
column34: Tokayev announced he was replacing Nazarbayev as chair of the security council
column35: and there were rumours on Wednesday that Nazarbayev might leave the country for “medical treatment”. It is not clear yet how the unrest in Kazakhstan will evolve
column36: and what role Nazarbayev will play in them
column37: but it seems certain that the events of the past few days will alter the historical legacy he had imagined he would leave.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/old-man-out-kazakhstan-discontent-to-change-leaders-legacy;1

column12: 'Health'];"Comparing the experience of European education systems in handling the Covid-19 pandemic is doubtless instructive (Masks in schools: several EU countries already enforce them in primaries
column13: 3 January). Your article presents the salutary examples of countries such as France
column14: which imposed a mask mandate on all pupils over 11 last November
column15: and Belgium
column16: which since December has required all pupils over six to be masked. However
column17: as an educational comparativist usually based in Japan
column18: I read reports like this while inwardly screaming: “What about east Asia?” There has been some lurid coverage in the UK press of China’s draconian lockdowns. But we see very little discussion of the very different cases of Taiwan
column19: South Korea and Japan
column20: which have managed the pandemic far more effectively than their western counterparts
column21: and with far less disruption to schooling. This is especially so in Japan
column22: where all primary and secondary pupils have worn masks at school (including in the classroom) since the onset of the pandemic. During that time
column23: Japanese pupils have missed a total of just four to five weeks of face-to-face teaching. Edward Vickers Kyushu University
column24: Japan; visiting professor
column25: UCL Institute of Education • In light of the reintroduction of face coverings to secondary school classrooms this week
column26: it is of course true to say teenagers are resilient
column27: demonstrating endless adaptability. But spare a thought for deaf schoolchildren who can’t lip-read or understand facial expressions when face masks are being worn. They have faced challenge upon challenge since the start of the pandemic
column28: isolating during everyday life
column29: facing cancelled exams and enduring online lessons without subtitles. Thousands of deaf secondary-aged pupils will be filled with a sense of dread about the reintroduction of face coverings in class as they return to school. Public health should always be prioritised
column30: but deaf children’s inclusion in society matters too. We cannot continue to see deaf children falling behind their classmates and their mental health suffering where a few simple adjustments and more sensitivity from the public would make all the difference. Jo Campion Deputy director of advocacy

column10: 'Mapping technologies'];An Italian mafia boss on the run for 20 years was tracked down to a Spanish town after being spotted on Google Street View. Gioacchino Gammino
column11: a convicted murderer listed among Italy’s most wanted gangsters
column12: was arrested in Galapagar
column13: a town near Madrid
column14: where over the years he had married
column15: changed his name to Manuel
column16: worked as a chef and owned a fruit and vegetable shop. Sicilian police carried out several investigations in their search for Gammino
column18: and a European arrest warrant was issued in 2014. The fugitive was traced to Spain
column19: but it was Google Street View that helped to pinpoint his precise location. The navigation tool
column20: accessible through Google Maps
column21: had captured an image of two men chatting outside a fruit and vegetable shop called El Huerto de Manu
column22: or Manu’s Garden
column23: in Galapagar. Police believed one of the men closely resembled Gammino
column24: but his identity was only confirmed when they came across a listing for a nearby restaurant called La Cocina de Manu or Manu’s Kitchen. The shop and the restaurant are now closed
column25: but the police found a photo of Gammino
column26: dressed in his chef’s garb
column27: on a still-existing Facebook page for La Cocina de Manu. He was recognisable by the scar on the left side of his chin. The restaurant’s menu included a dish called Cena Siciliana or Sicilian dinner. Gammino was arrested on 17 December but the details surrounding his capture did not come to light until they were reported by La Repubblica on Wednesday. The details were confirmed by the Palermo prosecutor Francesco Lo Voi
column28: who led the latest investigation. “It’s not as if we spend our days wading through Google Maps to find fugitives
column29: ” he told the Guardian. “There were many previous and long investigations
column30: which led us to Spain. We were on a good path
column31: with Google Maps helping to confirm our investigations.” After 20 years in hiding
column32: Gammino thought he had managed to sever all his ties with Sicily. Upon his arrest
column33: he reportedly told police: “How did you find me? I haven’t even called my family for 10 years!” Gammino belonged to a mafia clan in Agrigento
column34: Sicily
column35: which was caught up in a bloody feud with Cosa Nostra
column36: Sicily’s main mafia network
column37: in the 1990s. He was first arrested in 1984
column38: when he was investigated by the anti-mafia judge Giovanni Falcone
column39: who was assassinated by the mafia in a car bomb in 1992. Gammino was wanted for murder and various other mafia-related crimes. He was arrested for a second time in Barcelona in 1998. He had been serving a life sentence at Rebibbia prison in Rome when
column41: he managed to escape during the commotion of the making of a film at the prison. It is not the first time a mafia fugitive has been caught with the help of the web. In March last year

column13: 'UK news'];"Turn on the radio or scroll down your phone and the big headlines belong to Covid. But when this latest version of the plague drops off the front pages
column14: another story is set to take its place – and this one will hang around for most of the year
column15: setting the terms of trade at Westminster and possibly deciding Boris Johnson’s future. The cost of living is about to shape our politics in a way that it hasn’t for decades. You can spot the buildup this week
column16: from Keir Starmer’s warning of a crisis to Tory backbenchers clamouring for Johnson to act now on high fuel bills. And you can already see the misery in the stories about how Britons now wrap themselves up in blankets and turn on their hairdryers to keep warm
column17: rather than run the central heating. Over the next few weeks
column18: the crisis will only grow. On 7 February the energy watchdog
column19: Ofgem
column20: sets the new maximum price for energy bills. Utility firm bosses are warning that the cap could easily go above £2
column22: twice what it was last winter. Experts at the National Energy Action charity have warned that fuel poverty could rise to its highest levels since John Major was in No 10
column23: with about 6 million households having to choose between heating and eating
column24: or paying the bus fare or buying sanitary pads. This means 2 million households
column25: which as recently as last autumn were still keeping their heads above water
column26: will sink when the new cap kicks in on 1 April. At just that point
column27: taxes go up too. National insurance will rise
column28: as will council tax across much of the country
column29: alongside a stealth increase in income tax bills. Put all that together and the Resolution Foundation warns that the average household stands to lose an extra £1
column30: 200 a year. To this we can add the effect of higher petrol prices. These bills will pile up while wages and benefits are falling in real terms. It is a recipe for widespread deprivation and massive political turbulence. It also blows apart the electoral coalition that handed Johnson his landslide. In true-blue Woking
column31: only 6% of households are in fuel poverty; in Workington
column32: by contrast
column33: which went Tory only in 2019
column34: that proportion is nearly 14%. My bet has long been that boring old economics will inflict far more damage on Boris Johnson than baroque politics. Most critics of the Sun King have spent the days since 2019 attacking his rule-breaking
column35: his brinkmanship with Brussels
column36: his sheer bad behaviour. Until the revelations about the parties at No 10
column37: hardly any of it landed with a public that is wearily well used to a political class trashing norms to fill its boots; just ask the Right Hon Member for Greensill Capital. But all those voters
column38: left unmoved by 42-point headlines and stinging op-eds
column39: are far more likely to be mobilised by the largest tax burden in 70 years
column40: swingeing cuts to frontline services and surging inflation. No wonder the government can barely quell its anxiety. The business secretary
column41: Kwasi Kwarteng
column42: has been meeting energy bosses in a series of emergency summits
column43: the latest held on Wednesday
column44: while Chancellor Rishi Sunak’s team has been grumbling to journalists about having to stump up for any of this. Still
column45: with only a month to go before the Ofgem announcement
column46: no deal is on the table. What’s odd is that Johnson has himself pledged one such remedy. Co-writing an article in the Sun less than a month before the EU referendum of 2016
column47: he vowed that Brexit would mean the end of VAT on fuel bills. “We will be able to scrap this unfair and damaging tax
column48: ” Mr Leave wrote . “It isn’t right that unelected bureaucrats in Brussels impose taxes on the poorest and elected British politicians can do nothing.” A whole two and a half years since becoming prime minister
column49: he has done precisely nothing. This week he squirmed on TV that cutting VAT was a “blunt instrument” that wouldn’t direct help towards those in most dire financial need. Fancy that! If only someone had warned us that this guy reneges on a deal. But if Starmer wants to capitalise on this moment
column50: he needs to do far better than make nothingy speeches larded with abstract nouns and bedecked with flags. Labour wants to scrap the 5% VAT rate on energy bills
column51: but in truth it’s small change: £10 back on a £200 monthly bill. Better would be to call for a windfall tax on gas and oil companies
column52: which have been making a killing as fuel prices rise
column53: and direct that money to the least well-off. If Labour can take that position early and loud enough
column54: they’ll reap rewards when the Tories copy them. They can also point to the failures of the energy market – the collapse of 26 suppliers and the consolidation of their customer base back into the hands of the big six – as grounds to try something new: to use the public sector to direct more investment into nationally secure renewables. This is a generation of politicians that has never faced an inflation shock but is nevertheless haunted by the mythology around what happened in the 1970s. With good reason: Thatcher used that episode finally to dismantle the Keynesian welfare state and to exile the left for more than a decade. The right is already reheating those old arguments about how inflation and higher interest rates must mean reduced public spending
column55: and how taxpayers don’t want to pay for “green crap” and reducing poverty. It is essential that the left counter those points now. This isn’t the 70s
column56: and there is no danger of a wage-price spiral. This is a workforce that has just emerged from the worst squeeze on living standards since Napoleon marched across Europe – and it is just about to enter another one. It’s not the labour force that isn’t working: it’s the markets and the supply chain. Those are what need to be fixed. Aditya Chakrabortty is a Guardian columnist and senior economics commentator";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/05/cost-of-living-crisis-british-politics-2022-energy-bills-tax-rises-boris-johnson;5

column6: 'US news'];"John Salt
column7: who has died aged 84
column8: was a pioneer of photorealist painting
column9: a genre that emerged in late 1960s America
column10: in part
column11: like its predecessor pop art
column12: as a response to abstract expressionism. The paintings were of photographs of random subjects
column13: enlarged and rendered in such detail that they themselves could be mistaken for photographs. John was British but
column14: while living in the US
column15: and painting photographs of cars and trailer homes
column16: he became identified with the American photorealist movement. Like other artists around the same time
column17: John chose the photograph as his subject matter because there was no preconceived idea of how it should be represented. When looking at one of John’s paintings it is not his picture of a car
column18: but his picture of a photograph of a car
column19: that we see. The more photograph-like the painting
column20: the more essential it is to view the painting itself
column21: rather than a reproduction
column22: in order to assess
column23: for instance
column24: scale
column25: colour and texture. Within three years of having arrived in the US John joined Ivan Karp at his newly opened OK Harris gallery in New York in 1970
column26: and with Karp’s encouragement John’s career took off. For the next 25 years
column27: he showed regularly in New York and across the US and Europe. John was among the photorealists included in the 1972 Documenta 5 exhibition in Germany
column28: where the curator Harald Szeemann introduced photorealism to Europe.

column1: Photorealism conveyed the everyday and derived from its source material a sense of the chance configuration of captured moments. It was dismissed by US critics as shallow
column2: in that beyond the technical prowess required to produce a painting identical to a photograph
column3: there remained little of interest – and limited imagination and a minimal knowledge of art was needed to appreciate it. In the UK
column4: photorealism was similarly received by the art establishment. Apart from a 1973 group show at the Serpentine Gallery in London
column5: curated by the critic and writer Lawrence Alloway
column6: there were few exhibitions of photorealist work until 1975
column7: when John had his first major UK solo show in his hometown of Birmingham
column8: at the Ikon Gallery
column9: where I was then the director. Soon afterwards
column10: John and his family returned to the UK to live in rural Shropshire. Despite the physical distance he continued to paint predominantly American imagery. John was born in Birmingham
column11: the only child of Amy (nee Evans) and Cyril Salt
column12: who ran a garage. He studied at Birmingham School of Art (1952-57) at the same time as Peter Phillips and John Walker
column13: under Gilbert Mason and Kate Fryer
column14: and when strong drawing and technical skills were prerequisites for a career as an artist. He went on to the Slade School of Art in London (1958-60)
column15: under William Coldstream. His work then was abstract and frequently in collage
column16: with influences from Francis Bacon
column17: Prunella Clough and Alan Davie. He was drawn to work by Jim Dine
column18: James Rosenquist and Robert Rauschenberg and out of this interest arose an ambition to see the US. Shortly after he married Jean Arnold
column19: a science teacher
column21: the couple decided to spend a couple of years in the US. John was offered a scholarship for the master’s programme at the Maryland Institute College of Art in Baltimore
column22: which also included a paid teaching post. The head of its graduate school was the abstract expressionist painter Grace Hartigan
column23: who became John’s mentor and
column24: together with the figurative artist Alex Katz
column25: she was largely responsible for encouraging him to remain in the US. It was at this time that John’s new work
column26: using images from car sales brochures and later 35mm colour transparencies
column27: emerged. Using handcut lace-like paper stencils and a spray gun
column28: he produced paintings of wrecked and abandoned cars and trailer homes. John’s work became recognised as among the most sensitively produced of that first wave of this new school. In 2014 OK Harris closed and John joined the Louis K Meisel gallery in New York. His work was included in Picturing America: Photorealism in the 1970s
column29: at the Deutsche Guggenheim in Berlin in 2009
column30: and Photorealism: 50 years of Hyperrealistic Painting
column31: which travelled to several European cities
column32: including Birmingham
column33: in 2013. He continued painting until 2018 when failing health – including dementia and parkinsonism – began to take its toll. He leaves a body of work that
column34: according to Linda Chase
column35: author of John Salt: The Complete Works 1969-2006 (2007)
column36: “transmogrifies the ugly into the beautiful
column37: the discarded into the treasured
column38: and gives us new eyes with which to view and appreciate our world. These paintings impress with their mastery and verisimilitude but continue to engage with their mystery.” John is survived by Jean and their daughter
column39: Katy
column40: son
column41: Thomas
column42: and four grandchildren. • John Salt
column43: artist
column44: born 2 August 1937; died 13 December 2021";https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2022/jan/05/john-salt-obituary;5

column3: 'Ireland'];"My grandmother Maureen Byrne
column4: who has died aged 86 of lung cancer
column5: was devoted to her family and was a much-loved member of the Irish community in Wood Green
column6: north London. She was a devout Catholic and followed the words often attributed to Mother Teresa: “If you want to change the world
column7: go home and love your family.” Born Ann Dalton in Cabra
column8: Dublin
column9: but always known as Maureen
column10: she was one of nine children of Annie (nee Foy) and Michael Dalton
column11: a tailor. Two siblings died in infancy and her mother died when Maureen was 10. Maureen was educated in Dublin. She was always fiercely protective of her siblings. According to family legend
column12: once
column13: when her sister Carmel was bullied at school aged eight
column14: Maureen
column15: just a year or two older
column16: confronted the perpetrators. At the age of 18 she contracted tuberculosis and spent three years in isolation. After recovering
column17: in the late 1950s Maureen joined thousands who moved from Ireland to London in search of work. She took various jobs
column18: including
column19: for a time
column20: at a chocolate factory. In 1960
column21: while visiting her brother
column22: Maureen went to the Queen Adelaide pub
column23: Shepherd’s Bush
column24: where she met the head barman
column25: a quiet Waterford man named Tony Byrne. They married in 1960 and settled in Wood Green. Tony worked as a cleaner on the London Underground. Maureen and Tony had five children. When they had all started school she went to work part-time at Zetters football pools in Clerkenwell. As the children grew up and married
column26: Maureen loved their wives
column27: husbands and partners as though they were her own. She went to St Paul’s Catholic church in Wood Green for more than 60 years and made many friends in the Irish community. At the local community centre Maureen joined other women of a similar age; they encouraged each other to take up exercise and they all enjoyed the companionship on offer. Maureen was an avid watcher of Coronation Street and Emmerdale
column28: and a fan of Catherine Cookson novels. She loved to entertain people and to make them laugh
column29: enjoyed a pint of lager
column30: and had a keen sense of mischief. When asked by a grandchild why she never went to confession
column31: Maureen responded: “I have never sinned
column32: so I have nothing to confess.” In recent years Maureen had suffered from thyroid illness and diabetes
column33: and underwent heart surgery. She was diagnosed with lung cancer in 2018. She never lost her zest for life or her sense of fun. Maureen is survived by Tony

column37: and by a brother

column39: and sister

column10: and the deliberations of the secretive members of the judging panel at the Swedish Academy
column11: are kept confidential for 50 years. But the newly opened archives show that

column13: behind the scenes some members of the Swedish Academy were hesitant. They questioned how works such as Neruda’s odes to Stalin fitted with Alfred Nobel’s stipulation that the prize go to “the person who shall have produced in the field of literature the most outstanding work in an ideal direction” – according to journalist Kaj Schueler
column14: who researched the Swedish Academy’s documents from 1971 for the Swedish newspaper Svenska Dagbladet. While the Nobel committee chair Anders Österling praised Neruda’s “poetic natural power and dynamic vitality”
column15: he questioned whether “the increasingly dominant communist tendency in his poetry is compatible with the purpose of the Nobel prize”. Neruda
column16: known for his passionate
column17: romantic poetry
column18: was also a leftwing politician and diplomat
column19: and close friend of President Salvador Allende. Neruda died days after Augusto Pinochet’s military coup in 1973
column20: under circumstances that have since been investigated. “A writer’s way of thinking – whether Marxist
column21: syndicalist
column22: anarchist or something else – belongs to his free right. However
column23: Neruda is fully politically involved
column24: including through his hymns to Stalin and other purely propagandistic achievements. On that basis
column25: I have reservations about his candidacy
column26: without
column27: however
column28: wanting to firmly reject it in advance
column29: ” wrote Österling in 1963 – an opinion that he continued to hold in 1971
column30: according to Schueler.

column1: Österling had previously spoken out against the candidacy of Ezra Pound because he “propagates ideas of a nature that is definitely contrary to the spirit of the Nobel prize”
column2: and Samuel Beckett
column3: because of his nihilism. Österling was eventually persuaded of Neruda’s merits
column4: and Beckett won the prize in 1969
column5: but Pound never did. The opening of the archives also shows that WH Auden
column6: James Baldwin
column7: Philip Larkin and Jorge Luis Borges were all nominated for the 1971 award. Auden made the shortlist
column8: along with Patrick White
column9: André Malraux and Eugenio Montale. White (in 1973) and Montale (1975) would later win
column10: but Malraux and Auden never did. The list of 90 writers nominated for the 1971 Nobel includes just one woman: the Estonian poet Marie Under.";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/05/pablo-neruda-nobel-prize-almost-denied-odes-to-stalin;5

column9: and Shakib Sana
column10: a GP
column11: was given a national number last month and has been inundated with inquiries. Staffed mainly by volunteer medical students from rooms made available in the university hospitals of Utrecht
column12: Amsterdam
column13: Nijmegen
column14: Maastricht and Rotterdam
column15: the service has met “an extraordinary response”
column16: Peeters said. He told the Dutch public broadcaster NOS that there appeared to be more “doubters” than anti-vaxxers among the unvaccinated population. “The more you can help people come to a decision and limit hospital admissions
column17: the better
column18: ” he said. Peeters said callers to the line
column19: which is open from 8.30am to 4.30pm
column20: fell into three main categories. First

column23: as well as possible side-effects. The answers to many such specific questions could not be found on government information websites
column24: he said. “The strength of a telephone helpline is that people can call anonymously and ask independent medical professionals

column1: Before Christmas the line received 4
column2: 400 calls over five days

column6: gynaecologists and allergists – for more specific information. “The aim is to give every caller an appropriate and correct answer
column7: ” Peeters said. Conversations with the few committed anti-vaxxers who call are kept as short as possible
column8: with the students trained to always ask whether the caller has a specific medical question. If not
column9: they move on to the next caller. The objective is expressly not to pressure anyone into getting vaccinated

column1: 154;154;5396;5396;Tigrayans deported by Saudis ‘forcibly disappeared’ in Ethiopia – rights group;2022-01-05T17:10:08Z;['Katie McQue'];['Human rights'
column2: 'Global development'
column3: 'Migration'
column4: 'World news'
column5: 'Ethiopia'
column6: 'Saudi Arabia'
column7: 'Africa'
column8: 'Middle East and north Africa'
column9: 'Conflict and arms'];"Thousands of Tigrayans are being deported from Saudi Arabia and held in secret detention sites in Ethiopia
column10: according to Human Rights Watch. In a new report
column11: the international rights organisation says it has identified two detention sites where thousands of people from the war-torn Tigray region of Ethiopia are being mistreated and forcibly disappeared. The sites
column12: identified via satellite imagery
column13: videos and witness accounts
column14: in the towns of Semera and Shone are most likely used to detain Tigrayan deportees
column15: HRW said. The HRW report also includes testimony from returnees who claim that they were abused and beaten while in custody in Saudi Arabia.

column1: “Tigrayan migrants who have experienced horrific abuse in Saudi custody are being locked up in detention facilities upon returning to Ethiopia
column2: ” said Nadia Hardman
column3: refugee and migrant rights researcher at Human Rights Watch. “Saudi Arabia should offer protection to Tigrayans at risk
column4: while Ethiopia should release all arbitrarily detained Tigrayan deportees
column5: ” she said. Hundreds of thousands of Ethiopians have migrated over the past decade
column6: travelling by boat across the Red Sea and then by land through Yemen to Saudi Arabia. The causes of this migration include conflict
column7: economic hardship
column8: drought and human rights abuses. In January 2021
column9: the Ethiopian government announced it would cooperate in the repatriation of 40
column10: 000 of its nationals detained in Saudi Arabia. About 40% of the returnees from Saudi Arabia between November 2020 and June 2021 were Tigrayan
column11: according to HRW. The 23 Tigrayans interviewed for the report are undocumented migrant workers who were rounded up in Saudi Arabia and say they were also subjected to abuses there
column12: including beatings and overcrowding. Many spent up to six years in formal and informal detention facilities in the kingdom. After being deported to Ethiopia
column13: they were held in facilities throughout the country
column14: HRW said: in centres across Addis Ababa; in Semera
column15: Afar region; in Shone
column16: in a state known as Southern Nations
column17: Nationalities and Peoples’ region; and in Jimma
column18: Oromia region. Trhas*
column19: a 33-year-old Tigrayan woman who was deported from Saudi Arabia in December 2020
column20: told HRW that Ethiopian federal police stopped her at a checkpoint at Awash Sebat
column21: Afar
column22: and put her on a bus to what she describes as a “military camp” in Shone. “We asked the federal police for food and water and the toilet
column23: but we were beaten if we left our seats
column24: ” she said
column25: describing the 36-hour bus ride to the camp. “They said
column26: ‘Bandits don’t need food.’” In 2021
column27: the Guardian exposed Saudi Arabia’s mass mistreatment of undocumented African migrants
column28: exacerbated by the pandemic
column29: at al-Shumaisi detention centre near Jeddah. Detainees interviewed at the time said they were subjected to a litany of abuses including insufficient food and water
column30: unsanitary conditions
column31: denial of medical care
column32: and extortion by the centre’s guards.

column1: Nearly all interviewees said that Saudi authorities had arrested and detained them because of their irregular immigration status
column2: but that the authorities did not provide legal justifications for their detention
column3: nor allow them access to a lawyer or to challenge their detention. Prolonged detention without access to judicial review violates international law. Saudi Arabia is not party to the United Nations’ Convention on Refugees
column4: and has long drawn international criticism for not having an asylum system. “Saudi Arabia should stop contributing to this abuse by ending the forced return of Tigrayans to Ethiopia and allowing them to seek asylum or resettlement in third countries
column5: ” said Hardman.

column1: A conflict in the Tigray region
column2: in Northern Ethiopia
column3: between Ethiopian federal government and allied forces and those affiliated with the region’s former ruling party
column4: the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF) began in November 2020. Since then
column5: rights groups and the media have documented numerous abuses including massacres
column6: mass displacement
column7: sexual violence
column8: arbitrary arrests and blocking of humanitarian relief. The Saudi Arabian government’s Centre for International Communication and the Ethiopian government’s Communication Service did not respond to requests for comment. *Names in the HRW report have been changed to protect the identity of those interviewed. column7: 'Slavery'];"1636: Edward Colston is born into a merchant family in Bristol. In 1680 he becomes becomes a leading shareholder in the Royal African Company
column8: which has a monopoly in the trade in enslaved people. He dies in 1721
column9: having donated about £70
column10: 000 – equivalent to millions in today’s money – to Bristol
column11: helping to establish a number of the city’s oldest institutions. 1895: A statue of Colston is erected in Bristol “by popular subscription”. A plaque attached to its plinth says: “Erected by the citizens of Bristol as a memorial to one of the most virtuous and wise sons of their city.” Attempts to raise money for the memorial from Bristolians are largely unsuccessful and the monument ends up being financed by the wealthy Bristol publisher James Williams Arrowsmith.

column1: 1921: Rev H J Wilkins publishes a short book based on archival research that acknowledges Colston as a slave trader. Wilkins is the first in the modern era to question the image built around Colston and to ask if such veneration is appropriate for a man who traded in human beings. 1973: In response to historical silence surrounding the 600th anniversary of Bristol as a city and county
column2: Derek Robinson writes A Shocking History of Bristol
column3: exposing Colston as a leading financier of the slave trade and drawing attention to his continued celebration in annual rituals. May 1996: Complaints pour in after Bristol’s Festival of the Sea fails almost entirely to mention the city’s role in the slave trade
column4: with multicultural arts groups launching a counter Anti-Festival of the Sea. The Bristol trip hop band Massive Attack announce they are boycotting Colston Hall over its association with the slave trader. January 1998: The first direct action against the Colston statue takes place
column5: with “fuck off slave trader” painted on the statue overnight in red paint. Days later a Bristol councillor
column6: Ray Sefia
column7: said he could understand why the statue was targeted. “It’s like having a monument to Hitler
column8: ” he told the Bristol Post. “We have to be very clear about Colston’s role in the slave trade.”

column1: September-October 2007: Protests outside Colston Hall are orchestrated by activists angry at the venue being used to host events celebrating the bicentenary of the end of the slave trade. The protests
column2: some months after renewed calls by civil rights campaigners to rename the hall
column3: come as a number of public debates are held re-examining Colston’s legacy. July 2018: Bristol council agrees to attach a new plaque to the Colston statue to make clear his “active role in the enslavement of over 84
column4: 000 Africans”. However
column5: after an intervention by Bristol’s Society of Merchant Venturers
column6: the wording of the plaque is watered down. Bristol’s mayor
column7: Marvin Rees
column8: responds to the re-wording by blocking its installation. October 2018: The Bristol MP Thangam Debbonaire calls for the removal of the statue of Edward Colston. Days later an art installation made up of concrete figures depicting enslaved Africans packed into a slave ship appears in front of the statue of Colston. 25 May 2020: A Minneapolis police officer
column9: Derek Chauvin
column10: kneels on the neck of George Floyd
column11: an African American man
column12: for eight minutes and 40 seconds until Floyd is dead. The murder
column13: which is captured on video
column14: sparks worldwide anti-racist protests under the banner of Black Lives Matter. 7 June 2020: The statue of Colston is pulled from its plinth
column15: rolled to Bristol harbour and thrown into the River Avon by a crowd of thousands taking part in a Black Lives Matter protest. In the following days
column16: Colston girls’ school removes a half-size replica of the statue
column17: his name is removed from buildings in Bristol and his likeness taken from church stained glass windows. In London the mayor
column18: Sadiq Khan
column19: orders a review of statues connected with slavery in the capital. 25 January 2021: Jake Skuse
column20: Rhian Graham
column21: Milo Ponsford and Sage Willoughby are charged with damaging the statue and plinth “with each other and others unknown without lawful excuse”. 13 December 2021: The Colston 4 go on trial at Bristol crown court accused of criminal damage. 5 January 2022: All four defendants are cleared of criminal damage after jurors are urged by the defence to “be on the right side of history”. Source: Bristol Radical History Group";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/colston-timeline-of-protest-against-one-slave-trader;1

column7: 'Vladimir Putin'];"The European Union’s top diplomat has pledged “full support” to Ukraine on a visit to the frontline of the country’s war with Moscow-backed separatists. Josep Borrell is the first EU high representative for foreign policy to have visited the Donbass region since war broke out nearly eight years ago. “We are here first to reaffirm European Union’s full support to Ukraine’s independence
column8: sovereignty and territorial integrity
column9: ” he told journalists. “Any military aggression against Ukraine will have messy consequences and severe costs
column10: ” he said
column11: echoing recent declarations of EU leaders. Ukraine’s foreign minister
column12: Dmytro Kuleba
column13: who accompanied Borrell on a helicopter trip to the Luhansk region
column14: hailed the visit as historic. It was
column15: he said
column16: a “sign of Ukraine-EU unity in the face of elevated Russian threats”.

column1: Borrell visited Stanytsia Luhanska
column2: a village and crossing point on the frontline that has endured years of shelling in the conflict with Russian-backed separatists. Tensions have escalated as tens of thousands of Russian troops have massed along the border with Ukraine. “The conflict on the borders is on the verge of getting deeper and tensions have been building up with regard to European security as a whole
column3: ” Borrell said. The EU has been searching for a role in the conflict before a series of crucial meetings next week aiming to reduce the temperature between Moscow and the west. Officials from Russia and the US will gather in Geneva next Monday
column4: followed by a Nato-Russia council two days later
column5: with talks then moving to the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE).

column1: Meanwhile Germany has stepped up its own diplomacy. Berlin is sending German chancellor Olaf Scholz’s foreign policy adviser
column2: Jens Plötner
column3: to Moscow
column4: and on Wednesday
column5: the foreign minister
column6: Annalena Baerbock
column7: met the US secretary of state
column8: Antony Blinken
column9: in Washington to present a common front on Ukraine. “We jointly reiterated that Russian actions and activities come with a clear price tag
column10: and a renewed violation of Ukrainian sovereignty by Russia would have severe consequences
column11: ” Baerbock said. She did not specifically address the question of whether the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline project would be blocked in the event of a Ukrainian invasion
column12: but did say Germany would abide by an agreement with the US last summer that Russia would not be allowed to use energy as a political weapon against Europe. “We agreed on this
column13: together with our European partners
column14: that we would take effective measures together with our European partners
column15: should Russia use energy as a weapon or should it continue its aggressive acts against Ukraine
column16: ” Baerbock said. Blinken said the pipeline gave the EU leverage over Russia
column17: rather than the other way round. “If Russia renews its aggression toward Ukraine
column18: it would certainly be difficult to see gas flowing through it in the future
column19: ” he said. Paris is dispatching Plötner’s French counterpart
column20: Emmanuel Bonne
column21: to Moscow
column22: while France’s foreign minister
column23: Jean-Yves Le Drian
column24: called for close cooperation among Europeans in relations with Russia. “A demanding dialogue with Russia on the basis of parameters that we judge conform to our collective security interests is useful and necessary to reinforce strategic stability in Europe
column25: ” he said in a statement issued on Wednesday. Le Drian is due to host EU foreign ministers in Brest next week for further talks on how to handle relations with Moscow. Earlier this year
column26: France and Germany provoked fury among other EU members by calling for a summit with Vladimir Putin. Poland and the Baltic states rejected the idea
column27: arguing it would not change the Russian president’s behaviour. Instead the EU agreed to explore further economic sanctions against Russia
column28: but a paper on that subject drawn up by EU officials is yet to see the light of day. Despite Ukraine’s pleas for preventive sanctions
column29: EU officials oppose revealing any possible actions against Russia
column30: fearing it could deepen tensions. Discussing sanctions would also be likely to exacerbate divisions among EU member states on how to respond to Russia. The EU and US blame Moscow for provoking a crisis by massing tens of thousands of troops at the border with Ukraine and have threatened “massive consequences” if Russia invades. The Kremlin has called for guarantees that Ukraine will never be a Nato member and says the alliance should remove troops and weapons from EU member states bordering Russia
column31: demands dismissed as unacceptable by European leaders.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/top-eu-diplomat-offers-full-support-to-ukraine-on-visit-to-conflict-frontline;1

column3: 'Coronavirus'
column4: 'US education'];"Covid-19 hospitalizations among children in the US are soaring
column5: fueled by the Omicron variant and the holidays
column6: and adding pressure to already-strained health systems and schools. An average of 672 children were being hospitalized every day in the US
column7: as of 2 January - more than double the average just a week before. And the rate is rapidly increasing.

column1: Cases are also rising. There were more than 325
column2: 000 new cases among kids in the week ending 23 December
column3: a 64% increase from the previous week and nearly double the cases two weeks earlier
column4: the American Academy of Pediatrics reported on Monday. The increases appear to be driven by the more contagious nature of the Omicron variant and low vaccination rates among children over the age of five years old. As with adults
column5: early evidence appears to show that Omicron also largely causes mild illness in kids. Nonetheless
column6: experts are urging the use of every possible precaution
column7: including tests
column8: masks
column9: vaccinations and even temporary delays in reopening schools to curb both cases and staff shortages. “We have about four times as many children admitted currently as we have had in any other wave
column10: ” Dr Elaine Cox
column11: the chief medical officer for Riley Children’s Health in Indiana
column12: told reporters on Tuesday. They are also seeing the severity rise among the children who are admitted to the hospital
column13: Cox said. “So there are more of them
column14: and they are sicker.” More than half the hospitalized children have had to spend time in the intensive care unit
column15: and at least 40% of those kids need to be put on a ventilator
column16: she said. More than 1
column17: 000 kids have died in the US from Covid during the pandemic so far
column18: according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). More than 830
column19: 000 people have died in the US from Covid so far. In New York
column20: hospitalizations among kids quadrupled. In Washington DC
column21: children’s hospital admissions have roughly doubled. In Texas
column22: children’s hospitalizations were described as “staggering”. In Alabama
column23: cases were “like a rocket ship”. In Louisiana
column24: one doctor said: “We’ve never seen anything like it.” In Ohio
column25: one associate professor of internal medicine and pediatrics critical care recently told ABC news: “We’re on fire.” Hospitals are shooting past the peaks of previous surges
column26: many of them driven by the Omicron variant. In South Africa
column27: children and teens accounted for 17% of hospital admissions during the Omicron wave
column28: compared to 4% during the second wave and 3.5% during the third
column29: which was fueled by the Delta variant. Cox said she had also seen a sharp uptick in cases among pregnant people and newborns. In addition to Covid
column30: hospitals are also seeing a dangerous wave of RSV (respiratory syncytial virus) and the flu this year
column31: creating a triple threat of respiratory illness. At the same time
column32: health workers are also getting breakthrough infections with Omicron
column33: creating staff shortages. “We have significant numbers of our staff who are becoming ill with Covid
column34: so they can’t work
column35: ” Cox said. Indiana is one of the states calling in the national guard to help with hospital care and logistics. School systems across the country are also balancing soaring cases
column36: among students and staff
column37: and weighing virtual options. Leaders of Chicago public schools
column38: the country’s third-largest school network
column39: canceled classes on Wednesday after the teachers’ union voted to switch to remote learning due to the surge in Covid cases. In late December
column40: Joe Biden urged the widespread use of tools to combat the virus
column41: including tests and vaccines. “We can keep our K-through-12 schools open
column42: and that’s exactly what we should be doing
column43: ” he said. In Washington DC
column44: which has some of the highest rates of Covid in the country
column45: all students and staff are now required to take a rapid test before returning to school – one of the few districts in the country with this requirement. But schools in neighboring Montgomery county
column46: Maryland
column47: which has also been hit hard with new cases and hospitalizations
column48: are recommending
column49: not requiring
column50: tests for students and staff. Tests have been difficult to find in many places. “We have tools now that we didn’t have last year
column51: that will allow us to keep schools open if we deploy those tools in the best possible way
column52: ” said Brian Castrucci
column53: who is the president and CEO of the de Beaumont Foundation
column54: a former state and local health official
column55: and the parent to school-aged kids in Montgomery county. “We’re dealing with trying to make sure that schools are operational
column56: that there are enough bus drivers
column57: there are enough teachers
column58: ” Castrucci said. Educators and health officials worry that a return to school during a time of unprecedented spread could lead to the involuntary closure of schools due to staff shortages and contribute to rising cases
column59: especially in places that aren’t able or willing to institute precautions. “It is mind-boggling some states have a [mask] mandate ban
column60: or do not do enough to keep our kids safe
column61: ” said Tony Yang
column62: executive director of the Center for Health Policy and Media Engagement at George Washington University
column63: who has researched mask mandates in schools. Yang strongly favors in-person school with precautions in place. “Students should go to school in person
column64: ” he said. “But you have to do that safely.” In places where cases are particularly high
column65: even where some precautions are in place
column66: schools could choose to extend winter break to avoid staff shortages during the worst of the January peak
column67: Castrucci said. “The number one thing is
column68: we have to use every resource we have to keep kids in school in person over the long term
column70: we have to make a risk calculation as to whether this is the right moment to bring kids back from the holiday.” Vaccines are another key tool
column72: a pediatric infectious disease doctor at St Jude children’s research hospital in Memphis
column73: Tennessee. “Vaccination matters in terms of hospitalization and outcomes
column74: ” he said. Most of the hospitalized kids around the country are unvaccinated
column75: and Hijano had not seen a vaccinated child hospitalized for Covid – even though he works with many children who are at risk because of other medical conditions. Hospitals overwhelmed by Covid can lead to worse care and outcomes for children suffering from other causes
column76: he said. “If a kid has appendicitis and needs a bed for the surgery

column1: 159;159;5401;5401;How Bristol came out in support of the Colston Four;2022-01-05T16:54:26Z;['Damien Gayle'];['Black Lives Matter movement'
column2: 'Bristol'
column3: 'UK news'];"As long as they live in Bristol
column4: the three men and a woman cleared this week of toppling the statue of Edward Colston may never have to buy their own drinks again. Jake Skuse
column6: Rhian Graham
column8: Milo Ponsford
column10: and Sage Willoughby
column12: played key roles in tearing the statue of the 17th-century slave trader from its city centre plinth
column13: dragging it to Bristol harbour and throwing it in the River Avon. On the first day of their trial last month
column14: hundreds of supporters applauded the Colston Four
column15: as they have come to be known
column16: as they arrived at Bristol crown court. On Wednesday they were found not guilty of damaging the statue
column17: bringing their chapter in the saga to a close. But their actions
column18: considered to be one of the most significant and symbolic acts of public dissent in Britain this century
column19: sent shock waves that are still being felt nationally and globally.

column1: The toppling of Colston – which came just two weeks after the murder of George Floyd by Derek Chauvin
column2: a Minneapolis police officer
column3: sparked antiracist protests around the world – exploded like a cultural hand grenade. It catalysed a nationwide reassessment of the symbols of Britain’s imperialist past. Within six months nearly 70 tributes to slave traders
column4: colonialists and racists were removed across the UK
column5: a Guardian tally found
column6: as conversations intensified over which historical figures were appropriate for public veneration. Reverberations were felt as far away as the US where
column7: at the funeral of Floyd himself
column8: Rev Al Sharpton referenced the protest as symbolic of changing attitudes to race
column9: saying: “I’ve seen grandchildren of slave masters tearing down slave masters statue; over in England they put it in the river.” And it triggered outrage on the right. Dozens of so-called “statue defender” protests across the UK culminated in a chaotic rally by football fans around the statue of Winston Churchill in Trafalgar Square. Impassioned commentators compared protesters to a “woke Taliban” and warned of efforts to erase British history. “We cannot now try to edit or censor our past
column10: ” the prime minister tweeted. But as much as it was a trigger for a broader debate
column11: the toppling of Colston’s statue was also the culmination of a uniquely Bristolian story. Erected in 1895
column12: 174 years after Colston’s death
column13: the bronze likeness celebrated a man regarded by some as the city’s philanthropic patron saint. He had given his name to three schools in the city and half a dozen roads
column14: and a number of Bristol’s most ancient institutions owed their existence to his largesse. Every year celebrations were held in Bristol cathedral in Colston’s name. Leading pupils from the schools that bore his name were taken on pilgrimages to see a clump of his hair and his nails preserved like relics in the city’s Merchants Hall. A plaque attached to the plinth on which Colston’s statue stood celebrated him as “one of the most virtuous and wise sons” of Bristol. But concerns had long been raised over his presence. Looming over the heart of south-west England’s most multicultural city
column15: Colston had served as a potent reminder that its wealth was raised off the backs of enslaved people. Giving expert evidence in the trial
column16: the historian David Olusoga described how Colston had made his fortune as shareholder
column17: and eventual head
column18: of Britain’s most-important slave-owning enterprise
column19: the Royal African Company. During his tenure
column20: it kidnapped and enslaved an estimated 85
column21: 000 Africans
column22: including 12
column23: 000 children. “For me
column24: it was symbolic of power and lack of respect
column25: and the position of black people as a community
column26: ” Ros Martin
column27: a playwright and activist for many years with the Countering Colston campaign
column28: told the Guardian. She said she felt the trial was an “appalling injustice” but that she felt buoyed up by “the fact that [the defendants] are four young white people feeling empathy and showing empathy and getting people to think”. “It’s moving beyond being a bystander
column29: which is required from all of us
column30: ” Martin said. Throughout the 10-day trial
column31: the public gallery was packed with locals
column32: many of whom cheered videos shown in court of the moment Colston fell. Martin was there
column33: and other supporters and friends of the defendants. But others
column34: such as Douglas Peden
column35: a local lawyer
column36: and his two daughters
column37: had come to watch history play out in the courtroom. “It’s the symbolism of it
column38: ” Peden said
column39: admitting he also supported the defendants. “It’s property and ownership up against freedom of expression.” The feeling was reflected elsewhere in Bristol. Outside a pub in Bristol city centre after court one evening Jodie Lily
column40: from Exeter
column41: told the Guardian she knew at least 10 people who were present when the statue was toppled. “It’s only those four because they got their faces
column42: ” she said. “That piece of shit should have been taken down.” The bare facts of the case were not in question. Giving evidence
column43: the defendants proudly recounted the roles they played. But they denied criminal damage
column44: arguing their acts were justified by the offence caused in Bristol by the statue. It was a high-risk legal strategy
column45: given that support for the toppling of Colston was not universal
column46: even in Bristol. A week after the statue was felled
column47: a counter protest by the empty plinth drew a 300-strong crowd
column48: including a banner reading “all lives matter”. Concerns were felt across the UK. Polling by Policy Exchange found nearly half of people opposed the way the statue was toppled
column49: compared with a quarter in support
column50: while YouGov found that although a slim majority supported Colston’s removal
column51: just more than one in 10 thought it was done in the right way. Nevertheless
column52: change has since come in the wake of Colston’s toppling. Colston Hall
column53: Bristol’s major events venue
column54: changed its name – finally fulfilling an undertaking first made in 2017 – to the Bristol Beacon. Colston’s name was removed from pubs
column55: buildings and roads. The 275-year-old Colston society was disbanded and his image was removed from stained glass windows. But at the same time
column56: culture war battle lines were drawn
column57: and the government sensed a populist win. Skuse
column58: Graham
column59: Ponsford and Milo have been cleared but new measures in the government’s police and crime bill will allow courts to send people found guilty of damaging a memorial to prison for 10 years. As critics have pointed out
column60: someone caught defacing a statue could
column61: under the proposals
column62: be jailed for longer than someone found guilty of rape.

column1: As for Colston himself
column2: since being fished out of the River Avon by Bristol council
column3: his statue has found his way to the city’s M Shed museum
column4: where it has been transformed
column5: according to Olusoga
column6: into “the most important artefact” of the story of Britain’s relationship with its brutal slave history. There
column7: the statue of the old slave trader lies supine
column8: with red paint daubed on its eyes
column9: mouth and hands. Its coattail and staff are missing. It is surrounded by placards from the day it was pulled down and across its 17th-century robes is scrawled “BLM”.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/how-bristol-came-out-in-support-of-the-colston-four;5

column10: 'Air transport'];"The aviation and travel industry has welcomed the scrapping of pre-departure tests for people travelling to England
column11: which it had claimed were unnecessary and hugely damaging to the sector. Boris Johnson announced on Wednesday afternoon that the requirement would be lifted from 4am on Friday
column12: along with the need for travellers to self-isolate on arrival until they receive a negative PCR test result. He said – as the industry had argued – that the latest Covid variant Omicron was “so prevalent these measures have a limited impact on the growth in cases while continuing to pose significant cost to our travel industry”. Arrivals in England will now need to take a lateral flow test no later than the end of day two
column13: in line with the previous rules. Tim Alderslade
column14: the chief executive of the industry body Airlines UK
column15: said: “This is a hugely welcome move at a critical time in the booking season for passengers
column16: and will provide a massive boost to those wanting to travel abroad or come to the UK this year. People will now be able to book knowing that – for the fully vaccinated – all emergency testing restrictions have been removed. “Today marks an important step towards learning to live alongside the virus
column17: helping passengers and the travel sector look ahead to what will be an all-important spring and summer season.” Research commissioned earlier by Airlines UK and Manchester Airports Group suggested the removal of travel testing requirements would not affect overall rate of cases and hospitalisations in the UK. The two organisations said the research showed that domestic rather than international restrictions would be the only way to reduce Omicron’s spread within the country. Travel association Abta said the decision to reduce the testing requirements was “extremely welcome” but warned that the “damage had already been done”. The Business Travel Association urged the government to come up with a “robust plan for future variants that does not mean closing our borders and strangling our sector once more”. Ministers introduced additional testing requirements in late November and early December because of fears about the spread of the newly identified variant. Under the rules in place until they revert on Friday
column18: all passengers arriving in the UK have had to take a pre-departure Covid test in the two days before setting off
column19: although slightly different time limits apply in the four countries
column20: as well as a PCR test within the first two days after their arrival.

column1: Manchester Airports Group (MAG) said passenger numbers at its airports fell by more than 30% in early December after the introduction of new testing requirements. MAG’s chief executive
column2: Charlie Cornish
column3: said after Johnson’s announcement that the airport group looked forward to “working with government on a roadmap for the removal of all remaining restrictions
column4: in order to help our prized aviation sector enjoy a full recovery”. Global airline body Iata said the change was “long overdue”. Its director general
column5: Willie Walsh
column6: said: “It’s now time to look again at the overall scheme and remove testing entirely for vaccinated travellers.” • This article was amended on 5 January 2022 to clarify the details about pre-departure Covid tests for people entering the UK.";https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/jan/05/uk-travel-industry-international-covid-tests;2

column6: 'Health policy'];Official data shows the number of people getting boosted in the UK fell to just over 100
column7: 000 on Sunday
column8: compared with highs of more than 900
column9: 000 before Christmas when on some days people were queueing for hours to get vaccinated. Asked about the slowdown
column10: the government’s vaccine minister
column11: Maggie Throup
column12: said the Christmas break and public holidays were key factors. So will this week see higher numbers coming forward or are there other factors at play? What proportion of people are eligible for a booster? Almost 60% of over-12s have had their booster or third dose. But only half of the remaining 40% have had their second dose and it is notable that there wasn’t a dramatic uptick in the number of people coming forward for first and second doses in the pre-Christmas vaccination campaign. Since a three-month gap is needed between doses
column13: the ceiling for boosters will remain at 80% of over-12s well into the spring. How many people have had to wait because they’ve tested positive for Covid? People need to wait 28 days after testing positive to be eligible for vaccination. So the huge surge in cases – 2 million were estimated to have had Covid in the week before Christmas – will have inevitably meant a large number of people postponing their booster. Figures on how many people this affected are not available. But the highest rates of Covid
column14: with one in 15 people aged 25 to 35 estimated to be infected in England last week
column15: also coincide with the age group that would be roughly due for their booster if they had their previous vaccinations on schedule. What happens if you get boosted while not realising you have Covid? The general guidance
column16: not just for Covid
column17: is not to have a vaccination if you’re running an infection. Clinical trials automatically discount people who test positive
column18: so there is not much evidence on exactly how the immune system responds to an infection and a booster at the same time. There aren’t any known harms associated with the combination
column19: aside from the obvious one of putting health professionals at risk if you attend a clinic while infectious. Since infection also boosts antibody levels
column20: there is likely to be less benefit to getting a booster at the same time. It is possible that the side-effects of a booster
column21: on top of mild Covid symptoms
column22: might feel a bit worse
column23: but there is no suggestion that this would be a clinical concern. With the move to lateral flow tests (LFTs)
column24: how will positive results be recorded if people don’t have to get a follow-up PCR? Fom 11 January in England
column25: and from 6 January in Scotland
column26: people who receive positive LFT results will be required to self-isolate immediately and won’t be required to take a confirmatory PCR test. In theory
column27: all LFT results
column28: including negative ones
column29: are already supposed to be reported via the government’s test-and-trace system and feed into daily case numbers. In practice
column30: a much smaller proportion of LFT results are reported compared with PCR results
column31: which are automatically entered into the system when processed in the laboratory. However
column32: cases are already running far above the numbers being confirmed by PCR testing and the UK is already relying on other methods
column33: such as the Office for National Statistics Infection Survey
column34: to assess levels of prevalence.;https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/jan/05/will-the-uks-covid-booster-campaign-pick-up-speed-in-january;7

column3: 'Victoria holidays'
column4: 'Hobbies'
column5: 'Travel'
column6: 'Australian lifestyle'];"I love the ocean but in the last two years
column7: I haven’t seen her much. Now the world’s gotten a little bigger
column8: all I want to do is be by the water. Sup – or standup paddleboarding – is the closest you can get without actually getting wet. You cruise along
column9: admire the view
column10: find a nice spot for lunch. You can dip in
column11: dip out – hell
column12: you can take a rod if you want
column13: or do some downward dog on your board. Humans have been supping a long time – records go back to as early as 3
column14: 000BC
column15: but the modern iteration was born in Hawaii in the 1940s
column16: when surfer John Ah Choy could no longer get up and down on his board. He started to use a paddle to help him get out to the waves
column17: his kids picked it up
column18: and like many water-related activities that come from that island
column19: it spread quickly across the globe. Paddleboarding is now a common feature in most Australian waterways. It’s often cited as the fastest growing water sport – and when you do it
column20: you can tell why. For starters
column21: you can learn almost instantly. You just hop on the board and when your balance is right
column22: if you feel comfortable
column23: you stand up. Simple.

column1: Nic Cooper has been supping for years now. He loves it so much he’s made it his job – taking travellers around Victoria to the best spots. “I’m hardcore into it. But I’m not I’m not one of those that goes on
column2: like
column3: marathon Sups or anything like that. I just love being out in the ocean and just chilling
column4: ” he says. “I see it as relaxation.” Cooper says he’s never had a student who couldn’t do it – some stay on their knees
column5: but given you’re cruising past turtles
column6: dolphins and kangaroos
column7: it’s still a good time. “Depending on your balance and stuff like that
column8: you can get pretty good at it within a few hours
column9: ” he says.

column1: Egalitarian in its demands
column2: Cooper says all ages and most body types can Sup. “I think it’s made water sports accessible for everyone.” Once you’ve got the basics
column3: you need to finesse your technique to get the most out of each stroke. While this isn’t essential for beginners
column4: it’s a must to compete in a race
column5: or to Sup your way along a river for a few days. This requires “bending your knees as you go forward and … leaning down on your paddle … to get the most propulsion as possible
column6: ” Cooper says. “Even giving your paddle a little twist as it exits at the back will have less push on the water and therefore it’ll be a more efficient stroke.” More advanced Sup-ers can even ride them like surfboards. Before we set out for a lesson on Melbourne’s waterways
column7: Cooper’s best advice was “never look back”. Which of course
column8: I forgot when a turtle swam under me.

column1: I swivelled around and went very quickly from standing up paddleboarding to falling down paddleboarding. But I stayed dry
column2: and luckily out of the frame of our fast-moving photographer. Despite the tumble
column3: a sense of calm prevailed – it is like valium in a water sport.

column1: As we drifted on the ocean just off Mt Martha beach
column2: shadowed by peninsula “shacks” that would cost a cool $2m
column3: I asked whether the sport was as egalitarian in price as it is in skill. How much does it cost to sit on a board for a hit of bliss regularly? Not much
column4: or quite a lot
column5: says Cooper. The cheapest
column6: easiest way for those who want to try it is to book a Sup session or hire a board at the beach. Depending on where you are
column7: board hire can be about $30 for 60 minutes. If you want a lesson to make sure you’ve got the basics – or to mine your guide for the best spots – it’ll cost about $60 for an hour. As for buying your own gear
column8: it depends what you want to do with it. “If they want to go on these huge trips – 20
column9: 30km along the coastline or whatever – then they’re going to want a long
column10: thin touring board
column11: ” Cooper says. For activities like yoga
column12: he suggests something wide and stable.

column1: The cheapest Sup I could find online was a blow-up one going for $200 – without a pump. Price differences from there are about quality
column2: ease
column3: and weight – the more expensive boards blow up quicker
column4: last longer and are substantially lighter
column5: Cooper says. He warns to avoid the cheapest new boards “because it’s just going to break”. A high quality board new will cost about $900
column6: but secondhand options are the best way to score a bargain. Supping isn’t a solo sport
column7: either. Aficionados can join their local clubs and even plan holidays around the activity. “You can take them in a backpack so you could go to some really awesome places … Once you’re confident and you know you’re not going to fall off
column8: then you can go anywhere really.” This piece was supported by Visit Victoria and Wild Adventures Melbourne.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/06/you-can-learn-almost-instantly-a-beginners-guide-to-standup-paddleboarding;5

column1: 164;164;5406;5406;Messy? Unproductive? Need to dismantle your privilege? There’s a guided journal for that;2022-01-05T16:30:39Z;['Jenny Valentish'];['Health & wellbeing'
column2: 'Australian lifestyle'
column3: 'Life and style'
column4: 'Books'
column5: 'Culture'
column6: 'Publishing'];"The pleasure of watching a streak of positive habits accumulating on a whiteboard has become almost a dependency for me. So much so
column7: I debated packing it in my suitcase for a short trip away. But the humble whiteboard has a more portable
column8: sophisticated upgrade: the guided journal. A few years ago I thought the trajectory of these workbooks – designed to probe or organise different facets of your behaviour or health – had probably peaked. Back then
column9: deluxe hardbacks lined the shelves of stylish stationery chains (Kikki K favoured own-brand pastel numbers: Happy
column10: Thrive
column11: Dream Life)
column12: while Urban Outfitters displayed quirky titles (Moon Journal
column13: My Adorable Cat) from the lineage of Keri Smith’s 2007 Wreck This Journal in the gift section
column14: alongside moustache mugs and line-drawn temporary tattoos.

column1: But the upswing is far from over
column2: and the scope has become ever broader. There are journals designed to delve deeply into hobbies
column3: or straighten out specific personality kinks. Some favour style over substance – expensive hardbacks with minimal prompts – while others offer a wealth of theory between exercises. Bianca Jafari is a product development executive at Thames and Hudson
column4: focusing on gift products: puzzles
column5: stationery
column6: games and
column7: in the pipeline
column8: guided journals. She says journals are no longer just the domain of niche or self-help publishers. The bigger publishing houses are basing journals on their bestsellers
column9: such as Mark Manson’s The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck Journal (HarperCollins) and Michelle Obama’s Becoming: A Guided Journal for Discovering Your Voice (Penguin).

column1: “Producing a guided journal is a no-brainer because they can use content that they already have
column2: ” says Jafari. “For example
column3: the Michelle Obama journal is a big win for Penguin because they already own the images. They’ve already got data that says that the content is a bestseller. There’s already an audience that exists.” That’s all well and good for the publishers
column4: but can guided journals really live past the punter’s first flush of good intentions
column5: or are they destined to be abandoned as quickly as a teenage girl sets aside the diary she received for Christmas
column6: into which she poured her New Year resolutions? I decided to try a few. Journals to clean up specific areas of your life “Some journals are interest-based to help you practise a craft
column7: like astrology
column8: or manage your veganism or gardening
column9: ” says Jafari. Since none of those are areas of concern for me
column10: I unearthed some that are applicable to many of us as a new year begins. Collective Hub
column11: from Australian publisher Lisa Messenger
column12: puts out books and journals aimed at entrepreneurs. Know Your Numbers is one such product – a chunky hardback that works hard for the money with budget templates
column13: saving tips
column14: start-up launch advice and income tracking tables. Several publishers offer journals dedicated to going alcohol-free
column15: including Sober As F*** (based on Sarah Ordo’s memoir); the 90-day journal Dear Alcohol
column16: I’m Breaking Up With You and the Alcohol Experiment Journal
column17: based on the bestselling book This Naked Mind by Annie Grace.

column1: I tried the Declutter Challenge (Mango Publishing) by Cassandra Aarssen
column2: which suggests you “Namast’ay home this weekend and declutter some junk”. Cynics will say this paperback isn’t helping by adding to your hoarding
column3: but Aarssen does actually invite you to bin it
column4: on the final (120th) page. Her “30 quick steps” to organising your home draw on mindfulness
column5: visualisation and gratitude. As a way to avoid the long-overdue pruning of my garden hedges
column6: I list “six awesome things about decluttering my home” and draw the things in my lounge-room that make me the happiest in the cartoon picture frames provided. I do chuck some things from the drawers into a box in the car port
column7: but a few days later it’s Christmas Day and I receive a whole variety of future landfill. Then the Declutter Challenge joins the teetering pile of journals on my desk
column8: presumably for ever. Goal-oriented journals The line between habit-tracking books
column9: such as bullet journals (which focus on to-do lists
column10: logging completed tasks
column11: and the steps towards achieving various-sized goals) and guided journals has blurred to near indistinction. “Many people associate habit trackers with the new year and downloading a few apps and promising to drink more water
column12: ” says Jafari. She believes that they are satisfying
column13: but that commitment to a guided journal is “more special”. “You can sit with it over enough time to block everything else out … and you pour yourself into it.” One such hybrid is the Australian creation The Resilience Agenda
column14: a “mental fitness diary” that provides strategies for achieving said fitness; though your main task is to identify each day’s three top priorities to help you reach your goals.

column1: James Clear’s bestselling Atomic Habits has been turned into the Clear Habit Journal; while Adelaide United’s football club captain Stefan Mauk has created the Inner Game
column2: to help athletes with goal monitoring and preparation. I tried out Mindset. Reset
column3: from Perth-based finance professional turned life coach Alisa Pettit. Promising to focus on “the non-fluff emotional stuff”
column4: she’s delivered a generous amount of theory among the exercises. There’s still plenty of scribbling to do
column5: and I find this the most productive journal yet. I look at the hierarchy of 10 areas of my life and find I’m tanking on “spirituality” and “community”. I’m encouraged to analyse how blame
column6: justification and lack of responsibility have so far scuppered my goals. Then there’s the goal-setting itself. Pettit has designed three contracts that you can stick to the mirror
column7: based on your short-term
column8: middle-term and long-term goals. Mine are choreographing a pole-dance routine by February; developing an open mic comedy set in three months and entering a bodybuilding competition within 12 months. Serendipitously
column9: I see they could all feed into one another. Tough-love journals

column1: Finally
column2: there are the journals that go for the jugular
column3: either suggesting urgent reflection is needed – such as with Me and White Supremacy by Layla Saad – or tackling tough topics
column4: such as Grief
column5: A Guided Journal by Australian marriage celebrant Jo Betz
column6: written after she lost her husband
column7: and Susan Buniva’s Successful Co-Parenting with a Toxic Ex. “These are quite different to the self-help journals
column8: because they’re quite intrusive
column9: ” says Jafari. “Like the Judgement Detox Journal [by Gabrielle Bernstein]
column10: which asks
column11: ‘Why do I feel the need to judge
column12: and what happened in my own life that makes me confident to judge someone else?’”

column1: I tried Cheaper Than Therapy (Running Press)
column2: to which no author is credited
column3: unless you include the nods to Freud and Jung. Inside are Rorschach inkblot tests
column4: dream analysis
column5: word association tests and methods to actualise your worst self
column6: and 120 prompts
column7: hopping from the distant past
column8: to the past week
column9: to your general psyche. As the foreword says
column10: none of this is to be taken “super-seriously”. I decide this journal might be a good vehicle to tackle my pornography use (very healthy or very unhealthy
column11: depending on how you look at it)
column12: via prompts such as “Do you feel worthy of scorn? Why or why not?” and “What’s your sexual fantasy? OK. Now tell me the real one? What do you think that means?” as well as the quiz “How psychosexual are you?” (“Do you ever pee yourself a little?” “Do you relentlessly chew gum?”). The answers are enlightening but
column13: obviously
