column3: 'Children'
column4: 'Australia news'
column5: 'Social media'
column6: 'Health'];"Addressing children’s mental health is “more complex” than blaming social media and requires investment in social housing and supports through schools
column7: the children’s commissioner has said. Anne Hollonds spoke to Guardian Australia in a wide-ranging interview about Australian governments’ responses to Covid-19
column8: and a suite of new measures at the federal level to tackle bullying online. The prime minister
column9: Scott Morrison
column10: has made the affect of social media on youth mental health a focus in the lead-up to the 2022 election
column11: campaigning on online safety and arguing reforms are needed
column12: particularly to prevent harassment of women and girls.

column1: Hollonds said she “absolutely” supports the legislation to unmask anonymous social media trolls
column2: the social media inquiry and regime of eSafety commissioner content takedown orders as measures that put “the best interest of children as the first priority” in the “unregulated” digital world. But Hollonds warned that a decade-long increase in mental health problems including self-harm
column3: which predates the Covid-19 pandemic
column4: has other social and economic dimensions. “There are some people who might like to say ‘oh it’s all the fault of social media’. “That’s often the go-to answer as to why kids have mental health problems. I wouldn’t deny it has an effect but it’s not as simple as that
column5: it’s more complex.” Australian Institute of Health and Welfare data shows in any given year 20% of Australians experience mental ill health and that
column6: even before the pandemic
column7: three-quarters of Australians with mental ill health were under 25. Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: One in four Australian teens reported experiencing psychological distress in 2020 and parents have warned that the pandemic and lockdowns have made it harder to find help. Hollonds said poor youth mental health is a “long-term increasing trend” which Covid has “opened our eyes to in a way we can’t ignore” due to a “spike where there were extended lockdowns”. “It’s something that obviously worries me hugely … you just have to ask how bad does it have to get before we recognise that we need to make children a national policy priority?” In addition to the way living in a digital world has “changed the experience of childhood”
column2: Hollonds nominates the financial pressure from the cost of housing and inadequate support systems as causes.

column1: “For example the education system … for the kids who are struggling
column2: perhaps the old style education system where it’s just about academic learning is not really doing enough for kids
column3: ” she said. “I think Covid has shown schools are about much more than academic learning that can be replaced by zoom. “By closing schools we actually added pressure to the distress of kids.” One of the main lessons from the pandemic is that schools “should be the last to close and the first to reopen
column4: because of their importance in the overall wellbeing of children”
column5: Hollonds said. “In my view … we’ve under-estimated school as a community hub of support for the wellbeing of kids and their families.” Hollonds said that some other developed countries had better integrated the health and education systems making it “easier for people to get help they need”. Hollonds said the cost of housing and the “spike in costs during Covid” was also a deeply worrying factor that emerges from her consultation with children
column6: young people and their families.

column1: “It’s those areas with low incomes
column2: higher poverty and disadvantage … outside CBDs
column3: in rural and outer urban areas – [they are] precisely the areas where rents have become unaffordable [during the pandemic].” Hollonds called on governments to address “under-investment in social housing over decades” and to look at economic drivers of housing costs. Her comments back calls from other experts for more comprehensive mental health supports and higher income supports to tackle the youth mental health crisis. In November the former Labor premier of South Australia
column4: Jay Weatherill
column5: who’s now chief executive of Minderoo Foundation’s Thrive by Five initiative
column6: accused the Morrison government of neglecting to assess the affect of the pandemic on young children
column7: with current policies labelled “a series of crisis responses”. The latest Naplan data has found that Australian schoolchildren’s basic literacy and numeracy skills were relatively unscathed during first year of the Covid-19 pandemic
column8: but gaps are widening between city students and those in regional and remote areas. Guardian Australia previously reported concerns from teachers that the compounded effects of two years of intermittent learning in some areas are only just beginning to become apparent
column9: especially for younger cohorts (up to grade 2) that are not captured by the Naplan dataset.";https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/jan/06/youth-mental-health-australia-needs-to-look-beyond-ills-of-social-media-to-fix-crisis-childrens-commissioner-says;7

column1: 167;167;5409;5409;The Little Dum Dum Club: the 10 funniest things we have ever seen (on the internet);2022-01-05T16:30:39Z;['N/A'];['Comedy'

column4: 'Internet'
column5: 'Social media'];"We’re Tommy Dassalo and Karl Chandler
column6: and we make a living as hosts of comedy podcast The Little Dum Dum Club. The internet gave birth to us
column7: and it can end us. Guardian Australia has certain rules about what we can submit as the “funniest things we have ever seen on the internet” and according to them
column8: it’s not appropriate to just send in a bunch of clips of our comedian friends where we re-voice them and make them say negative stuff about vaccines. So instead
column9: we’ve sent in a bunch of other junk. Catch you at the end for a plug. 1. Dave Chappelle on Kramer Neither of us are very big consumers of standup specials on the streaming services
column10: but this short clip of Dave Chappelle at the Laugh Factory is a massive favourite – in which he kinda defends Michael Richards’s infamous set there. “Hang in there
column11: Kramer!” has become an essential
column12: multi-purpose catchphrase in most elements of our lives. But most of all
column13: it’s just fun to imagine that we live in a world where Dave Chappelle literally thinks that Michael Richards’s name is Kramer.

column1: 2. The ‘India’ prank calls to 2SM Prank calls were trolling before we had the internet. In 2006
column2: a bunch of people – including Sam Mac
column3: before he was a Gold Logie-nominated weatherman – were listening to a quiz segment on Sydney radio station 2SM and heard a caller mistakenly guess “India” to a question. The caller was then berated on-air by host Graeme Gilbert for guessing such a wrong answer.

column1: The natural next step for Sam Mac et al
column2: of course
column3: was to get everyone they knew to call in and guess “India” to every question that was asked – for the next million years or so. We both became obsessed with this. We discovered it just before we shared a car in a four-hour traffic jam
column4: and the word “India” was possibly 70% of our conversation. Sam Mac should’ve won the Gold Logie for this.

column1: 3. I Think You Should Leave: Driver’s Ed sketch Tim Robinson’s I Think You Should Leave is easily the funniest sketch show of the last few years – and this sketch is a really great taster of what you can expect. To be completely honest
column2: we’d probably both pick the courtroom sketch from season two
column3: but we had to submit clips that are officially available online. So go watch that sketch on Netflix and then pretend that you’ve seen it embedded in this article. Tables!

column1: 4. Jackass Forever: movie trailer We get it
column2: it’s incredibly stupid to put a movie trailer in the list of funniest things we’ve seen. But: as if this movie isn’t going to rule. Its release date getting bumped back from last October to this year is probably the worst thing to have happened to us in 2021. Although watching it in a packed theatre at the moment is probably a dumber stunt than anything they actually do in the movie.

column1: 5. Final 2 This is a longtime personal favourite of Tommy’s. An animation student put together an animation showreel of Dobby from Harry Potter – a decent way of showing off his skills – but then went the extra mile by inserting himself into the video and writing a little scene between himself and Dobby
column2: where they seem to be in love with each other? Which
column3: as far as I can remember
column4: is not canon in the Harry Potter universe.

column1: He’s also recorded Dobby’s dialogue on what seems to be the world’s cheapest microphone
column2: and then filmed all of his parts in a public park
column3: so you can see people walking their dogs through the background. No hate though
column4: because the animation is great and is far better than anything I could do (after dropping out of animation school after eight months).

column1: 6. Kay’s Cooking: avocado on toast Kay is a lovely lady in the north of England who videos herself learning to cook the most basic of foods. She’s intriguing and eminently likable but boy oh boy does her food look like a sack of crap. In this particular episode
column2: she’s trying to make avocado on toast for the first time ever. However
column3: she’s mistakenly used an eggplant instead
column4: and is confused when she tries to mash the rock-hard innards of this “avocado”. It sounds bad
column5: and it looks even worse. She’s since relabelled the video as “aubergine on toast”
column6: to save face. Kay
column7: you can’t fool us
column8: especially by using the fancier term “aubergine”.

column1: 7. Succession but everyone wants some of Logan’s M&Ms Another Tommy pick. It seems like everyone loves Succession at the moment
column2: but I don’t know if very many people have seen this clip. This guy is unbelievable. Doing even one of these characters so spot-on would be impressive
column3: let alone the whole cast.

column1: I have a very limited range of impressions – I think the only way I’d be able to pull off a video like this is there was a prestige HBO drama where every role was played by Dave Hughes. 8. Seinfeld A few years ago
column2: we were giddy off the back of selling out a live podcast at the Sydney Opera House and being invited to do a live podcast at the most exclusive comedy festival in the world
column3: Just For Laughs in Montreal. We had a meeting with a major radio station in Melbourne
column4: thinking
column5: “Here we go. We could get a radio show here.” Instead
column6: the executive who was going to meet with us pulled out without explanation and sent in some guy who knew nothing about us (or much else)
column7: and ended his meeting with two comedians
column8: in the year of 2017
column9: by asking us
column10: “Have you ever seen Seinfeld? That guy is funny.” So
column11: we’d like to pass that suggestion on to you guys. Have you ever seen Seinfeld? If not
column12: here it is.

column1: 9. Norm MacDonald on Saturday Night Live Weirdly
column2: the official Saturday Night Live YouTube account has no clips of the late
column3: great Norm MacDonald hosting Weekend Update: one of the best and most influential bits of comedy in the last 25 years. So instead
column4: I (Karl) am gonna supply this stupid
column5: weird sketch that I love so much in tribute to Norm.

column1: Most of the cast in this sketch were fired after this 1995 end-of-season episode (Adam Sandler
column2: Chris Farley
column3: Jay Mohr)
column4: and others were demoted (Norm and David Spade)
column5: and it’s clearly written by dead men walking. It’s SO dumb and the audience appear to HATE it. But what do people know? NOTHING. 10. The Little Dum Dum Club Seems a little silly to promote everyone else to people out there who
column6: more than likely
column7: don’t even know our own stuff. So
column8: here’s our stuff. It’s the story of the time I (Karl) annoyed an open mic-er who was trying to get a gig at my weekly comedy night by relentlessly insisting he bring Dave Hughes along
column9: despite the fact he clearly didn’t know him. And we told it on our show to Hughesy
column10: who loved it. Stupid
column11: pretty funny and a decent summation of the last 11 years of doing this podcast.

column1: The Little Dum Dum Club’s long-delayed live recording of their 500th episode takes place on 15 January at the Athenaeum Theatre
column2: Melbourne. Listen to their podcast here";https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2022/jan/06/the-little-dum-dum-club-the-10-funniest-things-we-have-ever-seen-on-the-internet;5

column7: 'World news'];"Several miles south of the small town of San Juan
column8: Texas
column9: beyond acres of onion fields
column10: orange groves and other cash crops sits a historic cemetery and the site of the beginning of a slow decay of American soil. I hadn’t been to this area for more than a year because of the pandemic
column11: and I was startled at how different this remote part of Texas had become. The most obvious change is the steel 18ft-high bollard fencing
column12: among the last vestiges of Donald Trump’s glorious border wall with Mexico. Trump visited this site in June with Governor Greg Abbott to tout his accomplishments in controlling the border and to praise Abbott for taking up the anti-immigrant baton that resonates so well with the conservative voting base in Texas. The last time I came to visit this spot
column13: no wall existed and the historic cemetery – the Eli Jackson cemetery – was under a 24-hour vigil by a Native American tribe called the Carrizo/Comecrudo
column14: as well as other supporters who feared a border wall would destroy sacred burial land and a sacred piece of history. The Eli Jackson family built this cemetery
column15: designated a historic landmark by the state
column16: on land owned by Nathanial Jackson
column17: Eli’s father. Nathaniel was a slave owner from Alabama who fell in love with and married one of his slaves
column18: Matilda Hicks
column19: before the two fled to the banks of the Rio Grande in 1857 and settled on the border with Mexico. Nathaniel was known for his generosity to visitors and his ranch soon began a relatively unknown line of the vaunted Underground Railroad in which fleeing slaves escaped servitude and
column20: with the Jackson family’s help
column21: fled to Mexico where slavery was forbidden. The Carrizo/Comecrudo tribe and its descendants also claim this area and
column22: with the permission of the landowners
column23: set up a camp in January 2019 to fend off any wall construction. Many of the inhabitants who camped out said they were veterans of the Keystone pipeline protests in northern Minnesota. And given the supply tent and other facilities that were erected adjacent to the Eli Jackson cemetery there was a suggestion that organizers hoped that a similarly large protest would develop in south Texas to fight the border wall.

column1: And despite a 24-hour vigil
column2: often by as few as one or two diehard protesters in heat and cold for nearly a year in 2019
column3: the efforts to protect the cemetery fell victim to Covid in 2020. As federal construction crews erected Trump’s wall ever closer to the cemetery
column4: the landowners finally told the protesters to vacate. Soon
column5: a large sign declaring the cemetery closed and camping prohibited was posted and the steel bollards marking the wall’s arrival began to overtake the horizon less than 100 yards from the burial grounds. When I returned to this remote site
column6: about a mile from the Rio Grande
column7: the first thing I noticed was a road to get over an earthen flood levee and back to the cemetery was closed; a sign said the area was now a construction zone
column8: a Trump border wall just a few yards east of the road. I found another road that circled around to the cemetery. The protesters’ area of encampment
column9: once a cleared field
column10: was now the site of overgrown vegetation
column11: leaving little evidence of human habitation for the better part of a year
column12: suggesting the border wall decay has begun. It’s a decay that marks the beginning of a no man’s land: virtually uninhabitable
column13: threatening because of its isolation
column14: essentially a chunk of US territory that might as well belong to Mexico. That’s because in south Texas the term border wall is a misnomer because of the unpredictability of the Rio Grande and a treaty with Mexico. While the great river is dammed and channeled along its international path through Texas
column15: the Rio Grande can still bite back with massive and unpredictable flooding. One attempt to mitigate the threat resulted in a treaty with Mexico that was signed during the Nixon administration that prevents either side from altering the flow of the river with land impediments – something like a border wall. To protect from flooding in south Texas
column16: a long
column17: mostly earthen levee generally follows the route of the Rio Grande from about a mile away. So
column18: while border walls in Arizona and California may straddle the border with Mexico
column19: those in south Texas are typically located atop or adjacent to the levee system
column20: meaning that this so-called protective barrier is ceding about a mile of US territory behind the wall
column21: effectively creating a no man’s land. It was true under the wall that was built by the George W Bush administration and it’s true of the walls that were erected during the Trump administration. Beyond the threat the creation of a no man’s land has to private homeowners and their property values
column22: this region is also rich in ecological sites along the river. One of these
column23: called the Southmost Preserve
column24: is a thousand-acre wildlife preserve home to one of the only two remaining large stands of native Mexican sabal palm. More than 900 acres of that preserve is now in a no man’s land south of a Bush wall and locals generally avoid it because of the potential danger a no man’s land poses. Another Bush wall runs near the historic Hidalgo Pumphouse Museum and World Birding Center in the city of Hidalgo. Several nature trails run behind this area. But many of those trails are now behind a border wall and impassable or too dangerous to enter. Critics had predicted that a Trump border wall in this region would have the same no-man’s-land result. What I didn’t realize was how quickly the negative effects of this isolated land would be felt. Aside from all the warnings to keep out when I recently visited the Jackson cemetery
column25: there was an emptiness in this area that I had never felt before. An isolation that hinted at vulnerability. The irony of this situation is that Texas
column26: a state that brags about its commitment to property rights
column27: continues its fight to finish the border wall. But I noticed that there was one section of the Trump wall that was about a mile long in this area. Then there was a mile-long gap before another section of wall began. So
column28: this barrier effectively did little to deter unauthorized immigration because the migrants simply need to walk a mile or two in either direction to go around the wall. But this barrier
column29: this big
column30: beautiful wall
column31: as Trump called it
column32: that was built to protect US citizens from the “invasion” of migrants
column33: was only truly effective at something else: keeping US citizens away from the no man’s land that it created and ceding the territory to Mexico. Carlos Sanchez is director of public affairs for Hidalgo county
column34: Texas. He was a journalist for 37 years and has worked at the Washington Post and Texas Monthly magazine
column35: as well as eight other newsrooms. He can be reached at borderscribe@gmail.com";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/05/trump-border-wall-south-texas-mexico;3

column7: 'World news'];"Emmanuel Macron faced criticism from political opponents and heated scenes in parliament on Wednesday after he gave a deliberately provocative warning to unvaccinated French people
column8: saying he would make their lives as difficult as possible by curbing their access to spaces such as cafés and restaurants. A crucial parliamentary debate on introducing a proposed Covid-19 “vaccine pass” for entry to areas such museums and long-distance trains was to resume on Wednesday afternoon. The debate had been suspended just before 2am on Wednesday as lawmakers expressed outrage at Macron’s newspaper interview in which he said the 5 million people who had not had vaccines against the coronavirus were “irresponsible” and that he really wanted to “put them in the shit” by making their daily lives as complicated as possible. The French government spokesman
column9: Gabriel Attal
column10: warned there would be a “supersonic” rise in Covid cases in France in the coming days and that infections were reaching stratospheric levels in the Île-de-France area around Paris as well as some in other regions. He said the situation in hospitals could worsen in the coming weeks. On Wednesday
column11: France registered a record number of 335
column12: 000 infections over the previous 24 hours.

column1: The government
column2: in a hardening of current rules
column3: is seeking to make it mandatory for people to show proof of Covid-19 vaccination to enter cafés
column4: restaurants
column5: museums
column6: cinemas and theatres
column7: or to use long-distance trains. Repeated disruptions and clashes in parliament
column8: as well as hundreds of proposed amendments
column9: are leaving the government struggling to push the law through before its deadline of 15 January. In an interview with readers of Le Parisien newspaper published on Wednesday
column10: Macron
column11: the French president
column12: deliberately used the verb “emmerder”
column13: which is derived from the word “merde” or “shit” and is widely used in France and considered vulgar slang. He said that he “really wanted” to put the non-vaccinated “in the shit” by making their lives very complicated and “limiting as much as possible their access to activities in social life”. Macron said: “We have to tell [the unvaccinated] ... you will no longer be able to go to a restaurant
column14: you will no longer be able to go for a coffee
column15: you will no longer be able to go to the theatre
column16: you will no longer be able to go to the cinema. We will continue to do this
column17: to the end. This is the strategy.” He explained that he could not force French people to get vaccinated on pain of prison or fines but life could be made very difficult for them without a vaccine.

column1: In parliament
column2: opposition parties slammed Macron’s choice of language as unfit for a president and worrying in terms of voting through the new law. Christian Jacob
column3: president of the opposition
column4: rightwing Les Républicains party
column5: told parliament: “A president cannot say such things ... I’m in favour of the vaccine pass but I cannot back a text whose objective is to put French people in the shit.” Damien Abad
column6: from the same party
column7: slammed what he called unworthy
column8: irresponsible and premeditated remarks which showed “childish cynicism”. On the left
column9: there was outrage over more of Macron’s comments
column10: when
column11: referring to unvaccinated people
column12: he said that when some people’s freedom threatened those of others they became irresponsible
column13: adding: “Someone irresponsible is not a citizen.”

column1: Mathilde Panot
column2: head of the parliamentary group for the left’s La France Insoumise party
column3: told the house: “We won’t keep debating a text you presented as a protection of the French people and which is in fact a text to put a part of the French population in the shit and which has invented [the notion of] stripping French citizenship – by saying irresponsible people are no longer French citizens.” Macron is expected to seek re-election in the presidential elections this April. However
column4: his key challenger
column5: Valérie Pécresse
column6: of Les Républicains
column7: told French TV that he was dividing the nation by making some citizens seem better than others. “It’s not up to the president of the republic to pick out good and bad French people
column8: ” Pécresse said. France needed a government to “unite people and calm things down”
column9: she added. But government figures and Macron allies stood by the president’s calculated choice of words and the strategy to make daily life very hard for unvaccinated people. Macron is no stranger to rows over off-the-cuff comments or slang
column10: telling interviewers last month that he regretted some of his comments of the past five years
column11: saying: “I’ve learned to have a lot more respect for everyone.” But the vehemence of his comments about unvaccinated people and his deliberate choice of hard language was aimed at his own electorate
column12: which is almost entirely vaccinated
column13: and it was also a pre-election message to address the widespread exasperation at the Covid crisis in France.

column1: Although France has historically had more vaccine sceptics than many of its neighbours
column2: it has one of the highest Covid-19 vaccination rates in the EU. A majority of people is in favour of vaccination; about 90% of French people aged 12 and over are vaccinated. The number of unvaccinated people in French hospital critical wards is higher than those who are vaccinated

column4: numbering around 5 million
column5: is too many. Christophe Castaner
column6: a key Macron ally and head of his grouping in parliament

column10: told parliament the aim of Macron’s entire interview was “the protection of the French people”. Marc Fesneau

column12: said: “We need unvaccinated people to hear the message being sent to them by the government
column13: parliament and the president – which is a message of responsibility.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/macron-rebuke-to-unvaccinated-citizens-incurs-anger-in-parliament;7

column4: 'Middle East and north Africa'];"A Palestinian man on a hunger strike in protest against detention without charge has agreed to end his fast after a deal was struck for his release owing to fears of unrest if he died. Hisham Abu Hawash
column6: a construction worker from Dura in the West Bank
column7: had previously served time in an Israeli jail after pleading guilty to terrorism offences related to membership of Islamic Jihad. He was rearrested and has been held without charge or trial for more than a year

His lawyer said on Tuesday night that Abu Hawash had agreed to end the 141-day strike – believed to be the longest by a Palestinian prisoner since 2013 – after a deal was reached between Israeli and Palestinian Authority (PA) officials to release him next month. column9: warning of “potentially irreversible health consequences and possible tragic loss of life”.

column1: The deal comes amid mounting support for Abu Hawash in the West Bank and Gaza Strip in the form of street demonstrations

column6: and Hamas called the issue a “red line”. The married father of five

column14: who had begun to lose consciousness for long periods of time

The news was met with celebrations across the Palestinian territories on Tuesday night
column16: while the Prisoners’ Club

column6: 'Sport'];"Back in 2005
column7: Ashley Giles played what is still one of my favourite Test innings
column8: when he made 59 on the fifth day of the fifth Test at the Oval. It was his top score in Test cricket at the time his team needed it the most. And because it was played in the shadow of Kevin Pietersen’s 158 at the other end
column9: it went almost unnoticed. Which felt characteristic. Giles always seemed like that team’s Guildenstern
column10: a steady lower-order bat and a spinner who often didn’t turn the ball at all. We called him the Wheelie Bin because of his ungainly action
column11: or the King of Spain
column12: because of a misprint on a souvenir mug. He hated the nicknames
column13: and
column14: understandably enough
column15: resented the idea that he was being laughed at. Because
column16: of course
column17: he took his game seriously. He had to. Giles operated on the reaches of his own talent
column18: and it was hard work out there. There was a prickliness to him that occasionally burst into the open. Like the time he marched into the press box in 2007 and confronted a journalist who had teased him in print for having the “temerity to remark that Tendulkar’s batting prowess had waned a little”. Giles didn’t like that at all. The journalist explained he was only being ironic. “What’s irony?” Giles shouted.

column1: You could hear some of that side of him in his latest interviews in Australia where
column2: as the England and Wales Cricket Board’s managing director of men’s cricket
column3: he had to try to explain how and why England had managed to make such a mess of an Ashes series for which they had spent two years planning. It was an odd interview
column4: which contained criticisms of previous England teams (“in the 90s that was accepted as normal for England leaderships and they got away with it
column5: we set our standards much higher than that”)
column6: of “armchair selectors”
column7: of England’s spinners (“we’ve got to have a spin resource that allows us to bowl much more overs of spin”)
column8: of fast bowlers (“we need a variation in our bowling attack but we need pace”)
column9: and of batsmen (“with first innings scores of 147
column12: we’re not winning many Test matches”)
column13: as well as digs at county cricket (“I think there is a dearth of leadership and in the county game”) and the international schedule. Giles also said he was at peace with the idea that he was accountable for it all. He just didn’t sound like he believed it. He came across as thin-skinned and indignant that he wasn’t being given more credit for his own modest achievements. “When I came into the job we were fifth in the world in Test cricket
column14: third in the world in Twenty20 cricket and No 1 in the world in ODIs. We’re now fourth
column15: first in T20 and second in ODIs.”

column1: Now Giles is working on his review of what went wrong. He said he didn’t want to go into his ideas for “how I want to take this team forward and improve our red-ball cricket”
column2: but he still gave a good idea of what his conclusions are likely to be. “It’s been an extraordinary year and I think we can look at the cricket-specific stuff but we also need to look at the other stuff
column3: particularly having 18 scheduled Test matches
column4: ” he said. “It’s a huge amount of cricket we’re playing and in a time of Covid it’s been pretty horrendous at times.” The players are reaching “their very top limit” of what they can deal with. On top of that
column5: Giles said
column6: what is needed now is systemic change
column7: collective responsibility
column8: and collective solutions. “We can make whatever changes we want. You can change me
column9: change the head coach
column10: change the captain. But we’re only setting up future leaders for failure.” Which underplays the degree to which getting the leadership team in place could transform the sport in this country. In the short term
column11: the difference between a good side and a bad one often is as simple as a change in the coach and the team culture. Just ask Eddie Jones. And the simple truth is
column12: everything is better in English cricket when the England team are winning. If Giles is right and more systemic change is needed
column13: the pressing question is whether
column14: given his track record in the job
column15: he is the right man to lead it
column16: given that he made such a mess of the (well-intentioned) rotation policy
column17: and the mistake of binning the head selector to load more responsibility onto the coach.

column3: who
column4: though not directly responsible for the England team’s performance
column5: has had a hand in the congested schedule
column6: the collapse of the Pakistan tour
column7: the mismanagement of the racism scandal
column8: and who also blew a ridiculous amount on a needless launch of a divisive new competition
column9: the Hundred
column10: which is now the single greatest obstacle to sorting out the first-class cricket schedule. And yet Harrison continues. As for Giles

column12: ” the 48-year-old said. No one ever said they weren’t. No one ever said that was the point

column7: 'Culture'];"If you find news websites too overwhelming
column8: too fast and too full of distractions then this might be the solution: a recreation of the BBC’s Ceefax service featuring up-to-date headlines
column9: an accurate weather map and the latest stock market prices. Nathan Dane
column11: has spent the last six years building a simulation of the BBC’s defunct text-based information service. It takes in data from the BBC’s existing website and repurposes it in the distinctively blocky font that was ubiquitous on television sets during the 1980s and 1990s.

column1: “It’s as close a recreation as I can make it
column2: ” said Dane from his home in Enniskillen
column3: Northern Ireland
column4: where he has a separate screen at his desk for showing news headlines from his recreation of Ceefax. “I do find it really useful myself. If I’m sitting in work eating my lunch I can just stick that on and get up to date. You’re not flicking about between websites – you have all the information you need on a page but without all the distraction.” At its peak
column5: tens of millions of Britons used BBC Ceefax and its commercial equivalent
column6: Teletext
column7: to check news headlines
column8: find travel information or wait an infuriatingly long time for a quiz answer to be revealed. Individual stories were often split across multiple pages
column9: meaning it could take minutes to fully comprehend an article if you were unlucky enough to load halfway through a piece. Only a few sentences of text fitted on each screen
column10: forcing writers to develop the skills to produce concise stories. But the limitations and slowness of a system designed in 1974 may be increasingly attractive in a world of unlimited choice
column11: while the cluttered advertising-heavy designs of many modern websites have made people nostalgic for the simplicity of Ceefax.

column1: The BBC closed the original Ceefax service as part of the transition to digital television broadcasts
column2: with Northern Ireland being the last region of the UK to lose access. “We had Ceefax in this part of the world until 2012
column3: which is probably the only reason I remember it
column4: ” said Dane
column5: who works for a digital signage company. “I have a great interest in all the old broadcast-TV type stuff. The Premier League football table (page 324) is up to date. A selection of national
column6: foreign and local stories can be accessed through the headlines section (page 101). Some fans have also set up YouTube streams looping through Ceefax pages with muzak in the background

column1: 186;186;5429;5429; Bill Bernstein’s best photograph: joy and humanity in a homeless centre;2022-01-05T15:00:02Z;['Daniel Dylan Wray'];['Art and design'
column2: 'Photography'
column3: 'Culture'
column4: 'Homelessness'
column5: 'Poverty'
column6: 'Society'];"In the 1970s I lived in SoHo in New York
column7: which is not far from the Bowery
column8: but the two districts were like separate universes. SoHo was full of artists and creative types but the Bowery was known as the place where you ended up when you were at the bottom of the barrel. There were a lot of flophouses and a lot of alcoholism and drug use. It was the darkest place in New York City for a long time. The Bowery Mission is a Christian rescue centre for homeless people. Only men are allowed to stay overnight but it feeds anybody. I used to go there around Thanksgiving and Christmas time to help serve dinner. The face-to-face contact and interactions I had with people meant that I always felt a real connection with them
column9: and it also made me grateful for what I had in my own life. In the 1990s there was a lot of focus on homelessness in New York City and money and public attention were put towards trying to end it. And then
column10: in the early 2000s
column11: the interest faded. It’s not that the problem went away – on the contrary – but for some reason we weren’t talking about it any more. That bothered me
column12: so I thought to myself: what can I do? I figured as a photographer I could create something that brings a little attention to these people and their situation. So I contacted the Bowery Mission and asked to do some portraits of the centre’s regular users.

column1: They gave me a room upstairs to work in. If you want to get a meal at the Bowery Mission
column2: you have to also attend a religious service. So I’d wait until people had eaten and listened to the sermon and were chilled out and relaxed and only then would I approach to ask if I could photograph them. I needed to be very careful because in a lot of ways these people are very fragile
column3: but I was also surprised by how much – had I not known they were homeless – I would have never guessed their circumstances. My plan was to focus on faces and eyes
column4: because we so often walk down the street and see somebody and we don’t want to actually look at them or engage. Not to sound corny but I was interested in trying to get into their story and their soul. I was interested when couples arrived at the centre as it was clear that they lived together on the streets. These guys were such a great pair. When they smiled
column5: I was like: that’s the picture. I shot with something called an Octabank
column6: which is like a gigantic umbrella that’s about six feet wide and means that the whole face is beautifully lit. It’s more often used in fashion photography. A lot of pictures of homeless people are really sad. I didn’t want to do that. There is some joy in these people
column7: and that’s what I wanted to show. That’s why I lit it the way I did. And from the poses I wanted to get the depth of feeling of them as humans but I also wanted to get over the fact that you would hang with some of these people – they’re cool! I choose deliberately not to publish their names out of consideration for their privacy and because I wanted to focus on the faces and humanity of the people captured in the moment in the project. With these two it was clear that they had each other
column8: and that was pretty much it in their lives at that point. I wanted to give a sense of what their relationship felt like. I was trying to get them to centre themselves in front of the camera
column9: and just be who they were and not try to do anything special or performative. Many of us are only a couple of steps away from something like homelessness. I was feeling helpless about a situation in my city that I thought was terrible and a life condition I saw every day when I walked out of my door. The worse the situation becomes the more it is normalised and your sense of helplessness is eventually numbed. I exhibited the work in the Mission headquarters in Midtown. We blew up eight or nine of the photographs to around 6ft by 4ft. You’re looking at these huge eyes and faces and the impact of having all those pictures in one room was pretty overwhelming. I think they felt really special having all the lights and cameras and attention on them when doing this project. I hope that feeling lasted for a while. Bill Bernstein’s CV

column8: the head of retail and consumer insight at Kantar

column6: brussels sprouts and Christmas pudding at the supermarket.

column5: 'Business'];"Nicola Sturgeon has cut Scotland’s self-isolation period from 10 to seven days
column6: after sustained pressure from businesses and opposition parties to address soaring staff absences. The first minister told MSPs on Wednesday her government’s highly cautious stance on the 10-day isolation period was being softened after data from hospitals suggested the Omicron variant was less medically severe than feared. Sturgeon also confirmed Scotland would adopt a new rule on taking PCR tests announced in England earlier on Wednesday
column7: to cut the number of PCR tests being taken unnecessarily and to conserve supplies. She said the requirement for someone with a positive lateral flow test to immediately book a PCR would be dropped
column8: as long as they did not have symptoms. That new rule will come into force on Thursday 6 January
column9: rather than 11 January as in England. Ministers in England and in Wales cut self-isolation to a week in December after deciding the impact of extended self-isolation on public services and businesses was not outweighed by Omicron’s risk to health and critical care services. In a recalled session of the Scottish parliament
column10: where she faced heavy criticism over the quality of NHS data in Scotland

column12: have no symptoms and record negative tests every day for seven days

The train operator ScotRail cut hundreds of services this month owing to staff shortages. Hospitality companies and retailers have struggled to stay open

column10: 'Society'];"There’s a moment in The Lost Daughter
column11: Maggie Gyllenhaal’s adaptation of the Elena Ferrante novel which stars Olivia Colman
column12: where I gasped out loud and swore at the character. Colman’s Leda
column13: a professor holidaying in Greece alone
column14: is conversing awkwardly with a pregnant stranger. “Children are a crushing responsibility
column15: ” she says
column16: by way of a conversational coda. The bluntness of Colman’s delivery meant that I was laughing as I gasped
column17: but still: everyone knows it to be on some level true
column18: but you don’t go around saying such things to pregnant women. Or at least
column19: you shouldn’t.

column1: The Netflix film is a fairly faithful adaptation of the 2006 novel; it holds the same capacity to shock while bringing out new feelings and elucidations. The moment in the film where one of Leda’s daughters cuts her finger and repeatedly begs her mother – a younger Leda
column2: played by Jessie Buckley – to kiss it better
column3: is far more emotionally affecting than when described in the slim
column4: interior novel. “Poor creatures who came out of my belly
column5: ” Leda narrates in the book
column6: and as a cinematic audience at times we are inclined to agree with her. Because what sort of mother abandons her children
column7: as Leda does? Is maternal ambivalence still a taboo? Some insist that it is
column8: though a woman failing to love her children as society deems she should is hardly a new story
column9: either in literature or reality. Maternal cruelty is still shocking
column10: whether it comes in the form of a performance of Medea or another heartbreaking headline case of child murder or neglect. For some
column11: even having mixed feelings about motherhood warrants punishment. Rachel Cusk’s 2015 adaptation of Medea at the Almeida theatre featured a chorus of “conforming yummy mummies”; Cusk herself was castigated by such a chorus for A Life’s Work
column12: her 2001 book which committed the crime of being honest about how exhausting and miserable it was to have a baby who cried unceasingly (hardly a controversial revelation
column13: or at least not by today’s standards). “Again and again people judged the book not as readers but as mothers
column14: ” Cusk later wrote. In recent years there has been a proliferation of awareness-raising about maternal ambivalence
column15: especially postnatal depression. Courageous women have spoken out and written about it
column16: defying what Cusk describes as the tendency of the communal to prevail over the individual when it comes to motherhood. These women are brave because the voices that contradict a powerful cultural myth are so often castigated. Eventually these voices formed their own chorus
column17: and the taboo itself is weakening
column18: or at least it seems that way to me. Yet these works maintain an emotional force
column19: perhaps because now
column20: with our greater understanding
column21: we know just how close so many mothers have come to being driven mad by it. Perhaps
column22: we worry
column23: our own mothers were. It is not a comfortable feeling
column24: and The Lost Daughter is not a comfortable film. Leda is not held up for judgment by us
column25: though at times the audience may of course judge her. In a recent adaptation of Nancy Mitford’s The Pursuit of Love
column26: maternal abandonment is played for laughs in the form of the character of “The Bolter”
column27: Fanny’s mother
column28: who flees any form of commitment. It is tonally entirely different to The Lost Daughter
column29: but again
column30: simple judgment is the least interesting reaction one can have. It feels less scandalous
column31: these days
column32: to admit that women can have other interests besides childrearing
column33: and that finding a way to reconcile making art
column34: in particular
column35: with the division of domestic labour is a worthy source of creative exploration. Works such as Lara Feigel’s Free Woman
column36: which explores Doris Lessing’s maternal ambivalence (she abandoned two of her children) as well as her own
column37: have added to this conversation
column38: as have novels by Sheila Heti
column39: Jenny Offill
column40: and Avni Doshi
column41: among others. Yet the death of Joan Didion saw a resurgence of the Caitlin Flanagan article in which she puts Didion’s childcare arrangements under the microscope. “Where was Quintana when Didion was living at the Faculty Club
column42: or finishing her novels at her parents’ house
column43: or bunking down in the Haight”
column44: Flanagan asks. “Not with her mother.” Those four words drip with judgment. “The children stared at me
column45: ” Leda narrates towards the end of the novel The Lost Daughter. “I felt their gazes longing to tame me
column46: but more brilliant was the brightness of life outside them
column47: new colours
column48: new bodies
column49: new intelligence
column50: a language to possess finally as if it were my true language
column51: and nothing
column52: nothing that seemed to me reconcilable with that domestic space from which they stared at me in expectation.” Ferrante remains the empress of maternal ambivalence. It comes down to language. In The Days of Abandonment

column7: 'World news'];To call Omicron’s rise in the UK “precipitate” is to violently understate matters. Daily case counts have broken the record set just the day before over and over again. Yesterday they hit over 218

column39: nothing at all. Any prescriptions for how to slow Omicron will be met

column45: next to luxury buildings and nice cars – all the same things
column46: ” says NasDas’s manager
column47: a 32-year-old who appears in the videos anonymously as the “masked man”.

column1: There are rappers
column2: dancers
column3: humorists and makeup artists from those places – but few instances of people simply documenting daily life. Nordine Idri
column4: a 17-year-old from Marseille who recounted his former life as a drug-network lookout on YouTube
column5: is another isolated example. Cinema about the cités (estates) – from La Haine to Intouchables to Girlhood – has tended to be steered by outsiders (2019’s Les Misérables was a rare high-profile example told by the residents themselves). But it seems surprising that social media
column6: where all the technology needed fits into your pocket
column7: hasn’t produced more chroniclers of the quartiers. Maybe the impulse in those impoverished places is more towards the aspirational kind of influencing. NasDas likes flashing the cash
column8: too. But the extraordinary thing is that he seems to give most of it away – he forks out banknotes on his feed almost every day. By summer this year
column9: he was Snapchat’s top influencer in France (or so he claims – Snapchat won’t confirm with exact figures) and had successfully monetised his operation with commercial contracts and product placements: for dentists
column10: online CV apps
column11: iced tea
column12: luxury cars
column13: all sorts. He estimates that he gives away about 80% of what he earns – most of it privately
column14: he says. Developing St Jacques is his main priority; with handouts
column15: through education (he encourages truant kids to go to school and organises street clean-ups for his Snap feed) and by promoting local businesses. The day before the race
column16: this social-media Robin Hood sits sipping a café noisette at a table on Place Cassanyes. He is six feet tall
column17: easygoing in the flesh compared with his antic Snapchat persona
column18: but authoritative too. He says people coming from all over France for selfies with him proves that he has changed St Jacques’ image. As we talk
column19: two brothers from Grenoble step up for a moment with their hero. But NasDas acknowledges that his neighbourhood won’t change overnight: “There’s a reality you shouldn’t hide. The level of violence is still quite high
column20: unfortunately. In my eyes it’s too high
column21: because I can’t stand violence.” In August a 23-year-old man was shot and killed outside a takeaway only metres away. On NasDas’s finger is a gold lion signet ring. Maybe it stands for his mother
column22: whom he describes as a “lion”. She is where he gets his sense of social responsibility from; she raised him and his four siblings solo after his father died when he was 10. They lived two floors above the abandoned police station on the corner of Place Cassanyes that became St Jacques’ key drug-dealing point. Some of his peers were earning €300 a day when he was 16
column23: but she battled to keep him out of the trade. Now
column24: with his newfound fame
column25: he’s taking St Jacques under his wing. *** At Perpignan’s funfair
column26: the dusk sky has faded to dark ochre as the Day-Glo lights of the rides obscure the stars. Team NasDas is trying to do a “low-profile” trip
column27: so he can chaperone his young niece and nephew. At least
column28: as low-profile as you can be when you and your right-hand man
column29: Samos
column30: are dressed in matching white tracksuits. At the entrance
column31: people are already peeking and whispering: “Il y a NasDas” (his niece is helpfully wearing a “NasDas la Chiennété” T-shirt). Soon they’re sidling up for a non-stop stream of photos. Next to the waltzers
column32: we get bogged down by fans and well-wishers for nearly 20 minutes. “He’s so funny
column33: ” gush a couple of twentysomething local women. “He doesn’t give a damn.” During hundreds of interactions
column34: NasDas is staunchly friendly – but there is a weary lag in his eyes. He admits he has struggled with his breakneck rise to fame
column35: and the constant requests for money and help: “There was a point I thought I was going mad. I just wanted to go and drink a coffee like everyone else
column36: and I couldn’t.” When he began having anxiety attacks
column37: his managers took him out to the countryside to get things in perspective. A couple of sessions with a therapist later
column38: he got back on the horse.

column1: Milling around him at the funfair is most of Team NasDas: Samos
column2: the rail-thin
column3: broken-toothed pal who often serves as his stooge in the videos; Tounsi
column4: a burly
column5: gruff twentysomething who is the only one NasDas was close to prior to fame; 4BDV
column6: an urchin-like 17-year-old who looks 12 and whom NasDas took into his house after he showed up in St Jacques after crossing the Mediterranean from Algeria by boat (the influencer is applying to be his legal guardian); only Billy DZ – ill
column7: apparently – isn’t present. Now there is an entire infrastructure supporting the team: a total of 40 people – including two Paris influencer agencies – looking after technical support
column8: event bookings
column9: commercial opportunities and strategy. And NasDas is sizing up the world beyond social media; he will soon appear on TV talkshows
column10: Netflix has contacted him about a possible documentary
column11: and he plans to perform a one-man show at Paris’s 3
column12: 000-seater Olympia venue next year. Even those things could be just the beginning. NasDas likes to use his feed to flex his social conscience
column13: beyond handouts for the residents. He has often criticised Perpignan town hall’s management of St Jacques; dysfunctional and corrupt under previous administrations
column14: but now with an extra vindictive edge under Louis Aliot
column15: the only far-right Rassemblement National mayor of a major French city. The influencer recently turned his smartphone on the case of an eight-year-old taken into police custody (along with 4BDV) after being spotted on CCTV with a plastic pellet gun. Parking charges imposed in September on Place Cassanyes – which many residents can’t afford are another of NasDas’s targets. Whether it’s judicial or economic
column16: he sees the intended effect in straightforward terms: “It’s repression.”

column1: Now that NasDas has become a public figure
column2: the town hall has begun taking notice of him
column3: he says. “I think they’re even more offended because I’m not asking for their help. It disturbs them: a young Maghrebin who doesn’t ask for help and succeeds in sorting out the neighbourhood.” (The town hall did not respond to requests for comment.) But he could have the perfect reply. He plans to stand for the national assembly in June elections to attempt to become one of four MPs for Pyrenées-Orientales
column4: the département of which Perpignan is capital. “I want to shatter the cliches
column5: ” he says. “I’m young
column6: of colour
column7: someone who dares. I want to annoy people a bit. To show France who we are.” Pyrenées-Orientales has about 350
column8: 000 registered voters; if only a portion of NasDas’s followers vote for him
column9: he could be Snapchatting from parliament this time next year. The pressures on NasDas aren’t just from the outside. St Jacques has a long history of unhealthy dependency on community figureheads with privileged access to power. Going back to the 1970s
column10: there have been claims that patriarchs among some Gypsy families in St Jacques traded the community vote for political favours. Cash sums and white goods were allegedly distributed after elections; latterly jobs and influence over the long-mooted renovation of this tumbledown district. Now NasDas
column11: through the power conferred by social media
column12: is the one with influence – in every sense. There can be no doubting his deep solicitude for St Jacques

column14: as we’re talking
column15: he is collared by a community “big brother”
column16: who harangues him in Arabic. Ten minutes later
column17: he turns up again
column18: demanding that NasDas speak to someone on the phone. What was that about? Apparently
column19: the man is one of several intermediaries
column20: including the man on the phone and someone else in prison
column21: who are facilitating a product placement on Snapchat for a business in Paris. He was trying to get NasDas to lower his fee to €5
column23: so he can take a larger
column25: 000 cut of the original price. The influencer insists it is just an isolated case; that he experiences virtually no open jealousy
column26: and 99.99% of St Jacques is behind him. But you suspect that this coveting of the money and publicity NasDas is generating will increase as his star rises. In any case

column1: Half an hour later
column2: on the racetrack of Place Cassanyes
column3: another kind of people management is required. At 8.05pm
column4: the square is heaving. “Disperse!” insists NasDas – and the throng loiters on all four sides
column5: trying to look as inconspicuous as 300 people gathered for the same reason can. Five minutes later
column6: NasDas has called off the race. Three policeman on bikes are mingling among them; Tounsi reckons it’s a warning shot across the bows. With Aliot watching
column7: there can’t be any slip-ups. The disappointed crowd starts filing away. Grinning incredulously – as if wondering how all this has happened – NasDas retreats to a cafe to stream his reactions. He’s going nowhere: “I was in St Jacques before social media
column8: I’m here during social media
column9: and I’ll be here afterwards too.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/i-want-to-show-france-who-we-are-the-slum-influencer-with-his-sights-on-parliament;5

column7: 'PFAS'];"Anti-fogging sprays and cloths often used to prevent condensation on eyeglasses from wearing a mask or on face shields may contain high levels of potentially toxic PFAS “forever chemicals”
column8: according to a new study led by Duke University. Researchers tested four of the top-rated anti-fogging sprays as well as five top-rated anti-fogging cloths sold by Amazon. In all nine products
column9: experts found fluorotelomer alcohols (FTOHs) and fluorotelomer ethoxylates (FTEOs)
column10: two types of per- and polyfluorinated alkyl substances (PFAS). PFAS have been dubbed as forever chemicals due to their longevity in the environment. “Our tests show the sprays contain up to 20.7 milligrams of PFAS per milliliter of solution
column11: which is a pretty high concentration
column12: ” said study lead Nicholas Herkert
column13: a postdoctoral researcher at Duke’s Nicholas School of the Environment.

column1: Exposure to some PFAs – perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) and perfluorooctanesulfonic acid (PFOS) in particular – have been linked to cancer
column2: thyroid disease
column3: fertility complications and other health problems. Herkert noted that FTOHs and FTEOs have not been studied extensively
column4: so scientists do not know what health risks they could pose
column5: but research currently suggests that FTOHs inhaled or absorbed through the skin could break down in the body and become toxic
column6: long-lasting PFAs. The FTEOs used in all four anti-fogging sprays were also analyzed in the new study and exhibited substantial cell-altering toxicity and conversion to fat cells during lab tests
column7: said Herkert. “It’s disturbing to think that products people have been using on a daily basis to help keep themselves safe during the Covid pandemic may be exposing them to a different risk
column8: ” said Heather Stapleton
column9: a distinguished professor of environmental chemistry and health at Duke. Stapleton initiated the study after reviewing the ingredients in a bottle of anti-fogging spray she bought for her 9-year-old daughter. Stapleton noted that the other eight products did not have their ingredients listed
column10: making it virtually impossible to tell if they contained toxic chemicals until they were analyzed using equipment from her research laboratory. This study
column11: conducted by Herkert and Stapleton with researchers from Duke University
column12: Wayne State University
column13: and the University of North Carolina at Charlotte
column14: is only the second ever to focus on FTEOS. The researchers published their peer-reviewed study on 5 January in the journal Environmental Science & Technology. Herkert and Stapleton said that more research would be needed to expand on initial findings
column15: with larger studies involving tests on living organisms being the next step. Studies that include a larger sample size of sprays and cloths could also help identify other unknown chemicals being used in these products. “Because of Covid
column16: more people than ever
column17: including many medical professionals and other first-responders
column18: are using these sprays and cloths to keep their glasses from fogging up when they wear masks or face shields
column19: ” said Stapleton. “They deserve to know what’s in the products they’re using.”";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/05/pfas-forever-chemicals-anti-fogging-spray-wipes;7

column6: 'England'];"My play began in a flash of inspiration
column7: but it would take me 10 years to finish it. At one point I completely discarded it as a failed project
column8: then Hampstead theatre’s Roxana Silbert inspired me to go back. Covid interfered and the production was delayed
column9: making me fear it might never see the light of day; then BBC Radio 3 included my adaptation in their Drama on 3/Culture in Quarantine series. Now
column10: finally
column11: the play has a full production at Hampstead theatre. I have a history of burning manuscripts that don’t please me
column12: but luckily this one had escaped the fire. I grew up in Somerset
column13: first in Glastonbury
column14: then in a small village on the edge of the Somerset Levels. Back in Glastonbury in 2009 I went to see an exhibition at the Rural Life Museum about Cecil Sharp and folk music. Sharp collected songs from 1903 until 1924
column15: and founded what is now the English Folk Song and Dance Society. In the exhibition there was a photograph of John England
column16: a gardener who had sung to Sharp what is purported to be the first song he ever collected
column17: The Seeds of Love. There was another of a singer who had lived in my own village. Then I saw the images of two sisters from a village near mine
column18: Louie Hooper and Lucy White
column19: who between them sang over 100 songs to Sharp.

column1: Folk-song collecting was a growing movement in the early years of the 20th century
column2: driven by a desire to rescue these songs before they were lost to the tail end of the Industrial Revolution
column3: when machines would work the land and the sewing would be moved into factories. Sharp published many of them
column4: arranging them for piano and editing the lyrics so that they were suitable for a middle-class audience. He tidied rhymes and rhythms and then placed his name on them
column5: copyrighting them. At the time this wasn’t seen as an egregious act. The two sisters gave Sharp over 100 songs
column6: yet their names were nowhere
column7: their stories untold. The images of the sisters kept coming back to me. I did some research and learned that they were the daughters of a well-known singer who would have sung these songs to her children
column8: songs that they knew by heart. I started to imagine what it might feel like if your body contained that many songs
column9: enough to sing for days without repetition. I write both drama and prose
column10: and ideas are born inside their form: this was definitely a play
column11: about the human voice
column12: about live song. I found an incredible transcript of a 1940s interview with Louie Hooper
column13: then in her 80s
column14: where she talked about her love for music
column15: how she listened to birds and rain
column16: found musical patterns in their sounds
column17: and how she sat by the older people in the village and “caught” their songs. She fascinated me. It is always the untold story
column18: the silent voice that captures my imagination.

column1: Meanwhile my research quickly revealed Sharp as opinionated and ferociously ambitious – Sharp by name
column2: sharp by nature. He was virulently against women’s suffrage
column3: and had refused to collect songs from black American singers. He published many of the songs that he collected in Somerset and beyond all under his name
column4: and promoted himself as the expert on folk song
column5: building a career on other people’s work. It would be easy to write a play that dismantled him
column6: and yet there was a problem. Sharp had another side: he had great respect for the country people who sang
column7: and managed to collect about 5
column8: 000 songs that
column9: were it not for his writing them down in his notebooks
column10: would otherwise have been lost. That dissonance would be at the heart of the play. I now had the story
column11: but as the themes started to become clear
column12: the complexity of the subject matter became overwhelming. The songs were also being gathered at a time when it was felt that England lacked a great classical composer. Since Purcell (who died in 1695)
column13: all the new music had been European and we were considered “Das Land ohne Musik” – the country without music. Sharp and his collecting peers hoped that these folk songs would stimulate composers to create a new classical music based on them
column14: and place England at the centre of classical music once again.

column1: Sharp furthermore saw these songs as having the potential to “refine and strengthen the national character” in the years before the first world war. This nationalism was the theme that caused me the most problems: it made me think about my feelings about my own country. The play is clearly about England
column2: her songs and her landscape; I was writing it at a time when I felt a sense of nationalism rising as we headed into and out of the Brexit referendum
column3: and
column4: also
column5: as the world around me was changing and questions were starting to be asked about the history of our country houses and artefacts in museums. History became more interesting and much more complex as it became more rigorous and more inclusive of others’ narratives. Sharp found “his” England very near where I am from. My imagination was born in my village in Somerset
column6: and I have a creative attachment to the land. I look back on my life there with an extraordinary sense of richness
column7: but I don’t know what to do with these feelings. How do I express that love without being nationalistic? And how do I express that love
column8: knowing that to romanticise the past is to ignore the fact that there was an intolerance to difference and a casual racism in my own village where in 1977 dogs were still named the N-word.

column1: I have come to see that the play is my way of working through those questions. Every time I write it is to find out what I think. Sharp raided the villages for the songs on which he built his career
column2: yet he also saved the songs. The play demanded that I find a way to show those two dissonant facts in the same story. I also needed to find a way of showing that I love the place where I was born
column3: without ignoring the complexities of that place and my feelings about it. As Louie Hooper says in my play: “Everyone loves their country. It’s just the bit of land where we was born
column4: what we first see and smell. It’s the stories
column5: the songs.” The songs Sharp collected did lead to many types of new music
column6: including the big folk revival in the 60s
column7: which still feeds folk musicians today; it also led to new classical music from Holst
column8: Vaughan Williams and Butterworth
column9: which in turn inspired Benjamin Britten. We owe all of this to Sharp
column10: but we also owe it all to a pair of little-known sisters who lived on the edge of the water
column11: right in the heart of the Somerset Levels. • Folk by Nell Leyshon is at Hampstead theatre until 5 February.";https://www.theguardian.com/music/2022/jan/05/folks-unsung-heroines-cecil-sharp-nell-leyshon-hampstead-theatre;5

column9: 'Musicals'];"Growing up

column34: Hale says

column36: giving a live account of the action

column42: eyes

column1: Soon the stage is filled with figures dancing. From my seat three rows from the front

column4: the “arms flailing
column5: feet tapping”

column7: pirouettes and leaps
column8: characters sashaying across the stage

column12: or them fidgeting nervously. She captures the tenderness of the moment when Zach and Paul hug
column13: describing the warmth of their embrace. I feel the weight of it with the same strength as fully sighted audience members. The commentary feels natural

column1: I recognise outfits from the pre-show talk
column2: and spot Bebe quickly
column3: remembering how Hinton-Lever described the character’s long red hair. During the finale
column4: my mind goes back to the look and feel of the golden costumes
column5: and how Beasley said they sparkle in the light. One of the hardest things about watching theatre growing up was not being able to tell which character was speaking. When you can’t see people’s lips move
column6: voices hang unaccounted for

column11: I’m able to follow a play. And it’s a revelation. I can enjoy theatre! I feel included. I am part of this shared experience. As I leave the auditorium and hand back my headset

column4: 'Sport'];"About this time 28 years ago the star of Swindon Town’s only season in the top flight finally started scoring. But not
column5: alas
column6: in those of Swindon

column11: before Swindon play Manchester City in the Cup’s third round on Friday. He cherishes his memories of Swindon and of a season in which he and his team endured harrowing lows while trying

column1: “We conceded 100 goals

column6: Glenn Hoddle
column7: was hired by Chelsea
column8: leaving his assistant
column9: John Gorman

column11: he was useless at first. Swindon did not win until they beat Queens Park Rangers 1-0 in their 16th league match
column12: by which time Fjørtoft
column13: still goalless
column14: had been dropped.

column1: “In the first game of the season at Sheffield United [lost 3-1]
column2: I got a knock
column3: ” says Fjørtoft
column4: bought after four free-scoring seasons with Rapid Vienna. “I had never been injured in my life and that was the start of a bad circle for me. I kept on playing because I was desperate to get that first goal and contribute to our first win. We were suffering heavy losses and it became the first time in my life that I didn’t score goals. I started to doubt myself. When you start losing your self-confidence
column5: you make compromises in the way you play and then you kind of drag yourself further into the dump. By the time of that win against QPR
column6: I was struggling. “Then Christmas Eve of 1993 was the lowest point of my career. I played for Swindon reserves against Wycombe Wanderers reserves on one of these fantastic facilities you have in England with like 12 pitches next to each other. It was cold and windy
column7: I was freezing to death and I was the worst player on the pitch. I remember I came home and opened the door and said dramatically to my wife: ‘Have a look at me now because no one can ever get lower in their football career than I am now.’” Paradoxically

column10: Jan.’ It was all over the place. That was an unbelievable moment.” An amazing transformation took place. Suddenly flush with confidence
column11: Fjørtoft cancelled the loan and became convinced he would open his Premier League account against Tottenham four days later
column12: in Swindon’s 27th league game. “After 20 minutes [the Spurs goalkeeper] Erik Thorstvedt

column1: The floodgates opened: in the final 16 games of the season Fjørtoft scored 12 goals

column2: 'Culture'
column3: 'Television & radio'
column4: 'Matt Berry'
column5: 'TV comedy'
column6: 'Comedy'];Steven Toast is the Fellini of failure. He’s an actor who can empty a theatre faster than a teargas canister. He’s a more disastrous on-set presence than an Omicron outbreak. And – after six years – he brazenly swaggers back on to our screens this week
column7: proving that it isn’t just a good man you can’t keep down. BBC Two’s Toast of Tinseltown is an incredibly welcome return for one of the best comic creations of the last 10 years. Toast (Matt Berry) has relocated to Hollywood
column8: following three series of Toast of London – which saw him tailspinning through demeaning bit parts
column9: mortifying scandals and doomed auditions since its launch in 2013. Now
column10: Toast believes he will finally get his due
column11: and the great wrong of his omission from the acting pantheon will be righted. There is one tiny problem
column12: though: the acting pantheon doesn’t want him. He doesn’t even make it to the opening credits of Toast of Tinseltown’s first episode before a furious Larry David is yelling: “Are you serious? Is this guy a real actor?” To see Toast in action is to be treated to the enthralling spectacle of a man who unshakeably believes that he is one of the finest thespians of his generation
column13: despite being the recipient of worst actor awards. For the whole of the first series
column14: rotten-veg-hurling protesters greet him upon his entrance to the stage door of the production he’s appearing in – dubbed London’s worst play. He gets the kind of radioactive reviews that have sunk the careers of better men
column15: has been cancelled by the literal PC police and was once buried alive by a maverick director. Toast wants to be the Milk Tray man
column16: but ends up as Basildon Bond. He’s the ultimate fish out of water
column17: an analogue actor in the digital age. Even his rivalries are the stuff of Greek myth – eternal conflicts played out by idiots. As the screen and stage work dries up
column18: he is reduced to cornball voiceovers where he is tormented by the millennial inanities of hipster sound guys Danny Bear (Tim Downie) and Clem Fandango (Shazad Latif). Toast facing down these Urban Outfitters rejects who have him read out obscene hearing aid adverts
column19: honking horns and whinnying like a horse offers a joy seldom seen on TV. You watch as the generation gap becomes a chasm. But the real joy is his ultimate rivalry with Ray Purchase (Harry Peacock)– a taller
column20: leaner
column21: more handsome Toast
column22: who looks like a Reader’s Digest knitwear model. In the first episode of Toast of Tinseltown
column23: the ludicrously OTT competition for a movie role and the affections of Mrs Purchase (Tracy-Ann Oberman) has Toast karate-chopping desks in half
column24: with Purchase’s moustache writhing so furiously it’s in danger of leaping clear off his face. The raw physical presence of Peacock’s scenery-chewing Purchase bumping up against Toast’s unbridled contempt and hauteur make it an unmissable watch. Berry’s role as Toast is responsible for the best performances of his career. Some say that Matt Berry always plays Matt Berry and
column25: admittedly
column26: if you’re looking for the range of Daniel Day-Lewis
column27: you will be disappointed. But this is to miss the point – Berry’s work is best seen as a single piece of performance art
column28: a career-long excavation of a very specific kind of near-extinct masculinity – all Old Spice
column29: coiffured hair and hammy glares. So of course there are deep echoes of previous characters: Doctor Sanchez in Darkplace
column30: Douglas Reynholm in The IT Crowd
column31: his perma-foiled suitor from Snuff Box. Toast
column32: though
column33: is the apex predator of Matt Berry characters. The rest are merely pale imitations. This is especially true given what a showcase Toast is for Berry’s unique musical output. Many episodes feature absurdist musical numbers that see him do things like duet with a moustachioed child version of himself about the shame of visiting a sex worker. Then there’s the surprisingly catchy masonic ritual ditty On the Square. Given the influence of co-writer/creator Arthur Mathews
column34: there are characters and scenes that wouldn’t be out of place in Father Ted – although the prospect of a Ted/Toast cinematic universe seems likely to remain a pipe dream. Dreams are sometimes all we have
column35: though
column36: and the saga of Steven Toast is all about one man’s dream to achieve the recognition he manifestly does not deserve. That thick-eared tenacity is the main thing that makes him relatable. If you’ve ever felt out of your depth at work
column37: bewildered by some aspect of youth culture or unjustly overlooked then all of a sudden
column38: he starts to make sense. He’ll never quit. Deny it all you like
column39: but there’s a bit of Toast in all of us.;https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/jan/05/one-of-the-best-comic-creations-of-the-last-10-years-matt-berry-is-back-as-steven-toast;5
