column2: a new year’;2022-01-05T12:14:24Z;['Jami Attenberg'];['Creative writing'
column3: 'Fiction'
column4: 'Books'
column5: 'Culture'];"When I was 21
column6: a man considered to be an authority on literature suggested I not become a writer. It was a few days before I graduated from college with a degree in creative writing. The National Book award-winning writer who had taught our senior fiction seminar told me
column7: quite gently
column8: to give up on my dreams. I can picture so clearly that room where we sat together
column9: him behind a desk
column10: sunlight streaming in from the windows behind him. He was not happy to see me when I walked in the door. I was young and punk and weird and had big hair. He was 55
column11: bearded
column12: grey and bespectacled. All semester
column13: he had barely critiqued my stories
column14: remaining quiet in class as my peers rattled off suggestions and ideas. He returned printouts of my work with just a few scribbles added. And now here I was visiting him in his office
column15: ready for the moment where he would tell me where I could improve
column16: what paths he thought I should take. He asked me what I wanted to do after graduation
column17: and I told him I wanted to write. He said: “You know
column18: honey
column19: not everyone makes it as a writer.” I walked out of his office
column20: dazed and discouraged. I suppose I had wanted him to say: “You’re a genius. Let me make a few calls and get you an agent. Or a job that will set you on your way.”

column1: Perhaps he thought I didn’t have talent. Or
column2: perhaps he saw me as frivolous. I was writing stories about sex and relationships and so-called domestic matters. I remember I wrote an entire short story about a woman waiting to get her period. He wrote big
column3: sprawling novels that were about soldiers and war and violence. Maybe he didn’t enjoy teaching; he had never seemed excited to be there. To discourage someone from even trying
column4: though? To say “give up” before I’d even gotten started? Writing is holy
column5: as my friend Patricia Lockwood says. It is true that it is hard to make it as a writer
column6: or any kind of artist
column7: for that matter. But if you love to write
column8: you should write forever. For years I have used this story as inspiration. He told me I couldn’t
column9: and yet somehow I did anyway. He was an older man
column10: negative and condescending. I’ll show him
column11: I thought. But it is only recently that I realised that moment was actually radically freeing. I was probably not suited to be a writer in the way he thought was important. But that did not mean I was not suited to be a writer. In a way
column12: he gave me a fresh start
column13: a new year. The first of January of the rest of my life. In fact
column14: he was telling me the truth as he knew it. The career path of a fiction writer in 1993 was defined but also limited. Achieving a master of fine arts degree
column15: perhaps adjunct teaching
column16: submitting to literary journals
column17: the New Yorker
column18: Granta
column19: the Paris Review
column20: every little journal across America
column21: applying for grants and residencies
column22: maybe working toward tenure. A lot of it sounded like the kind of work that I wouldn’t be any good at.

column1: But that was what was available at the time. There were no obvious workarounds coming out of the academic world. What I took away from him was that I would have to carve my own path. No problem
column2: easy-peasy. I only had to fail a hundred times to get there
column3: get terrible reviews until I got good reviews
column4: go broke once or twice (OK thrice)
column5: toss out any idea of achieving conventional life goals
column6: and essentially edit my very existence in service of being a writer. But I was that
column7: after all
column8: even if it took more than a decade to arrive there. I took dozens of jobs I could quit easily – and often did. I waited tables
column9: tended bars and temped in a blur of offices across the US. I made so many mistakes
column10: but I was always keeping my eye on the prize: the time to read and write and think. No matter what
column11: I always found my way back to writing. That’s the part that kept me sane all along. Not selling a book or publishing a book but making the book in the first place. Finally
column12: I landed in New York City. I worked in advertising
column13: writing bits of terrible copy to keep the lights on. I went to readings and studied other writers. I started to give readings myself. I made a few zines. The whole time I wasn’t thinking about literary credibility. I just wanted to write because it was the thing I loved best. I was building this creative life without consciously knowing it. I found my way to the internet in the late 90s. I started as someone with a blog. It wasn’t the way you were supposed to do it at the time
column14: but it was the way that made the most sense to me. There was no splashy short story debut in the New Yorker. But I attracted a readership
column15: and worked my way into writing essays
column16: more zines and then a short book with a small press
column17: and then very blindly and naively writing a linked story collection
column18: my first with a big press
column19: 13 years after I had graduated from college. Things have gotten a little easier as time has gone on
column20: but still I never relax. There is no coasting in a creative life; we are constantly adjusting
column21: altering
column22: tending our paths. And there’s a lot of insecurity: about money
column23: your identity
column24: your place in the world
column25: your reviews
column26: your relevance. A few things have helped me along the way: ideas or actions to continue stimulating my growth as a person and an artist. Travelling is one. I’ve driven across country
column27: caught trains to different cities and ridden my bike all over New York City in search of a new cafe or a sculpture garden I hadn’t seen before. Even just walking everywhere I can has been helpful
column28: eyes up
column29: paying attention
column30: watching
column31: listening. And I have read constantly
column32: outside my genre as well as within it. Reading is the surest path to understanding. It leads to a fullness within us. I focused on friendships
column33: too
column34: becoming part of a cohort I didn’t necessarily know I was developing – I have always just been so excited to meet other writers. I went to readings and drinks after literary conferences
column35: sent emails and liked tweets because I wanted to. The extra gift is that these people end up being your best cheerleaders and critics alike. I found the ones who would tell me the truth
column36: and who wanted me to succeed – and I have tried to be that person for them
column37: as well.

column1: I looked for role models
column2: too
column3: when I was starting out. I looked up to the writers who led the way by being inventive in form or genre
column4: or giving voice to characters of all kinds
column5: or who smashed through glass ceilings or knocked down gates. I paid attention to them and was inspired by them. I could never have planned for it to work out the way it did. I have written eight books and will probably write at least a few more. I live a quiet life with my dog in a small house with a nice back yard where I have finally stopped killing everything I plant. I treasure my friendships and the endless pile of notebooks I keep filling
column6: marvelling occasionally at how there are always
column7: somehow
column8: more words in the world. There is always a fresh start when I open a new notebook. It is always 1 January when I turn to the first page. I recently turned 50
column9: nearly 30 years since that (now deceased) old teacher of mine told me I probably shouldn’t bother. I’m old enough to realise that there is one more important part to carving out your creative life: honouring your successes no matter the size. And honouring the bad moments too. Laying your burdens down. Building this writing life has always been about recognising what was holding me back so I could move on. One writer told me no. I honour his rejection. He said no
column10: but I said yes. • I Came All This Way to Meet You by Jami Attenberg is published by Profile Books (£14.99). To order a copy for £13.04
column11: go to guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply.";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/05/jami-attenberg-rejection-gave-me-a-fresh-start-a-new-year;5

column15: an unusually fractious genre: for decades
column16: punks argued about what – and who – was or wasn’t punk. They drew lines
column17: divided subgenres into sub-subgenres
column18: and sometimes performed rituals of excommunication. (Green Day
column19: probably the most popular punk group of all time
column20: were banned from their local club
column21: and denounced as enemies of the movement by Maximum Rocknroll
column22: the definitive American punk fanzine.) For a while
column23: punk rock was all I cared about
column24: but in the years that followed I was pleased to discover that punk wasn’t quite as unusual as I first thought: every musical genre is in some sense a community of musicians and listeners
column25: which means that every genre is also a tribe
column26: defined by tribal rules of inclusion and exclusion. And so when I set out to write a history of popular music
column27: I decided to go genre by genre
column28: hoping to explain how these communities endured
column29: evolved and splintered. In Major Labels
column30: I settled on seven “major” genres: rock’n’roll
column31: R&B
column32: country
column33: punk
column34: hip-hop
column35: dance music and pop. Of course
column36: each of these contains multitudes
column37: and one of the pleasures of writing the book was the chance to read
column38: or revisit
column39: countless works of single-minded musical scholarship: books that dive deep into a genre
column40: or a scene
column41: or a sound. This is one of the paradoxes of musical fandom: the more you cherish the ability to listen to a wide range of styles
column42: the more grateful you should be to the musicians stubborn enough to find something they loved and stick to it. And the more grateful you should be
column43: too
column44: to the writers who were imaginative and perceptive enough to notice that something was going on
column45: and write about it. 1. Deep Down in the Ghetto by Roger D Abrahams In 1964
column46: a folklorist based in Philadelphia managed a neat trick: he published one of the most important books ever written about hip-hop
column47: long before hip-hop actually existed. In this classic study
column48: Abrahams records and analyses a trove of mid-century Black oral literature
column49: setting down street-corner rhymes
column50: tall tales and boasts – some of which are as violent
column51: and as bawdy
column52: as the rap records that shocked the world in the decades to come. 2. The Nashville Sound by Paul Hemphill Hemphill was not exactly a Nashville insider
column53: which explains part of the charm of this book
column54: published in 1970: he captured the genius and the weirdness of a country-music industry that was just starting to think of itself as such. Like virtually everyone who came after him
column55: he noted that the genre seemed split between “traditionalists” and “the new breed”. He noticed that the town was full of performers who were “modernising the simple music of their rural southern childhoods and blurring the distinction between country and pop music” – and of course it still is.

column1: 3. Like Punk Never Happened by Dave Rimmer A very strange book: a sharp treatise on the aesthetics of pop
column2: masquerading as a just-in-time biography of Boy George and Culture Club. In fact by the time this book was published
column4: Culture Club’s time at the top of the charts was pretty much over. Knowing this adds some wistfulness to Rimmer’s narrative. And it adds some context to his argument
column5: which is that
column6: in the aftermath of the punk explosion
column7: a new “pop” sensibility emerged
column8: rebelling against the punk-rock rebellion by steadfastly refusing to be rebellious. So what if it didn’t last? Who says great pop is supposed to last? 4. I’m With the Band by Pamela Des Barres When this book was published
column9: at the peak of the hair-metal craze
column10: some readers might have mistaken it for a gossipy compendium of backstage tales. The book’s subtitle is Confessions of a Groupie
column11: but the main draw is the way that Des Barres
column12: sometimes drawing from old diary entries
column13: charts her evolution from a curious consumer of rock ’n’ roll records to an important participant in the scene that helped create the myth of the rock star. Her writing is precise and perceptive
column14: affectionate but unsentimental. In one memorable passage
column15: she remembers listening to Led Zeppelin II while hanging out in Jimmy Page’s hotel room. “I had to comment on every solo
column16: ” she writes
column17: “and even though I believed the drum solo in Moby Dick went on endlessly
column18: I held my tongue and went on pressing his velvet trousers and sewing buttons on to his satin jacket.”

column1: 5. The Death of Rhythm and Blues by Nelson George For much of the 1980s
column2: George was a music editor at Billboard magazine
column3: which gave him extraordinary insight not only into the genre of R&B but the industry that nurtured it. This classic study is both a history and a manifesto – and also
column4: more than 30 years later
column5: a time capsule. George writes tenderly about the Black business owners who supported R&B
column6: and sceptically about the way that 80s R&B singers (including Michael Jackson and Prince) found pop success
column7: sometimes seeming to leave the genre behind. Was that really progress? 6. Black Noise by Tricia Rose This book
column8: published in 1994
column9: was one of the first academic investigations of hip-hop
column10: although
column11: like many of the books that came afterward
column12: it was not entirely celebratory. Rose was devoted to hip-hop
column13: but she was also devoted to the idea of hip-hop as a vehicle for resistance and emancipation
column14: which means she can’t help but notice the ways in which it often failed to live up to these ideals. In describing (and sometimes decrying) the genre’s tendency to focus on “male predatory sexual behaviour”
column15: and its existence within a network of white-owned
column16: multinational businesses
column17: she anticipated the way hip-hop would continue to delight and frustrate its biggest fans for decades to come.

column1: 7. Energy Flash by Simon Reynolds An enthusiastic and often contagious history of dance music
column2: with a focus on pleasure: Reynolds conjures up not only how house and techno (and their many offshoots) evolved
column3: but what it really feels like to love them. This feeling has not always been entirely organic: Reynolds pays close attention to the relationship between dance music and drugs
column4: explaining how often
column5: when the high changes
column6: the beat changes
column7: too. 8. Lords of Chaos by Michael Moynihan and Didrik Soderlind An intense
column8: scary book about an intense
column9: scary scene: black metal
column10: which in the 1990s took heavy metal’s obsession with darkness and evil to its logical conclusion. Moynihan and Soderlind chronicle a world of murder
column11: hatred and madness; even if you don’t have any interest in the bands (or in the 2018 Jonas Åkerlund film based on this book)
column12: you may come away with a new appreciation for what it means for music to be truly extreme. 9. Love Saves the Day by Tim Lawrence How do you capture a party? Often
column13: you don’t: the revellers go home
column14: the DJ packs up
column15: people move on. But in this careful work of excavation
column16: Lawrence shows how
column17: in 1970s New York
column18: casual get-togethers spawned glamorous nightclubs
column19: and eventually an entire musical subculture
column20: reconstructing the prehistory of disco
column21: and gesturing toward all the sounds and scenes that came afterward.

column1: 10. Girls to the Front by Sara Marcus Riot grrrl was at least two things at once: a musical movement
column2: which bloomed briefly in the 1990s
column3: and a literary movement
column4: sparked by fanzines
column5: which jammed together punk rock and feminism
column6: challenging and changing the identities of both of them. This book is an indispensable cultural history that emphasises both the strangeness and the sensibleness of riot grrrl
column7: an unlikely movement that seems
column8: in retrospect
column9: inevitable. Major Labels by Kelefa Sanneh is published by Canongate. To support the Guardian and Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply.";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/05/top-10-books-about-musical-subcultures-major-labels-kelefa-sanneh;5

column7: 'Wildlife'];"From the age of eight
column8: I attended a little boarding school on the Derbyshire-Staffordshire border where I’d often get in trouble on a Sunday afternoon. The teachers would leave us to roam the edge of the grounds where we were supposed to pass time making fires
column9: toasting marshmallows or playing cricket but my habit was to set out over the fences and stiles into the landscape and often
column10: much to the teachers’ chagrin
column11: no one knew where to find me.

column1: That was the point. To stand on unfamiliar ground and
column2: for a moment
column3: feel the world as something new brought with it a feeling I would crave and it formed a habit that stuck with me. By my mid-20s
column4: I was a committed pedestrian
column5: buoyed up by a privileged encounter on the streets of Whitechapel with east London’s resident visionary
column6: Iain Sinclair
column7: who warned against the underground as a way of getting around the city. He likened its subterranean networks to rabbit warrens that would cut us off from instinct and make it hard for us to know where (or who) we really are. Shuffling on fast feet between Aldgate East and Soho
column8: or kicking back for a languorous Sunday stroll up to Parliament Hill
column9: that was an insight I carried with me as I stumbled over Roman ruins and hidden histories of romantic poetry. Making sense of the city’s vast topography
column10: walking became a way of life that
column11: in turn
column12: gave shape to an itinerant decade and I would ease myself into new locations the world over by setting out on foot to get lost and then find myself again in the backstreets of Ahmedabad or Isfhanan
column13: Ramallah or Bari.

column1: And then beyond the towns and cities and beyond the scale of human history
column2: I’d walk in the foothills of the Himalayas or on the desert plains of the Jordan Valley and find new depths of experience. I’d watch the monsoon end in thick fog rising up the mountainside near Dharamsala or see the seasons laid out in space at the point where the fresh air of Ein-Al-Hilwe (“sweet natural spring”) presses up close against the heat and dust of Jericho. These were landscapes to fall in love in and I did
column3: discovering while walking a feeling of transcendence that moved me beyond the narrow quadrant of my own identity-story
column4: nurturing a feeling of connection with something deeper in myself
column5: and with the person beside me
column6: and with the planet that contains us. By the time I returned to England in my mid-30s
column7: I had got used to looking at walking as a way to cultivate a feeling of belonging. Back in Derbyshire
column8: clearing out the house I grew up in
column9: I was taken in by a community of Kashmiri hikers
column10: the Kramblers
column11: who had been thinking along similar lines.

column1: Home now in Rotherham
column2: Sheffield
column3: Salford
column4: Oldham and Rochdale
column5: each one of them was remembering a childhood in Mirpur where walking in the mountains had been an activity as natural as popping to the shop to pick up a pint of milk. Yet decades inhabiting an immigrant geography in northern England had turned them into dwellers of the cities and the suburbs – the “ghettoes” – cut off from the rugged rural landscapes that surrounded them. In response
column6: and to reclaim something lost
column7: they had begun to organise themselves
column8: every Sunday
column9: to get out together across the peaks and valleys of Edale
column10: Dovedale
column11: Malham
column12: Monsal
column13: Kinder Scout – to stand up to unconscious narratives about who belongs where and what land belongs to whom. They began to cultivate
column14: by walking
column15: a sense of belonging with the landscape of England that lies deeper than the surface layer of racist nationalism. And for me
column16: walking with the Kramblers became a way of piecing together worlds torn apart by geopolitics.

column1: That experience strengthened a sense of belonging that
column2: by the time I established my own home
column3: in the landscape of south Devon
column4: I knew could be cultivated here
column5: too – along the coastal paths and forest floors that surround the River Dart. Here
column6: walking now serves me (and my one-year old puppy
column7: Dharma) as an essential daily practice. The world outside our front door is a refuge from a day of successive Zoom calls or from the intensity of a writing deadline. It’s a place where I can get out of my head. Where he and I can remember where we are (and who we are)
column8: recover a sense of our equilibrium. We watch the seasons change and sense the movement of the sun and the light around the moon. We witness the earth and when I get home I make a cup of tea. The flowers of spring can feel just like a miracle. We walk the same path
column9: day after day
column10: but every minute of every hour can feel like new. How to do it The Ramblers Association has a tool for finding local walking groups and All The Elements is a volunteer-run library of organisations which help diverse communities enjoy the great outdoors. Gay Outdoor Club is another great resource for finding local LGBTQ+ groups and events to help you connect with people who want to run
column11: hike and ramble. When it comes to finding new routes
column12: National Trails can show you the way or look at the National Trust’s survey of Britain’s 100 Favourite Walks from 2018. If you want to try being an armchair walker
column13: read Frédéric Gros’s A Philosophy of Walking or London Orbital by Iain Sinclair.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/05/on-the-right-track-how-walking-connects-me-to-the-land-and-its-people;3

column9: 'Fruit'];"Spicy and ear-tinglingly sour
column10: this classic Thai soup is just what I fancy at this time of year: it’s something to cut through the pleasant
column11: festive fug and reset the senses. Though shellfish are a common ingredient
column12: this soup is almost endlessly adaptable
column13: even for vegans: as long as it vibrates with flavour – aromatic lime leaves and lemongrass
column14: warming galangal and fresh citrus – you’re on the right track. Prep 12 min Cook 15 min Serves 4 16 raw shell-on king prawns 1 dash vegetable oil 4 fresh makrut lime leaves 2 lemongrass stalks 2 thick slices galangal 2 bird’s eyes chillies 1 tbsp palm sugar
column15: or soft brown sugar Juice of 1½ limes 2 tbsp fish sauce 1 handful coriander or Thai basil leaves
column16: to serve 1 A note on the prawns You’ll need raw
column17: shell-on prawns here. Frozen are fine
column18: so long as they’re defrosted and soft enough to shell
column19: but if your prawns are very large (or very small)
column20: adjust the quantities accordingly. If you can find only shelled prawns
column21: use a litre of light fish or chicken stock (or even just water)
column22: and start from step 3. 2 Make a stock with the prawn shells

column1: Shell the prawns
column2: retaining the shells and heads
column3: and set aside the meat for the time being. Heat the oil in a frying pan over a medium-high flame
column4: then fry the shells and heads
column5: stirring regularly
column6: until they turn a vivid pink. Add a litre of water
column7: bring up to a lively simmer
column8: then strain into a clean pan and discard the spent shells. 3 Prepare the aromatics

column1: Roughly tear the lime leaves (avoid using the dried kind here: frozen are fine
column2: though
column3: but fresh are infinitely preferable and fairly widely available). Bruise the lemongrass by pressing down on it with the flat of a large knife
column4: then cut it into roughly 5cm lengths. Cut two thick slices of galangal – this ginger-like root is sold in specialist south-east Asian food stores and some large supermarkets
column5: but use ginger if you can’t source any. 4 Infuse the stock

column1: Add the lime leaves
column2: lemongrass and galangal to the stock pan
column3: bring it back up to a simmer
column4: then leave to bubble gently and infuse for five minutes. Meanwhile
column5: finely slice the chillies
column6: leaving the pith and seeds inside (depending on your taste for spice
column7: add more
column8: if you like). Slide the chillies into the broth and leave the stock to blip away for a couple of minutes longer. 5 Add the prawns

column1: Turn down the heat to the barest simmer
column2: add the prawn meat to the broth and cook for about a minute
column3: until just pink (be careful not to let the stock boil or to cook the prawns for too long
column4: or they will turn rubbery).

column1: Take off the hob
column2: stir in the sugar
column3: lime juice and fish sauce
column4: then taste and adjust the seasoning as necessary. 6 Serve with lots of fresh herbs Ladle the soup into bowls
column5: making sure the prawns are evenly divided
column6: then tear in the fresh herbs in generous quantities and serve immediately. It’s not traditional
column7: but you can bulk out the soup by adding some cooked rice noodles if you want to make it a more substantial dish
column8: or add other vegetables such as chopped tomatoes
column9: mushrooms or whatever else takes your fancy.

column1: 7 Alternatives to shellfish If you’re not a shellfish fan
column2: make this with good chicken stock
column3: and add torn cooked chicken (or pork or turkey) at the end
column4: just to warm it through. There’s also a more modern
column5: richer variation of tom yum in which coconut or evaporated milk is added at the end of cooking: if that appeals
column6: make only 750ml stock
column7: and stir in 300ml coconut milk with the seasonings just before serving. 8 … or to veganise To make this vegan
column8: use vegetable stock or water
column9: and add two round shallots
column10: peeled and cut into wedges
column11: along with the aromatics in step 3. Add two deseeded and roughly chopped tomatoes and 200g chopped oyster
column12: shiitake and/or chestnut mushrooms with the chillies. Vegan versions of fish sauce are available
column13: and I’d recommend getting hold of some for this dish. 9 Other flavourings Vegan or not
column14: you can also add some firm diced tofu instead of the prawns; I think it’s also rather nice with those fried tofu puffs sold in specialist south-east Asian food shops. Pick up a jar of nam prik pao while you’re there: this rich
column15: sweet chilli paste
column16: also available in vegetarian form
column17: is a great addition to tom yum
column18: and a great many other dishes besides.";https://www.theguardian.com/food/2022/jan/05/how-to-make-tom-yum-thai-soup-recipe-felicity-cloake-masterclass;1

column4: 'Derby'];"Preet Chandi
column5: thought to be the first woman of colour to complete a solo crossing on Antarctica
column6: has finished her expedition to the south pole almost a week ahead of schedule. Chandi or “Polar Preet”
column7: endured temperatures of -50C as she skied 700 miles across Antarctica in 40 days
column8: seven hours and three minutes
column9: narrowly missing out on setting a new world record by a woman for the trek. She finished just behind the time set by Johanna Davidsson of Sweden
column10: who finished in 38 days
column11: 23 hours and five minutes in 2016. Chandi
column13: is now the third-fastest female solo skier for the expedition behind Davidsson and Britain’s Hannah McKeand
column14: who recorded a time of 39 days
column15: nine hours and 33 minutes in 2006. She is also the first person to reach the south pole on foot in two years. Chandi
column16: a British Army physiotherapist who lives in Derby
column17: said it was surreal to reach her goal: “I made it to the south pole where it’s snowing. I’m feeling so many emotions right now. I knew nothing about the polar world three years ago and it feels so surreal to finally be here. It was tough getting here and I want to thank everybody for their support. “This expedition was always about so much more than me. I want to encourage people to push their boundaries and to believe in themselves
column18: and I want you to be able to do it without being labelled a rebel. “No matter where you are from or where your start line is
column19: everybody starts somewhere.” As well as freezing temperatures
column20: Chandi endured wind speeds of up to 60mph and battled whiteouts while pulling a 90kg sled across sastrugi
column21: parallel wave-like ridges on the hard snow caused by winds. She also suffered from exhaustion towards the end of the journey
column22: as well as a persistent cough and sickness. Setting off on 24 November from Hercules Inlet
column23: Chandi aimed to complete her trek in 45 days
column24: carrying enough rations for 48 days. In the end she finished five days ahead of schedule
column25: covering a daily average distance of about 17 miles. She spent years training for the trek
column26: having previously completed a 27-day expedition on the ice cap in Greenland and taking part in ultramarathons
column27: including the gruelling Marathon des Sables across the Sahara. Chandi said she hoped her journey would inspire young people
column28: women and those from minority-ethnic backgrounds. Speaking to the Guardian during her training for the trek
column29: she said people did not expect an Asian woman to attempt such an endeavour. “I am an Asian woman; I’m not the image that people expect to see out there
column30: ” she said. “People say the outdoors is for everyone and yes
column31: it is. But if you come from a community that is not involved in it at all
column32: or you don’t see anybody that looks like you doing it
column33: it can be really hard.” After completing the trek
column34: she plans to set up an adventure grant to help more women fund expeditions in what is often a male-dominated arena. “I have been told ‘no’ on many occasions and to ‘just do the normal thing’
column35: but we create our own normal
column36: ” she said. “You are capable of anything you want.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/preet-chandi-becomes-first-woman-of-colour-to-ski-solo-to-south-pole;6

column1: 223;223;5466;5466;TechScape: Elizabeth Holmes is far from the only tech leader overpromising and underdelivering;2022-01-05T11:45:22Z;['Chris Stokel-Walker'];['Technology'

column3: 'Silicon Valley'
column4: 'Facebook'
column5: 'Media'
column6: 'Social networking'];"It’s safe to say that it’s not a happy new year for Elizabeth Holmes
column7: the founder of Theranos and – following a guilty verdict on four of 11 charges in a California court this week – a convicted fraudster. Holmes
column8: you may remember
column9: promised her devices could diagnose a plethora of health problems from a pinprick of your blood
column10: gaining coverage from the media throughout the 2010s. We now know the technology Holmes hawked to investors
column11: the media and the general public was seriously flawed.

column1: Theranos was founded in 2003 and collapsed in 2018
column2: following a Wall Street Journal report by John Carreyrou that highlighted issues with the company’s test results. In court
column3: Holmes was acquitted on three charges connected to patients who received erroneous test results
column4: but as the Guardian’s Kari Paul writes
column5: the case “marks a milestone for Silicon Valley – an industry that has for years evaded accountability in its pervasive culture of ‘fake it till you make it’ that encourages founders to make big promises
column6: often with little proof.” British entrepreneur and investor Vikas Shah describes Theranos as “a very expensive canary in a coalmine. For the last decade
column7: we’ve seen investors pile money into [unproven] business time and time again.” Such investment begets a vicious circle
column8: in which the press and public play their own roles. Big money raises for hot new companies are fundamentally more interesting to journalists than dull business developments. We cover them enthusiastically (Forbes called Holmes the “next Steve Jobs”)
column9: which allows those companies in turn to raise more cash. Some companies even get to the point of publicly listing with great fanfare
column10: then flopping as the share price sinks – often on the day they launch. It’s a pattern that’s happened too many times to mention
column11: yet we still fall for it. I’m also minded to think of Holmes’ business
column12: and others like it
column13: in light of the manifesto of a relaunched WIRED magazine
column14: published this week by recently arrived editor Gideon Lichfield. WIRED
column15: of course
column16: was a techno-utopian booster when launched in 1993. It heralded tech’s excellence
column17: and captured the spirit of its time: a Jetsons-like promise for the future of the world
column18: carried on tech’s broad back. Since then
column19: we’ve all gone through the looking-glass. I often say I’m a tech-sceptic tech reporter
column20: because like many I’ve been jaded by successive scandals and endless “jam tomorrow” promises of the likes of Theranos. More generally
column21: many of us have become ground down by tech’s promise to radically rewrite our future
column22: only to find that it’s little more than a rebranding of the past imbalances
column23: designed to supplant one controlling power with another. The liberation of the media from a small cabal of editors resulted in the torrent of fake news and the polarisation of our planet on the likes of Facebook. What was meant to be a decapitation of the old leaders and a replacement with a flatter hierarchy actually just entrenched the power of the old guard
column24: and made social media companies more powerful. The promise of removing the gatekeepers in the old world of entertainment has done that to a certain extent
column25: but has ended up making Alphabet
column26: parent company of YouTube and one of the world’s richest firms
column27: even richer – all while a phalanx of creators produce content for free. Even within the creator economy
column28: the idea of a democratising force didn’t end up that way. 96.5% of YouTubers don’t make enough to break the US poverty line
column29: according to one analysis
column30: while TikTok disburses only around five per cent of its revenue to the people who produce its content. All of which is to say: don’t believe the hype. Tech companies overpromise and underdeliver. They’ve spent decades doing it. They’re continuing to do it. Yet Lichfield’s essay is an interesting one
column31: because it discourages us from thinking simply of things as wholly positive or wholly negative. After years of yo-yoing from tech idealism to tech scepticism
column32: we shouldn’t immediately discount the promise technology has to reinvent our lives. “We’re at what feels like an inflection point in the recent history of technology
column33: when various binaries that have long been taken for granted are being called into question
column34: ” he writes. It’s worth looking at the Theranos story through that lens. Yes
column35: the company appears to have exaggerated or invented many of its claims. But there are a range of tech-first companies actually doing miraculous things in the field of medicine and diagnostics. The fact we’re able to shoulder the burden of the omicron variant of coronavirus is largely down to the likes of techno-utopian companies BioNTech basically inventing new techniques to manufacture vaccines at a scale never before seen. Tech overpromises
column36: and tech coverage often too readily repeats unlikely claims. But technology is still significant. For every tech bro trying to rebrand PDFs as “literature NFTs” (which has more than a hint of Uber rebranding the bus)
column37: there are people who are doing legitimately exciting things. “The exciting part is we are genuinely at a time when technology is doing incredible things
column38: ” says Shah. “It’s not about being anti-utopian
column39: but it’s about asking sensible questions. Is something fair and reasonable?” Healthy scepticism is no bad thing
column40: then. It’s what keeps the vast majority of society from buying into the so-far illusory promise of Web3
column41: another gleaming vision of the tech-enabled future that promises to decentralise control
column42: but so far as resulted in a handful of people getting filthy rich by selling cartoonish JPGs. It’s what protects you from the endless number of scams and thefts that are dominating the world of NFTs at present. For years we have too readily accepted what tech founders and leaders tell us without thinking: “Is this really realistic?” Now
column43: we’re running the risk of slipping too far in the opposite direction. The new challenge is striking the balance between the two. column6: 'US domestic policy'];"A few days before Christmas
column7: Joe Manchin appeared on Fox News to publicly retract his support for the Build Back Better Act. Even by the pathologically callous standards of Washington
column8: it felt surreal to watch a politician jeopardize tens of millions of lives in a single 10-minute interview. But the stakes of his decision remain clear: without the act
column9: the United States will fall far short of its climate goals
column10: making a century of ecological collapse
column11: economic devastation and civilizational upheaval not only more likely
column12: but increasingly unavoidable. In the wake of the announcement
column13: despair flickered across the internet. Friends called me in tears. My generation has watched our government fail again and again to enact meaningful federal climate legislation. But this latest betrayal is almost too much to bear. It feels like we are being forced to say goodbye: to our democracy
column14: to our future
column15: to the world we were told we’d inherit. If Build Back Better fails
column16: Manchin may well be remembered as the man who killed the planet. Given the prospect of having to one day explain to his grandchildren why they can’t go outside in the summer
column17: you think he’d at least attempt to marshal some plausible justifications. But his arguments collapse under the lightest scrutiny. His inflation fears have been thoroughly debunked
column18: including by Larry Summers
column19: the patron saint of inflation anxiety. His climate arguments are fundamentally unserious
column20: anti-science propaganda copied straight from the big coal playbook. The most generous interpretation is that he’s a mulish egotist: a man who sticks to his guns
column21: even when his guns are firing blanks. But the bulk of the evidence points to simple bad faith. Since joining the Senate
column22: Manchin has personally grossed over $4.5m from coal companies he owns. In recent months he has received millions in campaign donations from Republican billionaires and fossil fuel executives who want to see Build Back Better die a slow
column23: painful death. Meanwhile
column24: he has ignored the pleas of West Virginia mothers
column25: tuned out the counsel of his own pope and bulldozed the very coal miners he’s so often wielded as political props. In the light of day
column26: his motives seem as obvious as they are depressing.

column1: Regardless of his true endgame
column2: Manchin’s reversal raises a pressing question: what exactly is Biden’s strategy? He’s already forfeited his most obvious piece of leverage
column3: allowing the bipartisan infrastructure bill to move forward without any promise of reciprocation. His “charm offensive” – an exercise in Beltway nostalgia
column4: if not outright political delusion – has run aground on the brutal logic of contemporary petro-politics. When it comes to his signature policy agenda
column5: his administration seems flustered
column6: reactive and naive. And yet
column7: the bill must not be abandoned. Executive action alone probably can’t deliver the lasting emissions reductions that climate science demands. If the first Democratic trifecta since 2009 fails to produce ambitious climate legislation
column8: both party and planet will suffer catastrophic consequences. So Biden needs a new strategy
column9: and fast. There are two basic options. The first is to take off the kid gloves and start playing hardball. If he doesn’t have any leverage
column10: then he needs to get some
column11: especially if Manchin is acting in bad faith. That means channeling Lyndon B Johnson and pairing noble intent with sharp elbows. Threaten targeted federal regulations that would cripple Manchin’s benefactors in big coal. Use the bully pulpit to call them out by name: Michelle Bloodworth
column12: Chris Hamilton
column13: Joe Craft
column14: Jim McGlothlin – all the special interests ready to sacrifice my generation on the altar of their quarterly returns. Have the justice department revisit allegations that Manchin’s daughter
column15: former Mylan chief Heather Bresch
column16: played a personal role in criminally inflating the price of life-saving EpiPens (as if corporate fealty and misanthropic greed were a sort of family tradition). Dare him to defect to the Republican party
column17: where he’ll either kiss the ring of the autocrat he voted twice to impeach or be eaten alive as a Republican in Name Only
column18: or Rino. The second option is to publicly accept Manchin’s private counteroffer
column19: get it to the Senate floor for a vote
column20: and then dare him to renege. The $1.8tn counter-offer – which reportedly included universal pre-K
column21: an expansion of the Affordable Care Act and $500 to 600bn in clean energy incentives – would fall short of what working people need. But it would offer some crucial support
column22: while keeping America’s climate commitments alive. There’s a chance Biden could still circumvent Manchin on extending the child tax credit
column23: which would lift millions of American children out of poverty. No state has benefited from the popular policy more than Utah
column24: and Mitt Romney has indicated a willingness to negotiate. Progressives could blanket his state in ads on child poverty while the administration buttonholes him on specifics. Whichever path the administration chooses
column25: they need to abandon their fixation on “projecting normalcy”. We are not living in normal times
column26: and every American knows it. With each new failure
column27: their genteel posture reads less like a steady hand and more like a form of sleepwalking. It’s time they communicated candidly with the American public and made clear what is actually happening. Manchin’s intransigence is not an unfortunate product of normal democratic deliberation. It is a perverse and dangerous attempt on the part of fossil fuel oligarchs to prevent the demos from protecting itself against climate change. Republicans’ lockstep opposition to clean energy investments supported by almost two thirds of American voters is not the product of legitimate policy disagreement
column28: but of a party actively and transparently opposed to majoritarian democracy. As the Biden presidency enters what could be the final act of a political tragedy
column29: the only way out is to break the fourth wall. Sound the alarm and enlist the public. Expose the actors standing between young people and a livable future; between working families and a dignified living; and between all Americans and their right to representation. If Biden wants to win the war for democracy
column30: then he must summon the courage to name it – loudly and repeatedly. Otherwise
column31: his base will remain as we were after Manchin’s announcement: demobilized
column32: despairing and deeply
column33: justifiably cynical. Daniel Sherrell is the author of Warmth: Coming of Age at the End of Our World (Penguin Books) and a climate activist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/05/joe-biden-manchin-build-back-better;1

column41: after judges rebuffed the DoJ. And media reports found that both the military and law enforcement have struggled to rid themselves of far-right ideas and supporters. But potentially violent far-right individuals and groups are now surveilled much more than they have been since 9/11 – we’re in a moment perhaps more similar to the short period after the Oklahoma City bombing of 1995
column42: still the most deadly domestic terrorist attack in US history. In short

column6: 'Environment'];"At least once a week April Wielputz jogs down Main Street in Greenville
column7: California
column8: as she has for years. But now the exercise takes her past piles of charred brick and warped metal that once constituted the 19th-century-era buildings of the historic downtown. Sometimes
column9: depending on her route
column10: she runs by the still-standing but empty high school where her eldest son was supposed to start his senior year this fall. The blackened trees
column11: crumpled buildings and even the cleared lots
column12: are a reminder of the Gold Rush town’s staggering loss. On a Wednesday evening in August
column13: this rural settlement of about 1
column14: 000 people found itself in the path of California’s largest single wildfire. Before it grew to nearly 1m acres and became the first known blaze to crest the Sierra Nevada
column15: the Dixie fire destroyed Greenville in about 30 minutes

column17: displacing hundreds of residents and inflaming fears in a region already shaken by years of deadly fires. “I saw what happened in Paradise
column18: ” Wielputz said

column1: The Dixie fire

column4: surprising firefighters. Unlike Paradise and Berry Creek

column8: Greenville and those who call it home are fighting to navigate their changed worlds and rebuild their community.

column1: Wielputz
column2: who lost her home in the fire
column3: is one of a few hundred people who have been able to return to the area – the majority of Greenville’s 1

column5: spared by the flames
column6: on a hill overlooking downtown
column7: just next to the home she lost. This town
column8: with its sweeping mountain vistas
column9: community spirit and soundtrack of passing trains
column10: is home
column11: she says
column12: which is why she was eager to return
column13: even with the rubble still piled up around town. “It’s still beautiful to me
column14: ” she said
column15: pointing to the trees and the mountains. “Everyone’s like
column16: ‘Oh my God

column19: to see all the trees that are gone
column20: ” said Jerry Thrall
column21: a 23-year resident whose home in Greenville survived.

column1: Marilyn Crouch
column3: spent most of her life in Greenville; her parents graduated from the local high school
column4: as did she and her husband
column5: high school sweethearts
column6: and later their children. Since the fire destroyed her home
column7: Crouch and her husband have moved into a trailer outside her son’s house in nearby Quincy. She longs to return to the community she treasures

column11: ” she said. “I didn’t want to go home that way. Because I didn’t want to go through Greenville.” Actually navigating within the town can be difficult with all the familiar landmarks burned away. Greenville was so small and close-knit that many residents got around not by street names
column12: but by houses and who lived there. “That’s how you’d tell someone how to get somewhere. You didn’t know the names of the streets
column13: you’d tell them ‘where Dick Hamblin lives
column14: three doors down’
column15: ” Crouch recalled.

column1: But those houses are mostly gone. Cleanup is under way
column2: though that process is expected to continue through January and much of the rubble still remains. While living in the area always came with challenges
column3: it’s been particularly difficult since the fire. There was a housing shortage before
column4: said Veronica Garcia
column5: a spokesperson for Plumas Strong
column6: a non-profit helping support residents after the fire
column7: and now hundreds of people are still displaced. State and federal officials recently brought 14 trailers to the town to house fire survivors

column9: and for residents who have found housing to furnish their new homes. For those who have returned
column10: cellphone reception and internet service are spottier than ever
column11: residents say. Getting gas or mail requires a drive to Quincy

column13: children are traveling to Quincy to attend classes. Sheriff deputies travel from nearby communities since the town’s substation burned down in the fire. “We’re facing the perfect storm of issues up here
column14: ” Garcia said. “There is a desperate need to have basic services back in this area.”

column1: It will take time but Greenville will come back

Insurers were reluctant to cover houses and businesses in the area before the fire due to the risk

column17: signalled by defining various nuances of loneliness
column18: anxiety

column11: it might just be a work of commercial genius. The benefit the author claims for his work is that readers might feel less alone by seeing strange feelings they have experienced set out in black and white

column2: the day after the opening of Molly Reynolds’ documentary My Name is Gulpilil. Last month the portrait
column3: I’m Gulpilil
column4: was displayed at the David Roche Foundation in Adelaide. In December
column5: Ruddy completed his last body of work
column6: titled 2021
column7: which Daniel Browning
column8: host of Radio National’s The Art Show
column9: said “puts me in mind of the dystopias conjured by the Spanish painter Goya”. Created in the studio adjoining his home in the Byron Bay hinterland
column10: Ruddy said of the works: “These past two years have been a rollercoaster of emotions and feelings for all of us
column11: including myself … Creating in my studio has helped me to maintain balance and perspective. We are definitely living in unprecedented times and the arts and deep human connection are paramount.”

column1: Ruddy was born in Forestville
column2: Sydney in 1968 and studied design and fashion illustration in the 1980s. In 2001 he quit his design career to become a painter
column3: and over the past two decades divided his time between homes in Tamarama in Sydney’s east
column4: the Byron Bay hinterland and Buenos Aires. On his website
column5: his work is described as exploring “questions of social conscience as well as current environmental issues. The recognition of Australian Indigenous people and culture is also a core theme.”

column1: When he wasn’t in his studio painting or travelling with his partner
column2: he enjoyed invigorating cold outdoor baths
column3: yoga
column4: dancing
column5: tending to his veggie patch
column6: swimming
column7: cooking and entertaining. Byron Shire Council mayor Michael Lyon said Ruddy was a “well-known locally based artist and Archibald prize-winner” who had “died as a result of complications from Covid-19”. “Devastated at the loss of my good friend and neighbour. Too young to leave us and such a beautiful
column8: kind and generous soul
column9: am still in complete shock
column10: ” Lyon said in a statement. The Yuin
column11: Bunurong and Tasmanian author Bruce Pascoe also paid tribute to Ruddy
column12: who painted him for the 2020 Archibald prize – the artist’s fifth submission to the portrait prize. “There goes a really decent and gentle soul
column13: ” Pascoe said in a statement. “The world needs the goodness of his spirit replaced. Teach your children well.” In a tweet marking Ruddy’s death
column14: former Olympic athlete Cathy Freeman wrote: “Forever in my heart / Forever in my mind / Forever in my life.”

column1: In a statement posted to Twitter
column2: Ben Franklin
column3: the NSW minister for Aboriginal affairs
column4: the arts and regional youth
column5: wrote: “A life so well lived
column6: but taken far too soon. Craig Ruddy was an extraordinary artist. And a wonderful human being.”";https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2022/jan/05/craig-ruddy-archibald-prize-winning-painter-dies-at-53;5

column1: 233;233;5476;5476;Keir Starmer to miss PMQs after testing positive for Covid again;2022-01-05T10:14:58Z;['Aubrey Allegretti'];['Keir Starmer'

column4: 'UK news'
column5: 'Politics'];"Keir Starmer will miss the chance to challenge Boris Johnson at the first prime minister’s questions of 2022
column6: after the Labour leader tested positive for Covid. He will self-isolate and his deputy
column7: Angela Rayner
column8: will stand in at the dispatch box instead at 3pm. Starmer has been doing daily lateral flow tests and on Wednesday the result came back positive. It is his sixth period of self-isolation since the pandemic began. He last tested positive in October
column9: forcing him to miss PMQs and the chance to respond to the budget.

column1: Fresh from giving a new year’s speech in central Birmingham setting out Labour’s strategy for 2022
column2: Starmer will have been keen to keep pressure up on the government given the Conservatives’ waning poll ratings after a damaging series of sleaze scandals. On Tuesday
column3: he said alleged rule-breaking including at Christmas parties across Whitehall during December 2020 meant ministers had lost “the moral right to set those rules”. The speech was attended by about two dozen people

column5: he was also forced to isolate in July 2021 after one of his children tested positive
column6: and in January 2021 after being identified as a “close contact” of someone who caught the virus. He also went into isolation in December 2020 when a staff member in his private office contracted Covid
column7: and September 2020 while someone in his household had symptoms and awaited a test result. NHS guidance says anyone who catches Covid should notify all those with whom they have been in close contact in the past 48 hours – but those people do not need to isolate unless contacted by test and trace or they develop symptoms. Cases of the virus in Britain have rocketed in recent weeks as the Omicron variant
column8: which scientists say is more transmissible
column9: spread through the country. The highest daily number of new infections in the UK was reported on Tuesday
column10: when 218
column11: 724 people tested positive for Covid. Johnson has resisted imposing further restrictions in England
column12: putting the nation out of step with leaders of the devolved administrations in Wales
column13: Scotland and Northern Ireland. The prime minister has himself been forced to self-isolate before
column14: but tried to avoid doing so in July 2021 after he and chancellor
column15: Rishi Sunak
column16: came into close contact with the health secretary
column17: Sajid Javid
column18: who later tested positive for Covid. Johnson and Sunak initially said they were part of a pilot testing scheme allowing them to avoid isolating
column19: but U-turned after an outcry from members of the public and backbench Conservative MPs.";https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/jan/05/keir-starmer-to-miss-pmqs-after-testing-positive-for-covid-again;1

column7: 'Music'];"Gal Gadot has sought to explain the thinking behind her widely ridiculed cover of the John Lennon song Imagine
column8: posted to Instagram at the start of the pandemic. The video
column9: which featured Gadot along with stars including Kristen Wiig
column10: Natalie Portman
column11: Will Ferrell
column12: Zoë Kravitz and Jamie Dornan each singing a line from the song
column13: was intended as a statement of solidarity.

column1: “We are in this together
column2: we will get through it together
column3: ” Gadot captioned the original post from March 2020
column4: but many criticised the project as tone deaf
column5: highlighting the apparent disconnect between lyrics such as “imagine no possessions” warbled from multimillion dollar mansions while hundreds of thousands lost their lives
column6: relatives
column7: jobs and homes.

column1: Speaking to InStyle magazine
column2: Gadot said that the timing of video – now viewed more than 10m times – was the central problem. “The pandemic was in Europe and Israel before it came [to the US] in the same way. “I was seeing where everything was headed. But [the video] was premature. It wasn’t the right timing
column3: and it wasn’t the right thing. It was in poor taste. “All pure intentions
column4: but sometimes you don’t hit the bullseye.” At the time of posting

column6: she said
