column1: 235;235;5478;5478;Woodlands Dark and Days Bewitched: A History of Folk Horror review – casts a spell ;2022-01-05T10:00:38Z;['Leslie Felperin'];['Film'
column2: 'Documentary films'
column3: 'Horror films'
column4: 'Film criticism'
column5: 'Culture'];"At three-and-a-bit hours long
column6: this is worth every geeky minute if you’re into the genre of the title – think Witchfinder General all the way through to Midsommar. With its really smart deep dives into cultural criticism
column7: this is a seasonal stocking overflowing with spooky fun. Writer-director Kier-La Janisse
column8: founder of the Miskatonic Institute of Horror Studies
column9: clearly knows the subject inside out
column10: and finds the best authors
column11: scholars and authorities to talk about the subject. But what’s really admirable is the way it is organised into digestible chapters that flow silkily from one subject to another
column12: eased along by a spontaneous and colloquial voiceover from the director herself. As a film essay
column13: the methodology is exemplary; if you want an education in an aspect of film over the winter and have finished watching all of Mark Cousins’ Story of Film docs
column14: this offers an excellent next component. Arguably there may be a little overload
column15: as Janisse and co get so engrossed in tracing the roots and shoots of the term “folk horror” across film
column16: TV
column17: literature and even theatre
column18: that by the end it’s hard to remember what the genre’s defining characteristics are supposed to be. But ultimately you’ll know it when you see it: in film terms
column19: it has to do with stories in rural settings where ancient skills
column20: beliefs or practices rub up against a newer form of civilisation. Think of the pagan islanders with their maypoles and sacrifices in conflict with the austere Christian policeman in The Wicker Man
column21: or the witchcraft practices involving animal transformations and blood meeting the prim 17th-century pilgrims in The Witch
column22: directed by Robert Eggers (interviewed here).

column1: These are just two of the obvious touchstones. Janisse includes clips from hundreds of much less well-known movies
column2: many from the UK
column3: which might be considered the spiritual homeland of folk horror
column4: but spreading out to include gems from Australia
column5: Indonesia
column6: Mexico and Iceland. The discussion of the trope of Indigenous burial grounds in American folk horror is especially fascinating
column7: for example
column8: particularly to see how contemporary Americans struggle to cope with their colonial past (see Pet Sematary) as well as attitudes towards death and grieving (Midsommar). Pro tip: keep a notebook handy – there will be loads of titles you’ll want to look up afterwards. • Woodlands Dark and Days Bewitched: A History of Folk Horror is available on 10 January on Shudder.";https://www.theguardian.com/film/2022/jan/05/woodlands-dark-and-days-bewitched-a-history-of-folk-horror-review;5

column1: 236;236;5479;5479;‘I felt powerless – so I started filming’: CyclingMikey on his one-man battle with dangerous drivers;2022-01-05T10:00:38Z;['Peter Walker'];['Cycling'
column2: 'Road transport'
column3: 'UK news'
column4: 'London'
column5: 'Life and style'
column6: 'Motoring'
column7: 'Society'
column8: 'Road safety'
column9: 'Social media'
column10: 'YouTube'];"As we chat
column11: Mike van Erp keeps glancing at the line of vehicles queueing on the road in Hyde Park
column12: London. Suddenly
column13: he spots something. “Here we go
column14: ” he says
column15: swinging around his sensible-looking blue touring bike
column16: and pedalling away from the traffic lights. He edges along the stationary vehicles until he is parallel to a car. It is well over a minute before the driver looks up and spots him – and the camera strapped to his baseball cap. When he returns
column17: a grinning Van Erp tells me the man reacted badly to the realisation he was being caught on camera. Why the fury? The driver was using his phone as he waited for the traffic to move – and Van Erp recorded him doing it. In the coming months the man will most likely face a fine and six points on his driving licence
column18: in turn triggering a significant jump in his insurance premium.

column1: Van Erp
column2: a 49-year-old professional carer
column3: says he has now reported close to 1
column4: 000 law-breaking drivers to the police
column5: with about 80% facing prosecution. After any court proceedings are finished
column6: he posts the footage on his YouTube channel. There have been some famous faces among the drivers he has reported. In early December
column7: Van Erp allegedly filmed Frank Lampard using a phone while driving – the former footballer has denied the offence. Footage shot by Van Erp
column8: however
column9: has resulted in court action against ex-boxer Chris Eubank and Guy Ritchie
column10: with the film director banned from driving. All of this has led to headlines
column11: occasional TV appearances and made him the semi-reluctant public face of a new era of road crime enforcement
column12: one in which police forces are being encouraged to accept online complaints about offences
column13: backed up by video footage. Many of the complaints come from cyclists
column14: who view such footage as one of the few ways they can push back against endemic levels of dangerous driving. It can be a controversial area. Van Erp regularly features in news articles as a “vigilante cyclist”
column15: a description he dislikes intensely and which he has
column16: on occasion
column17: managed to have altered after complaining.

column1: Van Erp’s 65
column2: 000 subscribers to his CyclingMikey YouTube channel have been enough to earn him a modest extra income as a result of his actions. Yet
column3: he says
column4: far from selecting prominent targets
column5: he did not recognise any of the celebrities when he approached them. (The footage of him challenging Eubank for holding a phone at the wheel of his convertible Rolls-Royce sees him ask the clearly unimpressed former world champion
column6: “Are you famous?”). And
column7: he insists
column8: a media profile was never his aim. His motivation is much simpler: trying to make the roads safer
column9: one driver at a time. A Dutch national
column10: who grew up in Zimbabwe and moved to the UK in 1998 to work in IT
column11: he has a particularly personal stake in this. When he was still living in Zimbabwe
column12: his father was killed by a drunk driver while riding his motorbike. Van Erp
column13: then 19
column14: was called by a local shopkeeper about the crash
column15: and went straight to a suburb of Harare
column16: where they lived
column17: to find the mangled wreck of the motorbike and his father’s body covered by a blanket. “It was his birthday on the day
column18: and in the morning I’d begged him to come gliding with me
column19: ” Van Erp recalls. “I had a pretty awesome upbringing and was close to my dad. He taught me to ride a bike
column20: to fix punctures
column21: to ride a motorcycle
column22: and to drive a car.” It’s this memory
column23: he says
column24: that “really gives me that extra ounce of determination to cope with the hassle of admin of reporting drivers – I don’t like admin very much.” There is
column25: he adds
column26: a wider motivation: “I just like to think that with the power of one I’m trying to change a little bit of road safety. Most people who cycle realise that bad driving is largely tolerated by society. It’s not considered a really serious thing. Yet it’s claiming 1
column27: 800 people’s lives a year in the UK alone
column28: and 27
column29: 000 are seriously injured. That’s a quite serious toll
column30: isn’t it?”

column1: It is not only a serious toll
column2: but one that disproportionately affects the most vulnerable road users. While the UK has better overall road casualty statistics than most nations
column3: the risk of injury or death per mile is 25 times greater for cyclists than for than those travelling in cars. The UK is also one of the few European countries where fatalities among pedestrians have risen in recent years. The sort of law-breaking captured by Van Erp and his fellow camera cyclists undoubtedly plays a part. On 20mph-maximum roads
column4: an average of 86% of drivers break the speed limit. And to understand the sheer extent of motorists using handheld phones while at the wheel
column5: you only need to watch Van Erp at work. He began taking his on-the-road shots in 2006
column6: using an early bike-mounted camera. “I started filming because I felt a little powerless
column7: ” he recalls. “I couldn’t do anything if a bad driver gave me a close pass
column8: or risked my life in some way. On the various cycling forums we started talking about cameras
column9: how they were miniaturising and getting better – even though they’re terrible compared with now.” Initially
column10: police forces had very little interest in following up his footage even of the most dangerous incidents. Yet
column11: very gradually this has changed – Van Erp’s first successful prosecution followed an incident in 2018 when a taxi driver overtook him very closely. Today
column12: many forces allow footage and complaint details to be uploaded via the web
column13: making it easier – and possibly more likely – that cyclists and other road users with dashcams will bother reporting bad driving. The National Police Chiefs’ Council (NPCC) recently recommended that all forces in England and Wales set up such systems
column14: a move instigated by DCS Andy Cox
column15: the NPCC’s lead on traffic casualties and a pioneer in efforts to tackle them. But the ease of reporting road offences online for citizen volunteers such as Van Erp – who provide many more eyes on the road than would be possible for even the best-resourced police force – remains notably patchy. Camera users in Scotland
column16: for instance
column17: are still obliged to put their footage on to a DVD. Many people also complain that by submitting video they are treated only as witnesses
column18: not potential victims
column19: and so are not kept up to date about action taken. Statistics are limited on this new era of road crime enforcement. The Metropolitan police
column20: the UK’s biggest police force
column21: for example
column22: says it does not keep any relevant figures. But freedom of information requests have revealed that several smaller forces now get hundreds of video complaints a year each
column23: and as many as half lead to action. Van Erp says he has been told “sometimes half of driver awareness courses are filled with people caught by camera cyclists”. He became more diligent in his recording of road offences when he began seeing the results. “I started realising that real prosecutions were happening. And I thought
column24: do you know what
column25: it’s worth doing more than what just affects me
column26: because that will help other people. You hope it will improve other people’s safety.” An hour with Van Erp in Hyde Park brings too many phone users for him to report. Yet
column27: he says
column28: while he is organised about backing up video files and cataloguing complaints and number plates
column29: not least to identify what he calls “repeat customers” (his record is three – the driver of a red Porsche)
column30: he does not go out looking for phone-using drivers. He encounters enough of them during his usual cycle journeys – and official statistics illuminate how this happens. In the past four years
column31: according to DVLA statistics
column32: more than 90
column33: 000 British drivers have been caught driving while distracted
column34: with 932 convicted at least twice
column35: and one motorist punished nine times. Van Erp says he has to be mindful of how common phone use at the wheel is: “I don’t want this to consume my life. I have hobbies
column36: and I have family. I limit how much time I spend on this.”

column1: Riding with him
column2: however
column3: also highlights how distracted drivers become once they pick up their phones. Several remain completely oblivious to the fact a lanky Dutchman has spent several minutes staring at them through the driver’s window
column4: a camera attached to his white baseball cap – and that David
column5: the Guardian photographer
column6: is training a longer lens on them from across the street. Such up-close footage is needed because using a handheld phone is only deemed illegal if there is proof of interactive communication
column7: such as sending messages
column8: talking
column9: or commenting on social media – although this law is due to be updated this year. “It means I have to get right up close and personal
column10: ” says Van Erp
column11: who now uses a high-spec GoPro. What of those who argue that using a phone in stationary traffic does no harm? Van Erp has little patience with this – noting the “WhatsApp gap” – the way phone-distracted drivers tend to jerk forwards belatedly when the queue moves
column12: often after a toot from behind. “There is evidence that phone use is as dangerous as drink-driving. I think it’s also very naive to imagine these people only use their phone in [stationary] traffic
column13: ” he says. Yet aside from his phone-use videos
column14: his YouTube channel also documents an arguably more confrontational strand of his activism. A few years ago
column15: Van Erp heard how queueing drivers at another London junction
column16: in Regent’s Park
column17: were impatiently darting down the wrong side of a traffic island to reach a right-hand turn – sometimes nearly hitting cyclists who were going the right way.

column1: He began lurking at the junction
column2: and if a car tried the manoeuvre he would step out in front of it
column3: blocking its path
column4: and ordering the driver to go back. The results make compulsive viewing. In one particularly astonishing episode
column5: currently on 1.7m views and rising
column6: a pair of doctors in a hulking Volvo SUV are aghast at being challenged and insist that their profession means the driver should be allowed to flout road laws. But the most-watched clip
column7: at almost 4m views
column8: sees a driver become so incensed he bumps Van Erp several times with his Mercedes. When the police arrive the driver starts to argue with them too. Van Erp’s resolve – what he calls “a good example of Dutch stubbornness” – however
column9: seems as unshakeable as his good humour. “You know what keeps me the most even-tempered? It’s the camera
column10: ” he says. “I know that the consequence will come anyway
column11: and I know that I’m filming myself
column12: and it’ll look worse if I behave badly. And also
column13: the kinder and calmer I am
column14: the worse it looks for the driver.” He regularly receives threats on social media
column15: where he faces a near-continual barrage of anonymous insults. But again
column16: his actions are rooted in painful personal experience of the consequences of such driving: when Van Erp was at school
column17: he witnessed a friend being struck by a taxi driving the wrong way round a traffic island. His friend survived
column18: but was badly injured. It’s not all criticism
column19: however. Van Erp also has fans. “Mikey is an inspiration
column20: genuinely
column21: ” says Jeremy Vine
column22: the radio and TV presenter
column23: who also chronicles the bad driving he sees on his bike commute via snappily edited videos using a 360-degree helmet camera. “I often bump into him around London
column24: ” Vine says. “He is not mad
column25: not obsessed
column26: not a vigilante
column27: not on a crusade. He simply believes rules are there to be followed
column28: because it was a drunk driver breaking the rules that took the life of his father. The police can’t police everything
column29: so people like Mikey fill in the gaps.” Van Erp uses his social media reach to spread the message that there are increasing numbers of camera-equipped cyclists
column30: meaning that poor driving has consequences.

column1: “I don’t really want the fame
column2: ” he says. “On the other hand I haven’t really got any choice about it. The result is I have to use it to spread the word about camera cyclists. “Most people are really quite careful towards others. But cars do blunt that a little bit. There’s something about being in a car that takes the kind edge off us. We’re insulated in a soundproof comfort zone
column3: and we very much see it as our personal space.” With that
column4: our chat ends and
column5: camera still clamped to baseball cap
column6: Van Erp cycles through the park towards home – not searching out dangerous drivers
column7: but only too aware how easily one can arrive in your life
column8: unheralded
column9: and with devastating consequences.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/05/filming-cyclingmikey-dangerous-drivers-mike-van-erp-motorists-britain-roads-safer;7

column1: 237;237;5480;5480;Cuba’s vaccine success story sails past mark set by rich world’s Covid efforts;2022-01-05T10:00:38Z;['Ed Augustin'];['Cuba'
column2: 'Americas'
column3: 'World news'
column4: 'Coronavirus'
column5: 'Vaccines and immunisation'];"General Máximo Gómez
column6: a key figure in Cuba’s 19th-century wars of independence against Spain once said: “Cubans either don’t meet the mark – or go way past it.” A century and a half later
column7: the aphorism rings true. This downtrodden island struggles to keep the lights on
column8: but has now vaccinated more of its citizens against Covid-19 than any of the world’s major nations. More than 90% of the population has been vaccinated with at least one dose of Cuba’s homegrown vaccines
column9: while 83% have been fully inoculated. Of countries with populations of over a million
column10: only the United Arab Emirates has a stronger vaccination record. “Cuba is a victim of magical realism
column11: ” said John Kirk
column12: professor emeritus of Latin American studies at Dalhousie University
column13: Canada. “The idea that Cuba
column14: with only 11 million people
column15: and limited income
column16: could be a biotech power
column17: might be incomprehensible for someone working at Pfizer
column18: but for Cuba it is possible.” Like most Latin American countries
column19: Cuba knew it would struggle to buy vaccines on the international market. So in March 2020
column20: with foreign exchange reserves plummeting due to the loss of tourism revenue and ferocious new US sanctions
column21: the island’s scientists got to work.

column1: The gamble paid off: this spring Cuba became the smallest country in the world to successfully develop and produce its own Covid vaccines. Since then its well-staffed
column2: if dilapidating universal health service
column3: has rolled out injections at a fast clip
column4: inoculating even young children (all vaccination on the island is voluntary). Both vaccines are over 90% effective
column5: according to Cuban-run clinical trials conducted last spring. Successful rollout has brought infection rates down from among the highest in the western hemisphere last summer to low levels today.

column1: Last August the island reported hundreds of Covid deaths per week; last week there were three. The vaccine success is all the more striking when set against the parlous state of the healthcare service in other areas. With hard currency inflows cut in half over the last two years
column2: antibiotics are now so scarce that 20 pills of amoxicillin trade on the black market for the equivalent of a month’s minimum state salary. Out of plaster cast
column3: doctors in some provinces now resort to wrapping broken bones in used cardboard. “Ever since the 1959 revolution
column4: Cubans have embarked on these grand crusades which are quixotic yet often successful
column5: ” said Gregory Biniowsky
column6: a Havana-based lawyer. A prime example
column7: Biniowsky said
column8: was Fidel Castro’s pipe dream of investing one billion dollars in biotech after the Soviet Union disintegrated. “Any rational adviser would have said this was not the time to invest resources in something that might bear fruit in 25 years. And yet here we are now … where these fruits of the biotech investment are saving lives.” Other quests have dramatically failed: the Ten Million Ton Sugar Harvest of 1970 aimed to produce an unprecedented amount of sugar to spur growth. But to cut the cane
column9: workers were pulled from their regular jobs
column10: paralysing industry and wreaking havoc on the economy. Last year Cuba harvested seven times less sugar than in 1959.

column1: “As a nation there’s a tendency to get really good with the big things
column2: and awful at the everyday things
column3: ” said Hal Klepak
column4: professor emeritus of history and strategy at the Royal Military College of Canada. “The whole idea of electrifying the country [in under a decade]
column5: abolishing illiteracy in 2.5 years
column6: and medical internationalism – these were all just mad schemes. And they did it.” Today
column7: Cuba posts tens of thousands of doctors and nurses doing humanitarian work abroad – but fails to grow enough potatoes for the population. Cuba’s highly centralized
column8: state planning system – one of the last in the world – goes some way to explaining this paradox. When there is political will from the top
column9: objectives can be driven forward; when there’s a lack of direction
column10: the island’s rigid
column11: Kafkaesque bureaucracy can elevate passing the buck to an art form. “In capitalism you tend to have
column12: even with very little things
column13: somebody to fill the market
column14: ” said Klepak. “The difference with Cuba is that for [most economic] decision-making
column15: there isn’t anyone but the state.” After registering less than 100 cases a day for weeks
column16: infection rates are now rising due to the highly contagious Omicron variant. Cuban scientists have not released data on the efficacy of their vaccines against Omicron but have begun work to update their vaccine against the variant. In the meantime
column17: the Cuban ministry of public health has fast-tracked its booster campaign
column18: and aims to give almost the entire population an extra shot of vaccine this month.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/cuba-coronavirus-covid-vaccines-success-story;3

column1: 238;238;5481;5481;Empty promise: new political group speaks up for depopulated rural Spain;2022-01-05T09:46:28Z;['Sam Jones'];['Spain'
column2: 'Europe'
column3: 'World news'
column4: 'Depopulation'];"Judith Iturbe grimaces as she thinks about August and what it means for the residents and rhythms of Milmarcos. At the height of summer
column5: the population of this small and beautiful Spanish village
column6: which sits close to Castilla-La Mancha’s border with Aragón
column7: rises from just 44 to about 1
column8: 000. “For me
column9: August is the worst time of the year because all these people come from the city with their urgent requirements
column10: ” says Iturbe
column11: who runs a tiny brewery in Milmarcos. Twenty-one years ago
column12: she and her partner decided to leave their hectic jobs and lives in Madrid and start over.

column1: If it was quiet they craved
column2: they have not been disappointed. The only people on the streets of the village this afternoon are two older residents who sit on garden chairs by the church tower to chat and soak up the rays of the low winter sun. The peace and quiet
column3: however
column4: comes at a price. The doctor comes through just once a week

column8: this corner of Guadalajara province is one of the most hollowed-out parts of the demographic realm known as La España vaciada – the hollowed-out Spain. Decades of depopulation have left huge stretches of rural Spain starved of people
column9: attention and investment
column10: and prompted the country’s Socialist-led coalition government to establish a ministry for the demographic challenge. But for many in such areas
column11: change has not come fast enough. At the end of September

column1: The España Vaciada platform took its inspiration from the fact that Teruel Existe

column8: ” he says. “These problems are now on politicians’ agendas
column9: even if we’re not yet seeing them in their programmes and actions.” Among the platform’s 101 initiatives is a national plan with guaranteed funding that would enable overlooked parts of the country to catch up with more developed ones
column10: the creation of a non-political
column11: expert agency to tackle depopulation
column12: and improved rail links and services. “We also have a simple plan to drive recovery and balance things up that we call 100/30/30
column13: ” says Saz. “Thats 100mbps of symmetrical internet
column14: 30 minutes to basic services such as education
column15: health or security
column16: and 30km [18 miles] to a high-capacity road. If we could get all that
column17: we’d have a far more well-balanced country.”

column1: The platform – which will face its first ballot-box test when it runs in February’s regional election in Castilla y León – is not fond of ideological labels. So would it be happy to strike deals with either the far-left Unidas Podemos or the far-right Vox? “Our ideology is driven by the vital necessity to tackle depopulation before it’s too late and we disappear – that’s what binds us more than left and right blocs
column2: ” says Saz. While he says it is far too early to speculate on electoral performances
column3: Saz acknowledges the platform is keen to acquire the kind of clout Teruel Existe can exercise: “The more weight we have when it comes to seats
column4: the more they’ll listen to us and the more we can do.” José Pablo Ferrándiz

column6: says the platform is likely to pose the biggest threat to Spain’s old political duopoly – the ruling Spanish Socialist Workers’ party (PSOE) and the conservative People’s party (PP). “In the face of these new demands – which actually aren’t new at all – the two big parties can’t say they’re the ones who are going to solve these problems because they’ve been voted in before and haven’t solved them
column7: ” he says. Ferrándiz thinks the arrival of España Vaciada – which follows the eruption in recent years of Podemos
column8: Vox and the fading
column9: centre-right Citizens party – could herald even greater fragmentation. “In a national political scenario where even the vote of Teruel Existe is fundamental in forming majorities – and potentially even in forming governments – the PP and the PSOE know that if these platforms grow and win even three or four seats
column10: they will be important when it comes to forming national governments.”

column2: 'Honours system'
column3: 'Politics'
column4: 'UK news'];So
column5: Anthony Charles Lynton “call me Tony” Blair must now be called Sir Tony. In addition to being “Right Honourable” he is to be the Queen’s Companion
column6: chivalrous and knightly. He is to wear a royal garter
column7: the highest honour the monarch can bestow
column8: and it is her personal decision. Gasps all round. A petition of protest has received almost 700
column9: 000 signatures already. On paper the reason for the garter
column10: not a normal knighthood
column11: is that Blair was once prime minister and all former holders of that office get one
column12: as they once got earldoms. James Callaghan did
column13: as did Margaret Thatcher. The difference is that Blair’s honour has been delayed for 15 years. The palace might argue that there are only three vacancies in the 24-strong companionship and there are four ex-prime ministers waiting
column14: along with other worthy candidates. That does not explain the delay in Blair’s case. In the light of history
column15: Blair was not a peculiarly bad prime minister. In winning three general elections he might even be rated a success. The two wars into which he led his nation
column16: in Afghanistan and Iraq
column17: were heavily supported by some at the time. But the charge against him
column18: as confirmed by the Chilcot report
column19: is that he woefully misled parliament and the public in stating his case. Hundreds of Britons and hundreds of thousands of foreigners died – and are still dying – as a result of Britain’s participation in those wars. Plenty of people did not think much of Thatcher
column20: who also went to war
column21: but no howl greeted her garter. The Commons Speaker
column22: Sir Lindsay Hoyle
column23: has suggested that all ex-prime ministers should be knighted on leaving office
column24: simply for having done “one of the toughest jobs in the world”. Like permanent secretaries
column25: senior judges and (most) Commons Speakers
column26: they deserve a farewell pat on the back
column27: and a knighthood comes cheap. To this extent
column28: Blair would be entitled to his reward. But
column29: in that case
column30: someone should have said so and done it. As it is
column31: the delay over Blair looks like a deliberate judgment somewhere in Buckingham Palace. Were some courtiers muttering
column32: “Must we really
column33: what with Iraq and all that?” Were others saying
column34: “It’s over
column35: just get on with it”? As for numbers
column36: they might hope that with a bit of luck
column37: next-in-line Gordon Brown will refuse
column38: and David Cameron can be dumped in the Lords
column39: where his recent misdeeds will vanish in its mire of sleaze. In other words
column40: the delay in the award to Blair could indeed be a royal comment on his botched job – at which point we should best treat it as matter closed. More evidence
column41: if it were needed
column42: that our entire “honours” system and its associated nomenclature is an outdated mess. Britain has inherited an honours system that
column43: like its Church of England and parliament itself
column44: is shrouded in past fashion and fancy language that it seems incapable of reforming. Honours are divided between people who get them through their job
column45: people who merit them and people who buy them. The cynicism of Boris Johnson’s (and Cameron’s) purchased honours has brought the House of Lords to a new low. I can think of no other democracy where membership of its parliament is so brazenly up for sale. It is not good enough to say it does not matter much. If it is to serve as the nation’s comment on the performance of public figures
column46: a system of honours should convey meaning
column47: not time-serving. In a climate of sleaze and corruption
column48: the case is overwhelming for a commission to clean up and modernise the hierarchy of national awards. Parliament
column49: politics and Downing Street should have nothing to do with it. We can eliminate archaic references to empires
column50: saints
column51: baths
column52: garters and chivalry. We can stick to orders of merit. As for prime ministers
column53: their reward is best kept in heaven
column54: or at least confined to the lucrative lecture circuit and memoir catalogue. It is there that the nation can best express its appreciation of their work. • This article was amended on 6 January 2022. An estimate of the death toll resulting from the UK’s participation in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars was changed from tens of thousands to hundreds of thousands. Simon Jenkins is a Guardian columnist;https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/05/tony-blair-knighthood-britains-honours-system-is-broken;1

column6: 'Saudi Arabia'];"The year 2022 – which launches into the Olympic Games in Beijing and ends with the World Cup in Qatar – is set to be a great year for authoritarian regimes looking to cover up their atrocious human rights records. Over the course of a 12-month period
column7: countries such as China
column8: Qatar and Saudi Arabia
column9: all of whom have been criticized for human rights violations
column10: will use prestigious sports events to polish their public image on an international stage. This process is known as sportswashing
column11: a term popularized by Amnesty International in 2018 to describe the use of sports by oppressive governments to legitimize their regimes and distract from their human rights abuses. Traditional examples of sportswashing include the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin under the Nazi regime
column12: which Hitler hosted in an attempt to showcase German and Aryan superiority. While sportswashing has long been a popular tactic
column13: 2022 is a particularly concerning year because both the Olympic Games and the World Cup – the two most-watched sporting events in the world – are being hosted in countries with markedly oppressive regimes. Beginning on 4 February
column14: China will host the Winter Olympics in Beijing and in towns in the neighboring Hebei province. Among other issues
column15: the country’s government has been criticized for its inhumane internment of Uyghur Muslims in the Xinjiang region
column16: its attempts to seize political control over Hong Kong and neighboring Taiwan
column17: and the disappearance (and questionable reappearance) of tennis star Peng Shuai after accusing a Chinese official of sexual assault.

column1: Several countries
column2: including the United States
column3: the United Kingdom
column4: Canada
column5: and Australia have announced that they will not send any government representatives to the Games due to concerns over China’s human rights record. However
column6: these nations will still send their athletes
column7: rendering the diplomatic boycotts as little more than performative theatre. Other countries such as France (host of the 2024 Summer Games) and Italy will not join the boycott
column8: while Russia’s President Vladimir Putin condemned the boycott as a “mistake”. China has since threatened that the countries who have announced diplomatic boycotts will “pay the price for their mistaken acts.” Following the Olympic Games
column9: attention will shift towards the World Cup in Qatar
column10: which is set to begin in November. The nation has a significant record of human rights violations. For example
column11: a Guardian investigation from February 2021 revealed more than 6
column12: 500 migrant workers from India
column13: Pakistan
column14: Nepal
column15: Bangladesh and Sri Lanka have died in Qatar since 2010. The shocking death toll
column16: compiled from government sources
column17: is most likely an underestimate and does not include data from other countries that send a significant number of workers to Qatar
column18: including Kenya and the Philippines. Dozens of migrant workers have died during the construction of World Cup stadiums in particular
column19: and more than 100 migrants employed on a construction project related to the event went up to seven months without pay. Most employees were eventually compensated
column20: though some still have several months of missing salaries. Other significant human rights issues in Qatar include restrictions on free expression
column21: forced labor
column22: the criminalization of same-sex relationships
column23: and a lack of accountability for violence against women and minorities. Reforms aimed at protecting migrant workers from exploitative labor were introduced in 2020
column24: though employers maintain disproportionate power and influence. Despite the harrowing reports of death and abuse in the construction of World Cup stadiums
column25: Fifa president Gianni Infantino announced on 30 December that the 2022 World Cup in Qatar was a “celebration of football and social inclusion”. “Fifa is the only governing body that looks after and cares about the entire world
column26: ” Infantino said in a prepared statement. “We will continue working hard to live up to the mission of not forgetting the ones who need most and who have no voice
column27: while also protecting the healthy growth of everyone else and the global football movement.” While China and Qatar will host the two most significant sports events of 2022
column28: other countries such as Saudi Arabia continue to expand their positions as key destinations for international sports events. The kingdom has spent billions on high-profile sports events aimed at strengthening its reputation and diversifying its economy to eliminate dependence on oil and gas. Most recently
column29: a group led by Saudi’s sovereign wealth fund – an entity headed by Crown Prince Mohamed Bin Salman – purchased Newcastle United. It is arguably one of the kingdom’s most successful sportswashing attempts
column30: as it provides Saudi with an influential position in English football as well as an opportunity to upgrade its public image and distract from its recent abuses
column31: including the infamous assassination of dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi
column32: its devastating war in Yemen that caused a humanitarian catastrophe
column33: and its crackdown on intellectuals
column34: reformers
column35: and women’s rights activists. Saudi Arabia has proved to be an alluring hub for sports events over the past few years
column36: having signed a 10-year
column37: $650m deal for a Formula One motor racing event
column38: invested millions in a Saudi International golf event
column39: and hosted some of the biggest boxing showdowns in recent memory. The kingdom has also hired the Boston Consulting Group to help lobby its interest in hosting a World Cup event in the not-so-distant future. There are other concerning sportswashing affiliations
column40: including the Ultimate Fighting Championships’ troubling links to Chechnya’s dictator Ramzan Kadyrov
column41: the NBA’s blossoming relationship with Rwandan autocrat Paul Kagame
column42: and the NFL’s newly announced five-year partnership with China (which included a map that pushed the false narrative that Taiwan
column43: an independent country
column44: was a part of China). Each of these examples highlights the growing trend of authoritarian countries using prominent and established sports entities as platforms for propaganda and sportswashing campaigns. This strategy has proven to be remarkably effective in overhauling these states’ public images and legitimizing their regimes. As state-run political projects and soft power propaganda outfits take center stage over the coming year
column45: 2022 is shaping up to be one of the most politically charged sporting years in recent memory.";https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/jan/05/sportswashing-winter-olympics-world-cup;4

column2: 'Labour'
column3: 'Politics'
column4: 'UK news'];"On the back of encouraging polls – including one that eliminated the Tory lead on the economy – Keir Starmer started the new year with a speech linking the months of Tory corruption and incompetence to a wider argument about Britain. Though the Labour leader is surely correct to acknowledge that his party can’t just rely on Tory collapse
column5: there is some way to go to turn the headings of security
column6: prosperity and respect into something that can capture the public imagination. Tucked away near the start of his speech was a small reference to the other Keir
column7: Hardie
column8: in the context of a point about patriotism. “The Labour party is a deeply patriotic party. Keir Hardie once said that British socialism must ‘wear a local garb’. He meant that British socialism was rooted in the everyday concerns of working people.” But while Hardie’s socialism was quoted
column9: we heard no more from the present Keir about his own. It is something he must address but seems reluctant to. In an interview last month
column10: Starmer was asked whether he was a socialist. He refused to say
column11: asking “what does that mean?”
column12: moving quickly past the question. It was a strange response. Each Labour leader has had to define where they stood in relation to socialism. Labour was established through an alliance including trade unionists and socialists. Through clause IV of its constitution it was committed to a form of widespread common ownership. Leading figures from all parts of the party have argued about what socialism is. That contested nature is a reflection of its role in the political life of the party. There are two broad considerations that flow from Starmer’s answer. One is the perennial need to engage with and answer what is
column13: or should be
column14: a central question; and it is worth noting that leaders from the party’s centre and right have done so to further their own purposes as much as the left. Answering it
column15: with certainty and clarity
column16: certainly need not be a barrier to electoral success. But
column17: the other is that the crises of the 21st century – the pandemic and climate – surely cry out for a politics based on socialism. Reaction to Starmer’s positioning was not limited to Labour’s left. The commentator John Rentoul
column18: hardly a proselytist for the left
column19: argued that he ought to have answered “yes
column20: of course”
column21: and then should have defined what socialism means to him. The Labour leader’s answer was particularly unusual because in 2020
column22: he had set out his view of socialism in a Guardian article. “If I see something wrong or spot an injustice
column23: I want to put it right
column24: ” he argued
column25: adding: “We can win again if we make the moral case for socialism
column26: a moral socialism
column27: that is relevant to people’s everyday lives and the challenges we face as we move into the 2020s and 2030s.” I took part in the discussion that preceded the publication of Starmer’s article. There was never any question that such a statement of political values was unnecessary or a hostage to fortune. It was a function of being a senior Labour politician that you set out a wider philosophy.

column1: His was not everyone’s view of socialism. But in a sense
column2: it was his attempt to answer in advance the question put to him more recently. That “moral socialism” piece
column3: so carefully thought through
column4: makes the Labour leader’s subsequent non-answer all the more perplexing. Why resile from it? Perhaps Labour’s leadership is inclined to avoid anything that nods to the wider left. Yet all Labour leaders
column5: left and right
column6: have to resolve their approach to socialism. Ed Miliband said he was bringing it back. Tony Blair’s replacement for clause IV declared “the Labour party is a democratic socialist party”. Neil Kinnock
column7: well versed in the language of the labour movement
column8: was interviewed for Marxism Today
column9: whose analysis was seen to be of use to a Labour leader moving the party rightwards. Some may say that any talk of socialism is a turn-off
column10: but no one is so naive as to believe that Labour ought to fight the next election with socialism as its slogan. Jeremy Corbyn’s overarching platform was not “vote Labour for socialism”
column11: but “for the many not the few”. People will vote for left politicians of every stripe because their stances and policies connect to the direct interests and values of the voters. The challenge is to work out how to apply socialist ideas in order to advance at an electoral level. Our times demand more
column12: not less
column13: socialism. Polling consistently shows high levels of support for socialism among young people – to the alarm of rightwing analysts. Even among the wider population
column14: including in the US
column15: positive and negative views of capitalism and socialism poll closely together. More importantly
column16: the free market has offered no solutions to the most fundamental aspects of the present pandemic. The state has had to intervene
column17: massively and repeatedly. Ninety-seven per cent of the funding for the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine came from the public sector and charities
column18: for example. The vaccines would have been impossible without the state. Gordon Brown’s demand for global action to end the scandal of undervaccination around the world should remind us that this is an unequal planet
column19: organised to the benefit of a relatively small number of rich countries. A socialist view looks at the contending class interests in society. In any given situation socialists will ask
column20: who pays? So it is with the fallout of this pandemic. No new furlough for the Omicron wave has left huge numbers of workers in the lurch. The TUC highlighted the worst Christmas wage squeeze in nearly a decade. Many key workers
column21: having seen the economy through the phases of the pandemic
column22: can now expect a pay cut. The Treasury’s case that public sector pay settlements should not keep pace with inflation equates to a real-terms reduction. The pandemic has seen our society gripped by questions long-raised by socialists: internationalism
column23: collectivism
column24: inequality
column25: class interests
column26: planning
column27: public ownership and state intervention versus the free market. The same applies to the climate crisis. Labour appears reluctant
column28: but it simply must engage with where it stands on socialism. It is just over 30 years since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. At the time
column29: many on the right hoped that seismic event would also mean the end for a politics that looked to a future beyond capitalism. It was never likely then
column30: and the twin global challenges of Covid-19 and climate emergency must surely lead to the opposite conclusion now. Simon Fletcher is a former adviser to Keir Starmer
column31: Jeremy Corbyn and Ed Miliband. He previously served as chief of staff to the mayor of London
column32: Ken Livingstone

column2: 'Fiction'
column3: 'Culture'];"In a bowling alley somewhere in postapocalyptic rural America
column4: a 10-year-old savant is celebrating his birthday. His mother has chosen this moment to tell him
column5: via the unusual method of having a murder scene rendered in icing on his cake
column6: that his father killed his grandfather. The baker
column7: though
column8: has erred
column9: and topped the cake instead with an edible version of Goya’s Saturn Devouring His Son
column10: an image so disturbing it causes the child to question his own existence. “Saturn
column11: ” a party guest helpfully informs him
column12: “represents Time
column13: which
column14: with its ravenous appetite for life
column15: devours all its creations.” Later we will learn that the bowling alley never existed
column16: and that some or all of these characters may very well be dead. Welcome
column17: if you have not been here before
column18: to the world of Joy Williams – widely praised
column19: sadly not quite as widely read. My Vintage paperback of 2001’s dazzling The Quick and the Dead carries admiring quotes by Don DeLillo
column20: Raymond Carver and Bret Easton Ellis
column21: yet in the UK it is unforgivably out of print. Williams’s 2015 short story collection The Visiting Privilege was heralded by all who read it as a major literary event
column22: yet it took the tiny imprint Tuskar Rock to bring it to the UK market. On the surface of it
column23: Harrow
column24: her first novel in more than 20 years
column25: seems unlikely to broaden her audience. This is not to say the book is not brilliant – it is. It’s simply that Williams has made no concessions; she remains wonderfully and determinedly herself. What might be a little different
column26: though
column27: is the world into which her work emerges
column28: and the reality she so daringly alchemises into her vision.

column1: Attempting a precis of this novel feels like exactly the kind of misguided endeavour Williams would scorn
column2: but allow me to try. Harrow is set in an undefined near future in which the global environmental situation has gone from being on “the verge that people thought would go on forever” to all-out catastrophe. Khristen
column3: the novel’s not-quite-central character
column4: briefly died as a baby
column5: or so her mother adamantly believes
column6: and may never have entirely returned. Post-disaster
column7: amid a hallucinatory terrain that may or may not be an afterlife
column8: she finds herself at The Institute
column9: where a loose collective of geriatric terrorists “in the worst of health but with kamikaze hearts” plot suicide missions targeting vivisectionists and pesticide salesmen in the hope that this will “refresh
column10: through crackpot violence
column11: a plundered earth”. Williams’s method is one of adjacency more than linearity. Language
column12: not narrative
column13: is the connective tissue. To read her is to be flung every which way: from the spiritually profound to the farcically bizarre. One minute we observe “unprepared souls
column14: moments from the clarity of their deaths”. The next
column15: we are invited to consider the condition of a very old man’s penis: “She wondered if his pecker was as shredded and gribbled and nicked as the rest of him or whether it hung wondrously
column16: impossibly smooth and aloof
column17: its head like burled oak.” Every sentence is lathed into sleek and startling perfection. At the bowling alley
column18: serious bowlers “held the afterward of their poses for a vanity of time”. A crashing car flies “like a crumpled Kleenex into a cement utility pole by which it was trephined with glittering efficiency”. A salesman is so talented he “could sell a shock collar to a Doberman”. Even seemingly offhand phrases glitter with wit. Admire if you will the sing-song perfection of “Eddie Fucking Emerald offed by a fatty in a Caddy”.

column1: Zeroing in on our collective complacency and denial
column2: Williams is both wry and merciless
column3: lamenting “twelve lane highways with bicycle supplements” and people “who think they can still save the earth by grinding up some modest nut or bean for pancake meal”. A pre‑collapse environmental conference includes a talk entitled The Potentiality of Landscape’s Emptiness: The Integrity of Half Measures. A TV channel streams nothing but minutes of silence. “We all lead three lives
column4: ” Khristen is told. “The true one
column5: the false one
column6: and the one we are not aware of.” This life we’re not aware of is Williams’s great subject. She peels back the visible and known
column7: revealing death and chaos beneath. Wandering around a rescue centre for birds
column8: Khristen stumbles across “an old oil drum
column9: brimming with amputated wings”. A grove of trees is “surprisingly green and freshly pleasant except for the packages of meat dumped there”. What seems to be a livestream of a nesting bird is in fact a recording
column10: the bird having long ago flown into a truck. Part of what makes Williams’s work so destabilising is that agency has almost no significance. Navigating a world that makes no sense
column11: her characters are lost and baffled
column12: their actions and ideas stripped of meaning. These are people who “suspected they were meant to be more or different but fumbled about in the smoky light of half-realised lives”. With free will in question
column13: and the borders between life and death or reality and delusion queasily blurred
column14: individuality itself begins to fray. “Every person
column15: ” Williams tells us
column16: “considered themselves unique as snowflakes but in the aggregate they were a blizzard
column17: a whiteout of swirling expectation and denial.” In her remarkable essay Hawk
column18: about a beloved dog that inexplicably attacks her
column19: Williams writes: “Experience is fundamentally illusory. When one is experiencing emotional pain or grief
column20: one feels that everything that happens in life is unreal. And this is a right understanding of life.” Harrow reminds us that
column21: as a consequence of climate collapse
column22: trauma and grief are the condition of our collective existence. As our world disintegrates
column23: it will take what we think of as reality with it. Addressing this in fiction will be the job
column24: partly
column25: of a certain kind of modern mystic. Williams – great virtuoso of the unreal – is one of them. • Harrow by Joy Williams is published by Tuskar Rock in the UK (£14.99) and Australia ($29.99). Sam Byers’ latest novel is Come Join Our Disease (Faber). To support The Guardian and Observer
column26: order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply.";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/05/harrow-by-joy-williams-review-after-the-apocalypse;5

column12: 'Natural disasters'];"A few days before Christmas
column13: Super-typhoon Rai – known locally as Odette – ravaged the Philippines. The morning after the onslaught
column14: on my way back to Iloilo City from San Jose
column15: Antique
column16: I could see the ocean still boiling; houses blown away and great trees knocked down
column17: making roads impassable. The sights were terrifying. Lost lives continue to climb two weeks on. Vast numbers of buildings were destroyed – from houses to schools; food crops lost to flooding. At first
column18: I did not know what to feel – anger
column19: helplessness? Later
column20: I knew what I wanted: climate justice. On average
column21: 20 storms and typhoons hit the Philippines each year and they are growing progressively more destructive. The culprit is greenhouse-gas emissions from human activities. The Philippines contributes less than 0.4% to the climate crisis; the global north is responsible for 92%. The Philippines pays the price for problems produced in the north. In 2019
column22: the Philippines made a strong statement to the world when it sent 1
column23: 500 tonnes of illegally dumped rubbish back to Canada. However
column24: Cop26
column25: heralded as the world’s last chance to avert disaster
column26: was seen as a failure by many climate activists. Commitments were not delivered. The final agreement saw a watered-down stand against coal
column27: and prioritised profits over people and the planet.

column1: Despite the Philippines’ small part in the worsening climate crisis
column2: the threat to the country is huge. Rising sea levels from global heating will submerge parts of the country
column3: creating thousands of climate refugees. Drought and flooding will hit agricultural production and destroy ecosystems. The risk and intensity of health emergencies
column4: such as dengue and diarrhoea
column5: will increase.

column1: The Philippine government romanticises the suffering of the affected communities to conceal inefficiency and inaction with its “Filipinos are resilient” rhetoric. When my family and I lived in a slum above a river in Iloilo City
column2: we would leave our shanty houses before a typhoon made a landfall and shelter in a nearby chapel. When the storm had passed
column3: some of us would be grateful to see our houses still standing. Others would be saddened to see theirs blown to bits by the wind or taken by the waves. There was no resiliency here. Families would have to start from scratch
column4: rebuilding their homes
column5: only to see them destroyed again by the next typhoon. We lived in fear and carried the trauma from the danger the calamities posed. On 17 December
column6: I learned that my cousin
column7: a freshly graduated seafarer
column8: was missing with at least 10 other crew members of the tugboat M/V Strong Trinity
column9: after the typhoon hit the port city of Cebu. According to the owners
column10: the boat had sought shelter
column11: but the wind and waves were too strong and washed away the tugboat and those on board. The coastguard has found no trace of the vessel
column12: so far.

column1: Citizens were quick to point to the ill-preparedness of the government
column2: saying it had not learned the lessons from Typhoon Haiyan in 2013
column3: one of the strongest typhoons on record to hit land – despite the fact that this time round there was a system to disseminate information about the storm’s arrival through text messages
column4: social media and on news channels. However
column5: the role of media has been curtailed in the country. The regional stations of the Philippines’ biggest broadcaster
column6: ABS-CBN
column7: which were on the frontline during previous natural disasters
column8: have not been in service since 2020 due to what many see as a politically motivated denial of their franchise renewal. Telecommunications were interrupted. Filipinos were left in the dark waiting for news. People created Facebook groups with updates on the hardest-hit areas
column9: information on missing people
column10: and appeals for help. Facebook news feeds were flooded with posts from those in need. People wandered the streets with signs saying they were hungry and thirsty. Many died of dehydration. Flooded cities have become ghost towns; houses have been buried by landslides. The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council has declared a state of emergency in several cities and towns where power and water supplies are still cut off; more than 5.4 million people were affected. More than half a million have been displaced. Last week’s official figures put the death toll at 397 with 1
column11: 147 injured and 83 missing. There were more than 535
column12: 000 houses destroyed and €350m (£290m) of damage caused to agriculture and infrastructure. People from communities in “danger zones” are unable to return. Despite years of such disasters
column13: natural defences have not been protected. Dams have been built on ecologically important rivers; dolomite mining continues
column14: and new coal-powered plants are still being built. A few days after the typhoon
column15: a four-year ban on open-pit mining was lifted to help economic recovery
column16: disregarding the contribution of mining to the typhoons and rainfall that are battering the economy in the first place. The Philippines has elections in May
column17: when Filipinos must choose a leader who has an unwavering will to tackle the climate crisis by demanding accountability from the global north and strengthening the country’s defences. Poor countries and poor communities remain the victims of anthropogenic climate injustice. The process of ending the human activities responsible is weak and slow; there is only disaster risk-reduction management and mitigation in place. As long as the world does not address the root cause of this crisis

column5: 000 people recorded on the index have been invested with the public’s trust
column6: having been entrusted with official positions and funded with taxpayer dollars. Many are current or former government employees at federal
column7: state or local levels. Among them are 213 incumbents in elected office and 29 who are running as candidates for positions of power in upcoming elections. There are also 59 military veterans
column8: 31 current or former law enforcement officials
column9: and seven who sit on local school boards. When the index goes live on Thursday
column10: it will contain a total of 1
column11: 404 records of those who played a role in trying to overturn the 2020 election. In addition to the 1
column12: 011 individuals
column13: it lists 393 organizations deemed to have played a part in subverting democracy. The index is the brainchild of Public Wise
column14: a voting rights group whose mission is to fight for government that reflects the will and the rights of voters. Christina Baal-Owens
column15: the group’s executive director
column16: said that the index was conceived as an ongoing campaign designed to keep insurrectionists out of office. “These are folks who silenced the voices of American voters
column17: who took a validly held election and created fraudulent information to try to silence voters. They have no business being near legislation or being able to affect the lives of American people
column18: ” she said. The project has been set up with legal advice from Marc Elias
column19: one of the most influential election lawyers in the US who was Hillary Clinton’s top counsel in the 2016 presidential campaign and who successfully led Joe Biden’s resistance to Trump’s blitzkrieg of lawsuits contesting the 2020 results. Elias told the Guardian that the index was needed urgently to avoid history repeating itself in 2024 or beyond. “We are one
column20: maybe two elections away from a constitutional crisis over election subversion
column21: ” he said. “If we don’t recognize who was behind the attempt to disrupt the peaceful transfer of power
column22: then next time we will be less prepared and it may succeed.” Elias said he saw the index as an example of the kinds of robust action progressives need to take to combat an unprecedented wave of anti-democratic legislation emanating from Republicans in the past 12 months. While Trump had reshaped the right to be laser-focused on elections and winning at all costs
column23: Democrats are spreading their energies thinly between a number of causes of which protecting democracy was just one
column24: he said. “The central theme of the Republican party today is undermining free and fair elections. Under Trump that has become a credential within the party
column25: and we can’t let those folks win without a fight because if we do we lose our democracy.” The individuals recorded on the index who are already in public office include the 147 members of Congress who objected to the certification of the 2020 election result. The list also names many elected officials in state legislatures across the nation
column26: including states like Arizona that were ground zero for Trump’s efforts to steal the election from Biden. Jake Hoffman
column27: a lawmaker who represents Arizona’s 12th district
column28: wrote to fellow Republicans a day before the Capitol insurrection urging them to pressure then vice-president Mike Pence into blocking Biden’s victory. “Vice-President Pence has the power to delay congressional certification and seek clarification from state legislatures in contested states as to which slate of electors are proper and accurate
column29: ” Hoffman wrote
column30: reflecting a theory embraced by Trump that has been thoroughly rebutted. The week before the insurrection
column31: 17 Arizona state lawmakers wrote to Pence urging him to “block the use of any Electors from Arizona” despite multiple counts by then establishing that Biden had won the state by more than 10
column32: 000 votes. Among the signatories was Mark Finchem
column33: a member of the Arizona House of representatives who was present at Trump’s “stop the steal” rally in Washington on 6 January and who is now vying to become Arizona secretary of state – the top election official who oversees the presidential count. Among the 59 individuals on the index with military backgrounds is Christopher Warnagiris
column34: who in June became the first active-duty member of the armed forces to be charged in relation with the Capitol assault. Despite facing nine counts of assault and violent entry
column35: he has been permitted to continue serving within the training and education section at the Marine Corps Base Quantico in Virginia. Public Wise has drawn on a number of public information sources to compile the index
column36: working in partnership with other pro-democracy groups who have added specialist skills. The partners include American Oversight
column37: a non-partisan organisation that has used freedom of information laws to extract information from government agencies that exposes participants in the big lie. “The goal is to build up a holistic picture so that nothing can fall through the cracks and no one can slip away
column38: ” said Austin Evers
column39: the executive director of American Oversight. “We ask: who is this cc’d on this email? What handle is this on a social media account? If we can connect the dots we can ensure accountability can be brought to bear.” Evers said that the most chilling revelation of the research was that the 6 January insurrection was inspired by an ideology that was supported by people in power. “State legislators in Arizona were involved in the run-up to January 6 and after January 6 used their positions to drive the big lie. That feels cancerous – the attack on democracy has the backing of political
column40: and even governmental
column41: infrastructure.” One likely charge leveled at the new index by rightwing individuals and groups is that it is a form of “cancel culture”
column42: designed to silence anyone airing uncomfortable views. Baal-Owens dismisses any such criticism. “Our call to action is about voting
column43: not doxing
column44: ” she said
column45: pointing out that no private information is included on the index. “The call to action is not to show up at this person’s house or chase their child to school
column46: but to allow every registered voter to have an educated way to cast their vote.” The groups behind the index hope that it will alert voters to the anti-democratic actions of people running for elected office. The value of such a record
column47: they believe
column48: would increase exponentially were the Republicans to take back control of Congress in this year’s midterm elections
column49: leading almost certainly to an abrupt halt in congressional investigations into the events of 6 January.";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/05/trump-capitol-attack-democracy-election-insurrection-index;2

column1: 256;256;5499;5499;Trump’s ‘cult-like control’ of Republican party grows stronger since insurrection;2022-01-05T07:00:35Z;['David Smith'];['Republicans'
column2: 'US politics'
column3: 'Donald Trump'
column4: 'US Capitol attack'
column5: 'US news'
column6: 'World news'];"Whether it was praising white supremacists
column7: siding with Vladimir Putin or suggesting bleach as a coronavirus cure
column8: there was nothing that Donald Trump could do to make the Republican party fall out of love with him. Then came 6 January
column9: and – for a brief moment – it seemed that was no longer true. “Today all I can say is: count me out
column10: ” said Lindsey Graham
column11: standing in a Senate chamber that just hours earlier had been overrun by a pro-Trump mob determined to overturn the 2020 presidential election. “Enough is enough.”

column1: A week later he was joined by Kevin McCarthy
column2: the Republican minority leader in the House of Representatives
column3: who called on Trump to “accept his share of responsibility” for the deadly violence at the Capitol. Other allies turned against the president. If ever there was a moment that the party could snap out of its five-year fever dream
column4: this was it. Yet it did not. In the year since the insurrection that reverberated around the world
column5: Trump’s stranglehold on Republicans has seemingly become stronger
column6: not weaker. Graham was soon back on the golf course with him; McCarthy was soon kissing the ring at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida. Many leaders of the party have set about changing the narrative of the insurrection to portray it as a heroic last stand – a new “lost cause”. “We now have a major political party that is embracing violence systematically
column7: ” said Elaine Kamarck
column8: a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution thinktank in Washington and former White House official. “They’re rewriting the events of January 6. They’re referring
column9: as President Trump does
column10: to these people as patriots. They are stirring up a minority.” Trump was the first president in American history to inspire an attempted coup. After a rally where the defeated incumbent urged supporters to “fight like hell”
column11: the angry mob laid siege to the US Capitol to disrupt the certification of Joe Biden’s victory. Five people died
column12: scores of police were beaten and bloodied and there was about $1.5m in damage in the first major attack on the Capitol since the war of 1812. More than 700 people have been charged in one of the biggest criminal investigations in American history. But even on the night 6 January
column13: as members of the House and Senate stepped over blood and broken glass to get the job
column14: some 147 Republicans still voted to overturn the election results. It was the first clue that Trump had burrowed too far down into the party’s foundations to be expunged – and that anyone who tried would themselves be purged. The second clue came after Trump had been impeached – for the second time – by the House
column15: a vote in which just 10 Republicans joined Democrats. A majority of senators voted to convict the former president but fell 10 votes short of the two-thirds majority required by the constitution. Trump was acquitted. Jamie Raskin
column16: a Democratic congressman who was the lead impeachment manager
column17: said: “The evidence was so overwhelming
column18: our legal case was so airtight and Trump’s culpability was so plain to see
column19: I thought that perhaps the Republican party would use this as an opportunity to perform an exorcism on their own body. “But Trump just controls way too much money and too much power in the Republican party and it was really only a matter of a week or two before he reasserted his authoritarian
column20: cult-like control over the whole GOP [Grand Old Party] apparatus.”

column1: The third clue
column2: demonstrating Raskin’s point
column3: came in May when Senate Republicans voted down an independent commission to investigate the riot
column4: based on the model of a commission that examined the September 11
column5: 2001 terrorist attacks. Even the minority leader
column6: Mitch McConnell
column7: who had condemned Trump for inciting the violence and remains an arch foe
column8: dismissed the proposed commission as a “purely political exercise”. Democrats instead created a House select committee to examine the events of that day and understand what role Trump played. It has interviewed hundreds of people and is threatening jail time for those who refuse to comply. But it has only two Republican members
column9: Liz Cheney and Adam Kinzinger
column10: and their fates say much about the direction of the party. Cheney
column11: vice-chair of the committee and daughter of the former vice-president Dick Cheney
column12: has faced the wrath of the Republican party of Wyoming
column13: which voted to no longer recognise her as a Republican. She will be challenged for her seat in a primary election by a pro-Trump candidate. Kinzinger has been subjected to death threats and will not seek reelection. Michael Steele
column14: former chairman of the Republican National Committee
column15: said: “They have to rewrite the history because that’s the only way they can justify their existence because if you let the actual facts of history speak to the truth of who they are
column16: then I don’t know how they look themselves in the face in the morning.” Today the loudest voices in the Republican party belong to the extremists. For them
column17: Trump’s “big lie” that the election was stolen from him due to voter fraud
column18: rendering Biden an illegitimate president
column19: goes hand in hand with the lie that the insurrection was a morally justified crusade
column20: an righteous endeavor to save democracy
column21: not destroy it. Trump himself perpetuates this through a regular barrage of interviews
column22: rallies and emailed statements since he was barred from Twitter. Notably he has sought to lionize Ashli Babbitt
column23: who was shot dead during the riot
column24: as a martyr. Marjorie Taylor Greene
column25: a Republican congresswoman
column26: has cast rioters currently held in detention in a similar light. In November she visit a Washington jail’s so-called “patriot wing” and complained the inmates were enduring “inhumane” conditions because of their political beliefs. Other pro-Trump Republicans in the House echo these messages – one referred to the Capitol attack as a “normal tourist visit” – or do little to contradict them. Some Republican senators are evidently more uncomfortable with the web of deceit and urge the party to look forward to the next election. But again only a small minority are willing to take Trump on directly. All are aware of the power of rightwing media over state Republican parties and the “Make America great again” base. Fox News host Tucker Carlson produced a three-part documentary
column27: Patriot Purge
column28: for the Fox Nation streaming platform that pushed the bogus claim that the insurrection was a “false flag” operation designed to hurt Trump’s supporters. Steve Bannon
column29: a former adviser to Trump
column30: uses his “War Room” podcast to promote the “big lie” that Trump won re-election in a landslide and features guests such as Mike Lindell
column31: a pillow businessman who peddles wild conspiracy theories. Bannon encourages listeners to support the legal defence of the 6 January “political prisoners”. This has helped fuel a climate in which fealty to Trump and his debunked narrative is a litmus test for Republican candidates for Congress. Almost a third of Republicans believe violence may be necessary to “save” the US
column32: according to a recent poll by the Public Religion Research Institute. Trump’s resilient ability to bend the party to his will
column33: and to his disinformation about election “integrity”
column34: have fueled a drive to make it harder to vote
column35: likely to have a disproportionate impact on Democrats. Between January and October
column36: 19 states enacted 33 laws to restrict voting access
column37: according to the Brennan Center for Justice. In addition
column38: Trump loyalists are running as candidates for secretaries of state and other positions that would give them power over the running of future elections. With Republicans in a strong position to regain control of the House and Senate this year
column39: the party is readying for a repeat of 6 January with a different outcome. Steele added: “The elements of it are being played out in states throughout the country as Republicans rewrite the election laws in their favor.” One year on
column40: many analysts argue that America is now split between a Democratic party and anti-democratic party
column41: the latter being barely recognisable as the one-time home of Abraham Lincoln and Dwight Eisenhower. Instead Trump remains its most powerful and popular figure and could run for the White House again in 2024. Kurt Bardella
column42: an adviser to the Democratic National Committee
column43: believes that 6 January will go down as the day that the Republican party surrendered to “an anti-democratic terrorist cell” and that its mission since has been to permanently undermine democracy. “I have long said that January 6 was merely a dress rehearsal for how Republicans intend to try to hijack free and fair democratic elections in this country going forward
column44: ” added Bardella
column45: a former Republican congressional aide. “They know that when the playing field is level and everybody can participate in the democratic process
column46: they cannot win
column47: so the only recourse that they believe that they can obtain power is by throwing out democratic norms and overthrowing elections
column48: even if that means using instruments of violence
column49: fear and terror to do so.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/05/donald-trump-republican-party-capitol-attack-insurrection;3

column2: 'Climate crisis'
