column6: 'Aramco'
column7: 'Goldman Sachs'];"Fossil fuel companies and firms that work closely with them are among the biggest spenders on ads designed to look like Google search results
column8: in what campaigners say is an example of “endemic greenwashing”. The Guardian analysed ads served on Google search results for 78 climate-related terms
column9: in collaboration with InfluenceMap
column10: a thinktank that tracks the lobbying efforts of polluting industries. The results show that over one in five ads seen in the study – more than 1
column11: 600 in total – were placed by companies with significant interests in fossil fuels. Advertisers pay for their ads to appear on the search engine when a user queries certain terms. The ads are appealing to businesses because they are very similar in appearance to search results: more than half of users in a 2020 survey reported they could not tell the difference between a paid-for listing and a normal Google result. ExxonMobil
column12: Shell
column13: Aramco
column14: McKinsey
column15: and Goldman Sachs were among the top-20 advertisers on the search terms
column16: while a number of other fossil fuel producers and their financiers also placed ads. Jake Carbone
column17: senior data analyst at InfluenceMap
column18: said: “Google is letting groups with a vested interest in the continued use of fossil fuels pay to influence the resources people receive when they are trying to educate themselves. “The oil and gas sector has moved away from contesting the science of climate change and now instead seeks to influence public discussions about decarbonisation in its favour.” Oil major Shell’s ads – 153 were counted in total – appeared on 86% of searches for “net zero”. Many promoted its pledge to become a net zero company by 2050 and align itself with a 1.5C warming target.

column1: However
column2: Shell’s net-zero strategy relies heavily on carbon capture and offsetting
column3: according to a Carbon Brief analysis
column4: which says: “Despite its ‘highly ambitious’ framing … Shell’s vision of a continued role for oil
column5: gas and coal until the end of the century remains essentially the same.” A spokesperson for Shell said: “Shell’s target is to become a net zero emissions energy business by 2050
column6: in step with society. Our short
column7: medium and long-term intensity and absolute targets are consistent with the more ambitious 1.5C goal of the Paris agreement.” Goldman Sachs
column8: which facilitated nearly $19bn of lending to the fossil fuel industry in 2020
column9: had the third highest number of ads. The bank’s ads appeared on almost six in 10 searches for “renewable energy”
column10: with many emphasising its “continued commitment to sustainable finance”. Consulting firm McKinsey’s ads appeared on more than eight in 10 searches for “energy transition” and four in 10 searches for “climate hazards”. Its ads stated: “McKinsey works with clients on innovation & growth that advances sustainability.” Alongside its work on sustainable investing
column11: the company receives significant income from fossil fuel clients. In recent years McKinsey has advised 43 out of the world’s 100 most polluting companies
column12: according to the New York Times. A spokesperson for McKinsey pointed to an op-ed written by a managing partner at the company
column13: which states: “There is no way to deliver emissions reductions without working with these industries to rapidly transition.” Aramco
column14: the state-owned Saudi oil company
column15: which is the world’s largest oil exporter
column16: had 114 ads on the keywords “carbon storage”
column17: “carbon capture” and “energy transition”. A number of their ads claimed the company “promoted biodiversity” and “protected the planet”.

column1: Melissa Aronczyk
column2: an associate professor at Rutgers University
column3: said: “Since at least the 1980s in the US
column4: there has been a very concerted effort by public relations agents to help polluting companies develop strategies to ‘go green’ while maintaining business as usual. “Many of the initiatives companies are taking are very piecemeal and will not amount to any kind of long-term or systemic change.” Johnny White
column5: a lawyer at environmental charity ClientEarth
column6: called for stronger regulation of adverts placed by polluting industries. “Fossil fuel companies spend millions on incredibly sophisticated advertising campaigns
column7: so sorting fact from fiction can be really tricky for the public. “Damaging greenwashing has become endemic – to stamp it out we need to legislate bans on all fossil fuel advertisements
column8: just like what happened with tobacco.” The analysis also looked at “snippets”
column9: which are not paid-for but are chosen by Google’s algorithm as the most relevant result. The Guardian found the snippet chosen for “fracking” linked to the website of an oil and gas lobby group
column10: the Independent Petroleum Association of America.

column1: In answer to the question: “Is fracking a threat to public health?”
column2: the IPAA page states: “No. In fact
column3: there is ample evidence that increased natural gas use … has improved public health by dramatically improving air quality in recent years.” A years-long piece of research by the US Environmental Protection Agency concluded in 2016 that in some cases fracking had harmed drinking water supplies. Unlike Facebook
column4: Google does not have a publicly accessible ad library
column5: meaning it is difficult to analyse advertising on the platform. In the EU and UK
column6: Google only provides comprehensive data on ads which directly mention politicians or a political party
column7: or those which feature a referendum question. A spokesperson for Google said: “We recently launched a new policy that will explicitly prohibit ads promoting climate change denial. This policy applies to all advertisers
column8: including energy companies and financial institutions
column9: and we will block or remove any ads that contain violating content. “When search ads do appear
column10: they have the word “Ad” clearly labeled in bold black text in the current design. We rely on extensive user testing both on mobile and desktop to ensure ad labels meet our high standards for being prominent and distinguishable from unpaid results.” A spokesperson for ExxonMobil said: “ExxonMobil has contributed to the development of climate science for decades and has made its work publicly available. And as the scientific community’s understanding of climate change developed
column11: ExxonMobil responded accordingly.” Aramco and Goldman Sachs did not respond to requests for comment. • This article was amended on 6 January 2022 to add a response from Google relating to search ads that was received after publication.";https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/jan/05/fossil-fuel-firms-among-biggest-spenders-on-google-ads-that-look-like-search-results;3

column1: 258;258;5501;5501;Tree-mendous news: noisy gas-powered leaf blowers banned in Washington DC;2022-01-05T07:00:34Z;['Oliver Milman'];['Washington DC'
column2: 'US news'
column3: 'Environment'];"A roaring and often harmful cacophony that has long afflicted Washington DC has finally been silenced. Not the roar of politicians sounding off
column4: alas
column5: but the use (and sale) of gasoline-powered leaf blowers
column6: banned since New Year’s Day. Anyone using the blowers
column7: which have been blamed for ear-splitting noise and a stew of air pollution
column8: risks a fine of up to $500.

column1: People who still want to rearrange the natural fall of leaves from trees have been offered rebates for quieter electric blowers. The push to ban gas leaf blowers was led by local resident James Fallows
column2: a former speechwriter for Jimmy Carter who has blamed the anti-social implements for producing “the secondhand smoke of this era”. It is just the latest crackdown on leaf blower use across the US. Last year
column3: Gavin Newsom
column4: governor of California
column5: signed a law prohibiting gasoline-powered lawn equipment
column6: including leaf blowers and lawnmowers
column7: from 2024. More than 100 cities in various states have already banned gas leaf blowers
column8: with Dallas and Portland the latest major urban areas to mull new restrictions. The use of gas-powered leaf blowers is deleterious
column9: opponents argue
column10: due to their toxic emissions and ruination of neighborhood harmony. The blowers typically use two-stroke engines
column11: an outmoded design that can produce up to 100 decibels of low-frequency noise
column12: around the same as a plane taking off. This has led to concerns regarding hearing loss and tinnitus for users. The inefficiency of such engines also causes enormous levels of air pollution: a 2011 study found that just 30 minutes of using a leaf blower in the yard can emit the same amount of hydrocarbons as driving a pickup truck from Texas to Alaska. Michael Leamy
column13: an expert in mechanical engineering at Georgia Tech
column14: said the amount of air pollution from such a relatively small device was “astounding”. “Homeowners will use them occasionally but mostly we are talking about people from lower socio-economic backgrounds working in landscaping who are exposed to these pollutants
column15: which are very harmful to human health
column16: ” Leamy said. “These are very dirty
column17: crude engines compared to the engine you will find in a modern car. The government should really step in to protect the workers dealing day in
column18: day out with the air pollution and hearing loss caused by these leaf blowers.” Regulators in Washington DC sent out notices to lawn and building maintenance companies last summer
column19: warning of the upcoming change and pointing out that residents are able to file complaints online
column20: along with photographic or video evidence
column21: if they see gas leaf blowers used. The change will require a major shift for most landscapers
column22: said Nancy Sainburg
column23: founder of the Enchanted Garden landscape company
column24: which operates in Washington. “Hardly anyone is using electric leaf blowers
column25: ” she said
column26: “and I have no idea what enforcement will be like
column27: will people rat out their own neighbors? “I mean it’s DC
column28: so probably.” Sainburg switched her own workforce to electric blowers five years ago
column29: after
column30: she said
column31: becoming fed up with the smell of gasoline on her clothes and company trucks. “The electric ones are just as powerful as gas blowers
column32: you charge them overnight and just go for it
column33: ” she said. “My crew doesn’t get sick like they used to
column34: they don’t get respiratory issues like they used to
column35: they love it. “These blowers don’t make the big stupid noise of the gas ones
column36: it’s more like a vacuum cleaner noise. I think they are great.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/05/gas-leaf-blowers-banned-washington-dc;7

column1: 259;259;5502;5502;I was sure my parenting had made our baby’s first flight go smoothly. Then came the return trip | Arwa Mahdawi;2022-01-05T07:00:34Z;['Arwa Mahdawi'];['Parents and parenting'
column2: 'Children'
column3: 'Flights'
column4: 'Travel'
column5: 'Family'
column6: 'Life and style'
column7: 'Society'];"On New Year’s Eve
column8: my wife and I locked ourselves in a tiny British Airways bathroom and frantically pulled off items of clothing. It would have been a pretty exciting way to see off 2021
column9: were it not for the fact that the clothes belonged to our seven-month-old
column10: who had decided to do an enormous poo at 30
column11: 000 feet. I had had a little chat with the child before the flight and told her Mummy and Mummy would appreciate it if she held off on any major bowel movements while we were in the air
column12: but she didn’t cooperate. Babies
column13: I have learned
column14: are not very good at listening. They are good at screaming
column15: though. At least
column16: my kid is. She has always had a good set of lungs on her
column17: but
column18: my God
column19: screams reach a whole new decibel level when you are squeezed into cattle class on a plane
column20: surrounded by people who are quietly judging you. So
column21: I would like to extend an apology to everyone on BA175 from London to New York last Friday who may be experiencing mild PTSD after seven hours of being trapped with the high-pitched squeals and shrieks – interspersed with grunts and farts – of my darling demon child. My wife and I had not approached our first big trip with a child lightly. We had spent days researching how to take a child on a plane without making your fellow passengers want to murder you. We had brought along an array of soothing toys and teethers; we had bought a fancy little tent that you stick over your baby to lull them to sleep. On our way to London
column22: this had worked like a dream. As I kept telling the lovely flight attendant
column23: who popped by every few minutes to check on us and mutter: “Oh dear
column24: ” our baby was not normally this cranky – she had been an angel on the first flight of her life. I had got all smug
column25: thinking I had this whole parenting thing down. Ha! Ha! HA! If I have learned anything during my short time being a mum
column26: it is that you should never be smug. The moment you think you have everything figured out
column27: your child will very loudly put you in your place. Another lesson I have learned painfully? Bring several changes of clothes with you everywhere. A few hours into our flight from hell
column28: I spilled dry baby formula all over myself. This was stressful – you don’t want to have an Arabic name and arrive at US immigration covered in mysterious white powder. I decided to deal with the stress via the medium of chocolate. I looked around for the little pot of aeroplane pudding I had set aside earlier. Then I discovered that I was sitting on it. It had exploded all over my trousers. An organised mum would have had something clean to change into. I just sat in my chocolatey
column29: formula-specked trousers and wished myself dead. I reckon a fair few other passengers wished the same; no one wants to sit in the vicinity of a “lively” baby. A few years ago
column30: there was even a trend for parents to hand out goody bags on planes as penance for procreating; on a flight in 2017
column31: Amal and George Clooney gave noise-cancelling headphones to their fellow first-class passengers
column32: in case their six-month-old twins started crying. Sorry
column33: but bribe bags are not the answer. We need to find a better way for babies to fly. Maybe we could stick them in the hold
column34: as we do with pets? Only joking; I am not a monster. I would never put my dog in the hold. Anyway
column35: I am afraid I don’t have any answers when it comes to improving the in-flight experience. I have only apologies. Lots of apologies. Sorry
column36: once again
column37: to my fellow passengers. But
column38: however bad it was for you
column39: let me assure you that it was much
column40: much worse for me. • Arwa Mahdawi is a Guardian columnist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/05/i-was-sure-my-parenting-had-made-our-babys-first-flight-go-smoothly-then-came-the-return-trip;5

column1: 260;260;5503;5503;A moment that changed me: Ben Okri – realising my dream to become a novelist at the age of 19;2022-01-05T07:00:34Z;['Ben Okri'];['Books'
column2: 'Life and style'

column8: 'Africa'];"Family legend has it that I began reading the Times at around the age of four. At school in London I was that kid who stuck his hand up to read aloud from the Shakespeare play we were studying or to recite a poem. At secondary school
column9: in Nigeria
column10: literature was something I was negligently good at
column11: but didn’t take seriously. Over the holidays I would visit the libraries of foreign embassies and read my way through their literatures. At the American embassy
column12: I discovered Emerson and Whitman; at the Japanese embassy
column13: I discovered karate
column14: Zen Buddhism and Bashō. It seemed then I was destined to be a scientist. I applied to university
column15: but at age 14 was deemed too young. I spent a year at home
column16: waiting to be old enough. My main task
column17: during that year
column18: was to dust my father’s library. I was to dust the books but not read them. The first book to catch my attention was Plato’s Symposium. I had a great thirst for philosophy and devoured all his dialogues. I read the plays of Ibsen
column19: Shaw
column20: Shakespeare; the short stories of Maupassant
column21: Chekhov
column22: Maugham; then I got lost in 19th-century novels. Like everyone else

column28: to see the truth of society in the raw. I began with poetry. I wrote a hundred love poems and burned all except five. Then something happened that plugged my writing into the nerve of life. I would wake up at four o’clock in the morning and write for an hour before setting out for work. When I returned
column31: I would sleep and then write till one o’clock. I was always dozing on the long bus ride to the office. The first draft took a year. I got myself fired from work and bought a typewriter and a camera with the severance pay. I then worked as a reporter for a news magazine. In the autumn of 1978 I came to London to study. column35: one morning

column10: 'Jessie Buckley'];"It is clear from the opening minutes of The Lost Daughter
column11: Maggie Gyllenhaal’s melancholic

column14: (a luminous Olivia Colman)

column20: languid member of the Queens bunch who immediately catches Leda’s attention

column1: It’s a familiar language of buried secrets

column3: evil spirits

column6: the molten core of The Lost Daughter is one of our culture’s most enduring and least touchable taboos: the selfish
column7: uncaring
column8: “unnatural” mother – one who doesn’t shift easily to care-taking
column9: who does not relish her role

column11: adapted (and anglicized) from the short novel of the same name by Elena Ferrante
column12: is a masterclass in imbuing ostensibly low stakes with spellbinding tension. The book is written entirely in Leda’s internal monologue
column13: which Gyllenhaal
column14: aided by Colman and Buckley’s fluid performances
column15: conveys through taut dialogue and flashback sequences. The action is relatively mundane – Leda goes to the beach
column16: eats dinner alone
column17: and observes an exhausted Nina fielding the demands of her restless daughter Elena
column18: who is lost for all of a few minutes. The most significant transgression is Leda’s impulsive and childish theft of Elena’s beloved doll. The film’s climactic reveal is not an act of abuse or searing trauma
column19: as the prevalence of the trauma plot in film
column20: TV and literature has taught us to expect
column21: but an absence: for three years
column22: Leda
column23: desperate for reprieve and recognition
column24: forfeited her role as mother
column25: and left her daughters with her husband (Jack Farthing).

column1: The stakes of The Lost Daughter feel so weighty
column2: the viewing experience so unsettling and transgressive
column3: because the myth Leda’s recollections deftly unravel – that motherhood will come to women naturally
column4: that it will give something without taking something irreparable and valuable away – is so deeply woven into our culture as to be almost invisible. It is everywhere and nowhere
column5: the idea of motherhood as an identity of tenderness
column6: sacrifice
column7: fulfillment and
column8: above all
column9: selflessness. It’s in commonly heard descriptions of motherhood as “my life completely changed”; “I became a different person”; “I found my purpose”; “I met myself”. (Which may be true for some people!) It shapes the image of mom-fluencers and so-called mommy blogs
column10: informs the constant pressure for mothers to optimize every facet of their child’s life
column11: and underpins the norms that
column12: in the US
column13: justify women as the de facto social safety net. The Lost Daughter
column14: as in several of Ferrante’s other works (fans will note themes further explored in her bestselling Neapolitan novels)
column15: dares to posit that for some
column16: motherhood might not actualize the self but plunder it
column17: especially if
column18: like Leda
column19: she becomes one while still barely an adult herself (doing the math
column20: Leda was 23 when she had her first child
column21: 25 for her second). Leda’s ambivalence toward motherhood – magnetic
column22: vulgar
column23: revelatory
column24: repulsive – is a posture still rarely explored on screen. There are anti-mothering villains in films and television (Psycho
column25: Carrie
column26: the horror films Hereditary and The Lodge) but few examples of women who struggle with the expectations of the role in good faith
column27: fewer still those who reject it.

column1: Crucially
column2: The Lost Daughter is not a portrait of regret
column3: for either having children or leaving them. Leda never says the word
column4: nor does she appear to feel in isolation from other emotions such as guilt
column5: anguish
column6: pride
column7: love. Gyllenhaal takes pains to portray Leda as anything but an uncaring person. She comforts Nina
column8: meets her confessions with serrated vulnerability

column10: comforts a frightened
column11: lost Elena on the beach. In flashback sequences
column12: Leda can be withholding
column13: vindictive
column14: unreasonable with her daughters; she is also doting
column15: curious
column16: radiant
column17: expressive as she teaches her children to read
column18: to play
column19: or just holds them. Watching the scenes of her failures and abandonment – rebuffing her daughters
column20: lashing out at them
column21: leaving them – is an uncomfortable experience. Self-absorption is often indistinguishable from self-preservation

column24: perhaps estrangement. (For what it’s worth

column1: 270;270;5514;5514;More than a feeling: why our emotions are crucial to the way we think | Leonard Mlodinow;2022-01-05T06:00:34Z;['Leonard Mlodinow'];['Neuroscience'
column2: 'Psychology'
column3: 'Science'
column4: 'Biology'
column5: 'Charles Darwin'];"Charles Darwin created the most successful theory in the history of biology: the theory of evolution. He was also responsible for another grand theory: the theory of emotion
column6: which dominated his field for more than a century. That theory was dead wrong. The most important tenet of his theory was that the mind consists of two competing forces
column7: the rational and the emotional. He believed emotions played a constructive role in the lives of non-human animals
column8: but in humans emotions were a vestige whose usefulness had been largely superseded by the evolution of reason. We now know that
column9: on the contrary
column10: emotions enhance our process of reasoning and aid our decision-making. In fact
column11: we can’t make decisions
column12: or even think
column13: without being influenced by our emotions. Consider a pioneering 2010 study in which researchers analysed the work of 118 professional traders in stocks
column14: bonds and derivatives at four investment banks. Some were highly successful
column15: but many were not. The researchers’ goal was to understand what differentiated the two groups. Their conclusion? They had different attitudes toward the role of emotion in their job. The relatively less successful traders for the most part denied that emotion played a significant role. They tried to suppress their emotions
column16: while at the same time denying that emotions had an effect on their decision-making. The most successful traders
column17: in contrast
column18: had a different attitude. They showed a great willingness to reflect on their emotion-driven behaviour. They recognised that emotion and good decision-making were inextricably linked. Accepting that emotions were necessary for high performance
column19: they “tended to reflect critically about the origin of their intuitions and the role of emotion”. Though the successful traders embraced the positive and essential role emotions played
column20: they understood that when emotions become too intense it is useful to know how to tone them down. The issue for them was not how to avoid emotion
column21: but how to regulate and harness it. Today
column22: it has become common for hedge funds and financial firms to employ “psychology coaches” to meet traders on a one-on-one basis
column23: as portrayed in the television series Billions. If emotions aid rational reasoning
column24: how does that work? Perhaps the most important discovery regarding the role of emotion is that even when you believe you are exercising cold
column25: logical reason
column26: you aren’t. People aren’t usually aware of it
column27: but the very framework of their thought process is highly influenced by what they’re feeling at the time – sometimes subtly
column28: sometimes not. As the Caltech neuroscientist Ralph Adolphs puts it: “Each emotion is a functional state of the mind that puts your brain in a particular mode of operation that adjusts your goals
column29: directs your attention
column30: and modifies the weights you assign to various factors as you do mental calculations.” Think of an iPhone. In its normal mode of operation
column31: the phone’s goal is to always be ready to serve you. To best accomplish that
column32: the iPhone is constantly at work
column33: doing things like “listening” for you to yell “Hey
column34: Siri”
column35: checking to see if there are new emails to download
column36: and updating your apps even if you are not currently using them. In low-power mode
column37: the priorities are changed. Energy conservation is important
column38: so these actions are reduced or stopped altogether. Though enormously more complex
column39: the human brain is like an iPhone in that it constantly carries out computations. It evolved to compute what actions would be most likely to nurture your health
column40: prevent premature death and increase the probability that you will successfully reproduce. And like the iPhone
column41: our brains possess a number of specialised programs
column42: each tailored to solving a problem. Some of our programs apply to practical issues such as foraging
column43: mate choice
column44: facial recognition
column45: sleep management and energy allocation. Others handle cognitive issues such as learning
column46: memory
column47: goal selection and so on. Just as the iPhone adjusts its programming when in low-power mode
column48: a biological brain can run in various modes
column49: each with different characteristics. An emotion – both in humans and animals – is a functional backdrop that orchestrates and coordinates those many programs in a manner tuned to the type of situation you are in. Consider anger
column50: for example. Backed by the threat of aggression
column51: anger creates incentives for others to appease the angry individual. Your mental calculus inflates the importance you place on your own welfare and goals at the expense of those of others. Coaches tap into anger as a motivational tool because the focus on self encourages athletes to push themselves to achieve their goals. Anger also causes you to perceive less risk
column52: exacerbating risk-seeking. That can produce better judgments in situations where risk-aversion is inappropriate
column53: as when you are analysing stocks
column54: or playing poker.

column1: The new view of emotion may not correspond to the way Darwin saw it
column2: but it does support one of the basic conclusions of his theory of evolution: humans are not as different from non-human animals as people believed. What can we learn from this? The first and most crucial step is self-awareness. Studies show that those with high levels of emotional intelligence fare better in their personal and professional lives. By learning about our emotions we can read others better and communicate more effectively. And by understanding how emotions affect our thoughts and reasoning
column3: we can learn to recognise and monitor them. Then
column4: once we’re in touch with our true feelings
column5: we can take steps to manage them whenever that would be of benefit. Leonard Mlodinow is a physicist and author of EMOTIONAL: The New Thinking about Feelings";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/05/emotions-crucial-to-how-we-think-charles-darwin-decision-making;6

column6: my new year resolution is to finish the first draft of a novel. It’s a realistic goal – I’m not saying it has to make money
column7: or even be any good. I just want the words on the page
column8: even if all they do then is languish for ever in a folder. Well
column9: I say that’s what I want – but of course finishing a draft was my new year resolution last year
column10: and the year before that
column11: and before that. In truth
column12: I’ve been pushing back this particular ambition since 2017. Maybe for you
column13: it’s running a marathon – or a 5k. It might be losing a particular amount of weight
column14: or completing a course in yoga or a foreign language. It could be a time-intensive project such as making a quilt or researching your family history. Many of us have these mid- to long-term goals that are ambitious
column15: but (in theory) achievable with the requisite investment of time and effort. I’m going to guess that many other people also have not made a start – even if last year’s lockdowns meant that they
column16: like me
column17: had endless hours to fill. So why do we put off these goals
column18: and how can we make 2022 the year we finally attain them? I spoke to experts to find out. Focus on the process – not perfection “It’s a very human problem
column19: ” says Fuschia Sirois when I describe my situation. A professor of psychology at the University of Sheffield
column20: Sirois studies procrastination and perfectionism – and their toll on wellbeing. She says both factor into our failure to get started on projects. “When you’re working towards something and you’re not quite there
column21: anything is possible; you can imagine how successful it will be
column22: ” says Sirois. “But we know that’s not what happens in real life.” In other words
column23: just taking a step towards my goal will be a sobering reminder of the long road ahead. The story I’m capable of writing may not be bad
column24: but it will
column25: inevitably
column26: be unlike how I have imagined it
column27: and that realisation alone can throw us off
column28: says Sirois. “We preserve that goal when we never get started – it just becomes that abstract thing
column29: out there.” So willpower and a plan are not necessarily enough. Sirois’s research shows that we procrastinate on a task to avoid difficult emotions. “We are not rational beings. Our fears
column30: anxieties
column31: personal internal struggles
column32: the negative scripts we have about ourselves
column33: our self-esteem – all these things come into motion.” Procrastinating can then add another layer of self-criticism – while perfectionism can trick us into thinking that there’s an optimum time to start. The paralysis Sirois describes is painfully familiar. I couldn’t count the number of weeknights and weekends that I’ve felt ambient guilt for not writing
column34: even though I had not planned to do so. Sirois suggests
column35: instead
column36: that I try drilling down into these emotional blocks. For instance
column37: they could represent my being critical of myself
column38: which I can meet with self-compassion – or my uncertainty about the task
column39: calling for research. “It’s easy to blame the plan. It’s much harder to say: ‘I don’t know how to manage my emotions’
column40: ” says Sirois. Part of the problem
column41: she says
column42: is that we find it hard to accurately forecast our emotional states
column43: meaning we can overstate the struggle of working towards our goal or the satisfaction we will feel achieving it – or both.

column1: “What we learn about ourselves along those longer journeys such as running a marathon or writing a novel
column2: how we build our skills
column3: the relationships we make and strengthen: that is actually what makes the experience much more rich and rewarding than we could ever imagine – but we tend to forget these things.” The solution
column4: says Sirois
column5: is to seek meaning from the process
column6: not the outcome. A recent study showed that people who thought about why their goal was important to them spent much less time procrastinating than those who only thought about how good it would feel to achieve it. If I thought my latest chapter was bad
column7: she suggests that I could reframe it to myself as “I’m becoming a better writer”. Someone training for a marathon might focus on keeping fit
column8: spending time with friends
column9: or following in family members’ footsteps. “You can look at the struggles you’re experiencing in a broader perspective
column10: to see what it means in terms of your own personal growth
column11: ” says Sirois. But it’s tough

column18: in the moment

column23: restricting our favourite snacks or tea to writing sessions or watching TV only when on the treadmill. Milkman mentions a student who let herself light a scented candle only when she was working on her dissertation. It would have to be a pretty special scented candle
column24: I say. “I agree

column27: 000 US gym members

Awarding reward points (equivalent to only 9¢ or about 6½p) to people who returned to the gym after missing a planned workout increased visits by about 16% compared with the baseline offering. Extending a bigger reward (points worth $1.75) for every workout was almost as effective
column29: increasing visits by about 14%. So

column11: but I think this would work better for me than a scented candle. Stop daydreaming One of the most common strategies for success is to visualise it – picturing yourself crossing the finish line with a personal best
column12: or seeing your bestseller on shelves. But
column13: says Gabriele Oettingen – a professor of psychology at New York University and the University of Hamburg
column14: and author of Rethinking Positive Thinking: Inside the New Science of Motivation – this could actually be counterproductive. Over many studies
column15: her research has established an unexpected but powerful correlation between positive thinking and poor performance. “The more positive a daydream about the future
column16: the less I put in effort to actually realise it
column17: ” Oettingen explains over Zoom from New York. In other words
column18: fantasising about our goals makes us feel good in the short term – to the point of lowering our blood pressure – but it saps us of the energy we need to take action. “People feel accomplished
column19: ” says Oettingen. “Like they’re already there.” Worryingly
column20: Oettingen suggests
column21: this inaction could over time even lead to depression
column22: with a correlative link established between fantasising about the future and a more negative mood. So
column23: instead of simply visualising
column24: Oettingen advocates what she calls “mental contrasting”: not just fantasising about success but comparing your daydream with reality to reveal what
column25: specifically
column26: is holding you back from achieving it. Once you understand clearly the obstacles standing in your way
column27: you can plan to overcome them with an “if it’s this then I do that” plan. For example
column28: my issue is that I prioritise work over writing my novel. So I could resolve to write fiction first thing in the morning
column29: before I check my work email. Or if my goal was to jog in the evenings
column30: but I lacked the motivation at the end of the workday
column31: I could start small by putting on my running shoes before I clocked off – helping me over the first hurdle. Oettingen dubs this approach “Woop” – wish
column32: outcome
column33: obstacle
column34: plan – and says it works for just about any behaviour change
column35: from creating healthy habits to improving relationships and academic performance. (There are free resources at woopmylife.org
column36: and an app.) Once you have nailed down what is holding you back

column38: Oettingen says

column28: 000 words to show for it
column29: Evans points out. “Give yourself a chance at succeeding
column30: ” he says. “One of the biggest problems psychologically with the grand goal is unattainability. It’s incredibly de-energising – people give up. So set the bar low: ‘What if I wrote for a week? I’m not writing a novel
column31: I’m writing a chapter.’ Then do it again. Give yourself a chance at succeeding
column32: ” says Evans. He calls this prototyping: exploring different paths and possibilities through defined experiments. “Before you run a marathon
column33: try a couple of 10ks
column34: ” he suggests. Not just for practice
column35: but because you may find that achievement is enough
column36: or that you don’t enjoy running enough to do a full marathon. The flexibility helps to ground your goal in reality
column37: Evans says – to connect with your actual motivation
column38: and confront the inevitable cost of pursuing it at the expense of other goals. “Many people who have this goal – the book
column39: the marathon
column40: the peak
column41: ‘gotta lose 50lb’ – have almost no idea at all what’s involved.” Some may even be in a “long-term
column42: nostalgic relationship” with their fantasy
column43: says Evans. “But design always starts with reality.”

column1: If you revisit your goal and find it is no longer relevant
column2: you can still honour it as something that was significant to your past self
column3: which has steered you this far and from which you can now move on. People who test their “grand goal” report feeling two things
column4: says Evans: “They feel more hopeful – and they feel it’s doable.” I assure him that I’ll check back in next year. Then
column5: that night
column6: I write a scene: messy
column7: not beautiful
column8: but words on a page.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/05/run-that-marathon-write-that-novel-how-to-make-2022-the-year-you-finally-smash-your-goals;5

column15: 'World news'];"The Mail on Sunday will pay the Duchess of Sussex just £1 in damages for invading her privacy by publishing a private letter she had sent to her father. The nominal sum is set out in court documents that also formally confirm that the newspaper – and its sister website MailOnline – has accepted defeat and will not be taking the long-running case to a supreme court appeal. The outlet will also pay an unspecified sum for the separate case of infringing Meghan’s copyright by publishing large parts of the letter. Mark Stephens
column16: a media lawyer
column17: said the nominal settlement for the privacy aspect suggested a weakness in that aspect of Meghan’s case: “Normally for that kind of invasion of privacy you would expect £75
column19: 000. It does show that the curation of her reputation was an area where she had effectively invaded her own privacy.” The newspaper’s publisher has also agreed to pay a confidential sum in damages for copyright infringement. The Mail on Sunday also faces having to cover a substantial part of Meghan’s legal costs
column20: which could be more than £1m.

column1: The duchess had always said that her three-year legal battle against Associated Newspapers
column2: the publisher of the Mail on Sunday and sister website MailOnline
column3: was more about principles than money. Her spokesperson said the court victories demonstrated the strength of both claims and the financial remedies would be based on Meghan’s right to an account of the newspaper’s profits following her win. The spokesperson described the payment as substantial and said it would be donated to charity. As part of the court settlement
column4: the Mail outlets have also been ordered to avoid disclosing the names of five of Meghan’s friends who anonymously spoke to People magazine for a 2018 article about the royal. The newspaper had previously sought to name the individuals in legal proceedings. The Mail on Sunday and MailOnline were also ordered to carry front page and homepage declarations that they had lost the legal case
column5: with the courts even specifying in which font the statements should appear. The outlets chose to do that on Boxing Day
column6: one of the quietest news days of the year. Associated Newspapers had argued that Meghan’s case should have gone to trial but judges concluded otherwise. A ruling at the start of December said the duchess had a “reasonable expectation” of privacy regarding the contents of the letter to her father
column7: Thomas Markle. “Those contents were personal
column8: private and not matters of legitimate public interest
column9: ” said the appeal judge Sir Geoffrey Vos. Meghan celebrated that victory by calling for a reshaping of the tabloid industry and spoke of how she had been patient in the face of “deception
column10: intimidation
column11: and calculated attacks” and criticised a “tabloid industry that conditions people to be cruel
column12: and profits from the lies and pain that they create”. At the time Associated Newspapers claimed it was willing to take the case to the supreme court but this turned out to be an empty threat. Focus is now likely to turn to the actions of the duchess’s husband
column13: Prince Harry
column14: who is suing both Rupert Murdoch’s News UK and Daily Mirror publisher Reach over phone-hacking claims in a case that could be heard later this year.";https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/jan/05/meghan-one-pound-mail-on-sunday-privacy-invasion;1

column6: 'Gray report'];"The new head of an investigation into alleged rule-breaking Downing Street parties has not “started from scratch” and is unlikely to re-interview all government staff who have already been spoken to about their knowledge of the gatherings
column7: the Guardian has been told. Sources said that Sue Gray
column8: who took over the probe after cabinet secretary Simon Case recused himself when a Christmas event in his own office was revealed
column9: would more likely “pick up” the existing work and look for “holes” in the testimony provided so far. In addition
column10: Gray’s attention will have to turn to more gatherings that came to light since the initial probe led by Case began. Among them was an event revealed by the Guardian attended by prime minister Boris Johnson
column11: his wife and 17 others. Attendees were pictured with cheese and wine in the No 10 garden in spring 2020
column12: when socialising in groups was banned. The prime minister has insisted it was a “work meeting”.

column1: One insider with knowledge of the investigation said they did not expect everyone already interviewed to have to go through the process again. They characterised the inquiry as “same team
column2: different leader”. A second government source said Gray was unlikely to “discount anything the team has gathered before”
column3: but that given the final report will be in her name
column4: she would probably go through existing witness evidence to check for “holes” and seek further clarification from some people. They said Gray was not expected to re-interview everyone for the sake of it
column5: explaining: “She won’t do things by default
column6: she’ll be pragmatic.” The source added that “a different leader can make a team do different things”. It was initially hoped the parties probe would be concluded by Christmas. However
column7: Case’s decision to step back from his role in it delayed the publication of its findings. Given there are more gatherings than the three included in the initial remit of investigators
column8: Gray was said to have “a lot more on her plate than Case started with” so she would not have “started from scratch”. The result of her inquiry is expected to take several more weeks
column9: however it will be made public. No 10 said the investigation was continuing
column10: but stressed it was an “independent piece of work”. Asked if Gray would pick up where Case left off
column11: the prime minister’s spokesperson said on Tuesday: “The work was led … through the propriety and ethics team.... She has picked up that and has been briefed by them.” The Cabinet Office declined to comment
column12: but pointed to the original terms of reference laid down when Case ran the inquiry
column13: which said investigators would “be able to speak to members of staff” and that ministers
column14: special advisers
column15: and civil servants “will be expected to cooperate”. Gray has a fearsome reputation as a “Whitehall enforcer” and her appointment to lead the probe was seen by many as making it less likely ministers would be able to evade scrutiny over the issue of potentially rule-breaking parties. However another Whitehall probe into the funding of refurbishments to Johnson’s Downing Street flat is reportedly set to clear him of breaching the ministerial code
column16: fuelling claims of a “whitewash”. Johnson has denied personally breaking any Covid rules and said the inquiry into the gatherings would be released “as soon as we reasonably can”.";https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/jan/05/new-head-of-no-10-parties-investigation-unlikely-to-start-from-scratch;4

column6: 'Wildlife'];"I’m standing near the cliff edge
column7: on a narrow strip of wild
column8: unmanaged grassland and scrub
column9: with a light
column10: onshore breeze in my face. Beyond the precipice lies the North Sea
column11: calm today. To the south
column12: ships at anchor waiting for a berth
column13: offshore wind turbines and industrial Teesside. To the north
column14: the conurbations of Seaham
column15: Sunderland and South Tyneside. Behind me
column16: agriculture
column17: the coastal railway and a quarry. It’s high tide
column18: bringing from far below the soporific sound of waves slapping against rocks. Fulmars
column19: stiff-winged and silent
column20: glide past the cliff edge
column21: almost level with my head
column22: giving me a sideways glance as they pass
column23: as if to say: “I bet you wish you could do this.” And I do: it looks so effortless
column24: so pleasurable. Turning away with a few shallow wingbeats
column25: around they go again
column26: out to sea
column27: then back towards the cliff face
column28: lowering their feet as air brakes at the last moment as they rise to ride the updraught once more. They pass so close that I can see turbulent airflow ruffling small feathers over the top of their long
column29: slender wings
column30: generating lift.

column1: Around the headland is an impenetrable wall of wind-sculpted blackthorn
column2: which suddenly opens on to another vertiginous
column3: grassy slope
column4: revealing the tiny bay called Hawthorn Hive. The rock face is magnesian limestone; soft
column5: fast-weathering
column6: prone to landslips. Eventually
column7: storms and sea level rise will send this narrow remnant of wilderness crashing down on to the shore. Every winter
column8: waves chew away at the raised beach that protects the cliffs. A flicker of wings catches my eye: two small birds
column9: flitting skywards to catch flies. They are hard to identify with the sun in my eyes and lead me a merry dance as I try to get closer. Following them back along the path
column10: I finally see that they are stonechats. The male’s breast feathers are the colour of a glowing ember. It’s perhaps just as well that knee-high brambles
column11: as daunting as a barbed-wire entanglement
column12: prevent me from getting any closer to their cliff-edge perch. • Country Diary is on Twitter at @gdncountrydiary";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/05/country-diary-fulmars-so-close-you-almost-catch-their-eye;3

column1: 279;279;5523;5523;Scott Morrison’s dereliction of duty over rapid Covid tests is a threat to Australians’ public safety | Kevin Rudd;2022-01-05T05:26:17Z;['Kevin Rudd'];['Scott Morrison'
column2: 'Coronavirus'
column3: 'Australia news'
column4: 'Health'
column5: 'Australian election 2022'];"Scott Morrison’s bloody-minded refusal to fund rapid Covid-19 tests is misguided
column6: expensive and dangerous. It is just one more example of the Liberal leader putting his own crude political interests ahead of public safety. There are no silver bullets to end a pandemic. The public understand that. Vaccines are an important weapon. But only because they let us move from the blunt instrument of citywide lockdowns to a combination of other
column7: more targeted and inter-locking public health measures. This includes an effective regime of testing
column8: tracing
column9: isolation and quarantine. All these elements must work together. Morrison’s dereliction of leadership responsibility for Australia’s testing regime
column10: with queues snaking through city streets and rapid antigen tests being hawked online at extortionate prices
column11: is one more addition to the many errors that have come before it. At every stage of the pandemic
column12: Morrison has had to be dragged into half-hearted action – with catastrophic consequences. Morrison has been obsessed with picking political fights instead of his government’s core responsibilities like quarantine and aged care. Almost 1
column13: 000 Australians have now died in commonwealth-regulated aged care homes that were meant to keep them safe.

column1: In this pivotal stage of the pandemic
column2: it is in everyone’s interest to ensure every Australian
column3: regardless of their income
column4: has access to free at-home rapid antigen test kits. This is because every time a positive case is identified
column5: it provides the chance to staunch a chain of infection and keep bending the curve so that our hospitals aren’t overrun. Morrison’s myriad arguments against free rapid tests range from the hypocritical to the obscene. First
column6: Morrison insists the Treasury cannot afford it. This is patently ridiculous. Let’s not forget how Morrison wasted an eye-watering $40bn in JobKeeper payments to companies that didn’t need it – enough to buy every Australian household a dozen tests every month into 2024! Morrison’s position on rapid tests is ultimately a false economy because mass-testing saves money in the long run. Public hospitals can easily spend more than $100
column7: 000 invasively ventilating an intensive care patient
column8: or the chain of infection can be detected and halted weeks earlier using a cheap rapid test. Second
column9: Morrison points to conventional PCR laboratory tests as fully subsidised alternative. Apart from the mammoth queues to access a PCR test
column10: these tests are much more expensive to taxpayers. For every PCR test conducted by a private laboratory
column11: Medicare is charged $85; by comparison
column12: rapid tests generally cost about $10 (even less when the government is buying millions of units in bulk). Put another way
column13: for every rapid test that displaces a PCR test
column14: taxpayers would save at least $70. Third
column15: Morrison draws a distinction between medicine
column16: which he says should be funded
column17: and tests
column18: which he says shouldn’t. This is hogwash.

column1: Since 1991
column2: successive federal governments have funded free breast and cervical cancer screenings. John Howard expanded on these programs by including at-home bowel cancer tests. The fact that Morrison’s own government is conducting a feasibility study on free lung cancer screenings suggests he has no objection. Australia’s world-leading response to HIV/Aids also hinged on providing vulnerable groups with free testing
column3: treatment
column4: condoms and clean needles. Fourth
column5: the government warns it cannot possibly meet Australians’ insatiable appetite for free tests – a statement that is grounded in a deeply elitist perspective on public health behaviours by lower income Australians. Federal health minister
column6: Greg Hunt
column7: and Morrison talk down to Australians as though they are either hypochondriacs addicted to shoving cotton swabs up their nostrils
column8: or charlatans determined to cheat government programs. They suddenly insist on price signals to ensure people don’t seek help unless they are truly desperate. Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: Morrison might find this hard to imagine
column2: but not every household has an extra $25 saved for a rapid test when they need it. This is a recipe for massive undetected spread among those Australians least able to pay. Finally
column3: Morrison says he won’t “undercut” businesses trying to make a buck out of these tests. This is a total abrogation of responsibility
column4: leaving public health at the mercy of price-gouging companies who – unlike Morrison – listened to experts’ warnings of a looming spike in demand. The fundamental principle of Medicare is that Australians deserve access to healthcare based on their needs
column5: not their ability to fulfil the needs of the market. If Morrison wants to ensure Australians can find rapid tests at their local shops
column6: that’s good; he should involve those businesses in delivering publicly funded testing kits. But since Morrison’s stated motivation is to avoid “undercutting” their profits
column7: it seems he’s forgotten who he works for.

column1: One of the few things that unites most Australians is our revulsion at the hideous inequities of the American health system; Morrison’s apparent fondness for mingling business with healthcare suggests he doesn’t share that view. Why then has Morrison taken this hypocritical and unsustainable position? I suspect three reasons. Morrison may be trying to ease fears ahead of the election. Australians are watching rising case numbers with trepidation and soaring positive test rates – now more than 20% in most states – suggest there are many more cases lurking beneath the surface.
If Morrison cannot reduce the numbers in reality
column2: he can reduce the numbers that are announced in the media each day. As Donald Trump once claimed
column3: “if you don’t test
column4: you won’t have any cases”. Morrison also knows voters have now seen through the myth of Liberals being superior economic managers. Morrison is now the biggest-spending postwar prime minister with record debt and record deficit. National debt is set to reach $1.3tn – more than seven-times the Labor government’s supposed “debt bomb” of $189bn in 2013 – equivalent to 55% of GDP
column5: compared with 12% when we left office. Morrison’s performative austerity on rapid tests is a feeble attempt to regain some fiscal credibility. Finally
column6: Morrison now stakes this public position on a thread-bare ideology of “personal responsibility”. He’s borrowed this from his British counterpart
column7: Boris Johnson
column8: who thought he could politically skate through the latest UK debacle. But it’s also political code language for a Darwinian survival-of-the-fittest contest in which the weak
column9: the poor and the vulnerable are cast aside. Perhaps that’s what Morrison really meant when he said of rapid tests
column10: “someone’s always going to pay for it
column11: and it’s going to be you”. Once we had Medicare. Now we have MorrisonCare. Kevin Rudd is a former prime minister of Australia";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/05/scott-morrisons-dereliction-of-duty-over-rapid-covid-tests-is-a-threat-to-australians-public-safety;7

column1: 280;280;5524;5524;Scientists hope to unravel mystery of Sicily’s child mummies;2022-01-05T05:00:32Z;['Daniel Boffey'];['Italy'
column2: 'Archaeology'

column4: 'Science'
column5: 'World news'];"The 200-year-old secrets of the child mummies of the Capuchin Catacombs of Palermo in northern Sicily are to be revealed by a British-led team of scientists using X-ray technology. Dr Kirsty Squires
column6: of Staffordshire University
column7: will head a first attempt to tell the stories of some of the 163 children whose remains lie within the corridors and crypts of the famous underground tomb. The Catacombs contain 1
column8: 284 mummified and skeletonised bodies
column9: the largest collection of mummies in Europe. While many of the children contained there are now skeletal
column10: others have been described as appearing as if they are sleeping. The two-year investigation will focus on the children who died between 1787 and 1880 and
column11: initially
column12: on 41 bodies residing within a bespoke “child chapel”. None of the children’s identity
column13: cause of death and medical history is known
column14: and descriptive tags attached to them have long eroded away. It is hoped that a better picture about the children’s lives and passing will be revealed by cross-referencing the anatomical findings with archival records
column15: including two books containing names and years of death. “We are going in January to carry out our fieldwork
column16: ” Squires said. “We will take a portable X-ray unit and take hundreds of images of the children from different angles. “We are hoping to better understand their development
column17: health and identity
column18: comparing the biological fundings with the more cultural kind of things: the way the individuals have been mummified and the clothes they are wearing as well.” The catacombs
column19: once solely for the deceased friars of the Capuchin order
column20: have become a popular
column21: if macabre
column22: tourist attraction
column23: with every niche and crevice bearing bodies on open display. The preserved dead were often dressed in their finery and would be visited by their relatives.

column1: The friars first established themselves at the church of Santa Maria della Pace in 1534. They created a mass grave for their dead which opened like a tank under an altar but
column2: when that became full
column3: the deceased were held in a vault
column4: or charnel house
column5: while a new crypt was dug. When it came to relocate the bodies from the overfull vault
column6: 45 of the deceased friars exhumed were found to have been naturally mummified
column7: with their faces recognisable
column8: a development that was taken to be an act of God. Rather than bury the remains
column9: the bodies were displayed as relics
column10: propped in niches along the walls of the first corridor of the new cemetery. In 1787
column11: a letter was published stating that everyone
column12: including children
column13: in the region had the right to be accommodated in the catacombs after death. Almost all the research until today has been on the adult mummies
column14: excepting a headline-grabbing examination of Rosalia Lombardo
column15: who died of pneumonia a week shy of her second birthday on 6 December 1920. Her startlingly complete preservation was investigated a decade ago by Dr Dario Piombino-Mascali
column16: who is working with Squires on the latest project at the catacombs. He said: “Many of the mummies are a result of natural dehydration. Other mummies were chemically treated. Those chemically treated are normally better preserved. “Some of them are superbly preserved. Some really look like sleeping children. They are darkened by the time but some of them have got even fake eyes so they seem to be looking at you. They look like tiny little dolls. “Of course you want to do something to preserve them and to make sure their stories are told and give a sense that they are children. It is very upsetting when you deal with children in anthropology.” Radiographic images – 14 per mummy
column17: from head-to-toe – will be taken and examined by Dr Robert Loynes
column18: a retired orthopaedic surgeon who has previously investigated ancient Egyptian mummies. Piombino-Mascali said it was vital that the work on the fragile corpses was “non invasive”. Images will be drawn by an artist from Los Angeles
column19: Eduardo Hernandez
column20: who will produce illustrations for use in educational leaflets for handing out at the catacombs and elsewhere. The project has received over £70
column21: 000 in funding from the UK’s Arts and Humanities Research Council. The last bodies interned in the catacombs died in the early 20th century.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/sicily-palermo-child-mummies-scientists-hope-unravel-mystery;6

column1: 281;281;5525;5525;‘People said I didn’t have enough talent’: the rise of Italy’s graphic novel gonzo;2022-01-05T05:00:32Z;['Lorenzo Tondo'];['Italy'
column2: 'Animation on TV'
column3: 'Books'
column4: 'Netflix'
column5: 'Europe'
column6: 'Television'
column7: 'Culture'
column8: 'World news'
column9: 'Television & radio'];"Michele Rech is uncomfortable with success. The shy 38-year-old comic book artist
column10: who works from a modest apartment on the outskirts of Rome
column11: does not use the word “fame” but refers instead to his rise to national prominence as a “thing” he struggles to manage. In the art world
column12: he is known as Zerocalcare and is the cartoonist’s equivalent of Hunter S Thompson. Rech’s graphic novels are a form of gonzo journalism – inspired by his own adventures as a protester on the frontlines of police violence in Italy
column13: and in Syria
column14: where he was embedded with Kurdish forces. This year
column15: Netflix released an adaptation of his most well-loved cartoons
column16: in which Rech struggles with grief and job insecurity
column17: all while a giant armadillo represents his imaginary conscience. Last month
column18: the series topped the streaming charts in Italy
column19: ahead of South Korea’s hit show Squid Game. Rech’s career began in 2001 when he chronicled the bloody riots during the Genoa G8 summit in which the Italian police severely beat anti-globalism protesters. He was just 17 at the time and was among the demonstrators.

column1: “That experience was overwhelming
column2: ” says Rech. “I sensed that anyone with a uniform wanted to kill us all. A year later they arrested 25 protesters who were accused of vandalism. The brutality wasn’t enough; they wanted to put behind bars those who took part in the protests. I needed to tell what happened. That’s where it all started.” The aim of Rech’s first short comic book
column3: La Nostra Storia alla Sbarra (Our Story in the Dock)
column4: was to use proceeds from its sales to offset the legal costs of the young Italians arrested during the turmoil in Genoa. He used for the first time his pen name
column5: Zerocalcare
column6: meaning “zero limescale”
column7: inspired by a catchy jingle for a TV commercial for a descaler solution. He chose the name in a rush – it was the first thing that came to mind. “I never thought that being a comic artist could be my main source of income
column8: ” said Rech
column9: who used to work as an after-school tutor. “Also because many people told me I didn’t have enough talent to become a cartoonist.” In 2010
column10: Rech began working on his debut graphic novel
column11: The Armadillo’s Prophecy. In it
column12: Zerocalcare recounts mourning the death of a classmate
column13: interspersed with Italian cultural stereotypes
column14: in the presence of the giant armadillo. It was turned down by dozens of publishers but one startup company
column15: Bao
column16: believed in the concept and in 2012
column17: 500 copies were printed. The book went on to be reprinted 24 times and has sold more than 150
column18: 000 copies. It was Rech’s first step toward renown among Italian cartoonists.

column1: The second was a 3
column2: 600km journey
column3: when in 2014
column4: Islamic State launched an attack in northern Syria. Rech
column5: who was supportive of the Kurdish cause
column6: made several trips to the city of Kobani in northern Syria to recount the resistance of the female fighters against IS. The result of those experiences culminated in his 2015 book
column7: Kobane calling: Greetings from Northern Syria. His success has continued to build and now on Netflix there is his offbeat animated series
column8: Tear Along the Dotted Line
column9: which follows the existential vicissitudes of a socially awkward cartoonist (Rech’s own avatar) with his armadillo-cum-conscience reflecting on his life’s path. “I was obsessed with the idea of creating an animated series
column10: ” says Rech. “First of all
column11: for the music. I had always mentioned my musical suggestions in my comics
column12: but I knew many people would never listen to them. So I wanted people to listen to my things. I sent Netflix hundreds of emails
column13: until they finally caved in. They allowed me free rein to decide the content as I pleased.” The series
column14: in which Rech performs the voiceover for all his characters
column15: except for the armadillo
column16: which is performed by the Italian actor Valerio Mastandrea
column17: has become the most-watched show on Netflix in Italy. The Turkish didn’t like the inclusion in the series of the PKK Kurdish flag
column18: deemed outrageous by Ankara
column19: which considers the organisation a terrorist group. “Those are the flags of the people who liberated northern Syria from IS
column20: ” says Rech
column21: “of those who gave their lives to fight Islamic fundamentalism.”

column1: Today Zerocalcare is one of the most trending hashtags on Italian social media. The crowds that gather at his book signings resemble the queues outside concerts and can last hours. “The last time I signed copies of my comic books it lasted 14 hours
column2: ” he says. “It’s extenuating
column3: but I want my relationship with readers to be as transparent as possible. Some people say I should hire an agent who says ‘no’
column4: and that I should only sign the first 40 copies. I’d feel like I’d be delegating dirty work to someone else. But it would be an injustice and I’d feel guilty.” Rech follows a strict subculture of hardcore punk called “straight edge”
column5: whose adherents refrain from using alcohol
column6: tobacco and drugs
column7: and says it helps him to deal with the recent barrage of success.

column1: He is glad things are going well but adds
column2: “I just have to learn that things aren’t the way they were a month ago. And maybe it’s not easy for someone like me.” For a good understanding of Rech’s personality
column3: there is a scene in the TV series that represents the artist’s philosophy of life. Returning home after a night with his would-be-love
column4: Zerocalcare finds the armadillo
column5: his alter ego
column6: sitting on a chair while sipping a herbal tea. Before Zero closes the door
column7: the armadillo asks him if he has had sex. “No
column8: ” answers the protagonist. The armadillo replies: “You’re a black belt at dodging life.’’";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/05/zerocalcare-michele-rech-people-said-i-didnt-have-enough-talent-the-rise-of-italys-graphic-novel-gonzo;5

column2: 'Belgium'
column3: 'Colonialism'
column4: 'Africa'
column5: 'Europe'
column6: 'World news'];"A popular prime minister of Burundi
column7: Prince Louis Rwagasore
column8: was shot dead just over 60 years ago with the complicity of Belgium
column9: the departing colonial power

column1: 289;289;5534;5534;‘Thematically richer than the Bible’: what I learned at the first annual Boss Baby symposium;2022-01-05T00:45:14Z;['Toby Fehily'];['The Boss Baby'
column2: 'Film'
column3: 'Culture'
column4: 'Animation in film'
column5: 'Philosophy'];"In the middle of a question and answer session at an academic symposium
column6: an audience member wearing a Boss Baby shirt showed off the Boss Baby lunchbox he takes to work every day. “Obviously I eat cookies for lunch
column7: ” he explained
column8: “because that’s what Boss Baby fans do.” There was polite applause.

column1: Boss Baby fans don’t just eat cookies for lunch – they also convene virtual philosophy conferences dedicated to the study of The Boss Baby
column2: the 2017 DreamWorks animated film starring Alec Baldwin. Organised by Jaime McCaffrey of the University of Kentucky and Tore Levander of Fordham University
column3: the first annual Boss Baby symposium
column4: held online on Tuesday
column5: brought together a wide range of thinkers to examine what we can learn from a movie about a baby who is also a boss.

column1: Over the course of an entire afternoon
column2: eight academics delivered presentations centred around three themes: Situating the Boss Baby in Myth and Media; Personal and Professional Growth: Work and Play in The Boss Baby; and “Not enough love for the two of us”: Birth
column3: Motherhood
column4: and the Lack Thereof. They were joined at the end for an informal chat with JP Karliak
column5: voice of Boss Baby in the Netflix television series The Boss Baby: Back in Business
column6: and its showrunner
column7: or “Boss Baby boss baby”
column8: Brandon Sawyer. “Frankly
column9: we don’t know exactly what you’ll find
column10: ” the symposium’s website admitted
column11: “but we know it will leave you thinking
column12: ‘Yep
column13: that was definitely a symposium dedicated to the 2017 film titled The Boss Baby.’” It was. But why The Boss Baby? Depends on who you ask. According to one of the symposium’s presenters
column14: it’s just the continuation of a long historical lineage of boss babies – or παῖς-ἄναξ
column15: “child leaders”
column16: in the ancient Greek – stretching from Astyanax from The Iliad
column17: Hikaru Genji from The Tale of Genji
column18: King Edward V of England and Richard of Shrewsbury
column19: Duke of York.

column1: Regardless of why
column2: there’s definitely a strong appeal at work. The film grossed half a billion dollars at the box office and has since been spun off into a 2021 sequel and four seasons of the Netflix television series. K-pop band BTS member Jimin learned English by watching the movie again and again. And when a Boss Baby balloon floated on to the 2021 Macy’s Parade
column3: a transfixed crowd reverently chanted “Boss Baby” in near-religious supplication. Despite this semi-ironic popularity
column4: The Boss Baby follows a plot that can be difficult to parse
column5: not that that would discourage academics. “It might be thematically richer than the Bible and more confusing than Ulysses
column6: ” McCaffrey said in her opening remarks. In the movie
column7: the suit-and-tie-wearing
column8: briefcase-bearing Boss Baby is sent on a secret mission by Baby Corp
column9: where all babies come from. He’s charged with protecting the world’s love of babies
column10: now under threat due to increasing love for puppies instead. So he sets out to stop the CEO of Puppy Co from releasing the “Forever Puppy”
column11: a new version of puppy that remains a puppy for life
column12: which would destroy babydom as we know it and for some reason is going to be launched into the world via a rocket filled to bursting with puppies.

column1: That’s a rough summary that doesn’t even touch on things like the super secret baby formula that keeps the Boss Baby eternally young while endowing him with adult faculties. It would take a PhD just to understand how that’s supposed to work
column2: let alone to conduct a Freudian and Marxist analysis of the milk
column3: as two academics did for the talk The Land of Milk and Money: Lactic Capital in The Boss Baby.

column1: Perplexing as the plot may be
column2: the first annual Boss Baby symposium urged us to not throw out the Boss Baby with the boss bathwater. By the end of the day
column3: we’d learned about everything from intertextual references in DreamWorks movies and US attitudes towards sexuality to Erik Erikson’s stages of psychosocial development. We even sat down for a serious chat about Boss Baby’s “narcissistic and psychotic orientation”
column4: which
column5: to be fair
column6: doesn’t really seem like a rare phenomenon among upper management. It was during a presentation on the French philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre’s concept of play that it all twigged for me. The speaker had been arguing that an authentic existential attitude is predicated on a synthesis of facticity (boss) and transcendence (baby). I realised that the symposium itself embodied what it means to truly be both boss and baby. The presentations were both tongue-in-cheek larks for a laugh and sincere explorations of the speakers’ areas of expertise. There was genuine affection for the film
column7: as well as a willingness to make fun of it. It was serious (boss)
column8: but it was also silly (baby). I wouldn’t go so far as to say that the answers to all of life’s questions can be found in The Boss Baby
column9: but
column10: like the occasional cookie for lunch
column11: it doesn’t hurt.

column7: 'Airline industry'];"Late Monday
column8: Verizon and AT&T agreed to a two-week delay rolling out their new 5G technology.

column1: The technology was slated to launch on Wednesday
column2: but in response to fears that the 5G service will impair airline safety – and amid threats from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to ground or divert flights at a time when the travel industry is already playing catch-up from recent weather and Covid-related flight disruptions – the telecom companies agreed to a pause. Here’s what you need to know about the controversy: What is 5G? 5G is the newest generation of cellular network
column3: following 4G
column4: which was introduced in late 2009 and is used on most US cellphones today. Nearly every 10 years since 1980
column5: a new generation network has arrived
column6: offering faster speeds and expanded capabilities. At the simplest level
column7: 1G allowed for phone calls
column8: 2G brought messaging
column9: and 3G provided internet access. Today
column10: on 4G
column11: users can download apps
column12: stream video
column13: and more
column14: with relative ease and speed. The fifth generation is expected to offer new levels of speed – making it possible
column15: for example
column16: to download a movie to one’s phone in seconds – and allow more devices to be connected to a network at once. The latter is increasingly important in our crowded cellular landscape. (Ever been in a concert or stadium unable to send messages?) “Those types of data rates could enable virtual reality applications or autonomous driving cars
column17: ” Harish Krishnaswamy
column18: an associate professor of electrical engineering at Columbia University
column19: told Live Science. Why is the US airline industry concerned about 5G? To execute the upgrade
column20: cellular networks plan to move operations on to a new band of radio frequencies called the C-Band. Last year
column21: Verizon and AT&T spent a combined $67bn acquiring the C-Band spectrum licenses needed to upgrade their networks to 5G
column22: according to Forbes. But some aircraft regulators worry that planes’ radio altimeters
column23: which measure how far above ground a plane is to help pilots land their crafts in low-visibility situations and also operate on C-Band frequencies
column24: could be disturbed by 5G. Can 5G and the aviation industry coexist? The Federal Communications Commission (FCC)
column25: the FAA and telecom carriers all agree that 5G and airline travel can exist together. In fact
column26: they already do in nearly 40 countries. The telecom companies have pointed out that there have not been any accidents in other countries where 5G is operational and American airlines regularly fly to those countries. The FAA
column27: too
column28: has said that “5G and aviation have safely coexisted in other countries”. That’s because in those regions
column29: “power levels have been reduced around airports and the industries have worked together prior to deployment”
column30: the agency said in a 3 January statement. So what’s the problem in the US? The discussions over how the transition should take place in the US
column31: however
column32: have been brewing for years and intensified in recent months. Verizon and AT&T had initially planned to launch 5G in December and until last week
column33: appeared unwilling to postpone it further. But amid pushes from both Steve Dickson
column34: the head of the FAA
column35: and the transportation secretary
column36: Pete Buttigieg
column37: to delay the rollout to allow for further coordination
column38: they relented on Monday. Both companies have proposed several measures to mitigate the possible impact of the switch to 5G
column39: including reducing the strength of their 5G around airports and helipads
column40: and operating 5G service at lower power levels nationwide for the first six months. The FAA has thanked the companies for those proposals
column41: but said the pause remained necessary to create “additional time and space to reduce flight disruptions associated with this 5G deployment”. It remains unclear what specific actions will be taken in the two-week period. “At Secretary Buttigieg’s request
column42: we have voluntarily agreed to one additional two-week delay of our deployment of C-Band 5G services
column43: ” an AT&T spokesperson said by email. “We also remain committed to the six-month protection zone mitigations we outlined in our letter. We know aviation safety and 5G can coexist and we are confident further collaboration and technical assessment will allay any issues.” “While the airline industry faces many challenges
column44: 5G is not one of them
column45: ” Hans Vestberg
column46: chairman and CEO of Verizon
column47: said in an email to employees today. “In November
column48: we agreed to pause activation until January to give the FAA more time for their analysis. We also voluntarily offered to implement a number of temporary proactive protective measures
column49: including reducing 5G power levels near airports and directing 5G nodes away from airports … Despite our efforts and the overwhelming scientific data
column50: the FAA still has not resolved all of its questions.”";https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/jan/04/5g-fight-att-verizon-loggerheads-faa;2
