column2: 'Medical research'
column3: 'Science'
column4: 'Health'
column5: 'Society'];Scientists have developed a blood test that could help detect cancer in people with nonspecific symptoms such as unexplained weight loss or fatigue. If validated
column6: the test could enable cancer patients to be identified earlier
column7: when they are more likely to respond to treatment
column8: and help flag up who could benefit from early access to drugs designed to tackle metastatic cancer. The test can also tell if the disease has spread. There is currently no clear route through which someone with nonspecific symptoms that could be cancer is referred for further investigation. NHS rapid diagnostic centres are being set up to support faster and earlier cancer diagnosis
column9: but often patients will be examined by their GP
column10: and if they can’t identify an obvious cause of their symptoms then the patient will simply be told to come back if they get worse. “The problem we’ve had in the past is that if they do have cancer
column11: that cancer is growing all the time
column12: and when they come back the cancers are often quite advanced
column13: ” said Dr James Larkin
column14: of the University of Oxford
column15: who was involved in the research. Although it is difficult to know precisely how many individuals fall into this category
column16: “it is likely to be tens of thousands of patients across the UK
column17: ” Larkin said. “We’re hoping to capture these patients when they come to the GP
column18: to give them an immediate referral option. “The moment you can say ‘you have a cancer’
column19: it provides a strong incentive to send that patient for an imaging investigation to see if you can find that cancer.” The new test utilises a technology called nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy
column20: which profiles levels of small molecules called metabolites in the blood. Healthy individuals have different metabolic “fingerprints” to those with localised or metastatic cancer. In a study published in the journal Clinical Cancer Research
column21: Larkin and colleagues analysed samples from 300 patients with nonspecific but concerning symptoms of cancer
column22: such as fatigue and weight loss
column23: and found that the test correctly detected cancer in 19 out of every 20 of those with the disease. It cannot yet pinpoint the type of tumour they have
column24: but this is the ultimate goal. The test could also distinguish between patients with localised or metastatic cancer with 94% accuracy
column25: making this the first blood test to be able to detect if a person’s cancer has spread without knowing type of tumour they have. “Such information changes how you treat patients
column26: ” Larkin said. For instance
column27: certain immunotherapies have been shown to increase survival rates among people with metastatic cancer
column28: but they are expensive and have side-effects. “We don’t want to prescribe them to everyone
column29: but there are patients out there that would absolutely benefit if you could only identify them early enough. A different type of blood test that aims to detect circulating tumour DNA (ctDNA) is being trialled in the NHS
column30: but metabolic changes may be detectable earlier
column31: while ctDNA technology also requires you to know which mutations to look for when finding a tumour. The next step is to confirm the accuracy of the test in 2
column32: 000 to 3000 British patients with nonspecific symptoms
column33: which Larkin hopes could happen within the next two years. This data would then be submitted to national regulatory agencies responsible for authorising such tests.;https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/jan/05/blood-test-could-help-detect-cancer-in-people-with-nonspecific-symptoms;6

column6: 'World news'];"Emmanuel Macron has prompted a furore after saying that his government’s vaccination strategy is to “piss off” people who have not had coronavirus jabs by continuing to make daily life more and more difficult for them. “I am not about pissing off the French people

column12: introduced this summer

column23: Macron said

column31: you will no longer be able to go to the theatre. You will no longer be able to go to the cinema.” Macron added: “When my freedoms threaten those of others

column1: Macron’s political opponents accused the president – who in the early stages of his term faced accusations of arrogance

column11: adding: “It’s clear the vaccine pass is a collective punishment against individual liberties.” Analysts said that while the language was crude and could prompt an extreme

column13: the president’s remarks appeared to reflect a careful political calculation. Polls show a large majority of French voters are growing increasingly frustrated with the pandemic and back the vaccine pass as an effective means to end it

column5: 'Coronavirus'];"Shelves are empty in supermarkets once again as staff shortages due to illness or isolation combine with ongoing supply chain difficulties. Australia hit the grim milestone of more than 500
column6: 000 Covid cases since the pandemic began on Tuesday. Daily cases in the states and territories continue to rise

A spokesperson said the company had “stringent and optimised Covid-safe plans” including rapid antigen testing in place along with a range of other measures to keep teams separated. column5: 'US news'];"Californians will not be able to water their lawns for 48 hours after rainstorms or let their sprinklers run on to the sidewalk under new
column6: mandatory water saving rules that could result in a fine of up to $500 a day. The restrictions
column7: adopted by state regulators on Tuesday
column8: come as California continues to struggle under drought conditions
column9: despite a recent wave of heavy rain and snow.

column1: The rules could take effect as soon as the end of the month
column2: though regulators stressed they want to encourage voluntary conservation and that it will be up to local authorities to decide on whether to enforce fines. California’s governor
column3: Gavin Newsom
column4: had previously called for residents to voluntarily reduce water use by 15% compared with last year
column5: but the state has continued to fall short. Between July and November
column6: the state’s water usage went down just 6%. Among the water uses that will not be allowed under the new rules: outdoor watering that results in excessive runoff into the street and sidewalks; using water for landscaping and irrigation during the 48 hours after storms that bring at least 0.25in (0.63cm) of rain; washing cars with hoses lacking shut-off nozzles; using potable water to wash driveways
column7: sidewalks
column8: buildings and patios and for street cleaning or to fill decorative fountains or lakes. There are some exceptions. For example
column9: trees in street medians can be watered
column10: while turf cannot. The rules will take effect once an administrative review is completed. The new restrictions come after an extremely wet December that state officials warned may not continue during the winter months. Weather patterns have become more unpredictable due to the climate crisis and state climatologist Michael Anderson said forecasts show January
column11: February and March could be drier than average. The wet December has offered some reprieve in the water crisis: in mid-December
column12: about 80% of California was in extreme or exceptional drought conditions

column9: Boris Johnson has admitted for the first time as he insisted England can “ride out” its biggest ever Covid wave “without shutting down our country once again”. column5: 'World news'];"A C$40bn agreement-in-principle has been reached in Canada to reform the child welfare system for First Nations people and compensate more than 200
column6: 000 individuals and families who suffered because of it. At the heart of the deal is a legacy of discrimination in child welfare systems that saw many children removed from their homes and placed in state care
column7: and others who were denied adequate medical care and social services because of their Indigenous identity.

column1: Half of the C$40bn (US$31bn) is earmarked for reforming a child welfare system deemed discriminatory by the Canadian Human Rights Tribunal (CHRT) and federal court. The other half is reserved for payments to First Nations people harmed by the on-reserve and Yukon child welfare systems between 1 April 1991 and 31 March 2022. First Nations people who experienced delays or denials of medical care and social services between 1991 and 2017 will also receive compensation. “For too long
column2: the Government of Canada did not adequately fund or support the wellness of First Nations families and children
column3: ” said Patty Hajdu
column4: minister of Indigenous services
column5: as details of the deal were released on Tuesday. “No compensation amount can make up for the trauma people have experienced
column6: but these agreements-in-principle acknowledge to survivors and their families the harm and pain caused by the discrimination in funding and services
column7: ” the minister continued. Cindy Woodhouse of the Assembly of First Nations (AFN)
column8: who participated in the negotiations
column9: told reporters that federal policies had led to the overrepresentation of First Nations in every province’s and territory’s child welfare system. “This wasn’t and isn’t about parenting. This is about poverty and First Nations children being removed from their families and communities instead of provided help with food
column10: clothing or shelter
column11: ” Woodhouse said
column12: adding that child welfare agencies wouldn’t receive funding unless a child was removed. Another of the First Nations organizations involved in the negotiations warned against premature celebration. Cindy Blackstock
column13: executive director of the First Nations Child and Family Caring Society of Canada
column14: underlined that this was merely a non-binding agreement. “I see it as words on paper
column15: ” she said on Tuesday. “Nothing changes in the lives of children today.” First Nations children are more than 17 times more likely to be in foster care than the typical Canadian
column16: and after they turn 18
column17: they are often left without support to find safe housing
column18: employment or education opportunities or even the most basic care services
column19: Blackstock said. She said some of the $20bn earmarked for reform will go toward those needs.

column1: The $40bn settlement was reached in the 11th hour of negotiations
column2: on 31 December – the culmination of years of hard-fought litigation
column3: class-action lawsuits and challenges from the federal government
column4: which began with a human rights complaint in 2007. That complaint alleged that federal authorities intentionally underfunded services for First Nations communities and needlessly removed children from their homes. One of its primary arguments was that Canada was not respecting its duty to uphold Jordan’s Principle
column5: which was passed after the 2005 death of five-year-old Jordan River Anderson of the Norway House Cree Nation in Manitoba. Born with medical problems
column6: Anderson spent most of his life in hospital and ultimately died while the provincial and federal governments squabbled over who should pay for his care. Jordan’s Principle dictates that the first government of contact is required to immediately cover the cost of services
column7: and resolve jurisdictional disputes later. In Canada
column8: healthcare is a provincial responsibility for non-Indigenous individuals
column9: but Indigenous people fall under federal jurisdiction. Nine years later
column10: the CHRT found the government acted intentionally. Tuesday’s settlement reflects this judgment
column11: as well as other litigation. The outcomes of discrimination in child welfare have long been seen as an extension of the residential school system
column12: a program that ran from the 1880s until 1996 that saw First Nations
column13: Métis and Inuit children removed from their homes and placed in residential schools where physical
column14: sexual and psychological abuse was often rampant.

column2: the bodies of thousands of children were discovered on the grounds of former residential schools across Canada
column3: as well as in the United States. Blackstock noted that many of the children included in this compensation program were born to parents who attended residential schools or who were separated from their families in the “Sixties Scoop”. “[The federal government] is a repeat offender against First Nations children
column4: ” she said. David Sterns
column5: a lawyer representing one of the classes
column6: pointed out that more First Nations children are in foster care than were living in residential schools at their height. He said some individuals will receive more than $40
column7: 000 each for their suffering. He urged First Nations people who may have been affected to register for class inclusion at SotosClassActions.com.";https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2022/jan/04/canada-first-nations-child-welfare-compensation-deal;1

column8: 'Society'];"Back in October Sajid Javid insisted: “We don’t believe that the pressures currently faced by the NHS are unsustainable.” It was a statement that did not age well. It led to snorts of derision from senior doctors and hospital bosses

column13: “this is ceasing to function as a hospital”. Days earlier a patient had died in the back of an ambulance outside the hospital. Its inability to cope with demand was so worrying
column14: Sinker said
column15: that it might have to send patients to London or Birmingham. “I’m much more anxious and scared now” than when he took over in 2015

column26: than hear such stories of the inability of the nation’s most important service to do its job. At Tuesday’s Covid press conference Boris Johnson declined to define what an “overwhelmed” NHS looked like. He denied suggestions that it was already in that state
column27: though did concede that “there will be a difficult period for our wonderful NHS in the next few weeks because of Omicron”. The reality is that today’s pileup of problems shows that much of the NHS is already overwhelmed. As the NHS Providers boss
column28: Chris Hopson
column29: points out
column30: while the service’s current difficulties are the result of “an exceptional Covid surge”
column31: years of government decision-making have left it in this weakened state. “Recent winters and NHS performance pre-Covid show that
column32: after [a] decade of longest/deepest financial squeeze in NHS history
column33: NHS has serious capacity/demand mismatch and broken workforce model
column34: ” he said. The NHS in England has had close to 100
column35: 000 vacancies for years now
column36: including for about 40
column37: 000 nurses and 10
column38: 000 doctors. The price of persistent understaffing is paid daily by health personnel routinely working extra hours to ensure patients get good care; that goodwill helps keep the NHS from falling over. Patients experience it in the form of delays in getting help or having a diagnostic test. And it is also felt by a service which
column39: in some parts
column40: too often teeters perilously close to falling over
column41: usually under the extra strain winter brings

column43: and certainly as a result of Omicron. Analysis by Stephen Rocks of the Health Foundation thinktank shows that the UK has only 3.93 hospital doctors per 100
column44: 000 people – the lowest in Europe. It also has just 2.42 beds per 1
column45: 000 people

column47: which has only 2.07. And it also ranks low down the international league table for its supply of nurses
column48: CT scanners and MRI scanners. The size of the NHS budget is important. But providing high-quality healthcare involves more than that. It also involves giving the service the staff it needs and taking firm action to reduce illness. Today’s immediate
column49: escalating NHS crisis has long roots
column50: which are also political roots. Years of decisions by David Cameron
column51: Theresa May and Boris Johnson
column52: especially their inaction on staffing
column53: left it enfeebled and woefully underprepared for this level of extreme pressure
column54: which the critical incidents and unavailability of ambulances dramatically illustrate. The service’s many supporters can only hope that it does not break altogether in the coming days. • This article was amended on 10 January 2022. The UK has 2.42 hospital beds per 1

column4: 'Sport'];"The changing of a year is a time to reflect
column5: to both remember moments that have passed and imagine how they might have happened differently. These considerations are likely to be personal: should I really have let my hair grow long? What if I had not forced the hire car into the narrow parking space next to the concrete pillar? They can also be grander too and one thought that has returned frequently over the course of the past week is of the latter type. It runs as follows: did we miss a trick by not letting the European Super League happen? By we I mean the source of the amorphous people power credited with bringing the 12-club breakaway competition to a halt. I also mean specifically the English contingent of that protest because the dynamics at work in Spain and Italy are different. Finally I mean the part of that group described as the ‘legacy fan’

column6: 'UK news'];"Call it a trial run. With parliament still on recess (what better way for MPs to endear themselves to the country than to award themselves an extra day off over the new year break?)
column7: Tuesday was as good a time as any for Keir Starmer to test-drive his latest pitch to voters. If it went well
column8: so much the better: he would be ahead of the game. But if parts fell flat then there would be plenty of time to put them right in more important speeches ahead. Such as ones where more than a handful of people outside Westminster were listening. Yet even though the stakes couldn’t have been much lower
column9: the Labour leader was leaving nothing to chance. The set was the full Liz “Gloriana” Truss
column10: with two large union jacks for a backdrop. If it took draping himself in flags to prove that he – and the Labour party – were patriotic then so be it. Keir didn’t care if he was laying it on a bit thick. He would bathe in red
column11: white and blue if necessary. Whatever it took. Starmer started as he meant to go on by celebrating the country we live in. Remembering how lucky he – and we – are to be British. We have the Queen. The NHS. The rule of law. The Queen. Musicians. Universities. The Queen. The BBC. Fashion. The Queen. But it wasn’t unpatriotic to suggest there might be one or two areas where there was room for improvement. Over the course of the pandemic
column12: the British people and the opposition had done the decent thing by giving the government the benefit of the doubt. But the government had betrayed that trust by thinking the rules didn’t apply to them. Not just the serial liar and party organiser Boris Johnson. The betrayal went far deeper than that
column13: into a Tory party that had been in power too long and took the country for granted. So replacing the prime minister with Truss or Rishi Sunak would make no difference. What was needed was a new Labour government. So far
column14: so good. But then it all got a little vague. After bigging up the achievements of Atlee – he even dared mention nuclear weapons
column15: Wilson and Blair governments – the best that Starmer could offer was a new social contract. If we worked hard and obeyed the rules
column16: Labour would give us security
column17: prosperity and respect. Which was fine
column18: as far as it went. But it didn’t quite feel as substantial as founding the NHS
column19: Nato
column20: the Open University and the national minimum wage. He also promised to make Brexit work. Which could have been a little rash as no one has
column21: as yet
column22: come close to even the vaguest hint of how they intend to do that. Starmer was more assertive when it came to the media Q&A at the end. After grabbing the moral high ground by pointing out the government’s failure to prepare schools for the new term
column23: and that it had only been down to Labour votes that it had been able to implement plan B
column24: Keir took on both Corbyns. First Piers and the anti-vaxxers
column25: then Jeremy. He made no apology for having pretended to sign up to the Corbyn masterplan only to ditch it once he became leader. He was in the business of winning elections rather than being in opposition. The public had had their chance to vote for Jeremy’s manifesto in 2019 and had given Boris an 80-seat majority. Enough was enough. And no
column26: Johnson was most definitely not the sort of prime minister who should be knighted. The speech hadn’t been quite as polished as Starmer might have ideally liked but it had been more than a decent marker towards the next election. And it was certainly enough to spook the Tories into bringing forward the Downing Street press conference by a day. Boris couldn’t take the risk of Starmer grabbing all the headlines on the evening news bulletins. Or for Keir to be seen as the only leader working. You could tell that Johnson didn’t really have anything new to say at the presser because he took an age saying it. That’s one of Boris’s most telling giveaways. His bullshit and waffle meters work perfectly in sync. Just about the only part of his government that does. So what we got was a lot of hesitation
column27: repetition and deviation. We have a prime minister whose only discernible current talent – other than as a party host – is to talk complete bollocks. His main message was that Omicron was very serious but not so serious for him to need to do much about it. Rather
column28: we should accept that his hands are tied by the libertarian maniacs on the right of the party who couldn’t even accept wearing a mask on public transport. So
column29: as the chances of them approving anything more than that was nil
column30: and imposing further restrictions for a second time with Labour votes was politically unacceptable
column31: we were stuck where we were. Sticking to plan B and keeping our fingers tightly crossed.

column1: Chris Whitty and Patrick Vallance alluded to problems with this approach but stopped short of spelling them out. So it was left to the media. Johnson talked of hospitals not getting overwhelmed

column3: er
column4: just get boosted
column5: ” he said. He hasn’t even realised that the vaccination programme has stalled. Here we were. With an incompetent prime minister who was making decisions for entirely the wrong reasons. And we would just have to sit tight and hope it somehow turned out for the best. Starmer must have been watching and thinking maybe he had less work to do on his speech than he had imagined.";https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/jan/04/starmer-flies-the-flags-in-test-drive-of-patriotic-pitch-to-voters;1

column8: 28 December) refers to Sinn Féin as a party “founded in 1905”; this unfortunately omits important context in understanding modern Irish politics. The Anglo-Irish treaty of 1921 was negotiated and supported by the British government and an Irish delegation led by Arthur Griffith
column9: the founder of the original Sinn Féin party of 1905. Following intense debate
column10: the treaty was passed in the Irish parliament (Dáil Éireann) in January 1922 to establish the Irish Free State. In the June 1922 general election
column11: almost 80% of votes cast were for pro-treaty candidates. The successful pro-treaty Sinn Féin party elected WT Cosgrave as president of the Irish Free State and the party changed its name to Cumann na nGaedheal (Association of the Irish)
column12: the precursor to today’s Fine Gael (Family of the Irish). Most of anti-treaty Sinn Féin were led by Éamon de Valera to become today’s Fianna Fáil. The small remaining rump of Sinn Féin maintained a policy of abstentionism to the Irish parliament
column13: leading to a split in 1970 – those wishing to take their seats became Official Sinn Féin
column14: and then the Workers’ party. Those wishing to maintain abstentionism called themselves Provisional Sinn Féin
column15: which included a young Gerry Adams. By 1986
column16: the Adams wing ended its policy of abstentionism and adopted a shorter name that no other party was using: Sinn Féin. Councillor David McManus Fine Gael

column2: but you can be the first to know about the next one - and other workshops like this - by signing up to our newsletter here. Strong dialogue is something we might be able to participate in in real life
column3: but capturing it on the page requires significant thought and skill. It’s a notoriously difficult aspect of the writing craft and something agents and editors look out for when assessing the quality of a manuscript. So how can you capture conversations between your characters that are not only compelling
column4: but drive your story forward? Emma Claire Sweeney
column5: award-winning novelist and director of the Ruppin Agency Writers’ Studio
column6: will lead a new masterclass that will unlock the secrets of impactful dialogue. With her
column7: you will work through a series of useful techniques that have the power to transform your dialogue in an instant. By examining virtuoso conversations

column4: 'US news'];"Lawyers for Prince Andrew and Virginia Giuffre
column5: who has long accused the royal of sexual abuse

column7: in his attempt to dismiss her civil lawsuit.

column1: The arguments via videoconference came a day after the unsealing of a 2009 settlement between Giuffre and the late financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The judge
column2: Lewis Kaplan
column3: questioned lawyers for Andrew closely over their claim that the settlement means Giuffre’s lawsuit should be dismissed. He also promised “a decision pretty soon”. Giuffre
column4: who accused Epstein and his ex-girlfriend Ghislaine Maxwell of sexual abuse and forcing her into sex with Prince Andrew at age 17 – an accusation he vehemently denies – received $500
column5: 000 in her settlement with the late financier. Using Giuffre’s maiden name
column6: the settlement contains a provision releasing “second parties and any other person or entity who could have been included as a potential defendant … from all
column7: and all manner of
column8: action and actions of Virginia Roberts
column9: including state or federal
column10: cause and causes of action”. Andrew
column11: who is not mentioned in the settlement
column12: has contended that this clause bars Giuffre from suing him. On Tuesday morning
column13: reporters missed up to 15 minutes of arguments. A teleconference number only provided audio at 10.15am
column14: after proceedings began. The judge
column15: Lewis Kaplan
column16: asked Andrew’s lawyer
column17: Andrew Brad Brettler: “What is a ‘potential defendant’?” Brettler said: “A potential defendant is someone who could have been named in this lawsuit but was not. Prince Andrew could have been sued in the 2009 Florida action. He was not. Therefore
column18: he was a potential defendant and releasee.” Later
column19: Brettler said: “I don’t even understand how there could be any question as to whether ‘other potential defendants’ had a meaning. Clearly
column20: Ms Giuffre intended to release a broad category of individuals including royalty
column21: including businessmen.” Brettler also said Epstein “would never want to have to be dragged into a lawsuit were she to sue Prince Andrew later”. Kaplan responded: “We don’t have Mr Epstein here to say that’s in fact what his view was.” The judge also said Epstein might have wanted to grant the broadest release possible
column22: or might have intended to provide the narrowest release possible. He also questioned how enforceability could apply to other parties if they didn’t know about the agreement
column23: which included a confidentiality provision. “Arguably
column24: ” he said
column25: “it would be that Epstein and Giuffre had an agreement between themselves that there was a release to other potential defendants
column26: whatever that means
column27: but they weren’t to know about it”. Apparently speaking rhetorically
column28: the judge added: “The only people who could enforce it were Epstein and Giuffre.” Epstein
column29: who also counted former presidents Bill Clinton and Donald Trump among influential associates
column30: killed himself in custody in New York in 2019. Maxwell
column32: was convicted on sex trafficking charges last month. Her lawyers have said they will appeal. Andrew has been dogged by his links to Epstein and Maxwell and by the Giuffre suit. On Tuesday
column33: Brettler reiterated what was said in a 29 October court filing. “Giuffre settled her sex-trafficking and sexual-abuse claims against Epstein in 2009
column34: ” the filing said. In doing so
column35: she provided Epstein with a general release of all claims against him and numerous other individuals and entities. “To avoid being dragged into future legal disputes
column36: Epstein negotiated for this broad release
column37: insisting that it cover any and all persons who Giuffre identified as potential targets of future lawsuits
column38: regardless of the merit – or lack thereof – to any such claims.” That filing also said: “Because Prince Andrew is a senior member of the British royal family
column39: he falls into one of the expressly identified categories of persons
column40: ie
column41: royalty
column42: released from liability under the release agreement
column43: along with politicians
column44: academicians
column45: businessmen and others allegedly associated with Epstein. “As a third-party beneficiary of the release agreement
column46: Prince Andrew is entitled to enforce the general release contained therein.” David Boies
column47: appearing for Giuffre
column48: argued that the parties on the agreement could handle their agreement as they jointly wished
column49: “at least so long as the third party has not reasonably relied to their detriment on what they have promised”. Boies also said there was no “reasonable” evidence Andrew knew about the agreement before being sued by Giuffre. As part of the litigation
column50: Giuffre’s lawyers have requested documents including proof of Andrew’s now famous claim that he cannot sweat. Giuffre has alleged that the prince was “sweating profusely all over me” at a London nightclub on an evening when

column1: Andrew told the BBC that could not be true

column8: 'US news'];"The only politician ever to beat Barack Obama will retire from the US Congress at the end of the year.

column1: Bobby Rush
column2: a Democratic representative from Illinois
column3: faced Obama in a House primary in 2000 – and beat him by more than 30 points. Obama went on to win a US Senate seat in 2004 and become America’s first Black president five years later. Rush said Obama
column4: then 38
column5: “was blinded by his ambition” and moved too soon
column6: against the wrong target. Obama said he had his “rear end handed to me”. Rush
column7: 75 and first elected to Congress in 1992
column8: is a minister and social activist who co-founded the Illinois Black Panther party and was described by Politico on Monday as “a legend in Chicago politics”. In a video
column9: he said: “I have been reassigned. Actually
column10: I’m not retiring
column11: I’m returning home. I’m returning to my church. I’m returning to my family. I have grandchildren. I’m returning to my passion. “I will be in public life. I will be working hand in hand with someone who will replace me.” Rush’s district is solidly Democratic but political rune-readers still found worrying signs for the national party. Rush is the 24th Democrat to announce that they will not run in 2022. Only 11 Republicans have said the same. Two of those
column12: Adam Kinzinger of Illinois and Anthony Gonzalez of Ohio
column13: voted to impeach Donald Trump over the Capitol riot and subsequently concluded they had no place in a party he dominates. Republicans are favored to take back the House in November – despite their supporters having physically attacked it
column14: in an attempt to overturn the presidential election
column15: on 6 January last year. Rush made headlines during his time in Congress. In 2012
column16: after the shooting death in Florida of the Black teenager Trayvon Martin
column17: he showed solidarity by wearing a hooded sweatshirt on the House floor. “Racial profiling has to stop
column18: ” he said. “Just because someone wears a hoodie does not make them a hoodlum.” It earned Rush a reprimand for violating rules regarding wearing hats in the chamber. Martin’s father
column19: Tracy Martin
column20: praised Rush and told the Washington Post: “This is something that needs to be talked about … This is a country of freedom of speech.”

column1: Rush could raise eyebrows with sharp comments
column2: as when he dismissed an anti-violence plan by an Illinois Republican senator
column3: Mark Kirk
column4: as a simplistic “white boy” solution to a complex problem.

column1: He also pushed legislation designating lynching as a hate crime
column2: named for Emmett Till
column3: a Black Chicago teen whose killing in 1955 fueled the civil rights movement. Born in Georgia
column4: Rush served in the US army and became involved in civil rights campaigning. In 1969
column5: he was arrested and convicted on a weapons charge. In his video on Tuesday
column6: he said: “My faith tells me that there’s a reason I’m still here. By all rights
column7: I should have been murdered on 5 December 1969
column8: the day after the police assassinated [the Black Panthers leader] Fred Hampton. “They came for me the next day
column9: shot down my door
column10: but by the grace of God my family and I were not home.” Elected as a Chicago alderman
column11: he made an unsuccessful bid for mayor before entering Congress. Just before the 2000 primary against Obama
column12: one of Rush’s sons was shot dead. Rush subsequently focused on gun control. He is also a cancer survivor. “I am not leaving the battlefield
column13: ” he said. “I am going to be an activist as long as I’m here in the land of the living
column14: and I will be making my voice heard in the public realm – from the pulpit
column15: in the community
column16: and in the halls of power.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/04/bobby-rush-retire-congress;1

column7: 'Women'];"Voyeurs who record images of breastfeeding women without permission and domestic abusers who escape jail because of time limits on prosecutions are being targeted by proposals put before parliament on Tuesday. A new offence of breastfeeding voyeurism
column8: with a maximum sentence of two years
column9: has been included by the Ministry of Justice in an amendment to the police
column10: crime
column11: sentencing and courts bill. It follows a campaign led by Stella Creasy
column12: the Labour MP for Walthamstow
column13: who was photographed while feeding her four-month-old baby daughter on a train in north London. She has been working with Jeff Smith
column14: the Labour MP for Manchester Withington
column15: on a campaign under the slogan Stop the Breast Pest. Creasy told the Guardian last year she was breastfeeding on a train when she noticed a teenage boy laughing and taking pictures. “He had his phone out and I thought he was playing with his phone
column16: and then I realised with horror that he was taking photos
column17: ” she said. “You feel exposed. I don’t think he can have got very much of a picture
column18: but the sheer horror at the point when you’re focused on trying to support your newborn baby … and somebody is doing that
column19: it was vile. Because I felt quite vulnerable
column20: I just got off my train as soon as I could.” The new offence of breastfeeding voyeurism
column21: which would apply in England and Wales
column22: is one of two new amendments to the police
column23: crime
column24: sentencing and courts bill. There will be a two-year maximum sentence for those caught and prosecuted. Under a separate amendment
column25: victims of domestic abuse will be allowed more time to report incidents of common assault or battery against them. Currently
column26: prosecutions must commence within six months of the offence.

column1: Instead
column2: this requirement will be moved to six months from the date the incident is formally reported to police – with an overall time limit of two years from the date of the offence to bring a prosecution. The government’s decision follows similar proposals put forward by Yvette Cooper
column3: Labour’s shadow home secretary
column4: who tabled an amendment to the bill in the Commons last year. It followed the release of figures which showed that over 13
column5: 000 domestic abuse cases have been dropped by police over the last five years due to the time-limit. Welcoming the government’s amendments
column6: Cooper said it is one of many measures Labour is pushing for to tackle violence against women and girls. Domestic abuse is often reported late relative to other crimes. The change is supposed to ensure that alleged victims have enough time to seek justice and that perpetrators answer for their actions. Dominic Raab
column7: the lord chancellor and justice secretary
column8: said: “We’re giving the victims of domestic abuse longer to report the offence to the police – so abusers don’t evade justice. “And we will introduce a new offence to stop people filming or taking photos of mothers breastfeeding without their consent – because no new mum should be harassed in this way.” The Voyeurism Act made it illegal to take a photograph under a person’s clothing without their consent but it does not specifically cover women who have to remove clothes to feed an infant. Nicole Jacobs
column9: the domestic abuse commissioner
column10: said: “It is important that all domestic abuse victims have the time and opportunity to report to the police. This is especially important following Covid restrictions
column11: when many victims faced additional challenges to seeking help and reporting domestic abuse.” Reacting to the decision
column12: Creasy said: “That breast pests can now be stopped is testament to the hard work of campaigner Julia Cooper
column13: Jeff Smith
column14: Lady Helene Hayman and Lord Pannick. We all worked across both the Lords and Commons to make the government listen to our call for change.”";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/04/breastfeeding-voyeurs-new-offence;7

column8: 'World news'];"The American social entrepreneur Phil Harvey
column9: who has died aged 83
column10: made contraception affordable for hundreds of millions of people in the developing world with subsidies provided by the profits from Adam & Eve
column11: the sex shop company he founded in 1970. A committed libertarian
column12: Harvey also used his considerable resources to champion the right to sexual healthcare and free speech in the US. While working in the Punjab in India in the 1960s for the charity Care International
column13: Harvey became deeply uncomfortable about the way western countries distributed aid. A woman in a threadbare sari knelt before him in gratitude for the food he was doling out
column14: and he became determined to find a way to give aid that did not humiliate recipients. He also began to think that the most urgent need for people in developing countries was better access to family planning
column15: and that the distribution of contraception was inherently a marketing rather than a medical issue. He theorised that the most effective way to distribute condoms might be to use social marketing techniques. This meant bypassing doctors and clinics and subsidising their sale in ordinary shops or market stalls
column16: promoted through local advertising campaigns. Returning to the US in 1969
column17: Harvey studied public health at the University of North Carolina
column18: where he met a British doctor
column19: Tim Black
column20: who shared his zeal for family planning. Keen to test out Harvey’s social marketing ideas
column21: they decided to see if they could persuade people in the US to buy condoms through the post
column22: and ran eye-catching ads in 300 college magazines with slogans such as “What will you get her this Christmas – pregnant?” It was a risky business as it was illegal at the time to send contraceptives (deemed an “obscene product”) through the US postal system. However
column23: an avalanche of orders arrived and no prosecutions ensued. Emboldened
column24: in 1971 Harvey founded Adam & Eve
column25: the first mail-order contraceptive business in the US
column26: which he soon expanded to include the sale of erotica and sex aids and which now has a chain of retail stores. Business boomed
column27: and using the proceeds from Adam & Eve
column28: Harvey and Black founded Population Services International (PSI) a non-profit organisation that started a social marketing programme to sell condoms in Kenya. Adam & Eve customers had no idea they were subsidising cheap contraception abroad
column29: and Harvey saw no reason to advertise the connection
column30: arguing that altruism exists in a different part of the brain from wanting to have a good time on a Saturday night. When it came to starting up foreign programmes
column31: he was also a hands-off manager
column32: believing in hiring the best people locally
column33: setting out his vision
column34: and then allowing them to use their initiative to achieve the desired result. Harvey stepped down as leader of PSI in 1977
column35: believing it was wrong for the founder to stay at the helm indefinitely. By that time he was in any case involved with a second organisation: Marie Stopes
column36: now MSI Reproductive Choices. The London family planning clinic had run into financial difficulties and in 1976 Harvey and Black rescued it
column37: buying up its original clinic in Whitfield Street. Harvey became a long-term board member
column38: helping it to grow from providing 150
column39: 000 women annually with contraception and safe abortions in the 70s to more than 12 million a year today. Finally
column40: in 1989 Harvey founded DKT International
column41: named in honour of his friend Dharmendra Kumar Tyagi
column42: an official in charge of India’s family planning programme. It operates in a similar way to PSI
column43: has subsidised the sale of more than one billion cheap contraceptives in 90 countries
column44: and is active in sex education and HIV prevention. Harvey was born in Evanston
column45: Illinois
column46: to William
column47: a farm tool supplier
column48: and his wife
column49: Lucy (nee Smith). The youngest of five siblings
column50: taciturn
column51: private and a deep thinker
column52: he went to Harvard University in 1957 to study Slavic languages and literature. In 1963 he joined Care International to work in India
column53: spending several years with the organisation before returning to the US and branching out with Black. As head of Adam & Eve and a committed libertarian
column54: Harvey soon became embroiled in legal battles to defend people’s access to sexual healthcare. In 1977 he challenged a law in New York state that prohibited the advertising and display of contraceptives. The case went to the supreme court and he won
column55: arguing that advertising was protected by the first amendment and the right to free speech. In 1986 Adam & Eve’s offices were raided by the police and Harvey was charged with disseminating obscenity. Ronald Reagan’s administration hoped to close down the adult entertainment industry and filed lawsuits against the company in many different states
column56: trusting that the financial burden would make it buckle. But Harvey fought back
column57: winning a lawsuit against the justice department in 1990 on the grounds that it had abused its power. In 1987 he had also successfully challenged Reagan’s Mexico City policy
column58: known as the “global gag”
column59: which aimed to prevent any organisation that received a grant from the US Agency for International Development from performing
column60: referring to
column61: or even speaking about
column62: safe abortion care. To the end of his life Harvey supported organisations that fought to oppose government control of people’s private lives. He also founded the DKT Liberty Project
column63: which campaigns on issues such as stopping the government from confiscating people’s assets
column65: and safeguarding the right to free speech. He wrote about his work and philosophy in books that included Let Every Child Be Wanted (1999) and The Government vs Erotica (2001). He was also a novelist
column68: the psychological thriller Show Time (2012). In 1990 Harvey married the artist Harriet Lesser. She survives him
column69: as do her two children from a previous relationship
column70: and three grandchildren. • Philip Dow Harvey

column7: 'Culture'];"Emma Watson has been accused of antisemitism by Israel’s former ambassador to the United Nations after she posted a message of support for the Palestinian cause. Watson
column8: best known for playing Hermione Granger in the Harry Potter films
column9: posted an image on Instagram showing a photograph of a pro-Palestinian protest with the banner “Solidarity is a Verb” written across it. It was accompanied with a quote about the meaning of solidarity from the intersectional feminist scholar Sara Ahmed. While the post elicited widespread support from Palestinian activists
column10: it drew strong criticism from Israeli officials. The most combative was Danny Danon
column11: who formerly held the posts of science minister in Benjamin Netanyahu’s government and Israeli ambassador to the United Nations. Sharing Watson’s post on Twitter
column12: Dannon said: “10 points from Gryffindor for being an antisemite.” Israel’s current ambassador to the UN
column13: Gilad Erdan
column14: was also critical. “Fiction may work in Harry Potter but it does not work in reality
column15: ” Erdan wrote. “If it did
column16: the magic used in the wizarding world could eliminate the evils of Hamas (which oppresses women and seeks the annihilation of Israel) and the PA (which supports terror). I would be in favor of that!” PA refers to the Palestinian Authority. Danon’s comments were met with a backlash
column17: including from Leah Greenberg
column18: a co-executive director of Indivisible Project
column19: a non-profit organisation founded in 2016 in response to the election of Donald Trump. “A perfect demonstration of the utterly cynical and bad-faith weaponization of antisemitism to shut down basic expressions of solidarity with the Palestinian people
column20: ” she wrote. The Tory peer Sayeeda Warsi called Danon’s comments “appalling”. “These constant attempts to stifle any and all support for Palestinians must be called out
column21: ” she said.

column1: Watson
column3: is an outspoken feminist who has used her platform to support a number of high-profile causes
column4: earning her a spot on Time magazine’s list of the 100 most influential people in the world in 2015. In 2014 she was appointed as a UN women’s goodwill ambassador and delivered an address at the UN headquarters in New York to launch HeForShe
column5: a campaign that urges men to advocate women’s equality. A year later Malala Yousafzai told Watson she had decided to call herself a feminist after hearing her speech. Watson was appointed to a G7 advisory body for women’s rights in 2019
column6: consulting with leaders on foreign policy.

column1: During Cop26 in Glasgow last year
column2: Watson gave climate activists access to her Instagram account. Her bio still says the account “has been taken over by an anonymous Feminist Collective”. The image posted by Watson’s account was originally created by the Bad Activist Collective during clashes last year in which Israeli jets bombed Gaza in response to rocket attacks. At the time other celebrities including Bella Hadid
column3: Dua Lipa and Susan Sarandon expressed their solidarity with the Palestinian cause. Ahmed’s full quote
column4: cited in part by Watson
column5: said: “Solidarity does not assume that our struggles are the same struggles
column6: or that our pain is the same pain
column7: or that our hope is for the same future. Solidarity involves commitment
column8: and work
column9: as well as the recognition that even if we do not have the same feelings
column10: or the same lives
column11: or the same bodies
column12: we do live on common ground.” Watson’s post has been liked by more than a million users and attracted more than 100
column13: 000 comments – many of which include either Palestinian or Israeli flags.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/04/emma-watson-pro-palestinian-post-sparks-antisemitism-row;2

column5: 'Science'];"Reinfections should be included in Covid figures for the UK as soon as possible

column8: daily Covid case figures – which reflect the number of infections picked up by testing – do not include reinfections for all countries of the UK. While figures for Wales do include multiple cases for the same person
column9: provided the positive tests are more than 42 days apart
column10: this is not the case for England
column11: Scotland or Northern Ireland. However scientists have said that with the proportion of cases that are reinfections growing
column12: such figures should be urgently updated. “The reinfection rate was fairly low with Delta
column13: but is higher now
column14: both because prior infection provides little protection against Omicron
column15: and there is a bigger pool of people with prior infection
column16: ” said Prof Sir David Spiegelhalter
column17: a statistician at the University of Cambridge. According to a report released by researchers at Imperial College London last month
column18: the risk of reinfection with Omicron is more than five times higher than with Delta. Speaking on the Today programme on Tuesday
column19: leading epidemiologist Prof Neil Ferguson of Imperial College said between 10% and 15% of Omicron cases are reinfections. The figure chimes with data released by the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA)
column20: which found that of 116
column21: 683 people identified as having an Omicron infection in England between 1 November and 18 December last year
column23: 103 – or 9.5% – had previously tested positive for Covid more than 90 days ago
column24: and hence would be identified as being reinfected. The Guardian understands that reinfections were not included in the case figures published on the government’s dashboard at the start of the pandemic as it was uncertain at the time whether it was possible to be reinfected and
column25: if it was
column26: the interval between infections.

column1: Tim Colbourn
column2: professor of global health systems
column3: epidemiology and evaluation at University College London (UCL)
column4: said the case data should now be updated. “I think reinfections should be added to the dashboard as soon as possible as they will be a growing proportion of cases going forwards
column5: ” he said. “10-15% now sounds plausible and I’m sure the [proportion] will increase over the coming weeks as immunity from prior infection and vaccination wanes.” Prof Christina Pagel
column6: director of UCL’s Clinical Operational Research Unit
column7: agreed that the proportion of all Covid cases that are reinfections will continue to grow
column8: although the rate of rise is going to be modest now that Omicron is the dominant variant in the UK and the lower reinfection rates with Delta are no longer part of the overall case picture. Pagel added that in order to understand how quickly an immune-evasive variant is spreading
column9: it is important to include reinfections. “As more and more people get infected
column10: given current policies
column11: over the longer term it’s going to be rare to find someone who’s never had Covid
column12: ” she said
column13: although she added many people who have had an infection will never have had a test. The Guardian understands the UKHSA is planning to include reinfections in case data from the end of the month

column1: 352;352;5599;5599;Jury in Colston statue trial urged to ‘be on the right side of history’;2022-01-04T17:12:19Z;['Damien Gayle'];['Bristol'];"A jury has been urged to “be on the right side of history” by acquitting four defendants accused of criminal damage over the toppling of the statue of the slave trader Edward Colston. column9: Milo Ponsford

It condoned the shrugging acceptance of racism. It celebrated the achievements of a racist mass murderer. The continued existence of that statue was a racist hate crime.”

column3: 'Modern slavery'];Only 7% of confirmed victims of trafficking from overseas have been granted leave to remain in the last five years according to new data disclosed to the Guardian. A Home Office data shows that 447 out of 6
column4: 066 confirmed trafficking victims who requested leave to remain between April 2016 and June 2021 were granted it – 7%. Meanwhile
column6: 695 confirmed trafficking victims had their applications for leave to remain in the UK rejected
column7: according to the response to a freedom of information response request by the Scottish Refugee Council (SRC). In the remainder of cases a decision is still pending. The government has repeatedly pledged to protect trafficking victims. But charities have documented that some of those removed from the UK and returned to their home countries have fallen back into the hands of their traffickers or have been vulnerable to being picked up by new traffickers. A landmark high court judgment in October 2021 said that all confirmed trafficking victims should be granted leave to remain in the UK. Ahmed Aydeed of Duncan Lewis Solicitors
column8: the lawyer who brought the high court case
column9: expressed concern about the new trafficking data. “Victims of trafficking
column10: experience a profound loss of their sense of safety and security. A reliably safe environment is a pre-requisite for recovery. By refusing
column11: en masse it seems
column12: leave to remain to victims
column13: the home secretary is re-traumatising survivors and putting them at risk of being re-trafficked.” The SRC has also obtained freedom of information data which reveals that the delay in processing asylum claims has reached the highest figure for two decades with 83
column14: 733 people waiting for an initial decision on an asylum claim with 56
column15: 520 of them – including 3
column16: 796 Afghans – waiting for more than six months for an initial decision. The SRC says the newly released data is evidence of a system that is failing asylum seekers and victims of trafficking. They have shared the data ahead of the second reading of the nationality and borders bill in the House of Lords on Wednesday. SRC campaigners have urged the Lords to vote down the controversial bill which proposes “offshoring” asylum seekers to third countries while their claims are processed and imposing criminal penalties on asylum seekers who travel across the Channel in small boats to claim asylum in the UK. The new bill also proposes narrowing the grounds for discretionary leave to remain for trafficking survivors which has led to fears among anti-trafficking campaigners that very few modern slavery survivors will be allowed to remain in the UK. Graham O’Neil of the SRC said: “There is a real crisis in the chronically slow asylum decision system that awaits them. It entraps women
column17: men and children into state-enforced poverty limbo for years. This is even when they are from high refugee recognition countries like Afghanistan
column18: Syria and Iran. We urge the Lords to dismantle the bill
column19: and for the government to scrap it
column20: and invest in swifter better asylum decisions.” A Home Office spokesperson said: “A significant proportion of asylum claims in the last year should have been made in a first safe country
column21: rather than people risking their lives making dangerous crossings
column22: facilitated by people smugglers. “This
column23: as well as an overall increase in claims
column24: has led to asylum applications taking longer to be resolved and impaired our ability to focus resources on those who come to the UK via safe and legal routes and are in genuine need of our protection. “The government is committed to tackling modern slavery and providing support and protection to the victims of this heinous crime. The nationality and borders bill will go further than ever before in putting modern slavery victims’ rights into law
column25: including granting temporary leave to remain for victims.”;https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/jan/04/trafficking-victims-leave-to-remain-uk-data;2

column10: 'Scotland'];"One of the biggest television wishes I harbour for this year is the end of true-crime documentaries. Ever since Netflix’s Making a Murderer hit big in 2015
column11: the genre has found itself crashing from new low to new low. The majority of true crime shows since then have been grubby and exploitative – so quick to rush towards sensationalist thrills that they teeter on the brink of idolising criminals at the expense of victims. If I never watched another true-crime documentary
column12: I’d be the world’s happiest boy. So it’s irritating to discover that the first big true-crime documentary of the year is one of the best I’ve seen. The Hunt for Bible John (BBC Two) is technically not new – it aired on BBC Scotland late last year – but its BBC Two debut this week should bring it wider attention. If it does
column13: it will be absolutely warranted. The Hunt for Bible John tells the story of Scotland’s most notorious series of murders. In 1968 and 69
column14: three young women were killed. All three had been dancing at Glasgow’s Barrowland Ballroom
column15: and all three were found beaten and strangled. The nickname came from witness reports of the killer quoting from the Bible. The murderer has never been caught. In other hands
column16: this could easily have become just another true-crime documentary
column17: trading on nothing but cheap gratification and bloodlust. What’s so impressive here is how keenly the series wants to fit the murders into a wider societal context. A long introductory tract is dedicated to the state of Glasgow in the 60s. Grim and dark and still bomb-damaged from the war
column18: it is a city in total collapse. Running water is scarce
column19: open drains burble human effluent in the streets. The one escape
column20: we are told
column21: is dancing. This took place in venues such as Barrowland: dark
column22: heady clubs where young men and women could meet and forget the outside world.

column1: The clubs were a hive of anonymity – married men apparently made a point of visiting
column2: twisting off their wedding rings in the toilets then hitting on girls under assumed identities – which provided perfect cover for Bible John – a tall
column3: well-spoken man who reportedly liked to recite Old Testament verse. Reportedly is the key word. The secret of The Hunt for Bible John is that it isn’t really about Bible John – we’re shown a handful of suspects
column4: but they’re quickly tossed aside – but about how utterly out of their depths the detectives were. The purported iniquity of the dance clubs meant that witnesses were loth to reveal themselves. The media coverage of the murders quickly whipped up a fearful hysteria that spread across the city. To this day
column5: nobody can be completely sure if all three murders were committed by the same man. The best parts of The Hunt for Bible John show the police’s desperate attempts to try anything that could bring the murderer to justice. For the first time in Scottish history
column6: newspapers ran an artist’s impression of Bible John. He was the subject of one of Britain’s first photofits. Places of worship were scoured
column7: since you can’t get a nickname like Bible John without regularly attending church. They created a psychological portrait of the man. They flew in a clairvoyant from Belgium. Anything that could possibly stick was tried
column8: and all to no avail. Fans of David Fincher might know where this is going. One key touchpoint here is Zodiac – a film about another real-life serial killer who was never caught – with the show even going as far as to use songs from its soundtrack. Another is Mindhunter
column9: Fincher’s series about the birth of the FBI’s Behavioural Science Unit. Mindhunter depicted a crucial turning point in the understanding and capture of serial killers as we know them; their compulsions
column10: their motivations
column11: their patterns. If Glasgow detectives had had the benefit of this expertise
column12: Bible John might not have managed to evade justice so effectively. But his murders took place just before this development
column13: in a city that had been all but written off. The police never stood a chance. With everything we have now – improved knowledge of serial killers and advances in forensic technology – surely many
column14: if not all
column15: of these murders could have been prevented. This is the real message of The Hunt for Bible John
column16: and it’s chilling. Less than a week in and we already have the best true-crime documentary of the year. Now
column17: please: nobody make me watch any more of them. The Hunt for Bible John is on BBC Two on Tuesday 4 January at 9pm and is available via BBC iPlayer.";https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/jan/04/the-hunt-for-bible-john-is-this-the-best-true-crime-documentary-ever-made;2

column4: 'Asthma'];"Around one in 10 Australians – 2.7 million people – suffer from asthma
column5: a chronic condition involving inflammation and narrowing of the airways. This can cause breathing difficulties
column6: wheezing
column7: chest tightness and coughing. Understandably
column8: fear of triggering symptoms often leads to exercise avoidance. Some people avoid it due to a high symptom burden; others have exercise-induced asthma. Even people not in these categories live in fear of exacerbating symptoms
column9: says Dr Sarah Valkenborghs from the University of Newcastle.

column1: But this can be a catch-22. “With avoidance of sport and exercise comes de-conditioning
column2: ” says exercise physiologist Bridget Nash from Body Smart Health
column3: adding that physical inactivity can also worsen symptoms. “For anyone with asthma
column4: it is highly recommended to continue regular exercise to avoid this deconditioning cycle.” All people with asthma should benefit from an exercise program when taking the right precautions
column5: according to the Australian Association for Exercise and Sports Science. Some might even excel – about 7% of Olympians overall and 25% of Olympic swimmers have asthma. Here are some general recommendations for taking the plunge – but it’s important to first consult with a health professional for individually tailored advice and an asthma management plan. The move: diaphragmatic breathing Most research on exercise for asthma has focused on aerobic activities. But Valkenborghs says increasing muscular strength will also deliver a multitude of benefits and is considered relatively safe. “The thing with strength training is you don’t increase your breathing that much at all.” The most relevant study on strength training for asthma found that diaphragmatic breathing was as effective as aerobic exercise in improving lung function. This involved putting weights on the stomach and breathing deeply from the belly to lift the weight up and down.

column1: “A lot of individuals with asthma take shallow breaths
column2: using the muscles of the neck to expand the lungs rather than taking deep breaths using the diaphragm
column3: ” Nash says. She recommends the upper body strengthening exercises lat pulldown or row through to her clients to promote better and deeper breathing. The class: yoga or pilates Indoor classes may help avoid potential outdoor triggers such as cold air
column4: pollution and pollen. Yoga or Pilates are good choices
column5: according to Nash. “Slowing down and focusing on good-quality breathing will help make sure we are getting those deep
column6: full breaths in
column7: ” she says. “As you start to feel more confident
column8: you can start to incorporate with some moderate-intensity strength training to help with global strength and other co-morbidities.” Aerobic exercise is highly recommended for improving asthma-related outcomes such as quality of life
column9: asthma control
column10: air flow
column11: lung function and inflammation. When ready to move to more vigorous activities
column12: Valkenborghs says spin and Hiit classes are a good option; or aqua aerobics
column13: which would be ideal for people whose symptoms aren’t triggered by chlorine. For any aerobic exercise
column14: she says
column15: a 10–15-minute warm-up with low to moderate activity can help prevent sudden irritation to the lungs. The activity: walking There are plenty of free activities
column16: of course. Even walking is very beneficial
column17: says Valkenborghs
column18: especially for someone with asthma who wants to embark on an exercise program and is a bit deconditioned or unfit. “It’s low risk for inducing asthma and can prepare the muscles and bones for future high-intensity exercise.”

column1: As physical activity and fitness levels improve
column2: they can start increasing the intensity by progressing to low-level interval training with intermittent walking and jogging
column3: and later building up to a continuous jog or run
column4: stop
column5: run
column6: stop. Cycling is also a good option. Swimming is ideal
column7: especially at the beach for people triggered by chlorine. The air above the water contains virtually 100% humidity and in warm weather can provide minimal provocation to the lungs. The hard pass: scuba diving Scuba diving has long been a definite no-no for people with asthma
column8: says Valkenborghs
column9: although a small percentage of people with well-managed symptoms might get a doctor’s clearance. Nash says make sure to have your Ventolin when trying a new activity
column10: and seek professional advice on breathing techniques.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/02/how-to-move-with-asthma;7

column6: 'Society'];"Sometimes on a Monday or a Tuesday after work

column8: the rule is this: no. Not after a hard day. Not out with friends. Not if there’s a half-full bottle of impeccably chilled pinot in the fridge. No.

column1: Which isn’t to say that Wednesday to Sunday is a raging bacchanalian festival of booze. Rather
column2: designating two unchanging
column3: no-excuse-accepted alcohol-free days a week has had positive knock-on effects through the week. There are fewer times I drink alcohol at all
column4: even on my “permitted” days

column6: but sticking within the government’s not-long-ago revised down alcohol guidelines is easy. Drinking alcohol in Australia is often an all-or-nothing affair: teetotal rates (up until last year) have been steadily climbing
column7: while a quarter of us exceed the single-session recommended limits at least once a month. It’s the latter kind of event which often leads one to swear off the stuff – particularly after the revelry of the new year. Abstinence
column8: surely

column10: for those who do not have problematic drinking levels
column11: yet want to reduce their alcohol intake

column1: “Any reduction in alcohol consumption can have short- and long-term physical and psychological benefits
column2: ” says Dr Nicole Lee of the National Drug Research Institute at Curtin University. “With people who drink regularly
column3: when they reduce their drinking many find they sleep better
column4: they can think more clearly during the day and they lose a bit of weight. Your heart
column5: liver
column6: stomach and brain will thank you.” While any reduction is good
column7: Lee says that we should probably aim for a little better than my two-day rule. Ensuring three or four days a week are alcohol-free would make keeping within the recommended weekly intake easier. “Everyone is different
column8: ” she says. “Whatever helps you to maintain a reduction in drinking days is a good thing. You might need to try a few different strategies before you find one that’s right for you.”";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/05/easy-wins-cutting-down-on-alcohol-your-heart-liver-stomach-and-brain-will-thank-you;7

column5: 'Coronavirus'];"In mid-June 2020 in Melbourne

column1: The pandemic completely upended Asher’s plans for their son
column2: and themselves. And while not all of us have moved the world for our kids

More time spent focusing on our kids’ welfare.” Many parents are hollowed out by the anxiety they’ve carried for their children for the past two years while trying to mask their own. Hushed conversations about vaccines
column8: diving to turn the news down as a kid’s eyes grow wider
column9: attempting to empathise with a childhood plight we never had to deal with. There’s nothing quite like the rictus smile of a parent attempting to convince a child that another Zoom birthday is a really good time. “This is one of those times when the experience that children are having

column12: Dr Joe Tucci

column15: and alongside
column16: our children. As a result

column18: ” says Nick Tebbey

column1: The national body

Some of the initial findings of the study show that while around two-thirds of people were anxious about their children’s wellbeing
column4: those sorts of feelings weren’t mutually exclusive from a feeling of “we like being together”. “One of the things that we’re told over and over again is that people don’t want to lose that time
column5: ” says Tebbey. “Irrespective of all those other pressures and concerns and anxieties
column6: there was something there that people really held on to.”

column1: Of course
column2: not every family cuddled around a jigsaw together
column3: and as has been well established
column4: some experienced an uptick in acute stress
column5: financial pressure and domestic violence during lockdowns. But the desire for a continuation of more time with kids
column6: regardless of their age
column7: seems to cut across the vast majority of parents
column8: even accommodating for the vastly different experiences of the pandemic. For many
column9: Tucci says
column10: the pandemic has reminded us that time together can be a sanctuary
column11: not just for kids but for their parents. “And doing nothing together is even better
column12: ” he says. “There was a dad that I would see at the park near our house quite regularly during lockdowns. All he was doing with his three-year-old was lying down in the grass. They’d pick up a leaf and then they’d put it into a pile
column13: and then they’d pick up another leaf and put it into some other pile. This is all they did. The kid was delighted.”

column1: Some parents speaking to the Guardian had thought a lot about why they actually liked having their kids at home
column2: given it was often also stressful and unpredictable. Some had a sense of making up for lost time
column3: given their kids had spent a lot of time at daycare
column4: other parents of older kids realised they genuinely enjoyed their teenagers’ company. Tebbey says there is now a much broader awareness of mental health among parents. They’ve been present to read the ripples
column5: to observe their children far more closely. “Parents have become more attuned to their kids’ needs … because they’ll have noticed that small things set them off
column6: ” says Tucci. Patrick
column7: a father of a seven-year-old
column8: definitely feels “like I understand my kid more”. After home schooling one-on-one
column9: “you pick up things you never noticed”. Intuition and letting go A 2021 study shows Australian fathers stepped up to do more childcare and housework during the pandemic
column10: and as a result
column11: more evenly shared the stresses and anxiety that comes with those roles too. Pre-pandemic
column12: Patrick’s wife was the primary carer
column13: but that changed to half and half during lockdown. Whether the more evenly distributed roles remains a trend across parents remains to be seen
column14: but so far for Patrick it’s sticking. As for what Patrick learned about his son
column15: who is autistic
column16: the year taught him that his son is capable of more than he had thought. “Even small things to prove his independence
column17: like getting his own dinner or being able to speak in more complex ways.” For Patrick
column18: it’s been a wonderful thing to watch. “He is more capable than I give him credit for.” Extra time together taught Patrick to change his expectations of his son
column19: and many other parents told the Guardian their kids surprised them in different ways
column20: including realising they could be vulnerable around their children without the sky falling in.

column1: Emily
column2: a single mother of an 18-year-old and a 10-year-old who did her fair share of home schooling while in lockdown in regional Victoria
column3: feels like she’s learnt “to be more honest with my kids about my own feelings and circumstances”. “It’s been a realisation for parents to know how much their children know
column4: ” Tucci says. “You suddenly realise how much your life is on show to them.” Emily reckons she’s a more intuitive parent than she was
column5: more inclined to centre her children’s needs. “Don’t want to go to school? Maybe that’s OK.” This is big for someone like Emily. She comes from a “very
column6: very education-oriented” family – her parents are both teachers – but the past two years has taught her “the importance of understanding my kids as individuals rather than as part of the education system as a whole”. “A lot of parents gave up trying to maintain that school frenzy of doing everything
column7: ” Tucci says. “And schools were gentler
column8: too. They just sort of … slowed down. They were noticing what their children needed and their children just needed space. They needed time. They needed to play and they needed relationships
column9: which is what kids have always needed.” This combination of letting go and a faith in intuition may have resulted in a renewed sense of confidence among parents in their own skills. In a global study of more than 5
column10: 000 people across the US
column11: UK
column12: France
column13: Germany
column14: India
column15: Singapore
column16: China and Brazil
column17: 61% said they felt much or somewhat more confident in their parenting skills now than before lockdowns.

column1: “Certainly during the pandemic
column2: you could never subcontract out your responsibilities for your children to their teachers or their social groups or anything
column3: ” says Tebbey. “It really came down to you as the parents. We’ve seen now that we can play that more active role and be more invested in what our children are going through.” But can parents continue to carve out time
column4: and go gently
column5: as the world around them rapidly speeds up again? “If there’s opportunities for companies and businesses to think creatively about different work weeks or work hours for parents
column6: for families
column7: it’ll benefit everybody
column8: ” says Tucci. The Australian Childhood Foundation’s 2020 report A Lasting Legacy: the impact of Covid 19 on children and parents highlights the need for governments at all levels to have “a stronger focus on parental well-being and family functioning”. Support should come in different forms – ranging from online resources to connection with other parents through online communities
column9: to professional advice at times when parents need it. “It’s a potential legacy
column10: ” Tucci says. “I don’t think parents did relax our expectations. We broadened our expectations. Now we can appreciate that ability to do stuff that’s just nonsensical
column11: like just putting leaves into piles.” After a rocky start with the move
column12: Asher’s son’s new veggie patch is thriving. And Asher felt their relationship with their son shift. He saw the effort Asher was making with the relocation – the tradies
column13: movers
column14: re-enrolling in school – and began helping. “Unasked. Sometimes bringing in laundry or helping with dishes.” “We grew closer
column15: ” says Asher. “I’m not sure if he knew before that he’d always come first no matter what. I think he thought he was part of my whirlwind
column16: but didn’t know he was central to it all.”";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/05/i-understand-my-kid-more-how-the-pandemic-changed-parenting;5
