column6: 'Australia news'];"Waters off Sydney are undergoing an extreme marine heatwave with temperatures likely at their highest levels on record for January. Satellite data is showing the ocean surface off the coast of Sydney at 3C above normal
column7: with swimmers and surfers reporting conditions that feel more like February and March than early January. Prof Moninya Roughan
column8: an oceanographer at the University of New South Wales and an expert in marine heatwaves
column9: said the hottest water was covering an area of about 200sq km.

column1: Roughan is waiting until new data becomes available in the coming weeks from a long-term ocean temperature monitoring station at Port Hacking
column2: where temperatures have been observed since the 1950s. But she said: “It appears now to be reaching those record levels and will likely be the hottest January on record. It’s an extreme marine heatwave.” She said there were three factors behind the extra heat. Global heating was pushing up background temperatures in the ocean
column3: a La Nina weather system was helping transport warmer waters south
column4: and atmospheric conditions were also playing a role. “Marine heatwaves are having severe consequences on ecosystems and they can kill habitats
column5: ” she said.

column1: She said the warm belt of water off Sydney was still attached to the East Australian Current – the 100km-wide belt that runs south from the Great Barrier Reef in Queensland to the area off Sydney. She expected a large eddy would break off from the tip of the current and take warmer waters south of Sydney. “I expect that water will hang around and push south over the coming months
column2: ” she said. Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: Prof Rob Harcourt
column2: a marine ecologist at Macquarie University in Sydney
column3: regularly surfs off Sydney beaches. “It’s been over 21C in the water for over a month now. Everyone that surfs has been talking for weeks about how it’s felt more like February and March than December [when the heat started to build].” He said the warmer water was likely bringing bull and tiger sharks into the area and also farther south. Other species would also likely be arriving on the warmer waters.

column1: Harcourt said while some species may benefit from warming oceans
column2: the change in ocean temperatures along the eastern coast of Australia was dramatic. “A lot of animals will do poorly. A lot of animals that live in cooler waters
column3: like seals and sharks
column4: have a habitat that’s shrinking fast and the implications are hard to measure
column5: but it’s likely to be dramatic.” He said in recent weeks whale sharks had been spotted north of Sydney and tiger and great white sharks had been seen feeding off a sperm whale carcass on the state’s far south coast. “Whale sharks do come down the coast but they’re rare
column6: ” he said.

column1: He said warm water arriving on the current was nothing new
column2: but this arrival was particularly early and was unusually warm. Research in the journal Nature has found marine heatwaves around the globe are becoming more frequent and are lasting longer. Separate research suggests the southern points of the East Australian Current are also warming faster than the area farther north.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/05/extreme-marine-heatwave-waters-off-sydney-set-to-break-january-temperature-records;3

column5: 'Film'];"Still Life is a quiet British film with a mighty heart. Written and directed by Uberto Pasolini (best known as a producer of The Full Monty)
column6: it tackles the subject of loneliness with the lightest of touches. John May (Eddie Marsan) is a man who notices. His job at a local London council depends on it: part detective
column7: part chief mourner
column8: it falls on him to track down the next of kin of residents who died intestate and
column9: invariably
column10: alone. Over 22 years
column11: May’s role has expanded to include organising
column12: attending and writing the eulogies for the funerals of his “clients”. He pieces together their lives by observation – a birthday card here
column13: a dent in a pillow there – and creates a life for them in words and music.

column1: Marsan inhabits the role of May with very few words and even fewer gestures. His presence is a stillness in the centre of the camera lens while life in all its noisy chaos goes on around him. Background noise is turned up a notch – traffic
column2: bird song
column3: distant voices – as if to emphasise the quietness of his own life. Marsan himself is probably one of the best character actors you’ve never heard of. Known in the UK for his television and film appearances – including in Mike Leigh’s 2008 feature Happy-Go-Lucky
column4: and in the US for crime drama Ray Donovan – he received the best British actor award at the 2014 Edinburgh international film festival for his portrayal of May
column5: his first role as the romantic lead.

column1: Romance is not a part of May’s daily life. He lives alone in a tidy council flat devoid of any personal touches. He is shocked to learn that his latest client – left for weeks before being found – lived opposite him. “A loner
column2: ” says his unsympathetic boss Mr Pratchett (The Crown’s Andrew Buchan). “You know the type.” The death of this fellow loner – William Stoke – affects May more than any of the others. When May is “let go” from his council job shortly after
column3: he asks for more time to arrange a suitable send-off for Stoke. Pratchett grudgingly allows him a few days
column4: unpaid
column5: to complete this last case.

column1: May’s dogged research leads him to an estranged daughter named Kelly (Downton Abbey’s Joanne Froggatt) living in Truro
column2: Cornwall. She too lives alone
column3: and the two strangers share the unspoken empathy of lonely people. They meet up again at a cafe a few days before the funeral to go over the arrangements. Kelly Stoke can hardly fail to be touched by the thoughtfulness of the man sitting across from her. As her train leaves the station
column4: she asks John if he would meet her after the funeral for a cup of tea.

column1: From that moment on
column2: May’s demeanour changes. His blank expression takes on a sweetness bordering on a smile. For the first time
column3: a gentle guitar score can be heard above the now-muted sounds of the train running on its tracks and the cries of children in the park. He is now an active participant in the world that surrounds him
column4: not a passive onlooker. The camerawork in Still Life conveys the loneliness of the main character and that of his “charges” in this dialogue-light film. Its title is reflected in the painterly still shots and vignettes of the empty spaces they leave behind. Small gestures take on a poignancy that makes parts of it almost unbearable to watch. The final controversial scene has divided reviewers and led to accusations that it undoes all the goodwill built up to that point. The sceptical are outraged and the sentimental are moved by it: either way
column5: it’s worth investing the 88 minutes it takes to reach the end of this moving
column6: unpretentious gem of a film.";https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2022/jan/05/still-life-2013s-big-hearted-gem-is-a-salute-to-all-the-lonely-people;1

column7: 'Australian politics'];"“Our healthcare system remains strong
column8: ” says our premier. It’s hard to explain that to the 91-year-old woman who slept in a chair last night in the emergency department I work at. Or the patient with cancer
column9: receiving chemo
column10: stuck at the cancer treatment centre for more than 24 hours
column11: her journey delayed because she had became a close contact while waiting for a bed. Or the patient with suicidal ideation
column12: who has been scheduled under the Mental Health Act
column13: was told they have Covid-19
column14: and is being forced to wait indefinitely for days as there are no beds at the specialised mental health facility. Or the ever-growing number of Covid-positive and suspected Covid-positive patients we are treating in a makeshift tent – literally a tent that has been set up outside the front of the department
column15: as there is no room inside. No
column16: Mr Premier. As a nurse working in an New South Wales emergency department
column17: I can tell you our healthcare system no longer remains strong. After two years of fighting the pandemic
column18: the foundations of our healthcare system have been washed away.

column1: We do not have the capacity to treat the influx of Covid-positive patients. In addition to the Covid patients who require hospitalisation due to the virus
column2: the usual presentations to ED haven’t stopped – there are still all the patients suffering strokes
column3: heart attacks
column4: lacerated hands from broken beer bottles
column5: broken legs from motor vehicle accidents
column6: pregnant women with abdominal pain
column7: children with burns from scalding water – and they all happen to have Covid-19. These patients require treatment in a separated area from the rest of the ED patients to avoid a situation where patients come to hospital and catch Covid-19. This area is over capacity. At times
column8: we have to add additional chairs in the corridor to keep up with the demand. Ambulances have had to wait over an hour to offload their Covid-positive patients as there is simply no room. Despite the influx of patients the nursing ratio does not change
column9: creating an unsafe working environment. We are working with skeleton staff as so many senior colleagues have called it quits after having been worked into the ground over the past 24 months. It has become the norm for us to be asked every shift to do overtime or to come in on our days off. We do it
column10: not for the extra money
column11: but out of guilt and solidarity for our colleagues so they are not left to work a shift with deadly nurse-to-patient ratios. It is not uncommon for shifts to be so short-staffed that they have only one third of the nurses required rostered on. It is not a sustainable work model. Compounding the issue now is the growing number of staff members who themselves are testing positive. Adding to the situation is the issue of the staffing skill mix
column12: which has become dangerous. To scrape through each shift
column13: we are reliant on agency staff or staff being sent from other areas of the hospital to work in areas where they lack the specialised training. It is just not safe. The working conditions in hospitals has deteriorated throughout the pandemic. Beds replaced with chairs to make way for the growing number of patients. Tents erected outside
column14: exposed to the elements
column15: to make additional space to treat the ever-growing number of Covid-confirmed and suspected patients. Nurses having to work outdoors
column16: in over 30-degree heat
column17: in direct sunlight
column18: in blue plastic gowns
column19: gloves
column20: goggles
column21: N95 masks and a face shield. Simple procedures take twice as long and are twice as difficult to complete due to infection control procedures. We feel defeated: we are not able to provide the level of care we could pre-pandemic. What is most wearing
column22: though
column23: is the lack of recognition from our leaders about how hard this pandemic is for the nursing workforce.

column1: Every day of this pandemic
column2: we have been expected to come to work without any additional hazard pay for putting ourselves on the front line of this deadly virus. With this latest wave
column3: we have been begged to cancel our leave and extorted to dig deeper as our “community has needed us now more than ever”. Now we are told that we are exempt from isolating when we become a close contact. Yet when will our politicians care for us? When will our politicians stop calling us “healthcare heroes”
column4: as if we are superheroes able to work through any catastrophe
column5: and stop ignoring our pleas for mandated nurse-to-patient ratios to ensure patient safety
column6: and listen to our request for a fair pay rise following the wage freeze imposed on us in 2020? I worry for my colleagues and the profession that I have grown to love. We have already lost so many of our best senior nurses and paramedics over the past few months due to the fatigue of this pandemic. I just know that with this fourth wave of infections
column7: we are going to lose many
column8: many more. My colleagues and I are beyond fatigued. We feel hopeless
column9: we feel scared. There is nothing left for us to give. The author is a nurse in an emergency department in Sydney";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/05/the-foundations-of-our-healthcare-system-have-been-washed-away;4

column6: 'Australia news'];"An “unprecedented” number of people have withdrawn from Australia’s overseas diplomatic postings during the pandemic

column6: 'Christianity'];"The Catholic church’s failed attempt to argue it was not responsible for a priest’s abuse of a five-year-old
column7: because it took place during after-hours “social” visits
column8: has been slammed as “ruthless” by the survivor and an “affront to common sense” by a judge. Last month the Victorian supreme court handed down a judgment finding the current diocese of Ballarat was vicariously liable for the abuse of the boy
column9: who cannot be named

column11: Ken Cush & Associates
column12: say the ruling is a landmark win that will help countless others. Coffey abused the boy during pastoral care visits to his home on two occasions in 1971. The critical issue in the case was whether Coffey
column13: an assistant parish priest

column1: The church argued that Coffey was not a formal employee and so it could not be held liable for his actions. It also said Coffey’s home visits were “social outings” not connected to his work for the church. The judge in the case
column2: Justice Jack Forrest
column3: described the suggestion as “sheer nonsense”. “It is
column4: in my view
column5: both inconceivable and an affront to common sense to suggest (as the Diocese put it) that these visits to parishioners’ houses and [the survivor’s] home were unconnected with Coffey’s pastoral role within the Church and merely social outings separate to his role as an assistant priest
column6: ” he said. The court found the abuse occurred and that the diocese was vicariously liable for Coffey’s actions. Forrest found Coffey was not a formal employee of the church
column7: given the absence of any formal employment contract or arrangement
column8: and the lack of immediate control or supervision by the diocese of his work. But he found the diocese was still vicariously liable for the abuse due to the close nature of the relationship between the bishop
column9: the diocese and the Catholic community in Port Fairy; the diocese’s general control over Coffey’s role and duties; and the fact that Coffey had a pastoral role in the town
column10: which included home visits. The court found the relationship between the survivor

column4: 'Australia news'];"This week
column5: Scott Morrison insisted the provision of rapid antigen tests for those without symptoms or who have not been told to get tested by authorities should be left to the “private market”. Having referred to what he called more “casual uses” of rapid tests
column6: the prime minister said: “We’re at another stage of this pandemic now where we just can’t go round and make everything free.” While some state governments – principally New South Wales and Victoria – last week said they wanted to distribute rapid antigen tests free to the general public

column1: However
column2: some governments overseas have taken a very different approach when it comes to rapid tests. Here are some examples. United Kingdom Perhaps the best known example to most Australians
column3: the UK government offers people access to free self-administered rapid antigen tests through the National Health Service. They are provided free through local pharmacies
column4: with residents able to obtain a “collect code” and then pick them up. Individuals can also grab two packs of seven rapid tests from community locations such as libraries. And they can also be ordered through a home delivery service. The NHS website notes people might wish to do a free test when they “mix with people in crowded indoor places” or “visit someone who is at higher risk of getting seriously ill from Covid-19”. These are examples of what the Australian government views as “casual uses” for such tests. Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: Some Australians in the UK have noted the contrast between the two systems. “It’s been so good that they’re free
column2: ” says Jordan Marshall
column3: an Australian living in London. “My partner’s a paramedic so we’ve been quite proactive about testing.” Marshall says she’s probably used about 20 rapid tests over about three months
column4: with many of those in the lead up to Christmas. “While there’s been supply issues
column5: the fact that we can get boxes delivered to the house means you can have greater level of confidence you’re not out there spreading it in the community
column6: ” she says.

column1: Singapore The Singaporean government sent households 10 free rapid antigen tests in the mail between October and December. It undertook a similar process
column2: providing six tests per household
column3: between August and September. The government also has a program that offers free rapid testing kits to employers
column4: who then provide them to workers. By October
column6: 000 businesses had signed up
column7: reports the Straits Times. Tests that are sold at retailers are also now considerably cheaper than those currently on offer in Australia
column8: where tests had cost between $10 and $15 each
column9: but have since exploded to as much as $30 to $40 a pop in some cases. From 10 December
column10: it was reported that Singaporean retailers were stocking “Flowflex” tests at $5 each
column11: while a pack of five cost $24.

column1: Malaysia Home rapid test kits are considered a “controlled item” in Malaysia and supply is controlled by the government. They are sold at pharmacies with a capped price of $6.60
column2: though they are often cheaper than that. Aliya Ahmad
column3: a Pakistani Australian visiting her parents who live in Malaysia
column4: says tests tend to cost between $2 and $6 each. “The pharmacies and chemists are all over the place
column5: at least in the city where I live
column6: ” Ahmad says. “Also
column7: while I can only really speak for what I’ve been observing myself
column8: it seems like general practice to take one before going to a big gathering or a house with elders.”

column1: France Since late last month
column2: France has made self-administered rapid tests available at supermarkets. They are subject to price controls
column3: meaning they cannot cost more than $8 per test. The government urged residents to use the tests before New Year’s Eve celebrations.

column1: Portugal Rapid antigen tests administered in pharmacies are free. Citizens can obtain four of these tests per month
column2: though this was expanded to six tests in December during the lead up to Christmas. Self-administered rapid antigen test kits are also available in shops
column3: generally for about $4-6 per test. A negative rapid test is required to enter some venues throughout Portugal.

column1: Canada Some Canadian provinces
column2: such as Nova Scotia and Saskatchewan
column3: have offered free rapid tests through local distribution centres. In the case of Nova Scotia
column5: 000 tests were reportedly handed out in December through local libraries (the population is about 970
column7: though the initiative concluded late last month. Ontario
column8: home to Toronto
column9: is offering a free take-home rapid test to residents as part of a holiday testing blitz that will last into this month. The federal government also has a program offering free rapid tests to businesses. Germany Germany offers free rapid antigen tests once a week at testing centres. Self-administered take-home kits are also available at pharmacies and
column10: according to Bloomberg
column11: were on sale for as little as about $2.50 in November. United States The US has been hit by a shortage of rapid tests in many places and costs are broadly comparable with Australia. In some cities
column12: free tests are available to the general public for pick up
column13: subject to supply. For example
column14: Washington DC residents can pick up a free home rapid test from local schools.

column1: The Biden administration intends to distribute 500m rapid test kits free of charge to people to use at home. It’s expected the tests will be sent out from this month. Free doesn’t always mean available It should be noted that
column2: like Australia
column3: many of these countries have been hit by supply shortages. The Guardian reported that the UK’s free rapid tests system has been hit by supply issues that frustrated residents over the holiday period. And
column4: unlike some other countries
column5: high-quality PCR tests do remain free in Australia
column6: though the government is now trying to limit them to people who are symptomatic or high-risk close contacts. With the Australian system under massive pressure
column7: it has become incredibly hard to get a test and some results are taking as long as five days to come back. National cabinet is expected to determine concessional arrangements that might give some Australians access to cheaper rapid antigen tests on Wednesday. Some states are also set to provide more details about their plans to distribute some free rapid tests
column8: though these will likely only apply to certain vulnerable groups.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/05/scott-morrison-opposes-free-rapid-antigen-tests-but-heres-what-other-countries-are-doing;7

column5: 'Australia news'];"The federal government has pledged $316.5m for a new Indigenous cultural precinct in Canberra that would include a long-awaited national resting place for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander ancestral remains. The proposed centre
column6: to be called Ngurra
column7: which means home
column8: country or place of belonging in different Aboriginal languages
column9: will incorporate a learning and knowledge centre and the relocated Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies (Aiatsis). It will be built on the shores of Lake Burley Griffin on Ngunnawal country in Canberra within the parliamentary triangle that includes other prominent national institutions.

column1: The prime minister
column2: Scott Morrison
column3: said the centre would become a “place of national pride and significance” and hailed its proposed location as demonstrating the “importance and reverence this institution should hold”. “Ngurra is the realisation of a long-held desire to have a home for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures and histories at the heart of our nation
column4: ” Morrison said. “It will be a national landmark of the highest order
column5: standing proudly for us all to celebrate
column6: educate
column7: reflect and commemorate.” A national resting place for ancestral remains was formally recommended to government in 2014 when an advisory committee for Indigenous repatriation completed the national resting place consultation report. Two parliamentary committees have since endorsed the recommendation. The project
column8: which underwent a $4.7m business case process after the May budget

column1: The Aiatsis chief executive
column2: Craig Ritchie

column4: the sophistication of our world views and its relationship to country and place”. “There is a deeply ingrained way of thinking about Indigenous Australia that is defined by disadvantage
column5: and that challenge is real
column6: but it is not who we are
column7: ” Ritchie told Guardian Australia. “We wanted the opportunity to do more than just recite grievances
column8: but really showcase the brilliance of First Nations cultures in a way … that all Australians have access to.”

column1: Morrison said the centre would give Australians and international visitors “a deeper appreciation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples’ diversity and cultures
column2: and the richness this offers our country”. “This new world-class facility will contribute to our continuing journey of reconciliation
column3: where Indigenous Australians can tell their stories
column4: in the way they want
column5: for all visitors to have a greater understanding of our shared history
column6: ” the prime minister said. The minister for Indigenous Australians

column8: said the new learning and engagement centre – and the exhibitions
column9: research and curation that would occur at Ngurra – would result in “significant acts of truth-telling”.

column2: ” Wyatt said. “In instances where provenance has been forgotten or erased

column9: achievements and deep connection to country”.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/05/plan-for-new-indigenous-cultural-precinct-in-canberra-unveiled-by-morrison-government;1

column10: 'Blockchain'];"Bored Ape #79 looks almost as bored as I feel when I think about NFTs (non-fungible tokens) and their supposedly seismic impact on art. My jaw slides
column11: my eyelids hang down and I want to pick lice from my fur. Even though I can identify with Bored Ape #79
column12: I won’t be buying it
column13: unlike Eminem who has bought another in this highly fashionable NFT “art” brand that looks slightly like him. It’s called EminApe and sports a military-urban peaked cap above its enervated face. He reportedly paid around $450
column15: 000) for it. Just in case
column16: like me
column17: you have spent the last year averting your gaze with a sigh whenever another news item about NFT art wafted an unmistakable aroma of bull your way
column18: here is a quick reminder of what Eminem gets for his near half-million – which
column19: by the way
column20: is far from the highest anyone has paid for one of these nihilist monkeys. He owns a unique unit of data recorded in a digital blockchain
column21: which permanently records its provenance or sales history. It’s a way of restoring the idea of an “original” one-off artwork to the endlessly reproducible
column22: copyable realm of the internet. Anyone can grab Eminem’s ape image online
column23: but he owns the “original” and has the blockchain provenance to prove it.

column1: Someone was going to monetise digital culture eventually. And theoretically
column2: from an artist’s point of view
column3: that has to be a good thing – right? Suddenly
column4: creators don’t have to settle for feeble fees from Spotify or see their images circulate free of charge. They can clean up. Rags to riches stories have helped to make the NFT art market the sentimental bag of air it is. Struggling unknowns find themselves selling NFTs for wildly escalating prices
column5: outsiders who never got near success in the established art world suddenly leap to fame
column6: and the art world
column7: never slow to jump on a bandwagon
column8: has joined in the fun with Christie’s selling a JPEG file by Beeple for $69m last spring. The Bored Ape boom
column9: however
column10: should put an end to any romanticism about NFT art. It puts the consumer experience first and has absolutely nothing to do with empowering artists. It’s all about the collector’s ego. For Eminem doesn’t just get a “unique” masterpiece of digital “art” for his money. Purchasers of an NFT from the Bored Ape collection also become members of the Bored Ape Yacht Club
column11: a “swamp club for apes” where the cool dudes who fork out heaps of cryptocurrency for a monkey cartoon can hang out together. This is part of the well-planned strategy that is making Bored Apes a marketing sensation – and a mockery of all the inflated claims uncritically spouted about NFT art. The Bored Ape Yacht Club could even be a satire on the NFT craze
column12: were it not such a lucrative example of it. This is a totally cynical creation. The Club offers a new level of exclusivity
column13: a virtual social club
column14: on top of its promise of exclusive digital ownership. It seems the kind of fake cool meeting of pop culture and money that might attract the insecure Kendall Roy in the TV drama Succession – “Bored Apes are cool
column15: right? Yeah they’re cool. See you in the Yacht Club to dish out more stuff on my dad!” Yet real-life celebrities are queuing up to join including Jimmy Fallon and rapper Post Malone. If they get bored posting graffiti in the club toilet (this is one of the perks) they can purchase a “serum” that allows them to remix ape designs to produce a Mutant Ape. It’s all so neatly designed
column16: so smoothly negotiable
column17: so stylishly moronic
column18: it makes the early (as in
column19: early 2021) NFT art sensations look frightfully naive. The anonymous inventors of the Bored Ape were two literary loafers – they claim to have bonded over the novels of David Foster Wallace – who then hired a graphic designer to create the ape design. The Bored Apes are framed as portraits in an ironic nod to high art. But they’re not art of any bite or originality. The ape is a very ordinary and derivative bit of comic book design
column20: heavily indebted to inspirations ranging from Jamie Hewlett to Rick and Morty. It isn’t art that’s being sold here but attitude. The attitude says it all. Bored
column21: emptied out
column22: wrecked
column23: and proud of it. That’s how the NFT art investors all feel
column24: apparently. And so they should. NFTs are not good for art. They are not liberating for artists. Instead
column25: as the Bored Ape Yacht Club makes horribly obvious
column26: they serve nothing but money. They are just simian poker chips that celebrate the thrill of the market. A purer form of capitalism has never existed.";https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2022/jan/04/bored-ape-nft-art-eminem;5

column6: 'Culture']";"No wonder journalists have slated it. They’ve produced a hundred excuses not to watch the climate breakdown satire Don’t Look Up: it’s “blunt”
column7: it’s “shrill”
column8: it’s “smug”. But they will not name the real problem: it’s about them. The movie is
column9: in my view
column10: a powerful demolition of the grotesque failures of public life. And the sector whose failures are most brutally exposed is the media. While the film is fast and funny
column11: for me
column12: as for many environmental activists and climate scientists
column13: it seemed all too real. I felt as if I were watching my adult life flash past me. As the scientists in the film
column14: trying to draw attention to the approach of a planet-killing comet
column15: bashed their heads against the Great Wall of Denial erected by the media and sought to reach politicians with 10-second attention spans
column16: all the anger and frustration and desperation I’ve felt over the years boiled over. Above all
column17: when the scientist who had discovered the comet was pushed to the bottom of the schedule by fatuous celebrity gossip on a morning TV show and erupted in fury
column18: I was reminded of my own mortifying loss of control on Good Morning Britain in November. It was soon after the Cop26 climate conference in Glasgow
column19: where we had seen the least serious of all governments (the UK was hosting the talks) failing to rise to the most serious of all issues. I tried
column20: for the thousandth time
column21: to explain what we are facing
column22: and suddenly couldn’t hold it in any longer. I burst into tears on live TV. I still feel deeply embarrassed about it. The response on social media
column23: like the response to the scientist in the film
column24: was vituperative and vicious. I was faking. I was hysterical. I was mentally ill. But
column25: knowing where we are and what we face
column26: seeing the indifference of those who wield power
column27: seeing how our existential crisis has been marginalised in favour of trivia and frivolity
column28: I now realise that there would be something wrong with me if I hadn’t lost it.

column1: In fighting any great harm
column2: in any age
column3: we find ourselves confronting the same forces: distraction
column4: denial and delusion. Those seeking to sound the alarm about the gathering collapse of our life-support systems soon hit the barrier that stands between us and the people we are trying to reach
column5: a barrier called the media. With a few notable exceptions
column6: the sector that should facilitate communication thwarts it. It’s not just its individual stupidities that have become inexcusable
column7: such as the platforms repeatedly given to climate deniers. It is the structural stupidity to which the media are committed. It’s the anti-intellectualism
column8: the hostility to new ideas and aversion to complexity. It’s the absence of moral seriousness. It’s the vacuous gossip about celebrities and consumables that takes precedence over the survival of life on Earth. It’s the obsession with generating noise
column9: regardless of signal. It’s the reflexive alignment with the status quo
column10: whatever it may be. It’s the endless promotion of the views of the most selfish and antisocial people
column11: and the exclusion of those who are trying to defend us from catastrophe
column12: on the grounds that they are “worthy”
column13: “extreme” or “mad” (I hear from friends in the BBC that these terms are still used there to describe environmental activists). Even when these merchants of distraction do address the issue
column14: they tend to shut out the experts and interview actors
column15: singers and other celebs instead. The media’s obsession with actors vindicates Guy Debord’s predictions in his book The Society of the Spectacle
column16: published in 1967. Substance is replaced by semblance
column17: as even the most serious issues must now be articulated by people whose work involves adopting someone else’s persona and speaking someone else’s words. Then the same media
column18: having turned them into spokespeople
column19: attack these actors as hypocrites for leading a profligate lifestyle. Similarly
column20: it’s not just the individual failures by governments at Glasgow and elsewhere that have become inexcusable
column21: but the entire framework of negotiations. As crucial Earth systems might be approaching their tipping point
column22: governments still propose to address the issue with tiny increments of action
column23: across decades. It’s as if
column25: when Lehman Brothers collapsed and the global financial system began to sway
column26: governments had announced that they would bail out the banks at the rate of a few million pounds a day between then and 2050. The system would have collapsed 40 years before their programme was complete. Our central
column27: civilisational question
column28: I believe
column29: is this: why do nations scramble to rescue the banks but not the planet? So
column30: as we race towards Earth system collapse
column31: trying to raise the alarm feels like being trapped behind a thick plate of glass. People can see our mouths opening and closing
column32: but they struggle to hear what we are saying. As we frantically bang the glass
column33: we look ever crazier. And feel it. The situation is genuinely maddening. I’ve been working on these issues since I was 22
column34: and full of confidence and hope. I’m about to turn 59
column35: and the confidence is turning to cold fear
column36: the hope to horror. As manufactured indifference ensures that we remain unheard
column37: it becomes ever harder to know how to hold it together. I cry most days now. George Monbiot is a Guardian columnist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/04/dont-look-up-life-of-campaigning;3

column7: 'Activism'];"In 2017
column8: most Brazilians were still unfamiliar with the name Jair Bolsonaro. But for Júlio Lancellotti
column9: there was already cause for concern in the reactionary rhetoric of the man who would be elected president two years later under the slogan: “Brazil above everything
column10: God above everyone.” “I am astonished that a homophobic person like Bolsonaro appears on the presidential ballot
column11: ” said the priest during mass on 7 March of that year at St Michael the Archangel parish in São Paulo’s East Zone. The sermon
column12: in which he also preached against rape culture and sexism
column13: was typical of the man who has devoted his life to fighting injustice
column14: often finding himself targeted by conservative politicians as a result. An openly leftwing priest who embraces revolutionary ideas – the 72-year-old has demonstrated arm-in-arm with anti-establishment “black bloc” protesters and believes hotels should provide free rooms for homeless people – Lancellotti seemingly represents the antithesis of everything Brazil’s president stands for. He was even sued by Bolsonaro for moral damages because of his March 2017 mass (a judge dismissed the claim).

column1: But Lancelloti’s run-in with the authorities began long before Bolsonaro took office. As a novice in the late 1960s
column2: he was expelled from the seminary for “bad behaviour”
column3: as he describes it. He says the seminary where he first studied
column4: in the city of Araraquara
column5: was “very conservative”. His days were marked by censure and abusive punishments. “I was beaten with a bamboo stick
column6: I was forced to kneel on corn grains … one day
column7: a priest said I asked too much in class
column8: that I was very critical. They kicked me out.” After this episode
column9: Lancellotti spent years away from the priesthood. He graduated from a course in education in 1978
column10: started working with juvenile offenders and soon became a thorn in the side of the authorities. “I refused to accept the torture I witnessed against young people. I felt I was being tested all the time by those who were aligned with the government
column11: ” he says. It was during these years that Lancellotti met progressive priests who were actively engaged with the children’s rights cause
column12: and in doing so rediscovered a sense that social justice was possible within the Roman Catholic church. He resumed his theological studies and
column14: became a priest.

column1: Since 1996
column2: Lancelotti has coordinated the pastoral commission of homeless people in São Paulo
column3: which helps about 35
column4: 000 people in the district. He describes being pepper-sprayed
column5: spat at
column6: and punched in the stomach by São Paulo’s municipal guard while helping homeless people in 2018. Lancelotti says the Covid pandemic has worsened the living conditions of São Paulo’s homeless
column7: while the ultra-conservatism of the Bolsonaro era has fuelled what the priest describes as “aporophobia” – a fear and rejection of the poor. In August
column8: São Paulo state deputy Janaína Paschoal praised the military police after they blocked the homeless commission’s access to an inner-city area nicknamed Cracolândia – “Crackland”. Advocating for homeless people is the focus of Lancellotti’s activism
column9: but not its only cause. He does not hesitate to take a stand for controversial groups such as those involved in black bloc tactics at demonstrations. “The best guys I have ever met. The purest
column10: the truest. They have been tortured and criminalised unfairly
column11: ” says Lancellotti
column12: who helped secure the release of some of the demonstrators from jail in 2013.

column1: Consequently
column2: criticism against him comes from all sides. But of all Lancellotti’s critics
column3: Christians are by far the most ferocious
column4: the priest says. “The atheists are usually more human than those who claim to be Christians. Those who say ‘God above all’ are the same who put humans below everything.” He remains a popular figure for many. His phone rings throughout the day
column5: and he is kept busy with calls – whether it is a media request or speaking to a fellow activist. An avid social media user
column6: the images he posts while helping homeless people can bring happy results. “Families from all over Brazil have been able to find relatives who were believed to have disappeared
column7: ” he says.

column1: He has even inspired a federal bill. Approved by the senate on 31 March last year
column2: the “Júlio Lancellotti bill” aims to ban the practice of putting stones and iron spikes in underpasses – a measure adopted by mayors to prevent homeless people sleeping there. Now back in the lower house and waiting to be revised
column3: the bill is a reminder of the day Lancellotti took a sledgehammer to the stones that had been placed in a São Paulo underpass. Lancellotti’s present focus is on lobbying city hall to carry out a more responsible census. According to the priest
column4: the last one in 2019 did not accurately record the number of homeless people in São Paulo – which leads to policies that are incapable of solving the issue. Envisioning a better future for Brazil is still hard for Lancellotti. “Anyone who takes office after this monster [Bolsonaro] won’t be able to restore everything he destroyed in culture
column5: health and education – even in 10 years
column6: ” he says
column7: adding: “The Bolsonarismo didn’t appear overnight
column8: and won’t be beaten overnight.” In a country riven by violence and hatred
column9: he concludes
column10: the only way forward is through “dialogue and love”. Sign up for a different view with our Global Dispatch newsletter – a roundup of our top stories from around the world
column11: recommended reads
column12: and thoughts from our team on key development and human rights issues
column13: delivered to your inbox every two weeks:";https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2022/jan/04/preaching-truth-to-power-the-sao-paulo-priest-standing-up-to-bolsonaro;4

column6: 'Australia sport'];"Novak Djokovic will defend his Australian Open title after revealing he has secured a medical exemption for the tournament and he is on his way to Melbourne. The exemption ends weeks of speculation about the possibility of Djokovic being unable to compete in the opening grand slam tournament of 2022 since he had refused to divulge his vaccination status and had previously expressed doubt about taking a Covid vaccine.

column1: All Australian Open participants must either be fully vaccinated or apply for and secure a medical exemption in order to enter Victoria without undertaking the mandatory 14-day quarantine. “Happy New Year
column2: everybody! Wishing you all health
column3: love
column4: and happiness in every present moment and may you feel love & respect towards all beings on this wonderful planet
column5: ” Djokovic wrote on social media. “I’ve spent fantastic quality time with my loved ones over the break and today I’m heading Down Under with an exemption permission. Let’s go 2022 !!”

column1: Djokovic’s announcement has garnered mixed responses from some of his peers. “If it was me that wasn’t vaccinated I wouldn’t be getting an exemption
column2: ” said Jamie Murray at the ATP Cup. “But well done to him for getting clear to come to Australia and compete.” Alex de Minaur
column3: Australia’s No 1 men’s player
column4: said that he hopes that other players who applied for exemptions received the same treatment as Djokovic. “I just think it’s just very interesting
column5: that’s all I’m going to say
column6: ” De Minaur responded. “But
column7: hey
column8: it is what it is. I just hope that the other players that I heard were cases as well
column9: [I hope] they got exemptions.” Liam Broady
column10: who is Great Britain’s ATP Cup captain in Sydney
column11: said: “You have to trust that he does have a valid reason for the medical exemption.” Shortly after Djokovic’s announcement
column12: the Australian Open confirmed he had received a medical exemption and they released a statement outlining the process. Two panels of experts were charged with reviewing the evidence
column13: with the applications finalised by the Independent Medical Exemption Review Panel
column14: a panel of experts appointed by the government. According to a Victorian state spokesman
column15: the personal information of applicants is redacted in the process.

column1: The Tennis Australia CEO
column2: Craig Tiley
column3: told the Today Show on Wednesday morning that 26 players and staff had applied for a medical exemption but only “a handful” of applications were granted and that participants at the Australian Open had been subject to a more rigorous process than Australian citizens. “If they didn’t meet the guidelines
column4: and there were many that didn’t
column5: they were rejected
column6: ” Tiley said. “If they met the guidelines
column7: for example – which a lot of people forget – one of those conditions is having had Covid in the past six months. So any person who met those conditions has been allowed to come in. There’s been no special favour
column8: there’s been no special opportunity granted to Novak nor there would be to any tennis player.”

column1: Criteria listed by the Australian Technical Advisory Group as permissible reasons for a medical exemption range from those suffering acute major medical conditions to any serious adverse event attributed to a previous dose of Covid-19 vaccine. For those who have recently tested positive for Covid-19
column2: vaccination can also be deferred until six months after infection. The reason for Djokovic’s exemption is unclear. While most of the top players have arrived in Melbourne in order to compete in the first week of competition
column3: with some even landing before Christmas
column4: Djokovic remained at his training base in Marbella after withdrawing from this week’s ATP Cup. His presence could prove a defining moment as he attempts to win his 21st major title
column5: which would break the record he shares with Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer.

column1: Despite successful medical exemptions for Djokovic and some others
column2: not all players were able to make the trip to Melbourne. Natalia Vikhlyantseva
column3: a Russian player ranked 195th
column4: announced her withdrawal from the Australian Open last month since she had been vaccinated with Sputnik V
column5: which was developed in her home country but is not recognised by the Australian government.";https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/jan/04/novak-djokovic-secures-medical-exemption-to-play-in-australian-open-tennis;4

column6: 'R&B'];"One often overlooked aspect of the current pandemic is the effect that it has had on brands. The poor brands
column7: who long ago settled on a cool-sounding name only to have it coopted by a deadly once-a-century health crisis. Remember Corona
column8: the beer that people used to drink before the association with illness and death became too much to take? Remember Delta
column9: the airline that people used to use before it reminded everyone that new Covid mutations are destined to consign humanity to a quivering wreck for decades to come? These are the real victims. Until now
column10: the Omicron variant has escaped such a fate. This is because Omicron is such a stupid word that the only people who had ever adopted it as a name are an imposing German electrical diagnostic corporation and a Belgian death metal band
column11: and neither one seems particularly bothered by the association. However
column12: if you squint hard enough and pretend that you don’t know how to read
column13: the word “Omicron” sort of looks a bit like ‘Omarion’. And that’s bad news for the R&B singer of the same name who was once part of the band B2K. Because
column14: for almost a full month now
column15: Omarion has found himself on the receiving end of Twitter’s firehose. For a whole swathe of people online
column16: Omicron is now “the Omarion variant”. If you catch it by surprise
column17: you tweet a gif of Omarion on The Masked Singer. If you want to show how the virus spreads
column18: you tweet a video of Omarion dancing through the streets after a woman. If you’re forced into self-isolation
column19: you make a TikTok of Omarion dancing on the end of a lateral flow swab like an especially perky bogey.

column1: Through the thick of the outbreak
column2: Omarion himself has apparently remained oblivious to this association. However
column3: he has finally issued an official response. On New Year’s Day
column4: Omarion uploaded three TikTok videos to help clear up any misunderstanding. “Hi
column5: this is Omarion. I am an artist
column6: not a variant” he explained. “So please be aware that
column7: if you just so happen to run into me on the street
column8: you don’t have to isolate for five days”. “While it’s important not to touch me and keep your distance
column9: cause you know that’s how it’s supposed to be
column10: you don’t need a negative test to dance to my music
column11: ” Omarion continued. On another video referencing his old boyband
column12: he added that “The last time I had to do this was in 2000 when everyone confused Y2K with B2K”. Perhaps this is Omarion’s lot. Perhaps every 20 years
column13: some awful catastrophe will befall humanity
column14: and it’ll sound a bit like something vaguely related to something Omarion has done. Maybe in 2040 we’ll be crushed by an asteroid that will come to be colloquially known as Fat Albert
column15: referencing Omarion’s 2004 movie. Or maybe aliens will arrive from the planet Kourtney and Khloe Take Miami
column16: named after the reality show that Omarion appeared on for a single episode in 2019. Perhaps
column17: even
column18: we will be hit by a second pandemic
column19: and science will inexplicably choose to name each new variant after a different disappointing R&B album
column20: and the most deadly wave will carry the title of Omarion’s 2014 record
column21: Sex Playlist. What a way to go. Still
column22: you have to imagine that
column23: deep down
column24: Omarion must be quite pleased that his name is now synonymous with an unimaginably virulent strain of Covid. Because now
column25: when you Google the word Omarion
column26: you get swamped by results about his jokey clarification. And that means that all other news about Omarion has suddenly become much harder to find. That time Reuters ran a news story about Omarion asking his fans to pray for him because he happened to be in London – uninjured and inconvenienced – during the 2005 terrorist attacks? Very difficult to find now. Not impossible
column27: but very hard.";https://www.theguardian.com/music/2022/jan/04/omarion-rb-singer-not-omicron-variant;2

column8: according to the latest Bank of England data. The increase in reliance on loans and credit cards exceeded City forecasts of a £0.8bn rise and beat the £0.6bn average of the previous six months. Analysts said much of the increase reflected a more confident

column10: but warned that many low income households had become more dependent on loans to cope with an inflationary squeeze on their finances from rising utility bills and the higher cost of the weekly shop. Households also cut back on the amount of money set aside in deposit accounts to £4.5bn in November
column11: from an average over the previous 12 months of £11.2bn. The dramatic reduction in savings growth was seen as supporting the trend among some consumers to be more confident and spend a higher proportion of their income

column15: “it also appears to be indicative of a more bullish consumer mindset”. The threat from the Omicron coronavirus variant would probably reverse the trends for higher borrowing and lower saving in December as households responded to increasing economic uncertainty

column1: He added that a consumer boom led by a rapid reduction of pandemic-related savings “continues to look very unlikely” while much of the money is needed to offset higher prices. column2: 2015-19 average. The decline to 66
column3: 400 approvals a month is expected to become the norm over the rest of this year

column5: despite higher levels of buyer inquiries in November

column4: 'World news'];Israel has become the first country in the world to embark on a fourth Covid-19 vaccination campaign as part of efforts to stem rapidly rising infection rates caused by the Omicron variant. People over the age of 60 and healthcare workers who received their third shot more than four months ago became eligible for a second booster of Pfizer-BioNTech on Monday
column5: after a limited rollout began last week for elderly people and those with compromised immune systems. Officials had previously said they would wait for more data on the efficacy of a fourth shot before making it more widely available. The Israeli health ministry said on Tuesday

column1: 389;389;5636;5636;Ashes show will continue because there’s too much money at stake | Geoff Lemon;2022-01-04T14:32:03Z;['Geoff Lemon'];['Ashes 2021-22'

column7: 'Sport'];"As the Sydney Ashes Test rolls to the start line
column8: the conversations about selections and form and conditions do not really matter. What matters is that it is miraculous this match is going ahead. England have almost an entire coaching staff wiped out by Covid. Australia have lost their Brisbane century-maker Travis Head
column9: with three players named as cover. The Cricket Australia chief executive
column10: Nick Hockley
column11: is out and Glenn McGrath will miss at least part of his foundation’s fundraising efforts. In Australian domestic cricket
column12: Big Bash teams are losing quorum to the virus. Yet the show will go on.

column1: Sydney is complicated
column2: a town built on blood and corruption from the first days of its colonial founding. It is beautiful
column3: with a beauty bought by wealth and subsidised by poverty. When you walk its hills at night it can be disarmingly gentle
column4: the humid air curling around you
column5: distant lights on quiet streets
column6: the leaves of the Moreton Bay fig trees or the white-gold petals of frangipani unbearably lush. The harbour unwinds through the city’s core
column7: unspooling in all directions
column8: those waters captured in the words of Kenneth Slessor. To the east is the ocean coast and its storied beaches. To the west it becomes another city
column9: growing ever outwards. In the past year
column10: Sydney has also become the centre of Australia’s viral explosion. By now nobody can remember which wave this is
column11: but a country that successfully held back a global inundation for nearly two years has now given in. Political leaders have sold the idea of a harmless variant and the fantasy that everybody getting sick and getting better will mean an end rather than just another waypoint on a road that has miles to run. For those in countries that have suffered worse and earlier
column12: Australia’s situation may seem tame in comparison. But there has been an abdication of responsibility
column13: leaving people to fend for themselves. It is in Sydney
column14: as cases leap by the day and as leaders find ways to stop counting
column15: that the fourth Ashes Test will be held. It is safe to say that had this series been played at any other time in the pandemic era
column16: in any other country
column17: between any other two teams
column18: it would have been called off by now. England left South Africa in 2020 after one positive test from a worker at the team hotel. Australia gave South Africa an escalating list of demands in 2021 and still refused to tour. India left England early last September when the coach and a physio were infected. The suggestion above is not hypothetical. And yet
column19: this is the Ashes
column20: the main source of revenue for the two boards involved. England’s authorities gain nothing directly from a series played in Australia
column21: but need the reciprocal goodwill to make sure Australia’s touring commitments in the other direction go unaffected. CA’s entire financial existence hinges on the quadrennial infusion from this tour
column22: with broadcast deals in particular based on the popularity of even a one-sided contest. Ultimately it will not matter which players are available or where matches are played
column23: as long as they are on television screens in sufficient quantity to meet the contract.

column1: There will be plenty of ticket revenue too
column2: thanks to a New South Wales government that could most charitably be described as laissez-faire in its public health approach. Under current rules there will be no crowd caps
column3: no requirement to wear masks aside from a few indoor areas
column4: and no check-in required with the government app
column5: which presumably means vaccination certificates will not be checked on entry. A large attendance is expected. So England’s players turn out for the crowd again
column6: despite a week of shambolic preparation and the barrage of distraction from the situation they are in
column7: with a team unchanged bar one bowling selection from the surrender in Melbourne. In fairness
column8: there is little else on the selection front that could be done. The bigger question is how they can possibly find some confidence or motivation to tackle the rest of this series
column9: rather than simply hoping to get it over with. The Australians in contrast should be less affected
column10: coming into the fourth Test with the buoyancy of the first three when almost every move has paid off. Aside from replacing Head for one match
column11: that team will be unchanged from a position of strength rather than weakness
column12: with Scott Boland retained after his dramatic debut with the ball at the MCG.

column1: Ultimately
column2: the Test will be seen as sport fulfilling its purpose as a means of distraction for people who want to stop thinking about problems outside the ground. Sport is always more than that
column3: inextricably part of its wider world
column4: and this match cannot be divorced from its context. It should be seen
column5: too
column6: for illustrating the way cricket’s richest countries treat each other
column7: as opposed to those outside their tiny club. But it is happening. Sydney is
column8: most of all
column9: a town of glitz and cash
column10: where success matters more than how it is achieved. The show will always go on.";https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/jan/04/ashes-continue-too-much-money-at-stake;4

column8: 'Ballet'];"When people talk about modernising classic ballets

column6: 'US economy'];"Just six years ago Forbes magazine declared her the “the world’s youngest self-made female billionaire” and the “next Steve Jobs”. Now
column7: Elizabeth Holmes
column9: founder of the collapsed blood testing company Theranos
column10: is facing decades in prison after being found guilty of conspiring to defraud her investors out of billions. Holmes
column11: a university dropout with no medical training

column17: the company – which at one point was valued at more than $9bn (£6.6bn) – collapsed in 2018. On Monday a California jury convicted Holmes of four counts of wire fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud. Holmes had set her sights on becoming an inventor at an early age. column18: who co-founded Fleischmann’s Yeast

column23: she founded Theranos in 2003. Brimming with self-confidence
column24: she convinced her parents to let her drop out of university and cash in an education trust they had set up for her. She used it to rent a lab and hire her first employee. Holmes’s desire to improve medical testing was driven by a familial aversion to needles

column26: ‘OK

column29: while the person watches

column31: ” she told the New Yorker in 2014 for a profile that said she had the potential to “upend the lucrative business of blood testing”. Holmes
column32: who helped engineer the comparisons to her idol
column33: Jobs
column34: by dressing in black turtlenecks

column36: she said getting a blood test should be easier
column37: quicker and cheaper. It should be
column38: she said
column39: “a wonderful” experience. “We see a world in which no one ever has to say

column41: ” she told the Washington DC audience. “The right to protect the health and wellbeing of every person
column42: of those we love
column43: is a basic human right. Yet in the United States today
column44: healthcare is the leading cause of bankruptcy and the lack of it the leading cause of … finding out too late in the disease progression process that someone you love is really
column45: really sick.” The top comment under the video on YouTube says: “She did a better job playing Steve Jobs than Ashton Kutcher” (Kutcher played Jobs in the 2013 biopic Jobs.) “Here was a photogenic

Holmes’s tall tales started to unravel in 2015 – soon after Theranos hit its record $9bn valuation – when the Wall Street Journal reporter John Carreyrou began an investigation into the validity of the company’s tests. When Carreyrou went to Holmes for comment for his story

column8: 'Monarchy'];"Where does Prince Andrew drive to in his brand new
column10: 000 Range Rover – seemingly his only appearances these days in anything that could be considered the outside world? The duke is often pictured motoring broodingly out of his Royal Lodge home in Windsor at the wheel of this high-performance vehicle
column11: perhaps making his in-car security detail listen to a podcast about putting

column15: 000 deal with Epstein

column28: many committed anti-royalists in the UK

But in the event that Giuffre’s case against Andrew proceeds and he loses it
column30: and a multimillion-dollar payment has to be made
column31: you get the feeling public attitudes would change overnight if the maternal bailout ran to forking out Andy’s damages for him. You can imagine people who are quite happy for the Queen to spend money restoring obscure Scottish castles and whatnot suddenly feeling less relaxed about it being spaffed on paying blood money for a sex offender. Whatever the accounting

column33: that’s enough banging on about Andy’s mama. Not that I haven’t very much enjoyed the recent articles by gentlemen of a certain age who have FINALLY found a woman they care about in the long-running Epstein story. Unsurprisingly

column39: grooming and trafficking teenage girls for sex with Epstein
column40: not that you’d know it from the airtime still bafflingly given on both sides of the Atlantic to those such as her brother Kevin Maxwell. Ah

column42: sorry

column45: and a fraud trial acquitted him of having a clue about it. So I think broadcasters can spare audiences his “insights” on anything else

column48: alas
column49: is the ongoing sound of silence where the mention of other men’s names should be. Despite the saga rumbling on for years

column51: and absolutely no indication that anyone in law enforcement cares enough to find out now that they have got their woman. I can’t help feeling those hoping Ghislaine will name names for clemency are being pretty optimistic. Given that Ghislaine believes Epstein was murdered in jail

column10: 'Gender'];"Women who are operated on by a male surgeon are much more likely to die
column11: experience complications and be readmitted to hospital than when a woman performs the procedure
column12: research reveals. Women are 15% more liable to suffer a bad outcome
column13: and 32% more likely to die
column14: when a man rather than a woman carries out the surgery
column15: according to a study of 1.3 million patients. The findings have sparked a debate about the fact that surgery in the UK remains a hugely male-dominated area of medicine and claims that “implicit sex biases” among male surgeons may help explain why women are at such greater risk when they have an operation. “In our 1.3 million patient sample involving nearly 3
column16: 000 surgeons we found that female patients treated by male surgeons had 15% greater odds of worse outcomes than female patients treated by female surgeons
column17: ” said Dr Angela Jerath
column18: an associate professor and clinical epidemiologist at the University of Toronto in Canada and a co-author of the findings. “This result has real-world medical consequences for female patients and manifests itself in more complications
column19: readmissions to hospital and death for females compared with males. “We have demonstrated in our paper that we are failing some female patients and that some are unnecessarily falling through the cracks with adverse
column20: and sometimes fatal
column21: consequences.” The findings have been published in the medical journal JAMA Surgery. Jerath added: “These results are concerning because there should be no sex difference in patient outcomes regardless of the surgeon’s sex. “On a macro level the results are troubling. When a female surgeon operates
column22: patient outcomes are generally better
column23: particularly for women
column24: even after adjusting for differences in chronic health status
column25: age and other factors
column26: when undergoing the same procedures. Jerath and her colleagues analysed the records of 1
column28: 108 patients in Ontario who underwent 21 common surgical procedures performed by 2
column29: 937 surgeons between 2007 and 2019. They ranged from hip and knee replacements and weight loss surgery to removal of an appendix or gall bladder and more complicated operations such as a heart bypass
column30: aneurysm repair and brain surgery. For each of the 1.3m operations they analysed
column31: the sex of each patient and details of how their procedure had gone and also the sex of the surgeon who carried it out. They found that men who had an operation had similar outcomes regardless of whether their surgeon was male or female (an exception being significantly decreased mortality for men
column33: when the surgeon was female). However
column34: women experienced better outcomes if the procedure had been performed by a female surgeon compared with a male surgeon. There were no gender differences in how surgery went for either men or women operated on by a female surgeon. Jerath added that while “there are some excellent male surgeons who consistently have good outcomes
column35: what is concerning is that this analysis does signal some real difference among male and female surgeons overall where practice can impact general patient outcomes”. The researchers said the study was the first of its kind to examine the association between the sex of the patient
column36: the sex of their surgeon and the outcomes of surgery. They looked at three types of “adverse postoperative outcome”: death
column37: readmission to hospital and complications within 30 days. They found that for women
column38: treatment by a male surgeon was associated with a 15% increased likelihood of a poor outcome than if they were treated by a female surgeon. However
column39: men experienced similar results in most post-operative outcome categories whether they were treated by a male or female surgeon. Similarly
column40: women who were operated on by a male surgeon had a 32% higher risk of death than those whose surgery had been performed by a woman. For example
column41: while 1.4% of women who had a cardiothoracic operation with a male surgeon died
column42: fewer – 1% – did so when a female surgeon was involved. In both brain surgery and vascular surgery
column43: while 1.2% of women who underwent either type of operation with a male surgeon died
column44: again that proportion was much lower among those whose surgeon was female – 0.9% – giving a 33% higher risk of death. Overall
column45: female patients also had a 16% greater risk of complications and an 11% greater risk of readmission and were 20% more likely to have to stay in hospital longer when treated by male surgeons
column46: compared to female surgeons. Women had a higher risk of death
column47: readmission or complications when a man performed the operation across many of the 21 types of surgery analysed. For example
column48: while 20.2% of women who had cardiothoracic (chest) surgery by a male surgeon suffered some form of adverse reaction
column49: a lower percentage – 18% – did so if their surgeon was female. The same pattern was seen in general surgery
column50: brain surgery and orthopaedic surgery. Technical differences between male and female surgeons are unlikely to explain the findings “as both sexes undergo the same technical medical training”
column51: said Jerath.

column1: “Implicit sex biases”
column2: in which surgeons “act on subconscious
column3: deeply ingrained biases
column4: stereotypes and attitudes”
column5: may be one possible explanation
column6: she said. Differences in men’s and women’s communication and interpersonal skills evident in surgeons’ discussions with patients before the operation takes place may also be a factor
column7: she added. And “differences between male and female physician work style
column8: decision-making and judgment”. Fiona Myint

column11: ” she said. Parenthood
column12: “a lack of flexibility in [surgical] training schedules and rotas” and “negative attitudes to less than full-time training” all explain why many women do not become consultant surgeons
column13: she added. Scarlett McNally

column18: including steps they should take to improve their chances of a good outcome

column21: nurses

column2: 'UK news'];"Mountain rescue teams have urged day trippers to properly plan their walks after an “absolutely chaotic” Christmas period and warnings of blizzards on the way. A rescue group in the Lake District said there were 11 callouts during Christmas week

column6: 'World news'];"Police in India have detained a woman accused of organising a fake online auction in which hundreds of prominent female Muslims were put up “for sale” on a website. There were shock waves of anger and disgust in India after it emerged that a website calling itself Bulli Bai
column7: an offensive term for Muslims

column9: including journalists
column10: academics
column11: activists
column12: scholars and artists

It is the second recent incident where Muslim women in India have been harassed by being “sold” online
