column1: 408;408;5655;5655;Listen to the teachers – we have a plan to keep classrooms open and pupils safe | Rachael Warwick;2022-01-04T13:00:12Z;['Rachael Warwick'];['Coronavirus'
column2: 'Education'
column3: 'Schools'
column4: 'UK news'];"This is not the start to the new year that any of us teachers in England had hoped for: increasing Omicron case numbers and ongoing uncertainty about how this will play out have created a nervous start for us all. As someone responsible for 350 staff working across three schools in south Oxfordshire I continue to be extremely concerned for their health
column5: safety and wellbeing. As someone responsible for 2
column6: 700 children and young people I continue to prioritise their entitlement to an education. School leaders have spent the past 21 months of the pandemic balancing these two concerns.

column1: The greatest risk to schools remaining fully open this term is the absence of staff who have to self-isolate because of contracting the virus. Many schools were up against it at the end of last term
column2: forced to combine classes and to use an increasing number of cover staff and supply teachers (if they could find them) to keep classes running and year groups open. I am extremely doubtful that sufficient numbers of retired teachers will return to the profession this term to create the number of extra staff who may be needed. What more can be done to support schools and colleges? Quite a lot
column3: actually. The government should provide ventilation units
column4: free of cost
column5: to all settings that need them: the 7
column6: 000 announced on Sunday will not be enough. Schools and colleges should be reimbursed for the additional sums they are spending on supply teachers
column7: as well as other Covid-related costs
column8: from already strained budgets. Ofsted should automatically agree to requests to defer inspections this term as school and college leaders are focused
column9: quite rightly
column10: on managing a crisis situation. Parents and families should ensure their children and young people test twice a week at home
column11: without fail – and we need plentiful supplies of lateral flow tests to distribute to our families to enable them to do this. Exam results tables should be removed again this summer: schools up and down the country have been differently affected by the pandemic at different times
column12: and this will continue to be the case. It’s not fair or appropriate to pretend that we have worked on a level playing field this year.

column1: School and college leaders have shown great leadership throughout the pandemic and will continue to do so. We prioritised keeping our schools open for our most vulnerable children and the children of key workers: our three schools have not been closed at any point during the national lockdowns. We pivoted from remote education to mass testing to managing the process of centre-assessed grades. We continue to be agile and responsive to a fast-changing situation
column2: communicating well and regularly with our staff
column3: students and families
column4: providing reassurance and grounded optimism. There has been much talk about “a lost generation” of children
column5: victims of the Covid pandemic. I refuse to believe that any generation should or will be “lost”. Instead of indulging in hyperbole
column6: perhaps those with the power to make decisions could throw themselves behind those of us on the frontline working to keep young people in school
column7: to maintain their entitlement to an education
column8: to protect their health and wellbeing and to open doors to their futures. There is surely no more compelling call to arms
column9: no more important investment in our future than this. Rachael Warwick is executive headteacher at Ridgeway Education Trust";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/04/headteacher-new-term-england-covid-omicron-schools;6

column1: 409;409;5656;5656;Pushing Buttons: what you’re going to be playing in 2022;2022-01-04T12:45:12Z;['Keza MacDonald'];['Games'
column2: 'PlayStation 5'
column3: 'Xbox'];"Welcome to Pushing Buttons
column4: the Guardian’s brand new gaming newsletter. If you’d like to receive it in your inbox every week
column5: just pop your email in below – and check your inbox (and spam) for the confirmation email.

column1: Well done everyone
column2: we made it through to 2022. Has anyone else’s brain lost the ability to distinguish between “holiday at home with the kids” and “lockdown at home with the kids”? After 14 days ‘off’ I am very ready to be somewhere completely silent
column3: and perhaps be able to play a video game for longer than 20 minutes without either being asked for a snack
column4: or falling asleep. There’s a lot to look forward to this year
column5: not least all the big games that we were supposed to be playing in 2021. There are so many open-world timesinks
column6: especially
column7: that I don’t know how anyone is supposed to fit all of them in. If you want to know what I will be doing in late February and the entirety of March
column8: the answer is Elden Ring. Dark Souls meets Breath of the Wild! Get it in my veins! Speaking of Breath of the Wild
column9: the sequel to the most expansive (and
column10: in my opinion
column11: the greatest) Zelda game will be out sometime this year as well. Then there’s Horizon: Forbidden West
column12: a game about a flame-haired female warrior fighting robot dinosaurs
column13: a game that I’m pretty sure I made up in my dreams at the age of 11. Somehow I almost forgot about Starfield
column14: the first big Bethesda game since Fallout 4
column15: an explorable sci-fi universe that I still know tantalisingly little about. Will Mass Effect finally have some competition? – – – Traditionally it takes a few years for new games consoles to bed in
column16: and for developers to really explore what they can achieve with the technology. Though the Xbox Series X and the PlayStation 5 had a few standouts last year
column17: by the end of 2022 there’s going to be a proper catalogue of new blockbusters. Of course
column18: actually buying a new console to play them on is still
column19: more than a year after launch
column20: a total scramble. Supply-chain issues and huge demand as a result of ongoing global lockdowns have contributed to a scarcity that has had people frantically hitting refresh on Amazon and Game restocks
column21: mindful that they’ll all be sold out again in minutes (or snapped up by bots
column22: to be resold on eBay at an infuriating mark-up). This problem is likely to persist through 2022
column23: Sony’s CFO Hiroki Totoki has admitted. It’s never been so difficult to buy into the next generation of video games. But then: do you really need to? I have always felt that buying a games console in the first year or two of its life is only necessary if you get a real kick out of technological novelty. For most people
column24: there is no rush. We are long past the time when games became unplayably aged after a few years on the shelves. Though only a few games from my 90s childhood could be unreservedly recommended today – pity anybody coming fresh to GoldenEye on the N64
column25: with its bizarre single-stick controls and muddy graphics – pretty much all of the best games of
column26: say
column27: 2010 are a) still just as good and b) still available to buy. Sometimes I rather miss the thrill I used to get from tracking down a coveted retro game on eBay
column28: or from digging through baskets of cartridges in Japanese game stories in the late 00s and coming across a copy of some obscure sumo-wrestling game I once saw in a copy of Super Play. But it’s also undeniably a good thing that you can instantly download or even stream the vast majority of games released in the last decade
column29: when we used to have to go to such lengths. The video games industry is obsessed with the new. As a technology-driven art form
column30: new tech has always been part of the deal. But now more than ever
column31: it’s not what defines games. If you’ve not got a next-gen console yet
column32: you’re not missing out on much. 95% of the joy of this medium is available to you regardless. What to play

column1: Over the Christmas break I dipped into a few games that I hadn’t found time for over the course of the year
column2: and one that stood out was Unpacking
column3: the story of a life told through the act of moving house. Each chapter presents you with a diorama of a home (a childhood bedroom
column4: a college dorm
column5: a cosy one-bed)
column6: into which you must somehow fit all of the stuff jumbled into your cardboard boxes. I found this game soothing – it has an implied narrative that is quite sweet
column7: if also very predictable – until I started playing with my partner
column8: who methodically Tetrised everything on to shelves and surfaces however they would fit
column9: like a psychopath. Given that one of this game’s themes is how to fit your possessions (and therefore your life) in around someone else’s
column10: it felt appropriate that we were low-level arguing about how to arrange a virtual kitchen. Available on: Nintendo Switch
column11: PC
column12: Xbox One/Series X/S
column13: PC Approximate playtime: 3.5 hours What to read The games industry is busy in-fighting over NFTs
column14: the latest solution-to-a-problem-that-doesn’t-exist from the techbro universe
column15: and also one of the most depressing trends I have encountered in all my years covering this business. Ubisoft has introduced them to its games
column16: but nobody wants to buy them. Square-Enix’s CEO has declared his hopes that they become a major trend
column17: which seems rather ambitious as they have yet to be proven useful for anything except Internet flexing. Having spent several months gaining a better understanding of NFTs and cryptocurrency this year
column18: and listened to a few developers evangelise them (and more developers spit fury over them)
column19: I have found no better summary than this Gawker piece about the total soul-deadening dumbness of the entire scene as it stands: “world-altering technology is now in the hands of a culture so aesthetically and spiritually impoverished that it should maybe go back to telling stories around the cooking fire for a while
column20: just to remember how to mean something.” You’ve read the Guardian’s 10 games to look forward to in 2022
column21: right? It is becoming a running joke that every year
column22: about half of the games on it fail to actually come out in the year they’re supposed to. A full 6 of the 10 games I picked for the 2021 list are still unreleased
column23: and one of the 2020 games to watch still isn’t finished. Anyway
column24: if you are looking for more games to look forward to and then be disappointed by when they entirely fail to materialise
column25: Polygon has put out a list of 50. What to click The 10 best video games coming in 2022 Riot Games to pay $100m to settle gender discrimination lawsuit As a parent obsessed with my kids’ safety
column26: I have discovered the video game from hell How playing the video games of your youth reconnects you to yourself Question Block Because everyone is still recovering from their New Year’s hangover
column27: I’m in the hot seat for Question Block. This week
column28: reader Lawal Muhammad asks: Which recent games made you feel happiest/most content while playing them? For me there are three kinds of game that give me happy brain chemicals: anything involving playing to music (Guitar Hero
column29: Tetris Effect
column30: Rez)
column31: which induce a kind of flow-state euphoria; games with predictable
column32: repetitive
column33: gentle rhythms that you can sink right into (Animal Crossing
column34: Stardew Valley
column35: old-school Harvest Moon)
column36: which create a sense of safety; and absolutely mad nonsense that makes me laugh and gives me something unexpected
column37: feeding my insatiable need for novelty. So the games that made me happiest recently were Psychonauts 2
column38: a game about delving into people’s brains that brought a delightfully weird buffet of different game concepts
column39: visual gags and in-jokes to the table
column40: and It Takes Two
column41: a genre mashup about a divorcing couple that completely changes itself around every hour or so. If you’ve got a question for the next Question Block

column3: 'Sex'
column4: 'Men'
column5: 'Relationships'];I have enjoyed a long-distance relationship with my partner for five years. We are both male and used to enjoy a healthy sex life
column6: often enjoying the time we were together
column7: knowing we would not see each other for a few weeks. Sex seemed to be a reciprocal
column8: affectionate adventure that occasionally included a third person to spice things up. We have since moved in together and now it seems that I am the one doing all the work. Most of the initiation and certainly all of the imagination
column9: seems to be coming from me. I don’t feel he is attracted to me or interested in me physically any more. This weekend
column10: he wanted to go out to a gay sauna
column11: but I didn’t
column12: so he went alone. Which would be fine if we were enjoying a healthy sex life
column13: but we’re not. So the open part has now replaced our own intimate life. I feel that this is a significant change. He won’t talk about it
column14: other than to say I am being insecure
column15: hypocritical or unreasonable. To be honest
column16: I have doubted myself because I too have enjoyed the benefits of the open relationship but only when they were the icing on the cake
column17: not the cake itself. How do I reignite our own sex life? Your disappointment at the lack of ease you are experiencing in segueing into this new phase is understandable
column18: but
column19: for now
column20: you will have to lower your expectations. Such a significant change in a relationship typically requires time and careful negotiation. There is probably nothing wrong with your sex life itself – you just need to discuss your individual needs and desires and try to reach a workable understanding. Some couples are better off not living together
column21: but it is too early to know if you meet that criteria. In addition
column22: all kinds of extra issues arise in open relationships and you will have to tackle these one at a time. Be very specific in your negotiations: you could suggest for example
column23: “Could we agree to take turns initiating sex?” Many relationships – of all types – fail when one partner feels the unspoken contract is an unfair one. And sexual interest can be lowered due to the accompanying underlying resentment. It would be best to address it
column24: gently
column25: as soon as possible. Pamela Stephenson Connolly is a US-based psychotherapist who specialises in treating sexual disorders. If you would like advice from Pamela on sexual matters
column26: send us a brief description of your concerns to private.lives@theguardian.com (please don’t send attachments). Each week

column2: 'Coronavirus'
column3: 'World news'];"The French government has heavily criticised opposition MPs after a parliamentary debate on the proposed introduction of a “vaccine pass” was unexpectedly suspended after members of the Assemblée nationale voted with a show of hands to go home. The move came after seven hours of often-heated exchanges on Monday
column4: when ministers clashed with critics over the controversial measure due to be introduced on 15 January
column5: but now postponed. Government spokesperson Gabriel Attal on Tuesday accused opposition MPs of playing politics and halting the adoption of what he said were “essential measures … in an urgent situation”. He said the government would push on with the controversial legislation. The proposal is to turn the current “health pass” requiring either vaccination
column6: recovery from Covid or a negative Covid test into a “vaccine pass” requiring people to be fully vaccinated if they wish to access restaurants
column7: bars
column8: museums
column9: cinemas
column10: theatres
column11: long distance trains
column12: hotels and many other public places. Hospitals and health establishments would not require a “vaccine pass”. The debate
column13: which began on Monday afternoon
column14: was due to continue into the early hours of Tuesday and there were more than 500 amendments still to be debated when the parliamentary session was suspended shortly before midnight.

column1: Earlier
column2: the prime minister
column3: Jean Castex

column7: but we will not give in to panic
column8: ” the health minister
column9: Olivier Véran
column10: told MPs. Facing vehement attacks from the far right Rassemblement National (RN) and far left La France Insoumise (France Unbowed – LFI) over the infringement of civil liberties
column11: Véran added “selfishness often hides behind talk of supposed liberties”. Most MPs from Emmanuel Macron’s centrist La République en Marche (La REM) party and the mainstream opposition Les Républicains (LR) support the measure. “Last night we saw a form of irresponsible friendship being formed with the MPs of La France Insoumise
column12: the Rassemblement National and LR to derail the timetable for the adoption of the vaccine pass
column13: ” Attal told France Inter radio. “The vaccine pass has to come into effect as quickly as possible
column14: ” Attal added. Far left presidential candidate Jean-Luc Mélenchon of LFI
column15: who had called for the new legislation to be rejected
column16: accused the government of having “sown indescribable chaos because of your short-sightedness” and accused Véran of “arrogance”. He called for “a global plan” and poured scorn on “measures on those who have the right to eat popcorn or drink their coffee standing or sitting”. Critics also accused the government
column17: which is one-seat short of an absolute parliamentary majority
column18: of amateurism after it found itself without enough MPs present in the lower house to defeat the vote to suspend. Alexis Corbière of LFI said members of the governing party were to blame for the stalemate. “LREM MPs weren’t sufficiently mobilised last night and found themselves in a minority. It’s absolutely their fault

column21: 000) fines.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/04/french-opposition-mps-criticised-after-vaccine-pass-debate-suspended;1

column2: pleasure and pain;2022-01-04T12:30:12Z;['Alim Kheraj'];['Pop and rock'
column3: 'Music'
column4: 'Culture'
column5: 'Theatre'
column6: 'Stage'];"When Norwegian pop star Metteson was 18
column7: he had an experience at a festival that made him understand the visceral impact music can have. While Emeli Sandé was performing Heaven
column8: he kissed the boy he’d had a crush on for ages. “I wasn’t on drugs but I was as high as I’ve ever been and I had what was sort of my first sexual experience
column9: ” he says. “But the day after
column10: I got brutally dumped when he told me that he was in love with someone else. The picture of the night before exploded and cracked.” Feeling jilted
column11: he went to watch Lana Del Rey: “She sang Summertime Sadness and I was crying all alone. Both those of those songs have stuck with me. They’re emotional triggers and I wallow in them. I just love when music really pushes experiences to another level.” Metteson’s own music feels destined to soundtrack similar scenes. Now 28
column12: he creates kaleidoscopic pop that is unashamedly grand and theatrical. His debut EP
column13: 2021’s Convince Me
column14: flirted with the Scandinavian synth melancholia popularised by Robyn and the Knife
column15: while also pulling from the arty chamber pop of Patrick Wolf as well as Whitney Houston and George Michael. His most recent single
column16: the sumptuous Under Your Shirt
column17: is a symphonic yet tender devotional that perfectly captures the sparks of intimacy and the heart-pounding ache of yearning.

column1: “I tried early on to make more compact melodies and cool club music
column2: ” says Metteson
column3: “but I would whack on a big refrain because that’s what the emotion calls for. I’m not a whispery
column4: cool and gritty singer. Whether that big refrain comes packaged as a club banger or a piano ballad
column5: I want it to be a representation of myself.” Born Sverre Breivik and raised in the coastal town of Moss in Norway
column6: Metteson – the name literally meaning the son of Mette
column7: his mother – was always a creative kid. He was enrolled in various theatre and music groups and later studied at the National Academy of the Arts in Oslo. “I was a triple threat
column8: ” he laughs. “I was the loud
column9: musical theatre kid
column10: and I really think I bring a lot of that into my music now.” Since graduating
column11: he has worked as a repertory actor at the National Theatre in Bergen. When we speak
column12: he is just finishing up a run as Prior Walter in Tony Kushner’s Aids epic Angels in America – “one of the first shows that I ever saw and thought that there was a place for me in the world of theatre
column13: ” he adds. “It’s been a big deal for me.” Metteson initially struggled with his sexuality. “I can remember knowing from a very early age that I was different and that I liked boys; wearing women’s clothing and sensing that was
column14: in some way
column15: wrong
column16: ” he recalls. He remained closeted until he moved to Oslo to study. “It wasn’t a prison
column17: but I regret it. Now I’m discovering the joy and the pleasures of being young.” His new music
column18: due in the coming months
column19: is evidence that he has taken that leap: building on the grandeur of Under Your Shirt
column20: songs like Never Let Me Go and the baroque Second Heart run on melodrama and escapism. He also supports fellow Norwegian pop star Aurora on her UK tour this spring
column21: a chance for British audiences to get a taste of that newfound freedom in action with his sensual performances (think a poppier Perfume Genius). “I think I make music that’s made to be experienced live
column22: ” he says. “I hope that I can blow people away with a perfect pop experience.”";https://www.theguardian.com/music/2022/jan/04/metteson-the-norwegian-theatre-kid-embracing-pop-pleasure-and-pain;5

column7: 'UK news'];"Burger King UK is to launch vegan nuggets nationwide from Wednesday as the fast food chain evolves its meat-focused menu to cash in on the booming popularity of plant-based diets. The chain

column11: is made from soy and plant proteins only and tastes the same as its meat originals.

column1: Burger King
column2: which last year launched a Vegan Royale burger that is prepared separately from animal products

column4: ” said the Burger King UK chief executive

The bakery chain Greggs has experienced huge success with its push into vegan foods

column1: 4) Racism is given out A month ago

column7: it has leaked over 180
column8: 000 gallons of petroleum into the groundwater aquifer that provides drinking water for over 400
column9: 000 residents and visitors from Hālawa to Hawaiʻi Kai. Despite its longstanding threat to water systems
column10: this decrepit facility has been in use until operations were “paused” in late November
column11: after hundreds of military families reported rashes
column12: headaches
column13: nausea
column14: vomiting – symptoms of petroleum poisoning. The Navy denied these facts for days. “We have no immediate indication that the water is unsafe to drink
column15: ” their representatives said

column17: pregnant women and nursing moms – that “my staff and I are drinking the water on base.” Hawai‘i’s Health Department finally stepped in
column18: advising Navy water system users not to drink their tap water. Navy officials still refuse to acknowledge that this is a crisis. It views the Governor’s emergency order to de-fuel the Red Hill Facility as a mere “request
column19: ” and has enlisted top Navy lawyers to make sure its 600m liters of petroleum stay perched above our water supply. A military spouse in our legal proceedings this week sobbed as she described the family dog rejecting its water dish for days. Another mother teared up as she remembered her infant child vomiting constantly after the Navy advised that her water was safe (it wasn’t); their own beloved and once-healthy dog had to be put down
column20: after thousands of dollars could not diagnose its sudden debilitating illness. The Navy’s Assistant Secretary
column21: in his subsequent remote testimony from the nation’s capital

column24: provide free college for all

column26: and deadly
column27: machine. Not even Hawai‘i’s federal delegation has been to stand up to this mighty power. Their long-due request to the US federal government has been milquetoast: we need more studies

column6: 'World news'];"The transformation of the rapidly warming Arctic is being accelerated by a wave of thousands of newcomers that are waddling and paddling northwards: beavers. Scientists who sought to map the spread of beavers in Alaska were astounded to find that the creatures have pushed far north into previously inhospitable territory and are now set to sweep into the furthest northern extremities as the Arctic tundra continues to heat up due to the climate crisis.

column1: “We didn’t know what we would find and ended up being very surprised
column2: ” said Ken Tape
column3: an ecologist at the University of Alaska
column4: Fairbanks
column5: who co-authored the new research. “There are areas of Alaska that had no evidence of beavers 50 years ago that are now apparently saturated with them
column6: ” he said
column7: adding: “It’s just a matter of time before they head even further north. When you consider this is likely happening across the rest of the Arctic in Canada and Russia
column8: that gives you an idea of the scope of this change.” Using aerial photographs and satellite imagery reaching back to 1949
column9: and observations recorded from before then
column10: an international team of researchers involved in the Arctic Beaver Observation Network identified more than 12
column11: 000 ponds created by beavers damming rivers and streams across western Alaska. This number has doubled in the past 20 years. In recent years
column12: as the Arctic has heated up three times quicker than the global average
column13: the North American beaver has ventured north and west and now occupies vast swaths of the Seward peninsula
column14: a large landmass that extends from the western coast of Alaska. The impact of these portly semiaquatic rodents has been felt by the remote Indigenous communities of Alaska
column15: with the flooded areas created by beavers causing concern over access to food and travel. It’s unknown how many beavers are now in the northern and western parts of Alaska
column16: with estimates ranging from 50
column17: 000 to close to 100
column18: 000. “The true impact of the spread of beavers into the Arctic on the environment and the Indigenous communities who live there is not yet fully known
column19: ” said Helen Wheeler
column20: a researcher at Anglia Ruskin University. “However
column21: we do know that people are concerned about the impact beaver dams are having on water quality
column22: the numbers of fish downstream of the dams
column23: and access for their boats.” A broader consequence of the arrival of beavers could be the acceleration of the climate change which
column24: in combination with a reduction in fur trapping over the past century
column25: has probably allowed the beavers to push north. Beavers
column26: which do not hibernate
column27: have benefited from shortening winters and the wider availability of vegetation available to feed upon. The pools that accumulate when beavers dam rivers create localized unfrozen “hotpots” that result in the thawing of permafrost
column28: the always-frozen ground of the Arctic that holds vast amounts of carbon. Scientists warn that a widespread thawing of permafrost could cause global heating to spiral dangerously out of control. “Those ponds absorb heat better
column29: they change the hydrology of the area and the permafrost responds to that
column30: ” said Tape. “Beavers are coming in from the outside
column31: imposing themselves on the ecosystem and disrupting it. “It’s accelerating the effects of climate change. When you realize what’s happened in western Alaska is likely to happen to northern Alaska
column32: it does give you pause.” Tape said that the Brooks Range
column33: a mountain range that runs across northern Alaska
column34: will be an obstacle to the beavers but will not stop them as they follow rivers up to the north coast. Further research is under way.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/04/beavers-arctic-north-climate-crisis;3

column5: 'US news'];"An Ohio high school student has filed a lawsuit against his former school and sports coaches after they forced him to eat a pepperoni pizza against his religion. The 17-year old student

As a result

column13: 'Society'];Four former ministers and a serving secretary of state will be cross-examined this year in a potentially politically explosive climax to the four-year Grenfell Tower public inquiry. Eric Pickles
column14: the former secretary of state for communities
column15: Brandon Lewis

column17: and the former housing minister Gavin Barwell will face hours of questioning over claims Conservative-led governments prioritised a “bonfire of red tape” over safety. Senior politicians are likely to be interviewed on how they responded to direct warnings about safety in high-rise blocks from the commissioner of the London fire brigade just weeks before the disaster. James Wharton
column18: a former junior minister and close ally of Boris Johnson
column19: and Stephen Williams
column20: a former Liberal Democrat junior minister
column21: are also expected to give evidence in person. Over three months
column22: the inquiry will turn the spotlight from the actions of combustible materials manufacturers and the consultants and builders involved in the council block’s disastrous refurbishment
column23: to the government that pursued – lawyers for the bereaved claim – “a political ideology which broke free from common sense and safety constraints”. Michael Gove
column24: the secretary of state for levelling up

column26: has already admitted the government “failed people at Grenfell” and told MPs that “on a couple of occasions” it had “not necessarily appreciated the importance of fire safety and not necessarily done everything in the wake of the Lakanal House tragedy [a 2009 tower block fire where six people died] that it should have done.” While the inquiry will look at the actions of governments going back to the 1990s
column27: a principal context will be what David Cameron described in 2012 as his government’s “resolution to kill off the health and safety culture for good”. The bereaved have called for Cameron to give evidence to explain his policy
column28: but the inquiry has not asked him to do so and Lord Pickles will field important questions Pickles was Cameron’s cabinet minister in charge of building safety from 2010 to 2015
column29: and will be asked why the government failed to overhaul fire regulation guidance despite an instruction to do so by the coroner on the Lakanal House fire. The ambiguity of the guidance
column30: which remained in place at the time of the Grenfell disaster on 14 June 2017
column31: was a significant factor in allowing companies and consultants to use combustible materials
column32: the inquiry has heard. In one letter disclosed to the inquiry
column33: Pickles is shown assuring the coroner there would be a “future review” but arguing “fire protection in buildings is a complex subject and should remain
column34: to some extent
column35: in the realm of professionals”. Lawyers for the bereaved have argued the government became the “junior partner” in a relationship with the housebuilding industry
column36: which allowed companies too much control over standards. In 2011 Pickles launched the “red tape challenge” to slash bureaucracy facing business. In the budget that year a new rule was introduced that required a waiver for any change to the building regulations. The inquiry will examine internal Whitehall documents showing how in 2015
column37: a civil service briefing for the then housing minister Lord Wharton
column38: was explicit that the review had been postponed “whilst the department focused its attention on other priorities including the red tape challenge”. Only “lip service” was paid to the commitment to the coroner to review the regulations
column39: Anne Studd QC

Pickles has so far told the inquiry in a statement he does not recall “the potential industry use of combustible materials in external cladding systems was ever raised with me”. Pickles is also likely to be questioned on his resistance to introducing sprinklers as a safety measure
column41: which the Fire Brigades Union has told the inquiry would have saved lives at Grenfell. In October 2013

column44: adding £13
column45: 000 to the cost of building a new home”. In fact

column47: 000. The inquiry may ask where he got his numbers from. In February 2014
column48: Lewis
column49: a junior minister under Pickles at the time
column50: told parliament that “sprinklers work” but referred to a “one in two out” rule as part of the coalition’s red tape policy and said: “In that context … we want to exhaust all non-regulatory options before we introduce any new regulations.” Ministers are also likely to be asked about their dealings with Sir David Amess
column51: the Tory backbencher who was killed in October. In 2014 Amess chaired the all-party parliamentary fire safety and rescue group

It said: “Should a major fire tragedy with loss of life occur between now and 2017 … where the matters which had been raised here were found to be contributory to the outcome

column63: by that time policing and fire minister

column1: 428;428;5675;5675;Will the hundreds of Capitol rioters in court ever be held truly accountable?;2022-01-04T11:00:10Z;['Nick Robins-Early'];['US Capitol attack'
column2: 'Republicans'
column3: 'US news'
column4: 'US politics'];"It’s been one year since a mob of Donald Trump supporters stormed the United States Capitol
column5: as the “stop the steal” rally demanding to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election turned into a deadly insurrection. After the attack
column6: the Department of Justice and Federal Bureau of Investigation mobilized one of the largest criminal investigations in American history. Those efforts have so far resulted in more than 700 federal cases and counting
column7: with more suspects expected to be charged. But for all that we have learned about the insurrection and the people who took part in it
column8: crucial questions remain about the fallout of the attack for the far right and what it means to hold its perpetrators accountable. Federal prosecutors want the arrests and convictions of those responsible to act as a deterrent against extremism and future attempts to undermine democracy
column9: experts say
column10: but despite more than 150 guilty pleas so far
column11: the legacy of 6 January is already contentious. A judicial debate has emerged over the appropriate sentencing for rioters
column12: while trials in the coming months will test whether prosecutors can secure convictions on more serious charges facing far-right extremists.

column1: The fundamental understanding of what happened on 6 January is also being increasingly contested
column2: as Republican lawmakers and rightwing media attempt to whitewash the events and reframe the insurrection as an act of justified political protest. More than any court case
column3: researchers say
column4: this revisionist narrative may have long-lasting implications for the far right and for political violence in America. The suspects In the months after the insurrection
column5: law enforcement officials investigated hours upon hours of videos from the day
column6: thousands of social media profiles and hundreds of thousands of tips from the public. They have arrested hundreds
column7: sometimes raiding homes where suspects had stockpiled weapons and ammunition. As the arrests rolled in
column8: researchers began to get a more complete picture of who was involved in the attack. The people charged came to Washington DC from nearly every state in the union
column9: and ranged from teenagers to senior citizens. Beyond sharing a fervent support for Trump and belief in election conspiracies
column10: no single profile has emerged. Overall the suspects are overwhelmingly male – about 80% according to research from George Washington University’s project on extremism – and the average age is 39. The vast majority of suspects are white. Many belonged to far-right militias and white nationalist groups that played an outsize role in the attack
column11: but most had no direct affiliations with extremist organizations. “They’re sort of your nextdoor neighbor
column12: ” said Kurt Braddock
column13: an assistant professor of communication at American University and extremism researcher. “It shows how far far-right ideologies have extended.” There were white-collar workers
column14: people who came with their family members and a cross-section of other Trump supporters radicalized into committing political violence. Many believed in the QAnon conspiracy movement that viewed Trump as a messianic figure who would return to office and destroy a cabal of liberal elite pedophiles. The charges and sentencing Although the charges range from misdemeanors such as trespassing to violent assaults against Capitol police officers
column15: the bulk of cases that have come in front of a judge so far have involved individuals pleading guilty to minor charges. Except for some high-profile rioters – including “QAnon shaman” Jacob Chansley
column16: who was sentenced to 41 months in prison after pleading guilty to a felony charge of obstructing Congress – most of the sentences doled out have not exceeded several weeks in prison. Many of the rioters have received no jail time at all
column17: instead receiving fines or probation. There have been significant differences between how US district court judges have approached sentencing and cases. One group of judges has questioned why prosecutors are seeking jail time for misdemeanor offences such as trespassing on Capitol grounds. US District Judge Trevor McFadden
column18: a Trump appointee
column19: made comparisons between Black Lives Matter protesters and the 6 January attackers and told a defendant that he was “acting like all those looters and rioters last year”.(McFadden did
column20: however
column21: later reject a defendant’s claim that he was being treated unfairly compared with leftist protesters in Portland.) Other judges have vehemently rejected the comparison to BLM
column22: and have insisted that participants in the riot face serious consequences for their involvement. US District Judge Tanya Chutkan stated that the siege was an unprecedented attempt to “violently overthrow the government” and “stop the peaceful transition of power”. Chief US District Judge Beryl Howell questioned why prosecutors were letting rioters accept lighter misdemeanor plea deals and lamented that “the government has essentially tied the sentencing judge’s hands”. “No wonder parts of this public are confused about whether what happened on 6 January at the Capitol was simply a petty offense of trespassing
column23: with some disorderliness
column24: or was shocking criminal conduct that posed a grave threat to our democratic norms
column25: ” Howell said. The more complex cases and serious charges will probably go to trial in the coming months
column26: researchers say
column27: including those involving members of the Proud Boys
column28: Oath Keepers
column29: Three Percenters and other far-right militias. One member of the Oath Keepers
column30: Jason Dolan
column31: already admitted as part of a plea deal that he traveled with other militia members and stashed an M4 rifle at a Comfort Inn a short drive outside the Capitol. In December
column32: 34-year-old Matthew Greene became the first member of the Proud Boys to plead guilty in a felony conspiracy case
column33: with prosecutors stating that he and other Proud Boys coordinated their actions using programmable radios and dressed to conceal their affiliation with the group. After the riot
column34: Greene allegedly ordered more than 2
column35: 000 rounds of assault-rifle ammunition
column36: bragged that his group “took the Capitol” and told a friend to study guerrilla warfare and be ready to “do uncomfortable things”.

column1: The criminal trials this spring for felony charges such as obstructing Congress and a multi-defendant conspiracy case against members of the Oath Keepers may reveal new details about the level of coordination and planning that went into the attack on the Capitol. But they will probably also present difficulties for prosecutors. The government has already succeeded in dismissing some pre-trial defense objections
column2: such as whether the common charge of “corruptly obstructing an official proceeding” was unconstitutionally vague
column3: but more challenges will come. “It’s going to get complicated very quickly
column4: ” said Seamus Hughes
column5: deputy director of the program on extremism at George Washington University. “You’re going to get into uncharted water with this prosecution at some point
column6: just by the sheer number.” The investigation The FBI received more than 250
column7: 000 tips related to the siege
column8: including family members turning in relatives and Facebook friends reporting old high school acquaintances. One suspect
column9: New York state’s Robert Chapman
column10: told a match on the dating app Bumble that he had stormed the Capitol and bragged about making it all the way to the National Statuary Hall. “We are not a match
column11: ” the other Bumble user replied
column12: according to court filings
column13: before sending a screenshot of their exchange to law enforcement. More than 80% of cases cite some form of social media as evidence for the charges
column14: but the FBI’s investigation goes far beyond relying on amateur online sleuths and combing through social media profiles. Law enforcement has also used invasive technology and surveillance tactics that could expand law enforcement powers and have implications for future investigations. In addition to using facial recognition software to identify rioters
column15: itself a deeply controversial practice
column16: law enforcement appears to have expanded its use of geofencing search warrants – a process that involves using data from digital services to locate people within a certain area during a given time period. In practice
column17: it means that authorities can demand Google hand over anonymized user location data
column18: then ask for specific users’ private information
column19: including their names
column20: emails and phone numbers. Dozens of Capitol rioter cases cite Google location data in their court filings
column21: according to a Wired investigation. “It’s going to set a precedent for geofencing
column22: ” Hughes said. “If they can get enough successful prosecutions … that will be something that’s used in future investigations.” The FBI’s use of surveillance has come under additional scrutiny in recent weeks after a New York Times investigation found that the bureau deployed surveillance teams to monitor Portland activists’ protests against policing
column23: a move that civil rights groups condemned as domestic spying. Whitewashing the attack As the FBI has carried out its investigation
column24: there has been a parallel effort to create a different narrative of the insurrection. Republican politicians and conservative media have been on a months-long campaign to whitewash the attack on the Capitol. Over the past year they have settled on a story that presents 6 January as a largely peaceful protest for legitimate election grievances
column25: sometimes baselessly claiming that any violence was the result of antifa or leftist infiltrators. Prime-time Fox News host Tucker Carlson in November aired a three episode special entitled Patriot Purge that uncritically interviewed rightwing activists with ties to the white nationalist movement
column26: who claim that the FBI investigation is an unjust political crackdown on conservatives. Carlson states in it that there is a leftist “purge aimed at legacy Americans” and features sympathetic interviews with people who took part in the insurrection. Two Fox News contributors quit over the special
column27: with one suggesting that it would lead to violence. Many of the rioters have embraced a burgeoning celebrity status within the far right. Some suspects refer to themselves as “1/6ers”
column28: and have launched online fundraising campaigns where they identify as political protesters and victims of government persecution. One collective fundraising page for the approximately 40 suspects being held in pre-trial detention has already raised hundreds of thousands of dollars and sells hoodies emblazoned with the slogan “free the 1/6ers.” Other high-profile suspects have created individual pages to capitalize on their notoriety. Richard “Bigo” Barnett
column29: a self-described white nationalist who stole a document from speaker of the house Nancy Pelosi’s office and was photographed putting his boots up on her desk
column30: launched a fundraising site that doubles as a manifesto for his anti-government views.

column1: “Richard Barnett’s picture at Speaker Pelosi’s desk has become the face of the new anti-federalist movement
column2: ” Barnett’s website states on its fundraising page. “We will not go gently into that good night. Click below to donate to the fight.” The group being held in pre-trial detention at the Correctional Treatment facility in Washington DC has also banded together while incarcerated
column3: calling themselves the “Patriot Wing” and attempting to become far-right influencers. These suspects include numerous members of extremist groups such as the Proud Boys and Oath Keepers
column4: as well as others facing more serious charges of violence and conspiracy related to the insurrection. They have started writing open letters and reportedly passed around a handwritten newsletter in the jail
column5: in which they boast about reciting the pledge of allegiance and singing the national anthem together. Some Republican lawmakers have amplified this far-right narrative that the suspects being held in pre-trial detention are political prisoners and unjustly suffering for their beliefs. Representatives including Marjorie Taylor Greene
column6: Paul Gosar
column7: Matt Gaetz and Louie Gohmert have rallied in support of insurrection suspects and staged an attempt to visit the jail
column8: claiming a conspiracy to mistreat the prisoners and that their detention was evidence of Marxism and totalitarianism. Meanwhile
column9: more mainstream Republican lawmakers have stonewalled a House committee investigation into the roots of the attack
column10: and Trump allies have refused to cooperate with subpoenas.

column1: All these developments – the solidifying of in-group identity among the more dedicated insurrections
column2: the financial support for rioters and Republican lawmakers’ willingness to paint them as martyrs – concerns extremism researchers about the long-term effects of 6 January. Even if those responsible face significant prison sentences
column3: there is little incentive for them to de-radicalize once incarcerated. “You may get to a point where folks who spend their time in jail come out and are basically provided a kind of a rockstar status within the movement
column4: ” Hughes said. The revisionist history of 6 January has also correlated with a declining interest among Republicans in punishing those involved. After the insurrection there was wide bipartisan support for prosecuting rioters
column5: but a Pew Research Center study in September found the number of Republicans who believe it is important to hold those responsible legally liable for their actions significantly declined over the course of the year. Involvement in the events of 6 January is also apparently not disqualifying for Republicans seeking public office. At least 10 people who attended the Washington rally have now been elected to various positions
column6: according to HuffPost
column7: including three in state legislatures. What concerns some extremism researchers is that while it’s critical for prosecutors to secure convictions for those involved in the insurrection
column8: these broader problems remain of how deeply embedded the far right has become in American politics. Even if authorities may be better prepared against future rallies aimed at subverting the democratic process
column9: the reaction from rightwing media and some Republican lawmakers has threatened to legitimize far-right ideology and resorting to political violence to achieve their goals. “January 6 exemplified what the far right is now
column10: ” Braddock said. “But it definitely doesn’t end with January 6.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/04/will-capitol-rioters-be-held-accountable;2

column5: 'UK news'];"Go-Ahead has halted the trading of its shares on the London Stock Exchange after the train and bus operator failed to file its financial results because of issues surrounding a £25m breach of Southeastern’s railway franchise agreement. The transport group
column6: which was stripped of the contract to operate the commuter network in September

column1: 430;430;5677;5677;‘Quite incredible’: some of world’s rarest camellias discovered in Yorkshire;2022-01-04T10:50:20Z;['Mark Brown'];['Plants'

column3: 'Heritage'
column4: 'UK news'
column5: 'The National Trust'
column6: 'North of England'];"Horticultural experts have compared it to finding a wondrous and unknown library of rare first editions
column7: said the head gardener of Wentworth Woodhouse
column8: Scott Jamieson
column9: recalling the discovery of camellias believed to be some of the oldest and rarest in the western world. The important shrubs have been identified in a dilapidated glass and brick building on the estate of Wentworth Woodhouse
column10: a spectacular Georgian palace near Rotherham in South Yorkshire
column11: which is the subject of one of the UK’s biggest heritage restoration projects. The huge house and gardens are gradually revealing their secrets
column12: one of the most eye-catching of which has been the discovery of the camellia house. “It is quite incredible
column13: ” said Jamieson
column14: who has been at Wentworth Woodhouse for 17 years. “There are very few camellia houses left anywhere
column15: certainly not one with a great collection of historic camellias.”

column1: For many years the building
column2: with jagged glass likely to fall at any point
column3: was too dangerous to go into. That glass roof has been removed
column4: allowing access to the 200-year-old camellias. The shrubs were imported for wealthy families in the 18th century on merchant ships belonging to the East India Company. The camellias were
column5: wrongly
column6: judged so precious and fragile that they needed to be pampered in a building with lots of light and a stove to heat the brick walls. There are 19 camellia shrubs in total
column7: with the oldest believed to have arrived in 1792. That makes it older than any in the nationally important camellia collection at Chiswick House in London and a contender to be the oldest anywhere in the west. With the help of Chiswick House and others
column8: three varieties have been identified and the detective work continues to find out more. It was about two years ago that Jamieson began trying to work out what the building was. He sent a plaintive callout to people who might know and a number of experts came in and were amazed. “They said it was almost like having a library of first editions … it’s that important in gardening history. So it’s wonderful.” The survival of the camellia house is all the more remarkable given it spent decades only feet away from an open cast mine
column9: which began operating in the 1940s. It was a lunar-like landscape
column10: said Jamieson
column11: who has recently led a project restoring the original pathways to the gardens. “It would have been a strange environment
column12: I imagine
column13: you would have had a hacking cough and stinging eyes with that amount of pollution in the air. And it would have been noisy.” Two hundred years ago it would have been a very different story
column14: with the ladies gathering in the camellia house to drink tea
column15: gamble and smoke when the men were out hunting. The plan now is to develop the site into a specialist tea house and a community cafe. It is hoped it will open in 2022. Wentworth Woodhouse remains one of the nation’s most spectacular stately homes most people have never heard of.

column1: To say that Wentworth Woodhouse is “over the top” is almost an understatement. It is twice as wide as Buckingham Palace
column2: has 124
column3: 600 sq ft of living space
column4: three acres of roofs
column5: a room for every day of the year and is often described as Britain’s biggest house. The entire house would once have screamed opulence and excess
column6: the walls lined with important paintings – notably George Stubbs’s Whistlejacket
column7: now a star of the National Gallery. The volunteer guide Steve Ash says it hides in plain sight. “It’s lovely when you see young people come
column8: because very often this is the first time they’ve been to a place like this. Then they realise it is on their doorstep. It is absolutely a proper hidden gem.” The property was in a terrible state when it was bought for £7m in 2016 by the Wentworth Woodhouse Preservation Trust – established after a campaign by a local business owner
column9: Julie Kenny. It is now the subject of a restoration project that could easily cost more than £250m. The house was given £4.6m of levelling up money by the chancellor
column10: Rishi Sunak
column11: in his October budget. That money will enable work to begin this year on the house’s vast stable block
column12: a building so grand that some people assume it’s the main house.";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/04/quite-incredible-some-of-worlds-rarest-camellias-discovered-in-yorkshire;3

column3: 'Asia Pacific'
column4: 'World news'];A North Korean defector who made a daring return to his home country at the weekend had reportedly struggled to build a new life in South Korea since his arrival just over a year ago. The man
column5: who has not been named
column6: crossed the heavily armed demilitarised zone [DMZ] that has divided North and South since the end of the 1950 to 1953 Korean war
column7: on Saturday. Reports said the defector
column8: who is in his 30s
column9: had been prompted to make the dangerous journey back across the border after struggling to make ends meet in the South. His decision to return to North Korea has raised questions about how defectors are treated in the South
column10: where many face discrimination in employment
column11: education and housing. The North has not publicly commented on the man – one of about 30 double-defectors who have returned to their home country from the South in the past decade – but has acknowledged receipt of messages from the South Korean military about his escape
column12: the Yonhap news agency said. A South Korean military official confirmed that the man
column13: who had worked as a cleaner
column14: appeared to have been experiencing financial difficulties. “I would say he was classified as lower class
column15: barely scraping a living
column16: ” the official said. Officials said they had no reason to believe the man had been spying for the North and have launched an inquiry into how he was able to negotiate a barbed wire fence running along the 248km (155-mile)-long border
column17: which is dotted with landmines and patrolled by troops around the clock
column18: despite being caught on surveillance cameras hours earlier. After fleeing North Korea in November 2020
column19: the man identified himself as a former gymnast and told investigators that he had crawled over barbed wire fences to reach the South
column20: according to a defence ministry statement. An official at the South Korean unification ministry
column21: which is responsible for cross-border affairs
column22: said the man had received resettlement support from the government for his personal security
column23: housing
column24: medical treatment and employment since arriving in the South via the same eastern section of the DMZ. He had been spotted throwing away his belongings the day before he fled the South
column25: Yonhap said. “He was taking out a mattress and bedding to rubbish dumps that morning
column26: and it was strange because they were all too new
column27: ” a neighbour told Yonhap. “I thought about asking him to give it to us
column28: but ended up not doing that
column29: because we’ve never said hello to each other.” More than 33
column30: 000 North Koreans have defected to the South since the late 1990s – the vast majority via China and south-east Asia – to escape political persecution
column31: food shortages and poverty. While some
column32: such as the national assembly member Ji Seong-ho
column33: go on to become highly successful in the wealthy
column34: democratic South
column35: many others struggle to find well-paid work. About 56% of defectors are categorised as being on low incomes
column36: according to unification ministry data
column37: and nearly 25% are in the lowest bracket – making them eligible for basic livelihood subsidies – six times the ratio of the general population. In a survey released last month by the Database Center For North Korean Human Rights and NK Social Research in Seoul
column38: about 18% of 407 defectors polled said they were willing to return to the North
column39: most of them citing nostalgia for the country they had left behind. “There is a complex range of factors
column40: including longing for families left in the North
column41: and emotional and economic difficulties that emerge while resettling
column42: ” the unification ministry official said. “The government has been continuing efforts to improve our support programmes to help them better resettle in the South.”;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/04/double-defector-who-returned-to-north-korea-struggled-financially-in-south;1

column4: 'US news'
column5: 'California'
column6: 'Silicon Valley'];"Elizabeth Holmes
column7: founder of Theranos
column8: has been found guilty on four of 11 charges of fraud
column9: concluding a high-profile trial that captivated Silicon Valley and chronicled the missteps of the now-defunct blood testing startup. The jury found Holmes guilty of several charges – including conspiracy to defraud investors – following a dramatic day in which jurors said they remained deadlocked on three of the criminal counts she faced.

column1: On Monday
column2: the seventh day of deliberations
column3: the jury told US district judge Edward Davila that it was unable to reach a unanimous verdict on those three charges. In response
column4: Davila encouraged them to deliberate further
column5: but jurors later returned and rendered their final decision. As the verdict was read
column6: the Theranos founder bowed her head
column7: remained seated and expressed no visible emotion. Her partner
column8: Billy Evans
column9: showed agitation in earlier moments but appeared calm during the verdict reading. Holmes was found guilty on four charges: one count of conspiracy to defraud investors
column10: and three counts of wire fraud against investors. Holmes was meanwhile acquitted on three charges
column11: including one conspiracy to defraud patients and two charges related to patients who received inaccurate test results. One charge was thrown out earlier in the trial
column12: and the jury did not come to a verdict on the remaining three charges. The verdict seals Holmes’ extraordinary rise and fall and could have wide-ranging consequences for the tech industry. It also marked an indictment of the hype machine that helped rocket Holmes to fame
column13: as she graced the covers of major magazines
column14: headlined conferences
column15: and drew comparisons to Apple’s Steve Jobs. The split verdicts are “a mixed bag for the prosecution
column16: but it’s a loss for Elizabeth Holmes because she is going away to prison for at least a few years”
column17: said David Ring
column18: a lawyer who has been following the Holmes case closely. Holmes
column20: faces prison time
column21: although a sentencing date has not been set. She pleaded not guilty and is expected to appeal. After the judge left the courtroom to meet with jurors individually
column22: Holmes got up to hug her partner Billy Evans and her parents before leaving with her lawyers. Over the course of nearly four months
column23: federal prosecutors called 29 witnesses
column24: outlining missteps and alleged fraud Holmes committed during her 15-year reign as CEO. Holmes founded the company after dropping out of Stanford at 19 years old
column25: promising a revolutionary technology that could run hundreds of health tests on just a drop of blood. But the company ultimately fell short of its ambitious pledge. Once a charismatic figure
column26: Holmes was initially hailed as a visionary. As Theranos grew
column27: the company attracted big-name investors including the former secretaries of state George Shultz and Henry Kissinger. At its height
column28: Theranos was valued at more than $9bn. But cracks in the glossy surface began to show in 2015 when Wall Street Journal reporting revealed that its in-house tests had massive inaccuracies
column29: and that the company was performing other tests using traditional blood drawing methodology and outside labs. The fall of Theranos has been followed with perhaps even more fervor than its spectacular rise
column30: inspiring multiple documentaries
column31: a feature film
column32: and an upcoming television show. Starting in late August
column33: throngs of reporters have lined up in the early morning hours for a seat inside the federal court house in San Jose
column34: California. During the trial
column35: prosecutors painted a picture of Holmes as a strict
column36: power-hungry leader willing to go to any lengths to save her company’s image
column37: repressing internal and external dissent and manipulating the press. “She chose fraud over business failure
column38: ” prosecutor Jeff Schenk said in his closing arguments. “She choose to be dishonest with investors and patients. That choice was not only callous
column39: it was criminal.” As witnesses
column40: the prosecution called forward Theranos lab directors who testified that their concerns over the technology’s shortcomings were largely ignored. Meanwhile
column41: investors such as the former US secretary of defense James Mattis said he and others were discouraged from scrutinizing the company for fear of missing out on opportunities.

column1: The defense team for Holmes sought to counter that image by portraying Holmes as an ambitious entrepreneur who did not knowingly commit fraud
column2: but rather did not understand the shortcomings of Theranos’ complex technology. Those arguments came to a head when Holmes made the stunning decision to take the stand in her own defense
column3: arguing she made decisions in good faith and did not knowingly commit fraud. Prosecutors repeatedly pointed to documents that Holmes admitted to doctoring before sharing with potential partners
column4: adding the logos of pharmaceutical firms and falsely implying they had endorsed the methodology. “I wish I hadn’t done that
column5: ” she told the jury on the stand. Her defense team stated in closing arguments that the logo evidence was “a distraction” and that Holmes was in talks with those companies at the time. Her attorneys also put forward a line of defense that Holmes was abused by her former romantic and business partner Sunny Balwani
column6: who served for ten years as co-president of the company. “There was another side of Holmes’s relationship with Balwani that the public never saw
column7: ” said defense attorney Lance Wade in opening arguments
column8: adding that “trusting [Balwani] as her primary adviser was one of her mistakes”. Some of the most powerful moments in the trial came when Holmes testified directly about Balwani’s alleged abuse
column9: growing emotional as the prosecution called on her to read their romantic texts. She claimed he controlled what she did
column10: who she spent time with
column11: and even what she ate in an effort to turn her into a successful CEO. Balwani has strongly denied claims of mistreating Holmes. He faces his own trial in 2022 for fraud. Holmes did not respond to questions lobbed at her during a walk from the courthouse to the nearby hotel on Monday where she has stayed during jury deliberations. In a written statement
column12: the US attorney Stephanie Hinds thanked the jury for navigating the case through the pandemic and said Holmes must now be held “culpable” for her crimes. Holmes will remain free on bond while awaiting sentencing
column13: which will be determined by the judge. The Associated Press contributed reporting";https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/jan/03/elizabeth-holmes-trial-jury-finds-theranos-founder-guilty-on-four-counts;2

column1: 434;434;5681;5681;The next US civil war is already here – we just refuse to see it;2022-01-04T10:00:12Z;['Stephen Marche'];['The far right'
column2: 'Republicans'
column3: 'US politics'
column4: 'US news'];"Nobody wants what’s coming
column5: so nobody wants to see what’s coming. On the eve of the first civil war
column6: the most intelligent
column7: the most informed
column8: the most dedicated people in the United States could not see it coming. Even when Confederate soldiers began their bombardment of Fort Sumter
column9: nobody believed that conflict was inevitable. The north was so unprepared for the war they had no weapons. In Washington
column10: in the winter of 1861
column11: Henry Adams
column12: the grandson of John Quincy Adams
column13: declared that “not one man in America wanted the civil war or expected or intended it”. South Carolina senator James Chestnut
column14: who did more than most to bring on the advent of the catastrophe
column15: promised to drink all the blood spilled in the entire conflict. The common wisdom at the time was that he would have to drink “not a thimble”.

column1: The United States today is
column2: once again
column3: headed for civil war
column4: and
column5: once again
column6: it cannot bear to face it. The political problems are both structural and immediate
column7: the crisis both longstanding and accelerating. The American political system has become so overwhelmed by anger that even the most basic tasks of government are increasingly impossible. The legal system grows less legitimate by the day. Trust in government at all levels is in freefall
column8: or
column9: like Congress
column10: with approval ratings hovering around 20%
column11: cannot fall any lower. Right now
column12: elected sheriffs openly promote resistance to federal authority. Right now
column13: militias train and arm themselves in preparation for the fall of the Republic. Right now
column14: doctrines of a radical
column15: unachievable
column16: messianic freedom spread across the internet
column17: on talk radio
column18: on cable television
column19: in the malls. The consequences of the breakdown of the American system is only now beginning to be felt. January 6 wasn’t a wake-up call; it was a rallying cry. The Capitol police have seen threats against members of Congress increase by 107%. Fred Upton
column20: Republican representative from Michigan
column21: recently shared a message he had received: “I hope you die. I hope everybody in your family dies.” And it’s not just politicians but anyone involved in the running of the electoral system. Death threats have become a standard aspect of the work life of election supervisors and school board members. A third of poll workers
column22: in the aftermath of 2020
column23: said they felt unsafe.

column1: Under such conditions
column2: party politics have become mostly a distraction. The parties and the people in the parties no longer matter much
column3: one way or the other. Blaming one side or the other offers a perverse species of hope. “If only more moderate Republicans were in office
column4: if only bipartisanship could be restored to what it was.” Such hopes are not only reckless but irresponsible. The problem is not who is in power
column5: but the structures of power. The United States has burned before. The Vietnam war
column6: civil rights protests
column7: the assassination of JFK and MLK
column8: Watergate – all were national catastrophes which remain in living memory. But the United States has never faced an institutional crisis quite like the one it is facing now. Trust in the institutions was much higher during the 1960s. The Civil Rights Act had the broad support of both parties. JFK’s murder was mourned collectively as a national tragedy. The Watergate scandal
column9: in hindsight
column10: was evidence of the system working. The press reported presidential crimes; Americans took the press seriously. The political parties felt they needed to respond to the reported corruption. You could not make one of those statements today with any confidence. ••• Two things are happening at the same time. Most of the American right have abandoned faith in government as such. Their politics is
column11: increasingly
column12: the politics of the gun. The American left is slower on the uptake
column13: but they are starting to figure out that the system which they give the name of democracy is less deserving of the name every year. An incipient illegitimacy crisis is under way
column14: whoever is elected in 2022
column15: or in 2024. According to a University of Virginia analysis of census projections
column17: 30% of the population will control 68% of the Senate. Eight states will contain half the population. The Senate malapportionment gives advantages overwhelmingly to white
column18: non– college educated voters. In the near future
column19: a Democratic candidate could win the popular vote by many millions of votes and still lose. Do the math: the federal system no longer represents the will of the American people. The right is preparing for a breakdown of law and order
column20: but they are also overtaking the forces of law and order. Hard right organization have now infiltrated so many police forces – the connections number in the hundreds – that they have become unreliable allies in the struggle against domestic terrorism.

column1: Michael German
column2: a former FBI agent who worked undercover against domestic terrorists during the 1990s
column3: knows that the white power sympathies within police departments hamper domestic terrorism cases. “The 2015 FBI counter-terrorism guide instructs FBI agents
column4: on white supremacist cases
column5: to not put them on the terrorist watch list as agents normally would do
column6: ” he says. “Because the police could then look at the watchlist and determine that they are their friends.” The watchlists are among the most effective techniques of counter-terrorism
column7: but the FBI cannot use them. The white supremacists in the United States are not a marginal force; they are inside its institutions. Recent calls to reform or to defund the police have focused on officers’ implicit bias or policing techniques. The protesters are
column8: in a sense
column9: too hopeful. Activist white supremacists in positions of authority are the real threat to American order and security. “If you look at how authoritarian regimes come into power
column10: they tacitly authorize a group of political thugs to use violence against their political enemies
column11: ” German says. “That ends up with a lot of street violence
column12: and the general public gets upset about the street violence and says
column13: ‘Government
column14: you have to do something about this street violence
column15: ’ and the government says
column16: ‘Oh my hands are tied
column17: give me a broad enabling power and I will go after these thugs.’ And of course once that broad power is granted
column18: it isn’t used to target the thugs. They either become a part of the official security apparatus or an auxiliary force.” Anti-government patriots have used the reaction against Black Lives Matter effectively to build a base of support with law enforcement. “One of the best tactics was adopting the blue lives matter patch. I’m flabbergasted that police fell for that
column19: that they actually support these groups
column20: ” German says. “It would be one thing if [anti-government patriots] had uniformly decided not to target police any more. But they haven’t. They’re still killing police. The police don’t seem to get it
column21: that the people you’re coddling
column22: you’re taking photographs with
column23: are the same people who elsewhere kill.” The current state of American law enforcement reveals an extreme contradiction: the order it imposes is rife with the forces that provoke domestic terrorism. Just consider: in 2019
column24: 36% of active duty soldiers claimed to have witnessed “white supremacist and racist ideologies in the military”
column25: according to the Military Times. ••• At this supreme moment of crisis
column26: the left has divided into warring factions completely incapable of confronting the seriousness of the moment. There are liberals who retain an unjustifiable faith that their institutions can save them when it is utterly clear that they cannot. Then there are the woke
column27: educational and political elites dedicated to a discourse of willed impotence. Any institution founded by the woke simply eats itself – see TimesUp
column28: the Women’s March
column29: etc – becoming irrelevant to any but a diminishing cadre of insiders who spend most of their time figuring out how to shred whoever’s left. They render themselves powerless faster than their enemies can. What the American left needs now is allegiance
column30: not allyship. It must abandon any imagined fantasies about the sanctity of governmental institutions that long ago gave up any claim to legitimacy. Stack the supreme court
column31: end the filibuster
column32: make Washington DC a state
column33: and let the dogs howl
column34: and now
column35: before it is too late. The moment the right takes control of institutions
column36: they will use them to overthrow democracy in its most basic forms; they are already rushing to dissolve whatever norms stand in the way of their full empowerment. The right has recognized what the left has not: that the system is in collapse. The right has a plan: it involves violence and solidarity. They have not abjured even the Oath Keepers. The left
column37: meanwhile
column38: has chosen infighting as their sport. There will be those who say that warnings of a new civil war is alarmist. All I can say is that reality has outpaced even the most alarmist predictions. Imagine going back just 10 years and explaining that a Republican president would openly support the dictatorship of North Korea. No conspiracy theorist would have dared to dream it. Anyone who foresaw
column39: foresaw dimly. The trends were apparent; their ends were not. It would be entirely possible for the United States to implement a modern electoral system
column40: to restore the legitimacy of the courts
column41: to reform its police forces
column42: to root out domestic terrorism
column43: to alter its tax code to address inequality
column44: to prepare its cities and its agriculture for the effects of climate change
column45: to regulate and to control the mechanisms of violence. All of these futures are possible. There is one hope
column46: however
column47: that must be rejected outright: the hope that everything will work out by itself
column48: that America will bumble along into better times. It won’t. Americans have believed their country is an exception
column49: a necessary nation. If history has shown us anything it’s that the world doesn’t have any necessary nations.

column1: The United States needs to recover its revolutionary spirit
column2: and I don’t mean that as some kind of inspirational quote. I mean that
column3: if it is to survive
column4: the United States will have to recover its revolutionary spirit. The crises the United States now faces in its basic governmental functions are so profound that they require starting over. The founders understood that government is supposed to work for living people
column5: rather than for a bunch of old ghosts. And now their ghostly constitution
column6: worshipped like a religious document
column7: is strangling the spirit that animated their enterprise
column8: the idea that you mold politics to suit people
column9: not the other way around. Does the country have the humility to acknowledge that its old orders no longer work? Does it have the courage to begin again? As it managed so spectacularly at the birth of its nationhood
column10: the United States requires the boldness to invent a new politics for a new era. It is entirely possible that it might do so. America is
column11: after all
column12: a country devoted to reinvention. Once again
column13: as before
column14: the hope for America is Americans. But it is time to face what the Americans of the 1850s found so difficult to face: The system is broken
column15: all along the line. The situation is clear and the choice is basic: reinvention or fall.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/04/next-us-civil-war-already-here-we-refuse-to-see-it;5
