column7: 'World news'];"There is the kernel of a good idea in this second world war drama: a Gestapo officer (Sebastian Roché) in occupied France is invited to a dinner at a Côte d’Azur villa where the serving staff are
column8: unbeknown to him
column9: the rebel radio broadcaster (Cary Elwes)
column10: dissidents and Jewish fugitives he has been hunting all along. Unfortunately
column11: Matthew Hill and Landon Johnson’s timid film fails to fully capitalise on this uncomfortable scenario and misses opportunities elsewhere
column12: instead going big on self-satisfied pieties about fighting the just fight.

column1: Elwes’s Jacques is the gravelly voice of freedom in wartime Lyon
column2: bidding insurgents over the airwaves to “stay safe” from his garret. But when his daughter Juliet (Greer Grammer) is almost caught filching a radio vacuum tube
column3: she takes refuge in the office of Swiss financier Andre (Jason Patric). Her desperation is unrefusable – and her debutante looks don’t harm her either. Soon
column4: with chief goose-stepper Klaus Jager closing in
column5: Andre agrees to smuggle her and her household-in-hiding to his Mediterranean mansion.

column1: Resistance: 1942 has English-language dialogue throughout
column2: with – weirdly – only the Nazis doing “Cherman” inflections. (Having the French characters follow suit would probably have been too ’Allo ’Allo!) By far the most damagingly inauthentic thing
column3: though
column4: is Elwes’ oddly detached
column5: borderline-parodic performance. Maybe the impish presence he showcased in The Princess Bride would have been a perverse fit here if the film had dug more deeply into what a life of subterfuge means in practice
column6: culminating in his dissembling butler at the reception. But we learn little about Jacques
column7: and Elwes starches his turn with so much caricatural stiff upper lip
column8: ’Allo ’Allo! might in fact have been his primary research material. As written here
column9: the ambiguous Andre – who channels Nazi money – is a much more interesting character; a kind of Oskar Schindler lite. Patric’s inscrutable performance recedes intriguingly while Elwes over-reaches
column10: suggesting a man locked in internal combat. But beyond facile montages in which Jacques’ radio addresses uplift no one in particular

column1: 436;436;5683;5683;My new year’s resolution: to savour magic of playing as much five-a-side as possible;2022-01-04T09:50:33Z;['Elis James'];['Football'
column2: 'Sport'];"I look back at my list of failed New Year’s Eve resolutions with detached amusement. A few were vain attempts to improve myself (realistically
column3: was I going to learn the harmonica or grow my own beetroot?)
column4: some reflected my concerns at the time (“I probably should touch it less
column5: just in case it does drop off”) and as I aged others felt simple but somehow unachievable (eg 2018’s “have a shower before the school run”). My new year’s resolution for this year
column6: however
column7: will be achieved. Quite simply
column8: it’s to play as much five-a-side as possible. Like most football fans
column9: I’ve been playing the game for as long as I can remember. I grew up with loads of kids my own age on an estate of starter homes
column10: which – coupled with a local primary school headteacher who thought that homework damaged children – created the perfect conditions to play football every day. I commentated on the matches we played in the park
column11: I commentated on the kickabouts played in the hall of my friend’s house: “And the ball’s taken a wicked deflection off the Yellow Pages! LOOK AT HIS FACE
column12: JUST LOOK AT HIS FACE!” Growing up in west Wales
column13: where to PE teachers rugby union was king and football wasn’t played in lessons
column14: I took part in unofficial matches between schools organised by the pupils. Football’s enforced absence during the pandemic has restored my enthusiasm to these teenage levels. In fact
column15: to levels of eagerness not seen since Ian Rush played for Juventus.

column1: Although I never played 11-a-side Sunday League football
column2: I did play in a competitive five-a-side league for most of my 20s. This saw levels of hostility I hadn’t expected before signing up. A bloke squared up to me during one game and said that he’d knock me out in the car park
column3: even though I was turning out for a regional gas pipe company and he was representing the call centre of a big insurance firm – all that pent-up aggression and we weren’t even playing in one of the big utility company derbies that are so common at Tuesday night five-a-side. “It’s EDF versus British Gas here at Cardiff Powerleague
column4: AND IT’S LIVE.” As much as I loved playing
column5: and my mind often returns to goals I scored in those games more than 15 years ago
column6: that very angry bloke (who signed off with the brilliantly 1960s insult of “you longhaired freak”) is a good example of what I’m trying to avoid in the games I now play in as a man in my 40s. The right ethos is essential. I already play in one game where the attitude is perfect
column7: but having played so little in 2020 a match a week just doesn’t feel like enough any more. If I’m asked to make up the numbers for somebody else
column8: finding out if shinpads are usually worn is a good indicator of what the game will be like. Friends I’ve played with since primary school will confirm that I’ve never thrown myself into tackles like Bryan Robson during a World Cup group game
column9: but at 41 I don’t want to have my tib and fib broken by some meathead from Kent who works in recruitment and no longer loves his wife. As a self-confessed luxury player (trans: genetically unable to get stuck in
column10: a lot of what I try doesn’t come off
column11: the talent I do have is largely unappreciated in England) I would ideally like to play with nine other people who are a laugh and slightly less good than I am
column12: so I can score lots of goals and kid myself as I drive home that I could have played at a higher level.

column1: This is the magic of playing football. I’ve interviewed professional footballers who haven’t kicked a ball since they retired
column2: and yet when I kick the ball I could be 11 again. All the people I play with are the same. The only difference is that I now wear the boots my mum wouldn’t buy me in 1991 because they were too expensive
column3: and I’ve come to accept that
column4: age-wise
column5: I’ve progressed from being “a senior pro” to “elder statesman of the dressing room” to “can his creaking limbs cope with one more campaign” to “club legend devastated to have contract terminated” before settling finally into the “young manager has new ideas” phase of my life. Thankfully
column6: I’m usually playing against people closer in age to Eddie Howe than Erling Haaland. Five-a-side is the most accessible format of the world’s most popular sport
column7: and as football is so ubiquitous
column8: most players have a certain degree of competence. I love riding my bike
column9: but when I’m cycling to Tesco to buy an onion and some AAA batteries I don’t kid myself that what I’m doing is the same as Geraint Thomas gritting his teeth during the Alpe d’Huez stage of the Tour de France. But even though I know it’s not true
column10: a goal being lashed in with your weaker foot
column11: an intelligent lay-off to a teammate
column12: dribbling past an off-balance full-back will make me think: ‘Yes. I am Ferenc Puskas and I somehow slipped through the net.’ And then I will trip over my own feet or the ball will bounce off my shin and I will concede that actually: ‘I think the net was probably right to let me drift off into the Irish Sea.’

column1: I have watched too many American football documentaries where the coach will tell his young players that if they fail to make the high school play-offs
column2: this will be the final game they ever take part in. There is no real comparable NFL equivalent to five-a-side. Thankfully though
column3: the kind of football I like can be played into old age. If you ask me
column4: I will play. Just don’t expect me to track back.";https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2022/jan/04/my-new-years-resolution-to-savour-magic-of-playing-as-much-five-a-side-as-possible;7

column6: 'Health'];"The head of the influential Doherty Institute

column8: has added her voice to the growing chorus of experts who are calling for rapid Covid tests to be provided free of charge in Australia

As the Morrison government defended its failure to secure sufficient rapid antigen tests to deal with the surging national test demand
column11: the deputy chief health officer
column12: Dr Sonya Bennett

column1: “Where we’re seeing … in younger people

column26: 738 cases of Covid recorded nationally on Tuesday

column28: 000. Hospitalisation rates have almost doubled in the past week up to 2
column30: with 184 of those in intensive care. All states expect WA reported new record highs
column31: with NSW reporting 23
column32: 131 infections

column34: 020 and Queensland 5699. There were 3
column35: 246 cases in South Australia
column36: 926 in the ACT
column37: 702 in Tasmania

column39: with staff shortages exacerbated by furloughing contributing to an “exhausted” workforce. More than 2

column41: and Guardian Australia reported on Tuesday that some workers who had tested positive were being called in to work if asymptomatic. Testing sites continue to be overwhelmed
column42: with clinic closures across the country adding pressure to already strained pathology services. The demand for take-home testing kits

column44: is being hampered by supply constraints. But the strain on the health and testing network is expected to worsen
column45: with Bennett saying the experience of the Omicron wave overseas was for a “short sharp rise” in infections. She said case numbers would probably keep rising for several weeks before plateauing

column47: I’d expect
column48: with the booster program in place as well
column49: that we should see it plateauing and cases starting to come down
column50: ” Bennett said. “There are things that we need to do now

column60: ” he said. “We’re responding to that by procuring more rapid antigen tests
column61: by refining the definitions around assessing and testing
column62: and to make sure that it is targeted to those who most truly need it and by ensuring that supports will be in place for those who need financial assistance in accessing rapid antigen tests.” The Coalition has been resisting calls to make the tests free for everyone
column64: medical experts and Labor. The federal Labor leader
column67: saying it was responsible for the “largest public policy failure in Australian political history”. “Australians are being told

column70: ” Albanese said. “If people are lucky enough to find one
column71: they’re not affordable and for many people
column72: it’s simply pricing out access to important healthcare.” Albanese has resisted calling for the tests to be free but later on Tuesday he told the ABC he “would have no problem with that”. His counterpart in NSW
column75: saying the tests “need to be free of charge”.

column1: The Australian Consumer and Competition Commission announced on Tuesday that it would investigate claims of price gouging for rapid antigen tests

column6: Bennett defended the health department’s strategy for rapid antigen tests
column7: saying the department had modelled various scenarios but it was not possible to predict the “pathway” the virus would take. “This is a problem that we’re seeing around the globe. I think the sheer increase in numbers with Omicron

column1: 440;440;5687;5687;‘He gave his daughters wings to fly’: lives of 14 people lost to Covid;2022-01-04T09:00:11Z;['Rachel Obordo'
column2: 'Jedidajah Otte'];['Coronavirus'
column3: 'World news'];"Covid-19 has been recorded on the death certificates of more than 5.4 million people worldwide since the pandemic began two years ago. As countries brace for further waves of infections driven by the Omicron variant
column4: the families of 14 people who lost their lives tell of incalculable loss as they pay tribute to their loved ones.

column1: Ruth Lopes Rodrigues
column3: and Rosemeire Lopes Rodrigues Bortolin
column5: Brazil Ruth Lopes Rodrigues
column7: and her daughter Rosemeire Lopes Rodrigues Bortolin
column9: lived in São Paulo and died 15 days apart in early 2021. Rodrigues was hospitalised on 13 December 2020 after she fell and broke her femur. Bortolin decided to visit her mother in hospital on 29 December because she missed her so much. “Rose was so afraid of getting Covid
column10: but she felt she had to visit her mom
column11: ” her cousin Liliane Bacci
column13: said. “She got emotional when she saw her mother and kissed her
column14: even though she had been really careful throughout the pandemic and wore a mask everywhere.” The next day
column15: on 30 December
column16: Rodrigues was diagnosed with Covid-19. She deteriorated rapidly and was intubated two days later. Bortolin was hospitalised with Covid on 6 January. Rodrigues died on 18 January
column17: a day after her 80th birthday
column18: which she shared with her daughter
column19: who turned 54. Bortolin was intubated on 21 January
column20: and died on 2 February. “They were two women carrying their family
column21: and now they’re gone
column22: ” Bacci said. “Rose was like a sister to me. I miss them so much. If it hadn’t been for my aunt’s fall
column23: I think both of them would be alive now.” Oduetse Ratshipa
column25: Botswana

column1: Dr Oduetse ‘Odie’ Ratshipa was born in Serowe on 23 June 1980. He studied medicine at St George’s University
column2: Grenada
column3: and graduated in 2010. He then returned to Botswana to work for the Ministry of Health and Wellness in the capital
column4: Gaborone
column5: for 11 years
column6: later specialising in disease surveillance and outbreaks. In 2014
column7: he had a lung transplant after being diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. The transplant left him vulnerable but he was determined to continue his work. During the pandemic
column8: Ratshipa was working on the rollout of the vaccine and caught Covid after his second dose of the Pfizer vaccine. “It’s a blow to have lost someone so young
column9: ” said his father-in-law
column10: Peter Smith. “He was the bravest man I ever met.” Ratshipa loved playing chess and supported Chelsea football club. He died aged 41 on 7 August 2021
column11: and is survived by his wife
column12: Thato
column13: and two sons Jason and James. Saeid Azari
column15: Iran

column1: Saeid Azari
column3: was a businessman and philanthropist who lived in Tehran with his wife
column4: while his two daughters were living in Canada. Azari died in hospital on 14 July 2020
column5: 10 days after becoming ill with Covid. His family said his transfer to intensive care was delayed because of a shortage of beds. Covid restrictions meant his family was unable to hold the kind of memorial service they would have wanted
column6: and said goodbye to him at a small funeral with strict social distancing in place. Azari’s younger daughter watched via video call from Canada. It was only after his death that his family discovered he had been sponsoring the studies of two orphans for years. Azari’s eldest daughter
column7: Neda
column9: last saw her father in September 2019
column10: when he hugged her goodbye at the airport after visiting her in Canada. She said: “He was a source of inspiration for my mother
column11: my sister and I. He always had a sweet smile on his face and he encouraged us to pursue our dreams. He was a man who gave his daughters wings to fly. We love him so much and he is missed terribly
column12: his death has completely changed our lives.” Jean Hodgson
column14: UK

column1: Jean Hodgson
column3: lived her whole life in Manchester
column4: where she ran a successful bakery and a fish and chip shop. She raised her three sons as a single mother while maintaining both businesses before marrying her husband
column5: Jim
column6: who died in 2012 from asbestosis after years working as a labourer. In February 2020
column7: she had a heart attack and went into a care home
column8: shortly before the pandemic properly began. She was supposed to stay there temporarily
column9: as she wanted to live by herself with some assistance. But she contracted Covid and died on 8 August 2020. “The care home advised us that this was the safest place for her
column10: which was obviously wrong
column11: ” her granddaughter Alexandra Hastie
column13: said. “I saw her five days before she died
column14: and she was so happy
column15: but we only saw her through the glass. We didn’t get the chance to say goodbye properly. “The extent of her warmth on others was clearly shown on the day of her funeral when the entire street came out to say their goodbyes and the amount of people that turned up outside the church. I have never known an 82-year-old as popular as my Nana Jean! Her favourite sandwich was cow tongue and ready salted crisps – the most disgusting combination I have ever seen but would give anything to see her enjoy once more.” Andrey Schelkonogov
column17: Russia

column1: Andrey Schelkonogov
column3: a father of two and grandfather of three
column4: lived in the Moscow region and was an engineer at a state-owned infrastructure company
column5: a job he loved. His family believe he caught Covid either at work or on public transport. He was hospitalised on 18 October 2020. When Schelkonogov died on 5 November 2020
column6: just three weeks before his 61st birthday
column7: it was a huge shock to the family. “He was a big football fan and incredibly healthy and strong prior to his infection
column8: we thought he would recover and come home after perhaps one week
column9: ” his daughter Julia
column11: said. That his coffin had to be closed during his funeral was also difficult for his family. “It was a huge disappointment that we were not allowed to see his face one last time
column12: ” she said. “My daughter was just three weeks old when he died. I had sent him photos of her while he was in hospital
column13: as we couldn’t visit him
column14: it was prohibited. He loved his grandchildren so much.” Şenol Yaşar
column16: Turkey

column1: “I’ve lost my rock and now he’s no longer there
column2: ” said Deniz Aslan of her 55-year-old father
column3: Şenol Yaşar. Yaşar
column4: who was born on 12 February 1965 in Istanbul
column5: worked in real estate and had three children. He is thought to have caught Covid while dining in a restaurant after the reopening of businesses and public spaces in June 2020. His family said he started off with flu-like symptoms and was hospitalised at a time when Turkey was recording some of its highest daily death figures of the pandemic. He was in intensive care for nearly three weeks before dying on 22 November 2020. “I couldn’t hold his hand and say the words which I desperately needed to say before it was too late
column6: ” said Aslan. Alberto Lema
column8: and Pedro ‘Toto’ Gallegos
column10: Argentina

column1: Juana Lema’s grandfathers Alberto Lema
column3: and Pedro ‘Toto’ Gallegos
column5: died from Covid in Buenos Aires on 9 April and 1 June 2021 respectively. Born on 14 September 1938
column6: Alberto Lema was president of General Motors for Argentina and Latin America in the electro-motive division. He was hospitalised for two weeks before dying. Gallegos was born on 9 June 1945 and worked as a private driver. He always tried to make people laugh and had a “very unique personality”
column7: said his granddaughter. His family believes he caught Covid when he had to renew his driving ID. He was put on a ventilator and given a tracheotomy two weeks after being hospitalised. He was released a fortnight later and spent less than 24 hours in a recovery centre before having a stroke due to Covid. Juana Lema said: “We were burying Alberto when we were told Pedro had to go into hospital with Covid. It’s been really hard as I’ve never lost anyone close to me.” Mosharef Hossain
column9: Bangladesh

column1: Born in Noakhali on 9 January 1940
column2: Mosharef Hossain worked for the Pakistani embassy in Islamabad
column3: as a cypher assistant for years. He moved to the UK in 1971 before returning to Bangladesh in 2005 where he founded a school a year later. He caught Covid at the beginning of April 2021 and was hospitalised for 21 days. He was discharged and went home to where his wife lives in Dhaka to recover for a few weeks
column4: but died on 22 June at the age of 81. His granddaughter Sabah Hussain said it had been three years since she last saw him: “We were really close when he lived in the UK and we thought it was a miracle when he recovered from Covid. His death came as a really big shock.” Bagila Zhakypbayeva
column6: Kazakhstan

column1: Bagila Zhakypbayeva
column3: from Almaty
column4: was born on 13 April 1940 and worked in administration before retiring. She liked making beautiful patchworks and singing. She lived with her daughter and stayed at home for most of the pandemic. However
column5: both of them tested positive after Zhakypbayeva started feeling unwell. She was in hospital for 10 days and spent her last three days in intensive care. She asked to be taken home to die but died on 28 August 2021. “She was on her own and couldn’t be with the people who loved her
column6: ” said her granddaughter Nellya Serikova. “She sacrificed a lot of things for my sister and I when we were kids. We were so close.” Rimon George Sultanian
column8: Jordan

column1: Rimon George Sultanian
column3: worked as a decorator and in construction in Amman before he retired. He was an orphaned refugee from Palestine and lived alone initially when he came to Jordan. He went on to have four children and six grandchildren. Sultanian contracted Covid in October 2020 and died in hospital on 10 December 2020. “My dad worked really
column4: really hard all his life
column5: even after his retirement
column6: and sacrificed a lot for his family
column7: so we could have the education and lifestyle he wanted us to have
column8: ” his daughter Armen
column10: a sales manager
column11: said. “He had a difficult life but he always managed to not let us feel it.” Sultanian loved reading books
column12: especially crime novels by Agatha Christie. “He would walk two times a week to book stores and a library and return with many books
column13: ” Armen said. “My dad was everything to us.” Gianpiero ‘Nonno’ Carlo Luigi Albertini
column15: UK

column1: Gianpiero “Nonno” Carlo Luigi Albertini was born in London on 13 July 1930 to Italian parents who had moved from Italy after the first world war. He had three sisters and lived in Surrey. He served in the British army for two years and returned to his profession as a lawyer before retiring. “I have many happy memories of my nonno [grandfather in Italian]
column2: ” said his granddaughter Isabel. “Like him giving us a bath when we were little and cleaning our feet by instructing: ‘One footy up’. He was a gentleman and a gentle man
column3: always kind and polite to everyone regardless of who they were.” Albertini initially went in to be treated for kidney failure and had started to improve when he tested positive for Covid. He died four days later on 19 May 2020 at East Surrey hospital. He was 89. Albertini is survived by his four children and 10 grandchildren. Andrew Daly

column1: Andrew “Andy” Daly
column3: was a greyhound breeder
column4: owner and trainer from County Westmeath who was born on 20 November 1926. He settled in England after a career with the British army that involved time in Germany and Hong Kong. He took part in changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace and reportedly enjoyed drinks with Prince Phillip. column5: 'Television & radio'];"How on earth are the movies going to compete with all that deliciously seductive #content on streaming services? How do you persuade people to mask up and venture out to the cinema when they can sprawl on the sofa and watch Succession’s gorgeously horrible Roy family for less money and hassle. People will leave their homes for James Bond and Spider-Man. But the grownup movies – the cinema of ideas and character and dialogue and complexity – well
column6: people are increasingly tempted to stay home for those. James Cameron
column7: director of mighty box-office champs such as Titanic and Avatar has the answer: six-hour films! Films with the amplitude and the addiction factor of long-form TV. At first glance
column8: that sounds like a buttock-annihilating nightmare
column9: and a six-hour film from the alpha-gorilla Cameron is another worry. Six hours of Cameron’s cheerfully macho storytelling? Six hours of military hardware
column10: and people in flightsuits walking into vast hangars with fighter-planes? Or does Mr Cameron have a six-hour cut of Titanic up his sleeve? Actually
column11: that’s not really what he’s suggesting. What Cameron has in mind is a new integrated theatrical-streaming distribution model in which a six-hour “movie” is shown in a number of episodes for home viewing and then in a shorter
column12: slimmed-down two-hour version for movie theatres. It’s not out of the question – and it’s been done before. Olivier Assayas’s 2010 work Carlos
column13: starring Édgar Ramírez as Carlos the Jackal was shown in three TV episodes totalling five-and-a-half hours but in cinemas shorter versions were shown. And for literary adaptations
column14: it could make sense. After all
column15: Granada Television’s legendary 11-episode version of Brideshead Revisited in 1981 weighed in at almost 12 hours: a different
column16: perfectly plausible 2008 feature film version of the same novel came in at two hours 14 minutes. You could fuse the two concepts … couldn’t you? Film has traditionally responded to the threat from television by emphasising grandeur and scale. In the decades after the war
column17: and worried about TV
column18: Hollywood gave us epic movies
column19: biblical and sword-and-sandal dramas
column20: often shown in awe-inspiring widescreen mode. The threat to cinema is different here – now it’s almost as if television is the bigger form with an almost unlimited running time for its products. So maybe the Cameron model is workable.

column1: The danger is of course that the cinema will just come off looking like second best. Who wants to see the short-change cut version of some sexy new drama in cinemas – which will inevitably also be subtly longer than the comfortable feature-film length – when you can get the real thing at home in full measure
column2: and submit to the deferred
column3: extended pleasure of episodic narrative
column4: which is the whole point of TV entertainment? And of course
column5: it would be the sex and violence that would get chopped for cinemas and bowdlerisation would rule. Of course
column6: cinema is already giving us “serial” movies. Denis Villeneuve’s colossal new sci-fi Dune is only part one – part two is due to follow. And in the arthouse realm
column7: Joanna Hogg’s autobiographical film The Souvenir came out in two parts. But this isn’t quite the same thing. And time is different watching TV – bingeing something for four hours is different from watching a four-hour movie: with the TV show you can bail out at any stage without inconvenience or feeling culturally shallow or disloyal. Not so in the cinema. Well
column8: it would be interesting if Netflix or Amazon Prime tried the Cameron model. But what I’d really like – masochistically enough – is a six-hour movie culture that had the courage of its convictions: showing the actual six-hour films in cinemas. A new Bollywood-style sense of scale
column9: to toughen up pampered western movie consumers. Cinephiles dream of finding the original eight-hour cut of the Erich von Stroheim 1924 silent drama Greed. I would love to see the rumoured 20-hour cut of Quentin Tarantino’s Once Upon a Time in Hollywood. At all events
column10: I want to maintain the concept of committing to an entire created artwork
column11: in its entirety
column12: all at once
column13: from beginning to end – and the cinema is still the best place for that. Peter Bradshaw is the Guardian’s film critic";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/03/six-hour-long-movies-james-cameron-cinema;5

column11: 'Human rights'];"One day after work last month
column12: Tom Otieno* went to a shopping centre in Nairobi to pick up groceries before heading home. He got a call from someone he had been chatting to for a week on Grindr
column13: a social networking app for gay
column14: bi
column15: trans and queer people. The man had already tried ringing several times during the day while Otieno was with colleagues and was keen to meet. Otieno
column17: mentioned where he was but said that he did not want to see the man. Then
column18: as he was heading to his car
column19: he got another call. As he answered it
column20: someone approached him and said they were a police officer. Seconds later
column21: two other officers joined him and surrounded Otieno. “One of them had this envelope
column22: ” he says. “He was getting papers out of the envelope and looking at them and then at me. I saw it was a chat [from Grindr] and I saw my face on it. I knew I had been set up.” The police asked him to get in their car to “help with an investigation”. Otieno refused and they accused him of having sex with a minor and started getting violent. “One tried to cuff me by force. Then he punched me on the chest and bent me over the car bonnet.” Otieno agreed to go with them as long as they did not handcuff him. Once in the car
column23: he realised they were taking a longer route to the station and started to panic.

column1: “I felt I was going to die. A few months ago
column2: I heard a transgender person was found dead and word went round that it was the police
column3: ” he says. Tom refused to hand over his phone to the police
column4: even though they asked
column5: because he knew he had done nothing wrong and they had not officially arrested him. He started to call friends
column6: one of whom got in touch with a lawyer from the National Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission (NGLHRC). She rang Otieno and said she would meet him at the police station. Once the police knew a lawyer was involved
column7: they took Otieno to the station but not before threatening him and demanding money to “make everything go away”. Otieno’s experience on social media sites or dating apps of being “catfished” – as using a fake identity to lure someone online is known – by people intending to extort money is common among members of the LGBTQ+ community in Kenya. With section 162 of the colonial-era penal code criminalising sexual acts deemed “unnatural”
column8: there are fertile grounds for the practice to thrive. Activists want social media companies to take action to stamp out the extortion. Kenya’s high court rejected a bid to repeal the law criminalising gay sex in 2019. There is another move to repeal section 162
column9: which is at the root of this issue
column10: now waiting to be heard in the court of appeal. Njeri Gateru
column11: executive director of NGLHRC
column12: says: “The existence of laws that criminalise homosexuality create a landscape where anyone attracted to someone of the same gender is seen to belong to a lesser place in society
column13: and as a criminal. That creates room for people to take advantage of queer individuals.” According to Gateru
column14: cases of blackmail and extortion are increasing
column15: methods are becoming more sophisticated
column16: and while this type of crime used to be limited to Nairobi
column17: it has now spread to other areas of the country. Exact figures on its prevalence are hard to come by and Gateru estimates that only about 10% of cases are reported. The NGLHRC legal aid centre has dealt with 679 such cases since its inception in 2013. Other LGBTQ+ organisations in the country say they have anecdotal evidence of thousands of such cases.

column1: Otieno
column2: who works in finance
column3: was aware enough of his rights that he questioned the police officers’ actions and rebuffed their efforts to extort bribes from him. Once he arrived at the station and met his lawyer
column4: the minor the police claimed had wanted to press charges against him was suddenly unavailable. Otieno was not arrested or charged. Many other members of the LGBTQ+ community have ended up in dire situations after being catfished on social media and dating sites. Lawyers and caseworkers have reported cases where people have been beaten so severely that they required hospital treatment and some almost died. Others have been raped and robbed at gunpoint. Many have been forced to empty their bank accounts and pay bribes amounting to tens of thousands of pounds to their blackmailers. Perpetrators include police officers
column5: but also other officials and members of the public. Bruno Shioso
column6: speaking for the National Police Service
column7: says these claims are “suspicious”. “Police don’t stalk citizens on social media. I don’t understand what the motivation would be
column8: ” he claims.

column1: Kelly Kigera
column2: of the emergency security response team at the Gay and Lesbian Coalition of Kenya
column3: says blackmailers approach members of the LGBTQ+ community online
column4: sometimes using “cute” fake pictures
column5: to chat and gain their trust before arranging to meet. Sometimes they will take compromising pictures or videos
column6: which they use to threaten to expose their victim’s sexual orientation. Other people report police officers storming into their homes
column7: threatening them with prosecution under section 162. Kigera adds: “They take your phone
column8: contacts
column9: passwords. They see other gay men you’ve been talking to
column10: and trace them using other platforms.” The pandemic has made everything worse
column11: says Gateru: “There has been such a loss of income and livelihoods from within the community and some people have resorted to these means to try to make a living for themselves.” Activists say it is important to educate police officers about the rights of the LGBTQ+ community to try to avoid this happening. Gateru says she has made five allegations of misconduct to the Independent Policing Oversight Authority (IPOA) over the past two years. “Very little is done
column12: ” she says. “It’s very frustrating.” A spokesperson for the IPOA denies this: “The authority is not in receipt of any complaint falling within the ambit of police targeting individuals as a result of their sexual affiliation.” Many question whether the social media companies are doing enough to protect users. Gateru says: “It’s a very slow response from some sites
column13: even when we report instances of blackmail. Action taken is minimal to none.”

column1: A Grindr spokesperson says: “We are always saddened to hear about the difficult and sometimes tragic experiences that our community members have experienced both online and off.” He says that Grindr has published a security guide and safety tips and has weekly in-app messages to remind users to exercise caution in all aspects of life in countries where it is illegal to be gay. In Kenya
column2: those messages include links to the NGLHRC. In Nairobi
column3: Otieno is still recovering from his ordeal. Friends have since told him similar stories of abuse and extortion. He wants social media and dating sites to do more. “I really think they should do a lot more when it comes to eliminating such characters
column4: ” he says. “For most of us in Africa
column5: [these sites] are the only avenue where we can meet people of our type. “If they are now a threat to us
column6: something must be done
column7: ” he adds. “You can’t put people’s lives on ransom.” *Name has been changed to protect his identity Sign up for a different view with our Global Dispatch newsletter – a roundup of our top stories from around the world

Miller can’t see a world in which a balanced portfolio doesn’t have dividend payers as part of the mix; not paying a dividend shouldn’t see a company excluded if its prospects are good. The balance between growth and value stocks today is different than before the dotcom crash two decades ago. “In 1999

column25: mining firms
column26: oil companies

column5: 'Culture'];"There are few couplets in pop that capture modern life’s seesaw between cynicism and hope as well as this choice gem near the end of The Overload

column7: but it’s not though

column9: before finding unexpected humanity within them. A band who have won comparison to such caustic mavericks as Fontaines DC and Sleaford Mods
column10: at the same time as finding themselves unlikely residents of the Radio 1 playlist and the record collection of one Elton John

column13: Yard Act’s gangly
column14: garrulous frontman

column16: Post War Glamour Girls
column17: splintered. Then
column18: almost as soon as Yard Act formed

column1: Smith’s prospects weren’t always so sunny. Growing up in Lymm
column2: near Warrington
column3: he was a South Park-obsessed budding animator whose dreams were scotched by art teachers with whom he had “disagreements”. But as that door closed
column4: his next youthful obsession
column5: Gorillaz

column7: the early 21st-century indie renaissance of the Strokes
column8: LCD Soundsystem and Arctic Monkeys
column9: and the poetic growling of Tom Waits. “My world was small
column10: ” he remembers. “My ambition was to move to Leeds. I wanted to start a band
column11: and there weren’t enough people in my town who understood what I wanted to do.” He arrived in Leeds aged 18
column12: and found his home in the city’s “nurturing
column13: insular DIY scene”
column14: making friends with the other local bands and never dreaming much further than its city limits. “Most bands in Leeds aren’t bothered about breaking out
column15: or don’t know how to
column16: ” Smith says. Post War Glamour Girls were a little of both: “We didn’t connect
column17: for whatever reason. I was in a dark
column18: miserable place
column19: as most men in their early 20s are when they face life head-on and realise it’s not as fun as they thought it was gonna be.”

column1: Smith spent his days teaching music and as a support worker for “a lad with a brain injury and cerebral palsy
column2: who I worked with for nine years and is one of my best friends”. His evenings
column3: meanwhile
column4: involved post-work pints with friend Ryan Needham
column5: the bassist in another Leeds band
column6: Menace Beach. The pair bonded over music and more – “I just found him so funny
column7: and I wanted to be around him all the time because he made me laugh so much
column8: ” Smith says – and when Needham became briefly homeless
column9: Smith offered his spare room. “My wife was very accommodating and let me play music with my friend for three months and ignore her
column10: ” he grins. It wasn’t time wasted. Smith and Needham formed Yard Act in the image of US lo-fi indie rock greats Guided By Voices. “We were just gonna get drunk
column11: write pop songs
column12: record them on cassettes and give ’em to friends
column13: ” Smith remembers. “But Ryan started leaning towards no wave
column14: dance-punk basslines
column15: and encouraged me to explore the style I’ve ended up writing in now.” That style was a spoken-word post-punk hybrid
column16: heavy on narrative. “It’s rap music
column17: but it’s not rap music
column18: ” he explains. “A lot of rap is first-person statements and defining who you are. My approach was conversational
column19: and humorous. You’re putting yourself out there when you start cracking jokes. It’s a lot more nerve-racking than being po-faced and mysterious. But mystique’s never been my strong point.” Smith’s new style crystallised on Fixer Upper
column20: Yard Act’s debut seven-inch
column21: self-released in July 2020. An exercise in blackly comedic character observation worthy of Steve Coogan

column23: a charmless
column24: overbearing self-made man with a sideline in low-grade bigotry. “I’ve become quite defensive over Graeme

column28: with a lot of half-formed opinions he thinks are gospel. He’s an amalgamation of friends’ dads and men in the pub when I was growing up; they’re rife in small towns. Ultimately

column1: Smith says that with Yard Act he has struck a balance “between the anger and the mellowness that make me up”. That anger grew

column4: and the world
column5: can quickly get you into a spiral of Everything Is Bad

column7: we’ve got to coexist with it. “Lately
column8: I’ve been watching series after series of First Dates

column18: imminent pop stardom of some stripe and the patronage of a celebrity fan. “Maybe Elton could give Bernie Taupin a few weeks off

column5: 'Australian politics'];"When Sydney man Scott Sumner woke up in a “full sweat” at midnight on Monday with aches and cold symptoms he thought to himself: “This is not a good sign.” It was more bad news when the Petersham resident arrived at the Summer Hill testing clinic about 8.15am on Tuesday to find a queue of cars he guessed was 3km long. Still
column6: he joined it
column7: and inched forward
column8: passing the time with Netflix and hoping he might be home in time for lunch. But at 10.53am
column9: when he was about 100 metres from the clinic
column10: his hopes were dashed.

column1: “They just started calling people through and saying
column2: ‘Nope
column3: we’re done for the day’. I was like
column4: ‘What do you mean you’re done for the day?’” The clinic was closing at midday and they had to end the line somewhere. Sumner didn’t make the cut. By the time he spoke to Guardian Australia he was in a walk-in line at the Royal Prince Alfred hospital in Camperdown for his third attempt at being tested. “It’s pretty bad
column5: it’s pretty frustrating
column6: ” Sumner said. His head was throbbing in the hot weather and – because he’d initially expected to stay in his car – he had not brought sunscreen. He got home six hours after he left
column7: sick
column8: sunburnt but
column9: finally
column10: tested. “I feel kind of abandoned
column11: ” he said. Throughout the pandemic
column12: he said
column13: “I’ve been trying to do the right thing constantly … I’m now trying to do the right thing again and it’s like
column14: I guess I’ll just get messed around by the government all day. You feel like you’ve done so much to sacrifice already. We’ve done lockdowns
column15: we’ve done all those things
column16: and now it feels like they’re actively not wanting us to get tested.”

column1: In December
column2: the prime minister
column3: Scott Morrison
column4: said: “We have to move from a culture of mandates to a culture of responsibility. That’s how we live with this virus into the future.” But many Australians doing their best to take personal responsibility feel they are being thwarted at every turn. Across the Christmas and New Year period
column5: social media lit up with fury and frustration over lost hours and days as people tried and often failed to do the right thing. Australians are waiting hours to get tested
column6: waiting days for results
column7: and waiting who knows how long for rapid antigen tests to appear at their local store. If they can afford them
column8: that is.

column1: Instagram account @bondi_lines
column2: which previously posted wait times for popular nightlife spots in the beachside suburb
column3: has started posting testing clinic wait times
column4: as well as advice on where people can find rapid antigen tests. Tempers are fraying. When a driver tried to cut the line at Summer Hill on Tuesday morning
column5: two “large men” descended on the car
column6: Sumner said. “[They] were banging on the window and saying
column7: ‘You can’t do this’. We had all been in line for hours at that point … everyone’s frustrations were so high.” Tatiana Paipetis joined the queue at Mascot drive-through
column8: also run by Laverty Pathology
column9: about 7.30am on Tuesday. “I’ve said about five times I wish I had brought a book
column10: ” she told Guardian Australia in a phone interview from her car about 11am.

column1: Her voice was muffled by the mask she wore to protect against possible infection from her teenage son
column2: who was lying in the back seat
column3: too ill to sit up. He had tested negative twice before Christmas and both times received exposure alerts from the walk-in 4Cyte clinic. Now he was sick again after being exposed to the virus on New Year’s Eve and Paipetis thought she better take him to the drive-through. “I’m just trying to protect him and others
column4: because I’m pretty sure he’s got Covid
column5: ” she said.

column1: After they had been queuing for about an hour
column2: Paipetis watched a woman get out of the passenger seat in the car in front of her and walk away. She returned half an hour later – with McDonald’s. “I was like
column3: ‘Oh my god
column4: this woman went to Macca’s
column5: ” Paipetis said. “And she’s probably got Covid because she’s the passenger being driven to the testing.” Despite waiting nearly four-and-a-half hours to get tested
column6: Paipetis and her son were among the lucky ones. She was within 20 cars of the cut-off point
column7: where those lining up were told to go elsewhere. “They’re going to have a riot on their hands in a minute because they’re telling people they can’t be tested and they’ve been here for hours
column8: ” she said. Paipetis said she could afford to take the morning off work
column9: to use up petrol by running the air conditioner for four hours. But what about people who can’t? “It really is about equity and access that concerns me most
column10: ” she said. “This government is clearly looking after private interests and the top end of town
column11: and it’s really not the way we should be operating as a society.” The Omicron surge came just as private pathology providers closed testing clinics or substantially reduced hours for the festive season. Other closures were simply to cope with the immense backlog of tests. On Monday
column12: Australian Clinical Labs shut a number of sites
column13: stating it was necessary “due to the significant increase in testing volumes across the state”. On Tuesday
column14: of the pathology clinic’s 31 testing sites
column15: 19 were closed and the remaining 12 open during the morning.

column1: All Histopath centres
column2: bar the airport
column3: were either running on reduced hours or closed altogether until 9 January
column4: while several 4Cyte clinics were closed
column5: some until 5 January and others until 10 January. All but a couple of Laverty sites closed at midday on Tuesday
column6: while Medlab Pathology clinics were mostly completely shuttered
column7: one open until 1pm. “There’s obviously reasons everything slowed down
column8: ” Paipetis said. “But it’s not like we couldn’t logistically plan for this.” And the wait doesn’t end when people finally get swabbed. Balmain man Dean Morelli received a positive test result 126 hours after he was tested – a period of more than five days. “By the time [NSW Health] got that information and it was published as a daily statistic
column9: I’d substantially recovered from Covid
column10: ” he said. “The state government is hostage to the quality of the data being presented. If the data is inaccurate
column11: it begs the question
column12: what’s the quality of the decision-making process? “In fairness
column13: I fully appreciate the fact they were totally inundated. But someone’s got to take responsibility somewhere for this situation.”";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/04/i-feel-abandoned-australians-waiting-hours-to-be-tested-and-days-for-their-results-blame-governments;7

column2: ancient and quite fantastic: Scotland’s peat bogs breathe again;2022-01-04T07:30:09Z;['Phoebe Weston'];['Scotland'

column11: 'Wild flowers'];"Flanders Moss bog is slumped on the flat
column12: farmed landscape of the Carse of Stirling in Scotland like a jelly fungi. It wobbles when you walk on it
column13: and a metal pole goes down eight metres before reaching hard ground. This lowland-raised bog is a dome of peat fed mainly by rainfall and it acts like a single organism – the whole thing has to be looked after for any part to be in really good shape. If it is drained in one area it will affect the water level across the entire bog. For much of human history peat bogs have been thought of as wastelands. This 860-hectare (2
column14: 125-acre) site has been hacked away and drained since the early 1800s to make space for fertile farmland below. It is about 60% of its original size. Bogs scar easily and the drainage ditches made more than 100 years ago are still visible.

column1: It is now recognised that peat bogs are among the greatest stores of carbon and
column2: after decades of restoration
column3: the holes in the peat at Flanders Moss have been patched up. Areas that used to be purple with heather are turning green as key bog plants such as sphagnum (peat moss) and cottongrass come back. The bog rises out of the land like a sponge and “breathes” as changes in the weather and water level cause it to swell and contract. Researchers in Scotland are tracking “bog breathing” using the latest satellite technology that can detect just a few millimetres of change. This provides an accurate test of how healthy the site is and how much carbon it could be holding. Flanders Moss holds around 3m tonnes of carbon. Thanks to the restoration work
column4: the water table has risen by as much as 40cm on the site and is now at the surface. As the bog draws in water from the surrounding land it helps manage flood risk. Flanders Moss bog has removed 890 hectares of land from the Forth catchment
column5: reducing flooding downstream. A healthy bog is a bit like a malfunctioning compost heap. “With a compost heap we keep throwing stuff in and it all rots and breaks down
column6: but with a bog
column7: it doesn’t. It just keeps accumulating and accumulating
column8: ” says David Pickett
column9: who manages the site
column10: which is a National Nature Reserve.

column1: The Scottish government-funded Peatland Action project
column2: which started in 2012
column3: is helping revive 25
column4: 000 hectares of degraded peatland. In 2020
column5: the Scottish government committed £250m of funding over 10 years to bog restoration in a bid to lock carbon in the land. It is hoped the satellite data can be used to work out which bogs need urgent help and what efforts are working.

column1: “At some point
column2: hopefully
column3: we’ll be able to inform government
column4: but also private investors and other funding bodies
column5: to say ‘well
column6: it’s better to put your money into these sites’
column7: ” says Henk Pieter Sterk
column8: who is working on the Peatland Action project at NatureScot. “Here in Scotland
column9: we have the opportunity to protect and restore peatlands … It’s the easiest thing you can do. Restoring peatlands is a no-brainer.” It takes about a month to process the satellite data for a third of Scotland
column10: which is available through the Copernicus Open Access Hub. The technology is still in development but is likely to be cheaper than ground-based mapping. “The next steps would include looking at an even wider range of peatland types and conditions across Scotland
column11: followed by – hopefully – an assessment of the tool across the UK for the same purpose
column12: ” says Sterk. Despite these restoration efforts
column13: Flanders Moss is still a net emitter of carbon. Scotland’s bogs emit about 10m tonnes of carbon equivalent
column14: which is almost as much as the transport sector. Stopping these emissions and preventing further degradation are the primary objectives of the restoration project.

column1: Bogs work on a different timeframe than humans. They form slowly
column2: accumulating between 0.5mm to 1mm of peat a year
column3: taking up to 1
column4: 000 years to grow one metre. But Pickett’s team has jump-started recovery. “We’ve done most of the big work here
column5: ” he says. “Now
column6: it’s a question of waiting. The process of fixing this site will last 100 years
column7: and the benefits of work being done now will only be seen by the next generation.” It’s easy to see why bogs weren’t popular. They are stores of partly decayed organic matter
column8: which are too acidic and devoid of nutrients to support healthy trees. But this bog is colourful and has a fresh
column9: earthy smell. As well as being a fantastic store of carbon
column10: this ancient
column11: watery land – healthy peat is about 90% water – is also rich in wildlife
column12: including rare lizards
column13: dragonflies and even snakes. “There isn’t headline sexy stuff like puffins and seals but you go around the boardwalk and it’s a fantastic place
column14: ” says Pickett. “I always used to think bogs must have been named on a Friday after a really bad week. We’re trying to change the perception of bogs but it’s a hard sell.” Find more age of extinction coverage here
column15: and follow biodiversity reporters Phoebe Weston and Patrick Greenfield on Twitter for all the latest news and features";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/04/dank-ancient-and-quite-fantastic-scotland-peat-bogs-breathe-again-aoe;3

column6: 'Bradley Cooper'];"With the most recent Oscar ceremony having taken place abnormally late in April
column7: it feels like we barely had a break before the machinery of awards season started cranking up again. It began at the Venice film festival at the tail end of summer and is now in full cry
column8: with major critics’ groups and more dubious collectives like the Golden Globes having already weighed in – and a gaggle of apparent frontrunners establishing themselves in major categories. In the acting fields
column9: we’re already pondering the likelihood of victories for stars like Kristen Stewart
column10: Benedict Cumberbatch
column11: Will Smith and Rita Moreno – though there’s still plenty of wiggle room for surprises. Last year’s extra-long season yielded an almost entirely unforeseen nomination for Lakeith Stanfield and an against-the-odds win for Anthony Hopkins: never make the mistake of taking the pundits’ word as gospel.

column1: With that in mind
column2: we’re highlighting a few outlying performances that ought to be in the mix

column3: haughty cameo was a comic high point of The Souvenir

column8: ” she says at one point with pitch-perfect
column9: life-learned disdain. Charlie Shotwell

column3: the furious
column4: capricious
column5: heart-on-sleeve British prodigy of C’mon C’mon
column6: and Belfast lead Jude Hill

column8: however

column6: 'Culture'];"Tim Bergling – the Swedish DJ and producer known as Avicii – killed himself in Muscat
column7: Oman
column8: in April 2018 at the age of 28. The very worst happened when things were apparently looking up. The successful but troubled electronic dance music (EDM) star had retired from relentless touring in 2016 to focus on his wellbeing. He had weaned himself off opioids – prescribed by doctors when bouts of alcohol-induced pancreatitis led to debilitating pain and
column9: later
column10: surgery. He was communicating regularly with a therapist
column11: was often surrounded by childhood friends
column12: donated to charities. He meditated. Having crossed over from pure party music to making tracks alongside established stars such as Coldplay and Nile Rodgers
column13: Bergling was working on new material he was excited about. A documentary about his meteoric rise and his stress levels – Avicii: True Stories – had been broadcast in 2017
column14: seemingly with a happy ending.

column1: When it appeared on Netflix
column2: True Stories reverberated well beyond club culture
column3: super-charging the existing public debate around the mental health of performers. Viewers were witness to a life unravelling
column4: privy to alarming practices that were normalised. Stardom has always come at a high price
column5: but in EDM
column6: capitalising on your hot streak seemed especially urgent. Quite aside from the usual hedonism
column7: the hours an ambitious
column8: in-demand EDM DJ had to keep were gruelling: multiple gigs in one night
column9: sometimes in different countries or time zones
column10: with constant travel (especially hard for the flight-phobic Bergling) and scant basic self-care. In 2019
column11: an anonymous book by another industry insider
column12: The Secret DJ

column16: from World of Warcraft – an obsession of the younger Bergling – to the wild west of club culture
column17: via the monomaniacal perfectionism of digital music-making.

column3: curious
column4: stubborn youngster who feared he would get cancer
column5: he suffered from serious acne and social anxiety
column6: affecting his self-esteem. An interest in the esoteric led Bergling to name himself after a particularly punishing zone of Buddhist hell. He ended up in something like it. Mosesson had access to Bergling’s rehab journal and almost everyone in his life – ex-girlfriends
column7: childhood pals
column8: fellow superstar DJs

column10: emails and messageboard posts; a level of intimate access biographers must surely have only dreamed of until now. Bergling’s former manager

column12: declined to participate. After Bergling’s death

column14: Bergling senior was specific in exonerating Pournouri
column15: with whom his son had reconciled

column19: both external and internal

column24: which he credited with reducing his anxiety. But he would meditate intensely for hours

column6: 'US supreme court'];"The House select committee investigating the 6 January attack on the Capitol is facing a race against time in 2022 as Trump and his allies seek to run out the clock with a barrage of delay tactics and lawsuits.

column1: Republicans are widely expected to do well in this year’s midterm elections in November and
column2: if they win control of the House
column3: that would give them control to shut down the investigation that has proved politically and legally damaging to Trump and Republicans. The select committee opened its investigative efforts into the 6 January insurrection
column4: when a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol to stop the certification of Joe Biden’s election win
column5: with a flurry of subpoenas to Trump officials to expedite the evidence-gathering process. But aside from securing a cache of documents from Trump’s former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows
column6: the select committee has found itself wading through molasses with Trump and other top administration aides seeking to delay the investigation by any means possible. The former US president has attempted to block the select committee at every turn
column7: instructing aides to defy subpoenas from the outset and
column8: most recently
column9: launching a last-ditch appeal to the supreme court to prevent the release of the most sensitive of White House records. His aides are following Trump in lockstep as they attempt to shield themselves from the investigation
column10: doing everything from filing frivolous lawsuits to stop the select committee obtaining call records to invoking the fifth amendment so as to not respond in depositions. The efforts amount to a cynical ploy by Republicans to run out the clock until the midterms and use the election calendar to characterize the interim report
column11: which the bipartisan select committee hopes to issue by the summer
column12: as a political exercise to damage the GOP.

column1: The select committee
column2: sources close to the investigation say
column3: is therefore hoping for a breakthrough with the supreme court
column4: which experts believe will ensure the panel can access the Trump White House records over the former president’s objections about executive privilege. “I think the supreme court is very unlikely to side with Trump
column5: and part of it is the nature of executive privilege – it’s a power belonging to the President
column6: ” said Jonathan Shaub
column7: a former DoJ office of legal counsel attorney and law professor at the University of Kentucky. “It’s hard to see how a former president could exercise constitutional power under a theory where all the constitutional powers are vested in the current president
column8: so I think Trump is very likely to lose or the court may not take the case
column9: ” Shaub said. Members on the select committee note that several courts – the US district court and the US appeals court – have already ruled that Biden has the final say over which White House documents are subject to executive privilege
column10: and that the panel has a legislative purpose. A victory for the select committee at the supreme court is important
column11: members believe
column12: not only because it would give them access to the records Trump has fought so hard to keep hidden
column13: but because it would supercharge the inquiry with crucial momentum. The select committee got its first break when House investigators obtained from Meadows thousands of communications involving the White House
column14: including a powerpoint detailing ways to stage a coup
column15: and are hoping the supreme court can help to sustain their pace. “It’s pretty clear that these documents are serious documents that shed light on the president’s activities on January 6 and that may be quite damaging for Trump
column16: ” said Kate Shaw
column17: a former Obama White House counsel and now a professor at the Cardozo School of Law. “They could make a difference to the record being compiled by the committee and thus they could give the process additional momentum
column18: ” Shaw said. “That’s probably why Trump is resisting their release as hard as he is.”

column1: More generally
column2: the select committee says they are unconcerned by attempts by Trump aides and political operatives to stymie the inquiry
column3: since Democrats control Washington and the panel has an unprecedented carte blanche to upturn every inch the Trump administration. “The legislative and executive branches are completely in agreement with each other
column4: that this material is not privileged and needs to be turned over to Congress
column5: ” said congressman Jamie Raskin
column6: a member of the select committee. “Things have been moving much more quickly.” But the select committee acknowledges privately that they face a longer and more difficult slog with Trump aides and political operatives who are mounting legal challenges to everything from the panel’s attempts to compel production of call records and even testimony. The trouble for the select committee
column7: regardless of Democrats’ controlling the White House
column8: Congress and the justice department
column9: is that they are counting on the courts to deliver accountability for Trump officials unwilling to cooperate with the inquiry. Yet Trump and his officials know that slow-moving cogs of justice have a history of doing nothing of the sort. House investigators only heard from former Trump White House counsel Don McGahn this past summer
column10: years after the end of the special counsel investigation. The House has not even been able to obtain Trump’s tax returns – something Democrats have been fighting to get access to since they took the majority in 2018 – after repeated appeals from the former president despite repeated defeats in court. Trump and his aides insist they are not engaged in a ploy to stymie the investigation
column11: though they admit to doing just that in private discussions
column12: according to sources close to the former president. When the select committee issued its first subpoenas to his former aides Mark Meadows
column13: Dan Scavino
column14: Steve Bannon and Kash Patel
column15: Trump’s lawyers told their lawyers to defy the orders because it would likely serve to slow down the investigation
column16: the sources said. The result of Trump’s directive – first reported by the Guardian – is that Bannon and Meadows refused to appear for their depositions
column17: and the select committee now may never hear their inside information about the Capitol attack after they were held in contempt of Congress. It remains possible that Bannon and Meadows seek some kind of a plea deal with federal prosecutors that involves providing testimony to the select committee in exchange for no jail time
column18: but the court hearing for Bannon
column19: for instance
column20: is scheduled late into the summer. The reality for House investigators is that the cases are now in the hands of a justice department intent on proving it remains above the political fray after years of Trump’s interference at DoJ
column21: and therefore indifferent to the time crunch felt by the 6 January committee. The situation for the select committee may be even trickier with Republican members of Congress involved in 6 January
column22: as they just need to stonewall the investigation only through the midterms
column23: before which the panel hopes to release an interim report into their findings. A spokesperson for the select committee declined to comment on the outlook for the investigation and their expectations for the supreme court hearing in the case against Trump
column24: which the panel
column25: cognizant of their limited timeframe
column26: has asked to expedite. Bennie Thompson
column27: the chairman of the select committee
column28: originally aimed to have the final report completed before the midterm elections
column29: but the efforts by the most senior Trump officials to delay the investigation means he could need until the end of the year. Either way

column31: the select committee is hoping that the supreme court will deliver the elusive Trump White House records – and that it could pave the way for the investigation to shift into yet another higher gear.";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/04/capitol-attack-panel-race-against-time;1

column1: 458;458;5705;5705;Here’s some good news for 2022: this could be the year the pandemic comes to an end | Raghib Ali;2022-01-04T07:00:09Z;['Raghib Ali'];['UK news'
column2: 'NHS'
column3: 'Coronavirus'
column4: 'Health'
column5: 'Infectious diseases'
column6: 'Medical research'
column7: 'Microbiology'];"As an epidemiologist and NHS consultant
column8: 2022 begins much like 2021 did – I’m again analysing data on the impact of a new Covid variant that threatens to put huge pressure on our hospitals. And I’m back on the frontline in A&E
column9: helping my NHS colleagues to deal with that pressure. But we are actually in a much better position
column10: and there are good reasons to be confident that 2022 will be a much better year than 2021. Last January was perhaps the darkest time of the entire pandemic in the UK
column11: with tens of thousands being admitted into hospital and thousands losing their lives every week. Now
column12: with the majority of us well protected with highly effective vaccines
column13: we have a much lower individual risk of ending up in hospital – or worse – if we catch Covid. The combination of vaccines and a better knowledge of how to treat Covid means both hospitalisation and death rates are now much lower
column14: with the infection fatality rate having fallen by over 80%. And this means that
column15: unlike last year
column16: our children are going back to school this week
column17: retail and hospitality businesses are open and we are able to meet our friends and families.

column1: Although the NHS is again under massive pressure – particularly due to staff shortages – the early indications are that we are not facing a repeat of last winter with hospital admissions rising more slowly and ICU admissions and deaths mercifully still flat. The information from South Africa and the early data from the UK gives us a realistic hope that this wave will be over quicker than previous ones
column2: and with much less loss of life. There are reasons to be optimistic beyond just this wave
column3: as well. Firstly
column4: the long-promised antiviral medicines have arrived. These new Covid treatments
column5: which have just started being used in the UK
column6: have the potential to transform the situation as similar medicines have done with HIV and hepatitis C. They can reduce the risk of being admitted into hospital by up to 90%
column7: are effective against all variants
column8: can be taken orally and are much easier to distribute than vaccines. Two are already approved but many others are currently undergoing clinical trials and should be available this year. Next
column9: new vaccines are in development that will make it easier to manage the coronavirus variants that will inevitably emerge over the coming year. As with influenza
column10: “multivalent” vaccines – which protect against infection from multiple variants – will probably become available later this year. Other vaccines that target parts of the virus besides the spike protein – parts that don’t mutate as easily – are also on the horizon. There are also vaccines being trialled that can be delivered by nasal spray
column11: inhaler
column12: orally and using skin patches – all of which will make distribution easier and overcome needle phobia.

column1: But the immediate priority must be to ensure that our existing and very effective vaccines are distributed more equally across the globe. We have made huge progress
column2: with 8.5bn doses delivered to date
column3: but far too many – especially those at high risk and frontline healthcare workers in low-income countries – have not even received their first dose. Vaccinating the whole world in 2022 is a realistic prospect but this will require an end to hoarding in high-income countries and a temporary lifting of patents. And this is in our interests too – we won’t be able to prevent new variants completely but we can reduce the risk by ensuring everyone
column4: everywhere is able to be vaccinated. Sadly Covid is not going away permanently
column5: but we can be optimistic that 2022 will be the year the pandemic ends and it becomes an endemic disease here and in most countries thanks to the very high levels of population immunity we now have – through a combination of vaccination and natural infection. There are still likely to be seasonal winter peaks
column6: like with flu
column7: and an annual booster jab will probably be needed to deal with new variants and waning immunity. Like many
column8: I have lost family
column9: friends and colleagues. I have seen countless patients suffer from Covid – as well as from its knock-on effects on our health services – and from the lockdowns. But the huge loss of life and pain should soon be a thing of the past. We are certainly not out of the woods yet – cases are at unprecedented levels and rising (though more slowly now) and Covid is still a serious threat to the most vulnerable – so we need to continue following the public health guidance to protect them and to help reduce the pressure on the NHS so we can continue treating all our patients. But there is a realistic prospect that 2022 will be the year we can begin to live with the virus – and without the fear of both Covid and lockdowns that has haunted us for the past two years. Dr Raghib Ali is a clinical epidemiologist at the University of Cambridge and an honorary consultant in acute medicine at the Oxford University hospitals NHS trust";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/04/pandemic-end-uk-covid-hospital-vaccines-optimism;3

column2: take a train to Epping Forest;2022-01-04T07:00:09Z;['James Gingell'];['London holidays'
column3: 'Essex holidays'

column10: 'Travel'
column11: 'United Kingdom holidays'];"I’m no slouch
column12: but I’m struggling to keep up with Jeremy Dagley as he opens a gate off the A104
column13: the main road through Epping Forest
column14: and bounds into the woods. He is the head of conservation here and charmingly eager to show me his work. I had assumed his job would be all wellies and fleeces
column15: clippings and handfuls of soil. The reality is he spends a lot of time indoors helping local councils with planning applications
column16: making sure they are sustainable and sympathetic. It’s clear he’s happier out here.

column1: Jeremy’s knowledge is immense
column2: unspooling in tangles of “ologies”. While telling me that the chalk ridge we are walking along is a ripple caused by the formation of the Himalayas
column3: his ears twitch towards a chirrup and he points to a podgy bundle of grey and black feathers with a bright red cap. It’s a juvenile great spotted woodpecker
column4: says Jeremy. As he regales me with the history of the ownership of this land
column5: I stumble into a hidden ditch; eyes drawn down
column6: he points at a delicate yellow plant. Lousewort
column7: he says
column8: excitedly: it was thought extinct in these parts in the 1990s. It’s thrilling being in the company of such a master. We’re soon deep in the forest
column9: but it’s still airy and spacious
column10: with the low afternoon sun sending gold from the west. The trees here stand in friendly gatherings
column11: not crowds.

column1: Jeremy stops abruptly by an ugly
column2: gnarled thing
column3: and traces his hands across its snakeskin bark. Beeches normally last 300 years before they conk out and topple over. This one is 800 years old
column4: he says
column5: blue eyes shining. It has tickled the horses of medieval kings
column6: survived centuries of storms
column7: seen off war and pestilence
column8: and remained rooted here in this soil. I feel bad for judging its wrinkles.

column1: In fact its ugliness explains its longevity. Around head height
column2: the snub trunk bulges in a bole
column3: from which a handful of smaller
column4: strong
column5: smooth trunks reach up and branch out in subtle angles. This is the product of pollarding
column6: trimming the tops of trees for wood
column7: a commoner practice here for centuries. Done sparingly
column8: it exposes dormant buds
column9: encouraging new growth. The result is
column10: in effect
column11: a clutch of 200-year-old trees growing from one 800-year-old trunk. Pollarding struck me as a beautiful thing
column12: humankind and nature gaining strength from each other. Conservation by careful use
column13: not the lack of it. Epping Forest is home to 55
column14: 000 ancient pollards: 10
column15: 000 oak
column17: 000 beech
column19: 000 hornbeam. These are pollard riches unmatched in the UK
column20: and they are only half an hour on the overground train from the City of London. During the Covid lockdowns
column21: many Londoners realised their luck: visitor numbers increased by 300%.

column1: As local historian Mark Gorman explains in his book Saving the People’s Forest
column2: such easy access has not always been a given. In the mid-19th century
column3: a new train service to Forest Gate
column4: close to Wanstead Flats
column5: the southernmost point of Epping Forest
column6: brought thousands of new visitors from the East End. About the same time
column7: the crown estate began selling the land to local aristocrats
column8: who sniffed an opportunity to develop housing for the expanding London population. Just as the people had begun to enjoy the public land
column9: it was being taken away. When
column11: Lord Cowley of Wanstead instructed agents to fence off a large section of Wanstead Flats
column12: packed meetings agreed on a march to save the forest. On 8 July
column14: 000 people assembled on the Flats
column15: many with gorse in their lapels – a symbol of common land – and tore the fences down. Within a month
column16: parliament passed the first of a series of acts to protect the forest. The City of London Corporation lent support
column17: sensing a popular cause. Between 1871 and 1882
column18: it paid £256
column19: 275 to secure conservatorship. With its help
column20: the last of the Epping Forest Acts was passed in 1878
column21: the first legal declaration of the right of the public at large to use an open space for leisure. It wasn’t all progress. Locals had for centuries had the right in some places to “lop” branches seven feet from the ground for use as fuel over the winter
column22: but this was removed (in return for some compensation) in 1878.

column1: Jeremy is clear this was a mistake. The best thing for biodiversity
column2: he says
column3: is a mosaic environment
column4: a mixture of thorny scrub
column5: grassy clearings and thickets of trees. It makes sense to me. Not everything can live in the darkness and stillness of a thick forest: more niches makes for more species. Pollarding provides helpful disruption
column6: thinning the trees
column7: allowing light for low-growers and providing dead wood for fungi
column8: all encouraging a wider range of fauna.

column2: the corporation of London began regular pollarding again
column3: but even before that a visitor here wouldn’t have seen overgrown forest. That’s because grazing rights for commoners were never removed
column4: and cattle continued browsing parts of the woodland through most of the 20th century. As we walked through a lush clearing
column5: Jeremy explained the importance of hungry
column6: clumsy herbivores: they play a similar role to pollarding
column7: causing disruption by nibbling leaves and knocking over young saplings. It’s why the trees here are in friendly gatherings
column8: not crowds.

column1: In the 1990s the delicate balance was upset when the BSE crisis put an end to commoner grazing. In response
column2: the corporation introduced its own herd of longhorns. Most are brought inside for winter
column3: but a handful are left out to help maintain the habitat. Just before sunset
column4: Jeremy took me to Chingford Plain to see them
column5: a hit squad of squat muscle and sharp horns within charging distance of the high street. As they began to edge in that direction
column6: Jeremy showed me his phone
column7: displaying a map of the area with a moving dot for each cow. As one beast neared the virtual boundary
column8: its GPS necklace emitted a high-frequency sound
column9: prompting the animal to lumber off in a different direction. As the light drained from the blue sky
column10: everything here seemed in harmony: humankind
column11: nature
column12: technology. This is what the world can be.

column1: A few weeks earlier I had been at Cop26 in Glasgow
column2: and its gloomy graphs still haunted my dreams: one night I screamed myself awake. I came here needing a lift. If we are to heal the world
column3: it is of course essential to understand how it is degrading. But as US writer Rebecca Solnit says
column4: concentrating on what is being lost can leave us with the sense that decay is normal
column5: inevitable. We need to hold the good bits in mind – finding wonder in what works well. We need to “take that beauty as a sacred trust
column6: and celebrate the memory of it”
column7: she wrote. “Otherwise we might forget why we are fighting.” There are few finer reminders than Epping Forest.
